Posts.Content: Hi Clare Being monitored is a good thing. They will be able to spot any changes in the before and after CT scan, and perhaps if there are more changes there will be a biopsy.  Not being usual practice just means that most follow ups are straightforward, but there are always some that fall outside the bounds of average. Whoever wanted to be average, anyway?  Seriously, worry will not help anything, and if anything make things worse.  Enjoy every day while you can, try not to worry about the future, plan some nice bits, like days out, nice food, meeting with friends, doing new things.  Keep busy and the time will soon pass.
Posts.Title: Cannot move forward

Posts.Content: lobularou houkd  I think I translated as ....Lobular should ...! Where will you be in the UK?  Perhaps we should all get together for a mass coffee!
Posts.Title: Proposed chemo regime - looking for advice, info, help please

Posts.Content: Yvonne - you had a big operation only two days ago.  Be kind to yourself, don't expect anything of yourself for at least another week.  And anaesthetic maeks you feel yukky and depressed too - this could get worse before it gets  better.  I'm not sure what "twist" is though!   Anyway just doze on the sofa, have some pj days, chill out and don't stress.  You will be fine in a couple of weeks..  It's all very normal.  Get some painkillers (tramadol or diazepam) to help you sleep.
Posts.Title: Had my operation

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo Glad your surgery went well, but I'm sorry to hear that you had this poor experience on the ward.  Sadly I had several experiences like this, so I'm afraid I can only sympathise and say I don't think it's that uncommon.  I had three operations and every one was the same.  On the second one I was told early in the morning that I would go home that night with antibiotics.  Everyone left and I wasn't going to be discharged because no one was there to sign me out, and no antibiotics prescribed.  I told them I was going home and I would get antibiotics from the gp in the morning.  The ward nurse ran to get two for that night and I left.  Honestly, I was going to complain but in the end I didn't bother.  I knew that nothing would change.  There are just not enough conscientious nurses in full time employment and bank nurses in general just do the job and go home.  This is my opinion, I'm sure there are some of all kinds who are, just my experience.  But I hope you do mention something to the hospital, as an employee with insider info.
Posts.Title: Getting there.

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca I thought the same as you, was worried about recurrence, family history (in my case) and just general worry. Luckily, I was allowed to have the prophylactic Mx at the same time, and like you, have two Beckers. I know that you don't have any other options than implants, and my other reason was that you just don't end up with a matched pair naked if they're not, well, matched ... LOL ... and obviously that's important to you in particular. The only note of caution I would add about the Beckers is that I've recently been told they may not be able to remove the entire tube, and this is the main thing that I hate about them now (I still have my ports and the tube).  So depending on whether I will have the entire tube removed or not will inform my decision on whether I have them replaced with standard implants. HTH
Posts.Title: Thinking of voluntary MX

Posts.Content: Rach1969  Does it go away if you take an antihistamine?  I am terribly itchy at times but these usually work. Also, just because you haven't changed washing powder, doesn't mean the manufacturer hasn't changed the formula! A friend of mine suffered a massive reaction when this happened once!
Posts.Title: Itching...and I think it's from Anastrozole.

Posts.Content: Hi Clare I'm sorry to hear you have more tests to go through, and the waiting really is the pits.  I can understand the way you feel now, I had op and results three times and each time got worse until the last one. An indeterminate focal area could mean lots of things, so please don't panic just yet.   As Crystaljuju just said, counselling is a way forward, but you have to WANT to improve.  Sometimes just some relief in the form of some medication to stop your mind from dwelling on the problem can help.  Whatever else, you do need some help, so please do visit your GP and see what they suggest. In the meantime, I have everything crossed for you and please do let us know how things go.
Posts.Title: Cannot move forward

Posts.Content: kazash56 I'm sorry to hear that you are struggling. Did your  oncologist give you the statistics for taking anastrozole?  The % difference may not be significant enough to continue, but if it is, do talk to your team and see if there are options for you.  I was told the first two years on Tamoxifen were shown to have the biggest effect, so I stopped around this time, but you have to do what is right for you.  I think it might feel worse as a man, as the oestrogen strips muscles of strength and you will feel the fatigue as a result.  If you haven't already, you could try different  brands, do have a search through the groups to find what people have tried.
Posts.Title: 3yrs post cancer... I a man struggling with fatigue and this new life...

Posts.Content: Hi wendilou  I had cording.  If the unit knew how painful it is they would refer every time!  Ask for the name of a specialist physio and ask your GP to refer you urgently . After a week ring them and make sure you get an urgent appointment. If you can bear it, hanging from a door frame works but it is painful .
Posts.Title: On the outside looking in

Posts.Content: This is a known side effect of radiotherapy.  Cancer Research have more information on this here.  There is another side effect not mentioned here which I am struggling to remember the name of.  It can be longer term, so any issues should be mentioned to your oncologist or GP for further investigation.
Posts.Title: wheezing and inhalers

Posts.Content: Hi Siani Of course you have the right to have depressed days.  We all do from time to time.  The problem is, people who haven't been through it just don't get it.  You have to grow a slightly thick skin because they aren't intentionally being insensitive, it often just comes across this way.  But equally, you might decide that some of these people are not the right friends any more.  I definitely found out who my friends were (and weren't).   I'm afraid if they're family you're stuck with them though ;) Helen x
Posts.Title: Fed up

Posts.Content: Hi Emagermain  Sorry to hear about the fatigue.  Cancer is just the gift that keeps on giving, sometimes.  You said you WERE on a supplement, have you stopped?  Also, when you take Vitamin (D3) you should also take Vitamin K2, as  they are co-factors.  I am also concerned that you may have become hypothyroid or have a different hormone imbalance.  One tends to impact on another, and if you were deficient in D then it may be due to something else having a knock on effect.  If you can get a copy of the bloods that were done, that might give us some pointers as to where to look and what to ask for next?
Posts.Title: 3yrs post cancer... I a man struggling with fatigue and this new life...

Posts.Content: Pop into your local chemist or supermarket, antihistamines are cheap and generics work just as well for most people. Ask the pharmacist.
Posts.Title: Itching...and I think it's from Anastrozole.

Posts.Content: Bear in mind also that anaesthetic can make you feel down for a week or more.  If it goes on more than two weeks, then you might need to talk to your BCN, but by then you should have your surgery results, so that will help.
Posts.Title: SENTINEL NODE BIOPSY - PLEASE HELP

Posts.Content: Hi MrsShep Firstly, don't apologise for moaning.  If we can't moan here, where can we moan?!  Secondly, we all understand that terror until treatment actually starts.  Just because your diagnosis might not be as bad as the next person's doesn't make yours any less terrifying to you.  When we are diagnosed it's like we are put in our own bubble and it's very hard for anything to get through, including our friends, family and common sense!  You will be fine but if you are really struggling it could be worth getting your GP to give you some diazepam or similar to just get through the next week or so.   Good luck for Friday. Helen

Posts.Title: 4 am club !!!

Posts.Content: Anyone would start feeling depressed after that, Mandymoo76. I would give everyone a call and leave messages saying that you are not getting sufficient communication and that you will be contacting PALS if they do not respond by the end of the week.  But please don't worry about cancer growing wildly out of control, breast cancer really isn't like that, so a few weeks here or there won't make masses of difference.  That's not to say they shouldn't be getting on with it though.  Now go rattle some cages!  I always used to tell my kids, don't get sad, get mad!
Posts.Title: What are you supposed to do? :(

Posts.Content: Phones AND chargers.  LOL   I found I was too spaced out to read, but listening to an ipod might be good.  Magazines that you can dip into maybe. Snacks and especially drinks I found were useful - squash is good. I'm not a massive fan of water, but I did drink quite a lot in there.  make-up wipes are useful to freshen yourself. I'm sure other people will think of other things to add!
Posts.Title: What to take with me into hospital for MX & Lymph node clearance ...

Posts.Content: I think it's more like the "short sharp shock" treatment.
Posts.Title: What do we call surgery?

Posts.Content: Absolutely, Judith!  The thing is, I obviously caught it from my husband, who was given antibiotics, therefore it makes sense I should have them.  He did write me a prescription, and said if it got worse I could cash it in.  I did. I happen to know that he misdiagnosed someone who died of cancer not terribly long after.  It might have been too late, but they'll never know.  I only go to him for simple things, otherwise see my lovely GP, who is always really good.
Posts.Title: 4 am club !!!

Posts.Content: Ladies - I had a prophylactic mastectomy at the same time as my mx for BC.  I told the doctors when they said I needed the Mx that I wanted both off, so that I wouldn't worry about it. I said that I needed it done for my mental health.  The hoops I had to go through were a) an MRI to prove/disprove there was anything wrong with the other one (there wasn't), then a second opinion from another surgeon to make sure I wasn't having it done for "cosmetic" reasons, ie, a boob job.   For me it was partly cosmetic though - I wanted to end up with a matched pair, which I wouldn't have if only one had been done. It would have looked ok in clothes, but like Rebecca, I wanted to look good naked. And the mental anguish if they were unmatched wasn't to be discounted.  This may sound very shallow, but put that with the fact that three of my aunts had breast cancer, I felt there was a real possibility that I could carry the BRCA gene as well, and it would have been unbearable.  I never wanted to hear the words "You have  breast cancer" again, and whilst I do know that it could come back in the future elsewhere, I think I've done everything humanly possible to prevent that.  So persevere, ladies, if you're sure, and go for what you want.  I had my surgery at Bedford, by the way.

Helen

I asked for a double mastectomy as a precaution and eventually they agreed.  I had Becker permanent expanders and everyone is very impressed with them.  I was asked what size I wanted to be! But I was happy with the previous size.  I am actually slightly bigger now and I love them.

If your marriage is not what makes you happy then start going out with friends and maybe you will find the inner strength to move on.  I know it's not easy but who said life was easy?  Cancer is a wake up call, don't have survived for nothing.  If we always do what we have always done then we shouldn't be surprised when we always get what we've always got.  Hugs

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda I had carpal tunnel and I was diagnosed with hypothyroidism.  Have your GP run a simple blood test before you go down the route of lots of operations just to rule it out.   Also the aches and pains are probably tamoxifen but you may find magnesium and or Vitamin D3 helps (take it with K2 to help it get to where it needs to be and not clog the arteries with calcium).  Your GP can test for this too but most people are deficient in D3, they believe these days.

I did feel abandoned by them when I had cording, but after a small explosion on the phone they've been great. I was just being a diva (In know, you can't believe it, right?).  They are now down to two so I know their workload is high now
Posts.Title: BCN

Posts.Content: Hi Marmar  Are you taking any hormone inhibitors like Letrozole or tamoxifen?  Because these can cause some of the pains you describe.   The main thing is not to be fobbed off and keep making a pest of yourself until someone does something to help you.

Posts.Content: Don't forget that breast cancer is very treatable these days, so even if you get a diagnosis, chances are that you will be treated and be fine. I was diagnosed over 6 years ago and I am living life.  Enjoy Christmas and try not to worry too much.

Posts.Content: For less than, say 10% increase in survival, I'd say give it up and see how it goes. But that's me. I only had a 1 %increase in my chances of recurrence so my decision was easy. Quality of life over life at any cost.  Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Choosing whether to continue into another five years of hormone t...

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add my two pence worth - I've had implants, which are fine, but not great.  But am considering a DIEP and it does NOT use muscle, so would not affect that side of things.  Yes, you have to bend over for a while until the skin stretches, but as people have said, the results are well worth it.
Posts.Title: reconstruction diep, tram or ld

Posts.Content: Dolina  There is no test in the world that can test every cell in the body, so we can never be 100% sure that there no remaining cells.  You have been vigilant and found your lump, and your team have quickly removed it, so have faith and you will soon be over this hurdle.   You may find that you are now offered chemo and in the circumstances, it might be worth it just for peace of mind.

Posts.Title: Gap between chemo and surgery and radiation

Posts.Content: Oh Flower, they do say things come in threes.  But you've been here before, and you know that this is the worst time.   It is time to put yourself first again for a while, but try to hold on to the fact that your doctor is making sure that you are seen and checked quickly rather than fobbing you off.  If there's something to treat, that will happen sooner rather than later.  And if there's not, then celebrate.  Even if there is something, it might be a new primary rather than the secondaries you are imagining.  I have everything crossed for you.
Posts.Title: Feeling Totally Demoralised!

Posts.Content: I was lucky and my nodes were all clear.  However, the SNB was worse than the mastectomy for me, so if I had to have ANC I would be devastated.  If you have the choice, and your onco isn't giving you a clear signal, I'd be tempted to say leave it as you've already had chemo and are having rads, the ANC is belt and braces.  Do you really need both?!  Especially in the light of existing lymphodema.   But it's your decision to make, you are the one to live with the consequences if your cancer returned, can your oncologist give you the statistics for with and without?
Posts.Title: Moving from Chemo to Surgery August / Sept 2016 - join me here

Posts.Content: Shirls - did you have reconstruction?  If so, it's very normal.  If not, still not abnormal, if you are at all worried, I would get it checked over.
Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: If you tell the anaesthetist that you always throw up after a GE, they may give the better drugs. They don't use them routinely because cost, but I had it last time and it was brilliant. I'm always sick too.
Posts.Title: Moving from Chemo to Surgery August / Sept 2016 - join me here

Posts.Content: I believe the guidelines are to be treated within 31 days of diagnosis . So although it seems a long time, now you have a diagnosis you should expect everything to move fast.   Don't worry, breast cancer doesn't rage out of control in the three months you have waited, but I do think now is the time to stamp your foot and insist on urgent action.
Posts.Title: waiting and more waiting :(

Posts.Content: If you had chemo it is likely to be that causing them to discolour.  Nails are like skin and need to breathe, so take the polish off and give them a bit of air and speak to the unit when you go to radiotherapy.
Posts.Title: Toenails - Yuck!

Posts.Content: Unless you have a genetic problem, the risk is no higher.  But if you carry the BRCA gene then obviously risk is increased significantly.  The nurses can advise you.  However I had a prophylactic mastectomy because I could not have had one real and one implant.  The difference naked is marked although clothed you probably wouldn't know.  So it depends if you need to look good naked, or are happy with just looking good clothed.  Google the images to see what I mean.   I also felt that I couldn't go through it again.  I would have been a nervous wreck.  I'm happy with my decision.
Posts.Title: Both breasts removed

Posts.Content: Hi Mandyw50 I'm sorry to hear that your sister is having to undergo treatment for breast cancer. There are several options that might be available to her children. Firstly, if the children feel they want online support, there is an organisation called Riprap, which is for children who's parents have cancer.   If there is a Maggie's centre near you, they offer day courses for children who's parents have cancer.  You could also try calling the free helpline on 0808 808 0000, they are open Monday to Friday fro 9am to 8pm.   It could also be worth contacting Cancer Research which has some information that might be helpful.
Posts.Title: Is there any respite care offered for children and young people who...

Posts.Content: Optimistic i can so identify with this.  I was ONLY IDC Grade 1, no node involvement, ER8, no chemo or rads and yet I was planning my funeral, rehoming the horses, generally wallowing in self pity. I feel quite ashamed now of the stress I put on my husband. In fact he went on antidepressants eventually.  The thing is, it doesn't help, it just brings everyone down and takes away the time you have.  Don't feel a failure, use the antidepressants to get you over this bump in the road, and in the meantime see if you can get some counselling.  Now get out and enjoy the sunshine.
Posts.Title: Cant understand it

Posts.Content: One thing I have learned is that there are no two identical treatments even for what appears to be the same problem.  There are so many variables that unfortunately you cannot compare one to another.   You are, of course, entitled to a second opinion.  You will need to ask your GP to refer you - do a little research and find a surgeon you think you would trust.  If you are near a big cancer hospital it could be worth trying that.   Good luck.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed should I get second opinion

Posts.Content: Around day 5 after anaesthetic it has more or less left your body and there is a rebound effect of depression. Hopefully you will start to feel a bit better but with the death of your partner's mum you have extra to deal with.  I would plan a few treats - cinema, meal, drinks, whatever you enjoy, and maybe something bigger for after treatment depending on what you need.
Posts.Title: Emotions- can anyone relate?

Posts.Content: eliza44 If you have a look at my profile you will see what I had done.  If you are not having reconstruction, they are more likely to do it, I went for double with implants and they were OK with it, after I had a second opinion. Good luck whatever you decide.  If you need more information, just ask.
Posts.Title: DOUBLE or SINGLE or not at all

Posts.Content: That's fab news, Kath, and I'm glad she's doing well - something you can relax about for a while now! Hope your treatment goes well now. Helen
Posts.Title: Granddaughter's op

Posts.Content: Hi Claire It's a bit how long is a piece of string, because if you need chemo then that comes first before radiotherapy.  But if not, as soon as the wound is healed and there is space on the unit, so anything from 2-6 weeks. Usually surgery is within about 10 days, if you need further margins.  Mine was about 4 weeks, though.  And just to warn you, after that second WLE, I was told they found cancer on the other side of the sample so had a mastectomy. Don't forget that you can always call the helpline here for advice during working hours (mon-fri, 9am-8pm) on 0808 808 0000.  Trained nurses are there to answer your questions.
Posts.Title: timescales

Posts.Content: I don't blame you, especially with your history.  Good luck.  The waiting is pants, but you will get through it, and we are here to help.
Posts.Title: timescales

Posts.Content: Woody the Lab  I'm glad to hear you are improving and things are headed in the right way.  All the things you are describing are quite usual, unfortunately, but they will improve with time.  If you have nerve pain, you will need a nerve painkiller, such as amitriptylene, or gabapentin.  These are very effective, usually. You may feel a bit down over the next few days as the rest of the anaesthetic leaves your system.  Knowing why you do is half the battle! Don't suffer any pain, do mention it to your BCN who can arrange a prescription as required. Good luck for your results!
Posts.Title: Day 5 post op

Posts.Content: Nightingale My daughter works for Pfizer. They have a drug called Fragmin which is an anti-coagulant especially for taking during operations.  You need to insist on the intravenous type, not the oral type.  It should take away your risk of TIA during/after the operation. Helen
Posts.Title: feeling really down now.....

Posts.Content: Hi ce1 Firstly, when you want to start a discussion you go to the top of the page and there is a button that says "Start New Discussion".  That way your posts don't get mixed up with someone elses. Secondly, yes, it's completely normal.  Cancer diagnosis is like a car crash.  You get on with dealing with the physical stuff straightaway but after that's dealt with you get the emotional shock wave that just hits you. You may want to visit your GP and get something to help you through this rocky patch, or ask to be referred for counselling.  Also, don't put up with the pain, there are lots of different painkillers out there so if one doesn't work, another will.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Just to add, ladies, don't forget to ask for the form to claim the VAT back on Mx bras!
Posts.Title: Help with finding matching MX underwear

Posts.Content: It's entirely up to you.  Some people think that to avoid recurrence, they can change their lifestyle and diet and it won't come back.  Others think that if it's going to come back it will, and they might as well enjoy things while they can! I personally am in the second camp.  I don't eat meat, but I enjoy chocolate and red wine, I am having fun and if it happens, it happens.
Posts.Title: I am reading lots of info re diet and did not realise a change was...

Posts.Content: You'd have to check with your surgeon, Sascha, but yes, DIEP flap comes from the stomach - just above the pubic bone to just above the belly button.  But scarring both external and internal can make it inappropriate - you'd have to get expert advice I think.   This extract gives the details of the buttock one ... Free SGAP flap (Superior Gluteal Artery Perforator flap) or the IGAP flap (Inferior Gluteal Artery Perforator flap) This uses fat and skin taken from the upper or lower buttock to create a new breast. It is generally used when abdominal tissue cannot be used due to scarring from previous surgical procedures or because the woman is too slim. The IGAP flap gives a softer feeling to the breast than the SGAP flap. The IGAP flap allows a larger breast size to be created and the scar is hidden in the crease of the buttock. HTH Helen
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I haven't had Herceptin but I just wanted to ask if you have mentioned it to your oncologist, because it is important that they know of any issues that you may have.  It may be that the chemo has upset your natural gut flora and you would benefit from taking a prebiotic which you can get in all good health shops or on the Internet.  Hope you can get it sorted soon.
Posts.Title: Herceptin and bowel problems

Posts.Content: Carolyn28 Hi @dreamtheif it doesn't prompt on my iPad.  I did try that as it's the convention on FaceBook. Thanks for the tip. X Carolyn It might if you spell it right,  @Carolyn28?
Posts.Title: How do I change my perspective of a death sentence?

Posts.Content: Consider this. When the tombs of the Pharaohs were discovered they found honey in sealed jars that was absolutely all right to eat.  They also wouldn't have known what Manuka honey was.  Honey does not breed bacteria since it is basically sugar which is the same.  I see no reason why it would be a risk unless you subscribe to the whole sugar feeds cancer theory but that's a whole other thread.
Posts.Title: Wheezing and coughing

Posts.Content: Restory  Most people find that with FEC the first week is the worst, a bit better week two, and week three most people feel OK. You don't know until it happens, but if your husband could stay home at least the first week, that might be worth looking at, and review it after that? I know there are some ladies who have done this on their own, and hopefully they will be along later to add their comments.
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I agree, it doesn't have to be cancer or alcohol.  See if you can get a referral to a renal specialist
Posts.Title: liver function tests.

Posts.Content: She may wish to rethink, as there is an increased chance of recurrence if the nipple is retained.   It's not the end of the world (esp as she only has one side) but she will likely have little or no feeling/sensation anyway.  Nipples can be reconstructed and I personally have tattoos only although you can have both (the NHS tattooing isn't very long lasting though). It's a steep learning curve but ask any questions you have.
Posts.Title: Nervous huband

Posts.Content: Hi Siani I feel for you.  It feels like you're on a treadmill, doesn't it?  But things do start to settle down and I'm sure that you'll get to a point where you do want to wake up in the morning.   In the meantime, it might be worth checking with your Dr and maybe getting something to help you over this low phase. Helen x
Posts.Title: Feeling fed up of treatment and hospitals.

Posts.Content: I found a lump in 2010.  I went to the doctor and was referred to my local hospital where they did an ultrasound and said it was a cyst.  They biopsied it and it disappeared.   A year later, I felt a strange tingling in the same area, and after being referred again (different doctor and hospital), it was cancer.  I'm pretty sure it was in the same area.
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: Unfortunately the thyroid is very sensitive to radiation so it could well be affected.   Get all the tests done but if you are diagnosed send me a friend request and I will send you some useful information.  I have been hypothyroid for over 20 years and only did research in the past year or so.
Posts.Title: fear after treatment ends

Posts.Content: BluesJK If you haven't spoken to your oncologist about fertility treatment, do let them know. If you are ER/PR- and HER-  then you are classed as triple negative and chemo is usually recommended, especially in younger patients. Chemo can affect conception, and as you are ER/PR-, the treatment for IVF is an option.   I've not had to undergo any of this, as I'm older, but it is worth finding out as much as possible before going forward.
Posts.Title: 25 years old and possible breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi Knotofpeace I had a transfusion of 2 units after my Mx.  Didn't feel a thing, and it didn't make me feel any different.   The unit has to go through within 2 hours so you can allow a max of 4 hours.  Mine trickled through really slowly due to the position of the canula.  The second unit they adjusted it and it went through much quicker.  You can't give blood again afterwards though.   Helen x
Posts.Title: Has anyone had a transfusion for anaemia?

Posts.Content: Jessie - just wanted to say just because YOU have cancer, don't treat your child any differently - if he's misbehaving, tell him off.  If he doesn't know what's going on, explain it more to him.  Maybe he's lashing out because he doesn't know what's happening and feels out of control.  He's more likely to be affected if you keep him in the dark - be positive about what you tell him.  Mummy is sick, but she's going to have some treatment that will make her better, and then things will be back to normal.  That sort of thing. My sister had problems with her daughter when she got divorced (Yes, I know, not the same, but the principle is there), let her get away with things because she felt guilty about splitting up the family.  It led to a lot of long term problems.  Guilt is one of the most destructive, unhelpful emotions and we women are too ready to give in to it.
Posts.Title: effecting my son

Posts.Content: Please click on the link below for more details  community.macmillan.org.uk/.../133640
Posts.Title: Meeting in York for Macmillan members who are able to attend

Posts.Content: hedgewitch Hi Mistymoley. Actually it is probably a good job I didn't join at the beginning of my treatment. I lost what friends I had then by snapping at them. I would hate to have done that here and embarrassed myself. I got sick of people telling me to be positive. Sick of people saying they had a friend who had cancer and they were able to do this, that, and the other. And people telling me I'd be fine, then changing the subject. I am normally a very laid back person who agrees with people to keep the peace. But the cancer made me touchy to start with. So I lost all my friends by telling them it wouldn't be the cancer, or the treatment that would kill me, but people stressing me out. Now I just have five cats to support me through this, who don't deliberately upset me. I was fine doing it on my own. Then last night I suddenly felt a bit lonely and decided to join others who knew how I felt. Ah but the difference here is we all get it. We don't try to make you be brave, or positive.  If you want a good old rant, you can come here and do it safe in the knowledge that we've all been there at some point or another. We won't fallout with you, because we know what it's like.  That the worry is always in the background, sometimes further back than others, that although you look fine, you feel disfigured, vulnerable, weakened.  That passes, eventually, but it's a long hard road and we're here to walk it with you.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: I found a lump in 2010.  I went to the doctor and was referred to my local hospital where they did an ultrasound and said it was a cyst.  They biopsied it and it disappeared.   A year later, I felt a strange tingling in the same area, and after being referred again (different doctor and hospital), it was cancer.  I'm pretty sure it was in the same area.
Posts.Title: Anyone else had cyst become cancerous?

Posts.Content: The important thing is to make sure you take the anti sickness meds before you need them because once you feel sick you won't keep  them down.  Take your temperature before you take the paracetamol or ibuprofen.  You should be fine because it's too early for your immune system to be hit by the chemo, but the problem with taking paracetamol is that it can mask an infection by reducing temperature that would give you a sign that all was not well.   I hope you are feeling better soon too
Posts.Title: Had my first chemo today

Posts.Content: Hi Hedgewitch, and welcome to the Breast Group. You will wish that you had joined at the beginning, there is so much help and support here.  You are on the final lap, though, so congratulations! People will reply to your thread and you can reply to theirs or start new ones as necessary to keep a single topic separate to other topics. Come in, make yourself at home.
Posts.Title: Just joined.

Posts.Content: Hi Emma Firstly, it seems as though you are lucky to have a good surgeon and some considerate care! Secondly, whilst I am sure that there are many people who are perfectly happy to live with the LD flap, I was offered it, but I was very sure to make sure that my surgeon knew that I had a very active lifestyle (I ride and look after 3 horses), and consequently they decided that it would not be a good option for me. I think the amount of strength people have does depend to quite an extent on the amount they use their muscles, so they may not notice much difference if they didn't use the muscle much before? Also, when I had a second opinion at the Royal Marsden in Chelsea, the surgeon said that they rarely perform the LD flap operation there anymore, finding the DIEP flap a much more satisfactory result, even though it is a bigger operation.  As they are a centre of excellence, you have to wonder why this is?  Especially in these days of cost savings.   I've currently got Becker "permanent" expanders, but I'm planning to have the DIEP flap next year after I've done a few things that need doing here. Hope this helps in some way.  Oh and if in doubt, get a second opinion! Helen
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Haha well there you go - silver lining! I have no idea about it other than what I've told you, Sascha.  Research needed, I guess!
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Oh yes, sheep are heavy!  Used to keep our horses on a sheep farm ... long story! The hospital I had my original reconstruction done at doesn't do the DIEP flap either, they offered me implants or LD flap, or I could go to Stevenage for the DIEP but I was REALLY pushed towards the implants both by the surgeon and by my husband although bless him he really didn't realise that he was being manipulated at the time by the surgeon, who was really pushing the implants "Why wouldn't you have these?  Why wouldn't you?"  Erm because it's not such a good end result, and actually they don't last forever so they'll have to be replaced when I'm 62 and will I really need that at that age?  Plus they also don't feel the way they do when they're out of the body because you will implant them under the muscle ... blah blah blah I could go on.   Anyway, since then, I've been to the Royal Marsden for a second opinion, as well as the Norwich, who have both said that they would be more than happy to do a DIEP on me, so it really is a question of what YOU want.   One of the main reasons I wanted it was that we go on a lot of holidays, and I really needed to be able to wear a bikini ... ;) plus I actually know that even though he says otherwise, my husband would really struggle with me with only one boob.  But that's just me. The tummy tuck bit doesn't even bother me, I've had to actually put some weight on to have enough belly to do it ... :)
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: They're usually done by specialist plastic surgeons on the NHS.  If it is a delayed recon as yours would be, then they are certainly done by the plastic surgery dept, but if they are immediate, they are sometimes done in conjunction with breast surgeons, and some breast surgeons are multi-skilled and can do both.   I had a keyhole hysterectomy, but they've not said that it will cause any problems.  I have four very small scars.
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Hi Ange I'm no expert, but I would hazard a guess that your bones may show some sign of deterioration due to age/arthritis/other unknown (to me) reasons, so they decided Tamoxifen was better, and some people do have this extra boost of rads although no one has ever explained why to me. I would give your BCN a call or if she's not co-operative/available you could try ringing the helpline here on 0808 808 0000, Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm.
Posts.Title: change of treatment plan after ct scan. what do you think?

Posts.Content: I have to say that the aesthetic results of mine aren't too bad, but I have a small amount of rippling (which I could live with if all else were OK) but I have a problem with the left one falling to the side when I lay on my back, which doesn't sound awful in itself, but it is actually quite painful, and I have to support it with my hand, so tend to sleep on one side or the other.  Or my front, if I can pull a pillow down to my chest and make a dip. Also, my muscles are compromised because the implants are under them - In theory I still have the strength, but in practice it feels weird in many ways and I REALLY can't open jars any more and sweeping is harder than it used to be! So they're not the end of the world, but you are right, there is ongoing maintenance.  I don't know if I'd bother later on - I guess it depends how good a job they do in the first place.
Posts.Title: What are the long-term effects of having an LD reconstruction?

Posts.Content: One other thing - you will find that only people who have been on this road truly understand it.  Even our partners who are by our sides the whole time can only see it from the outside.  Which is where this site, and local support groups come in.  If there is one at your local hospital do go along and you will find lots of support.
Posts.Title: Very very bad day

Posts.Content: You're not mad, or stupid, or anything, Yvonne We've all been where you are (I still do it sometimes, only much less frequently).  When you are first diagnosed, you are bewildered, trying to make sense of it all (you're in the queue for the rollercoaster, not sure whether the ride is really for you or not), then you get in the car, you're strapped in, and the ride starts - there's nothing you can do at this point except hold tight and grit your teeth, scream at the drops and laugh when it stops.  Once you are through the worst of treatment, you have time to stop and contemplate what has happened.  It's like Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.   I think it's been said that we're never quite the same as before diagnosis but we are a new, modified improved version.  Radiotherapy saps your energy, so you don't have the reserves to maintain the control, the facade that you show normally.  And the real you leaks out around the edges.  Your family understand and they are there for you.  Please don't beat yourself up.  And if you can enquire at your hospital, try to get some counselling to help you through this bit.  The NHS is good at the slash and burn (surgery and radiotherapy) but less good at the emotional treatment which I think is the worst part of it all.  Chin up.  xx
Posts.Title: Very very bad day

Posts.Content: Dear MalH - I wanted to reply to you earlier, but couldn't log in (GRRR) You've had exactly what I had originally.  Your mind goes mad, thinking that you have cancer all over your body, you're going to be dead by Xmas, and all of that. The good news for you is that you are grade 1, so the lowest possible grade, and pr/er+, so you can have tamoxifen.  Here's hoping that your results come back clear and you don't need more than maybe rads.   My story is slightly different, as I ended up with no clear margins and had a Mx but I'm now free and clear, didn't need rads, just Tamoxifen, and my life is now as good, if not better, than ever.  I've had my down days, still do occasionally, but I have decided that I'm just going to make the best of whatever happens from here on in, and enjoy life! So the positivity comes with time.
Posts.Title: hoping to find some comfort from people who understand

Posts.Content: Hi Emma! Great to see you here and to hear you're doing so well. Very good timing with your lovely reply to Lizane.   It sounds like everything is working well for you -long may it continue!
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: Hi Lee I'm sorry to say that having a double mastectomy won't prevent you getting a recurrence, because breast cancer can occur anywhere in the body (I know this sounds odd, but it's true).  It can recur in lungs, bones, liver or brain (I think), so the AIs work by suppressing the hormones in the rest of the body.  I think you need to ask your oncologist for the statistics with you taking the AIs as opposed to not, and base your decision on this. The fact you are Stage 1 is in your favour, as it has been caught early, and I was the same.  I was given surgery and Tamoxifen which I took for almost 2 years and finally decided that the 1% difference wasn't worth it for me and I stopped.  But that was my personal decision.   I suggest you think very carefully about the options, because there is no failsafe against recurrence, but there are some things that are worth trying.
Posts.Title: Can I avoid hormone therapy if I elect to have a double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Just a thought, if you are hypothyroid, either diagnosed or undiagnosed, you can get these issues due to lack of or too much T3 in the cells.   Not sure if it applies, but worth mentioning. Most GPs aren't really aware of it, so you might need to research a bit - Send me a friend request and ask for information and I am happy to link you to some places to look

Posts.Content: Hi Snowie I had permanent expander implants, and I have to say that they still feel like that at times.  Also a bit like wearing a too tight bra even when you aren't wearing one? I will say, though, that things are easing (Had my op in Nov, last expansion in March), and the scars do take a while to heal.  I'm talking about the internal ones, as well as the external.  So it may be that yours have healed tighter on the inside, and maybe some massage may help?  I would also talk to your plastic surgeon if you can - I can't, as mine is a bit of an arse, frankly.  Helen x
Posts.Title: Discomfort still after implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: I suggest you just tell him you need something to help you sleep.  They usually give a low dose antidepressant for this.  There are plenty of us here who are on them in one form or another.  I was given some to help my headaches and I have to say they were brilliant for helping me sleep.  Took them about 8pm, ready for bed and 10, slept straight through.  And although I'm not on them now, the sleep pattern is largely good.   And don't apologise for moaning, we all know what it's like!!
Posts.Title: FEELING SO DOWN

Posts.Title: FEELING SO DOWN

Posts.Content: Hi Sr  Yes you will have had a sentinel node biopsy. You will now be having an axillary clearance which means all the nodes. It is vital to do the exercises after surgery,  but also to look after your arm so that you don't develop lymphodaema.  No blood pressure cuffs, or blood tests on that arm, be careful not to scratch it and protect from bites.   That said,  most people don't develop it, but you need to understand the risks.
Posts.Title: what is sentinal node biopsy?

Posts.Content: I also had a lumpectomy scar around the nipple which wasn't too bad.  But I needed further margins and although they cut in the same place,  my nipple started to look like a kid with a squint.  The nerves were also damaged and although I have always had an inverted nipple on that side, it was repeatedly inverting and reverting every few seconds and it was driving me mad.   When they said I needed mastectomy I was relieved that it would go.  All surgeons are different.  my mastectomy scar is horizontal across my breast. I wish I had had your type of scar because the line does sometimes show on low cut clothes and bikinis. That said it has faded a lot and you don't really notice unless you know what you are looking for.
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy scars

Posts.Content: I was offered the choice of implants, LD flap or TRAM flap.   I specifically asked for a recon that would not compromise any of my strength, since I have horses and didn't want not to be able to ride afterwards. I've had becker expanders, as they recommended this as the best choice, since both LD and TRAM will use muscles and this will, inevitably, reduce strength.  My op was at the end of November.  I've been riding since, and had no problem although it does still feel weird, with the expanders fitted under the pectoral muscles.   I am considering the DIEP flap for my own reasons, but certainly there is no reason why the implants would cause any problem.  I do know someone who has had ongoing problems with the LD flap, which is one reason I personally wouldn't consider it, although obviously there are a lot of people here who have had them and are happy with the result.
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: Hi Faith54 It's terrible to watch a family member with any disease, especially cancer.  Unfortunately unless you are in the position of having to make a decision you cannot know what you would do, you can only think you do.  It's best not to try to persuade your mum either way, because at the end of the day it has to be her decision, and whatever that is, you must support her.  (I know you will). I was 47 when I was diagnosed with a Grade 1 cancer.  Unfortunately although they tried to do a WLE (lumpectomy) it didn't have clear margins and the following attempt found further cancer cells, so I was told it would have to be a mastectomy.  At this point I was sure that I wanted both gone, I never wanted to hear the words "you have breast cancer" ever again and I also wanted reconstruction with a matching pair.  I did go for it, and I haven't regretted it, but I do now know that I may yet here those words again, as secondaries usually come back elsewhere in the  body.  That said, in your mother's case, she's had chemo, and not having radiotherapy isn't the end of the world, in fact there is now some thinking that it is overkill.   It was around 3.5 months from my initial diagnosis to final mastectomy with no chemo involved, and my surgeon was able to tell me that I was cured at the end of it. Usually the best you get is No Evidence of Disease (hence we have the NEDdy club here). One in 8 women will get breast cancer so the fact that there are a number in your family could just be pure bad luck, lifestyle, or genetic (even though your mum has been tested, they are getting better at these all the time, so it may be that they haven't found that link yet).  There is no point trying to work out why, but there is a good reason for you to be vigilant in your own checking, just in case.   One mastectomy is probably no easier to recover from than two, but possibly being even might be easier to live with in the long run.   I hope your mum has a successful operation whichever she chooses, and a speedy recovery.
Posts.Title: Never posted before - Mum has TNBC advice needed pls asap

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn I had double Mx with implants but no Radiotherapy.  I'm thrilled with the results and so is my husband and my friends!  :D I was on My Tattoo Addiction as I had permanent tattoos and it was filmed for Channel 4.  You should be able to see it here and you can see how they looked before and after.   Depending where you are, you could go along to a Keeping Abreast Group where you can meet ladies who have had surgery and will show their results and chat to you.  Happy to give any more information you may want.
Posts.Title: what reconstruction to have

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne The blue dye is in your body and it will break down over time.  Some people have it longer than others, I think it depends on the way your body works, but I think mine went quite quickly.  If you have a mastectomy I think it fades quicker than a lumpectomy.  In the meantime, embrace your inner smurf!

Posts.Title: ld flap Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi WORRIED2016  I think you need to be careful with what you eat if you are prone to weight gain. The Tamoxifen itself doesn't make you put on weight but it can make you feel like eating and drinking more than you need.  Every one is different, so what happened to one may not happen to you. Knowing you, I'd come away from that page and stop looking for things to worry about!  How are you feeling now? Are the antibiotics kicking in?
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and weight gain

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzie I haven't had the exact same experience, but have had fibroids and as a result I had a sub partial laparascopic hysterectomy (my choice).  This meant keyhole and they left my ovaries.  Make sure you're not anaemic, first of all!   Anyway the hysterectomy was a breeze and I've never looked back!  (until the cancer!)   HTH Helen x

Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

Posts.Content: I think they are between a rock and a hard place.  They must feel there is something to investigate, but they will not speculate as to what that could be until they have results.  So we must try not to speculate either.  Harder to do than say, I realise.  Having said that, I think if they do suspect something serious, they do tend to indicate in order to prepare you.  But not enough that you then spend the next waiting period in the depths of despair. Try to keep busy and not dwell on the what ifs.  They can be dealt with if and when necessary but for now live for the moment.
Posts.Title: scan and biopsy today

Posts.Content: The hardness and pain is perfectly normal. I had painkillers for months after, I am sorry to say, but the hardness does improve in time. For the first three months I thought about my new breasts 24/7, I was completely aware of them all the time. Now I don't think about them much at all.

Posts.Content: tallgirl1969  We all felt the same after diagnosis.  If you don't have personal experience of cancer, you immediately remember all the stupid newspaper headlines, who died from this type or that type, but what they never mention is the 1,000s of people that survive. You have a very good chance of survival, so focus on getting through whatever treatment is recommended for you, and getting on with life. Glad you have found the site helpful and yes keeping busy is hard work but keeping busy stops you from focussing on the cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi Jazzshampoo1 It could be that you have a bit of cording, or perhaps lymphodema. It's important not to overuse the arm, but to keep doing the stretching exercises.  As you say, it is early days, but if you don't have an appointment in the next few weeks, and it doesn't get any better, I would call your BCN and get it checked out.  There's not much point going to the GP, better to go to the experts!
Posts.Title: Lump in the arm

Posts.Content: Hi Millyimp. Love the name.   It must be hard to know that you are dealing with at least one cancer, let alone possible secondaries or a second primary.  And remaining optimistic must seem hard.  But there are people here who are being given various drugs, including letrozole, for their secondaries, and  I'm sure they'll be along to reassure you.   Do mention the wind/discomfort to your oncologist, as it may be a side effect and they can change your tablets.  It's worth knowing that some brands are better than others for side effects, but it is trial and error to find what suits you.  Make a note of which brand you are on and which side effects you get and hopefully you can get one that suits best.  And there are meds for most side effects. The waiting really is the pits, we all hate it.  And you are allowed to have down days.

Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Kate2017 Hi and welcome to the Macmillan Online community. I know that where you are now is a very scary place, but there is a very good chance that you won't be here long.  None of us have x-ray vision or psychic ability, so we can't tell you that what you have is or isn't cancer.  But the good news is that plenty of women just like you turn up scared and worried and leave with a cyst or some minor issue. On the other hand, if it is cancer, it doesn't mean that you need to put your affairs in order!  Obviously it's always good to do that, but there is no rush, because 90% of all breast cancer patients are still alive and kicking over 5 years on (that's how long they did the stats for, and actually the figures are, by their nature, 5 years out of date!).  You have done the right thing by going to your GP, the hospital is now on your case, you will be fine as soon as you know what you are dealing with, and if you need a treatment plan.  I'm sure that there will be others along in a minute to reassure you.  I was diagnosed over 5 years ago myself and I am going strong!

Posts.Title: One year on........

Posts.Content: Regency  - I'm a little confused, is it you or your mum or both that has been diagnosed? Assuming it's your mum, don't worry, grade 2 is very treatable.  There are lots of women here who have been here for several years following diagnosis and treatment and they are back living their lives.   People are used to hearing the word cancer in the context of "so and so has died of cancer" but there are actually thousands of people who are actively living after cancer rather than dying from it.   You have done the best thing by joining this group, and we are all here to support you and your mum.

Posts.Content: Hi Cazza I have to say that it is SO hard to both be the patient but also the carer.  It is unfortunate that your husband has gone this way around trying to alleviate his stress, but not altogether surprising.  I would like to give you more information but not here.  I shall send you a friend request - if you would like to accept me, I will tell you a bit more about my journey - it might help you understand. Posts.Title: had my mastectomy today

Posts.Content: Hi Rich1984, you don't need to hold it in for us.  I often think that being the patient is the easy part, watching someone you love go through treatment without being able to do anything is very hard.  And you are allowed to cry in front of your partner.  She cannot and will not expect you to be up all the time.  In fact, we women tend to think that guys who never show they are down or sad are uncaring and although deep down it's not true, we still want you guys to go through it with us. If you have a really good friend who can take you out for a walk and you can really unburden yourself to them and then go for a pint in the pub or something, you will feel million times better.  I know you haven 't come here for support for yourself as such, but we are here for you anyway.  You can also join our Friends and Family Group You can say anything you like there, people are in your position and totally get it.
Posts.Title: Books on breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Daphne Just popping in to say that I was diagnosed in August 2011.  I had WLE, further excisions, and finally they said Mastectomy.  I asked for bilateral although there was no indication of cancer in the other breast, but I wanted to have a matching pair at the end of the day, plus there was a strong history in my family, so was sure that sooner or later I would end up having the other done.  As it turned out, no cancer was found there after the op, but I am happy with my decision, having heard so many stories like yours.   I don't have much sensation, but 3 years on I have some.  It was never much of a thing for my husband, but he's more interested now, funnily enough!  LOL As far as friends go, you certainly find out who they are.  But some people are good friends, they just don't know how to deal with cancer, especially if you've always been the strong healthy one in the relationship!  You don't feel like keeping them posted, so don't.  You can catch up with them later, or you may decide you will move on, make other friends.  I certainly found out how many fantastic friends I had (and one of more than 30 years who I would have thought would have been there, really wasn't).  But it's their loss.   Send me a friend request if you want any more info. Helen

Just a thought. Helen

Posts.Content: Chemo is hard on the liver, so drinking while undergoing it is not advisable.  However, it's also hard on the mental health so she may need the support of a drink to get her through it.  As far as cancer is concerned, that boat has already sailed, so as long as her oncologist is aware, I would say you need to wait until after treatment has finished before trying to "fix" your sister. Be supportive, don't nag, explain about the effects on the liver, but don't tell her what she should do. She is an adult.

Posts.Title: Cording (AWS)

Posts.Content: Damn, was really hoping someone would say something positive.  Been on Tamoxifen for a year.  Put about 3/4 stone on since my diagnosis.  In fairness, originally I was deliberately trying to put some weight on for a DIEP which I've now decided I'm not going to do.  Told my husband I was going to diet in the new year but he's been sabotaging it, so have given up.   Also have major pain in my ankles - my oncologist sent me for an x-ray, turns out I have arthritis.  Now that's fine (at least it's not BC in my bones) but I don't know if the fact that it's now showing up is the result of Tamoxifen irritating it, or it's pure co-incidence.  I asked the GP today, but he didn't really answer me.  Since I only have a 1% difference either way, just need to know if it's worth it? And Pat - I've been on those type of meds - they really knock me out!  I'm just getting my life back, so this is NOT a route I want to go down!
Posts.Title: how to lose weight on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Babs - Massive hugs to you.  I know exactly how you are feeling - I was exactly the same at your stage.   The good news is that it DOES get better - let out the tears now, rant to us and let the feelings go.  As Sascha Rose says, the not knowing is awful, but you'll get your results and your treatment plan if needed and you can start to rebuild the next stage of your life.   I've all but forgotten I had breast cancer now - the things that remind me are emails from here, and sometimes the pain from my implants, which will be my next stage to deal with.  So it really does get better, honest! Helen xx

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Hi CarolineCat I assume as you have already had rads you aren't having chemo.  I would imagine that he will assure you that the cancer was removed, as you have already progressed past the stage of needing clear margins.  The rads mop up any stray cells in the area.  So assuming you are ER+ or PR+ they will be prescribing Tamoxifen and talking about the various issues that may arise with it.  You will have a check up sooner than May, I would think, although all hospitals have different schedules so I can't say for sure.  I don't think you would have a CT scan unless you are having any unexplained pains anywhere.

Posts.Title: Seroma in tummy after DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi Binny I've had a look, and I can't find out any particular drug that is stopped, and anyone that is currently on one will continue.  As to Tamoxifen, one of the things I have found is that my eyesight started to deteriorate more quickly than previously.  I'm sure it was down to Tamoxifen.  As my mother has glaucoma and macular degeneration, as well as always having to wear glasses, I was particuarly aware of this, and it was a factor in me stopping the drug. I have had a look here and there is some information on this page http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Cancertypes/Brain/Typesofbraintumours/Pituitarytumours.aspx (sorry, I can't do the fancy links like George does!) I'm sure it must be terrifying, but it's worth having a look in the brain tumour section of Macmillan, as I'm sure there will be people there who have more experience and can advise on treatments.  Big hugs and lots of love. Helen

Posts.Content: Hi GMc  You have already had some good advice.  Firstly, I want to add that the diagnosis your wife has is very good and there is a high likelihood of a full recovery.  You need to make sure that your wife understands that and that you are sticking around in any case.  I had the same thoughts as your wife, even though I was only stage 1. Above all I wanted my husband to tell me that he wasn't going anywhere and would stay with me whatever happened.  No matter how hard your wife tries to push you away, if you want to stay, push back, hug her tight and reassure her. Keep telling her you love her and the kids, and get those bags packed and go home!

Posts.Title: Happy stuff

Posts.Content: Hi Chris One thing I have learned is that everyone's treatment is different even if they appear to have the same problems/diagnosis.  I think in your position I'd be concerned too, but perhaps you should contact your BCN/consultant and ask to have a meeting to explain everything.  Their reasoning may put your mind at rest. I know that the Macmillan nurses here are very knowledgable, but in this instance I think someone who knows your actual case is probably a better bet, although there's no harm in speaking to someone. If you are concerned, I would ask for a second opinion to put your mind at rest.  You have every right to this, just ask your GP to refer you to somewhere that's a cancer Centre of Excellence like the Royal Marsden (or ask him what is your most local one depending on your location) But to reassure you somewhat, the variables are often to do with age, weight, degree of hormone positivity, and sometimes what the surgeon/oncologist had for breakfast.

Posts.Title: Panicking another lump

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia I'm going through it at the moment - you have to fill in a form all about your family history, including any partners' family history for your children's sake, and the testing is all explained to you by a counsellor.   You then have a blood test taken and it takes between 2 and 4 months to come back.  They then tell you the results, and if you are positive for one of the genes, then they let you know the options.   They won't do anything until after you have completed your treatments, as that is obviously the most important and time sensitive part.   I've only had the blood test done a few days ago, so have a wait for results now.  Because I had a medium risk family history, I had no problem getting the test, if you have no family history then it is unlikely you would be offered it.

Posts.Title: Horizon

Posts.Content: Lamonsea  You say it is hard for your children to be away from you and yet you are making decisions that could take you away permanently. Surely it is better that you are away from them for a night or two, or ill for a few days a week than permanently dead?  I am sorry this seems a bit harsh, but putting your children's needs above yours means they may end up without you. What happens then? Do call the helpline and talk through the details of your treatment and I hope they can point you at some help.
Posts.Title: Delaying chemo

Posts.Content: There is no good time to lose a parent. What if you delay chemo and only have a year, two at the most?  You MUST put yourself first in this case. As you say, you have already wasted time, don't waste any more. You don't know how chemo will affect you unless you try it, and there are drugs for all the side effects.  Statistics are not facts. We are all individuals, and we all react differently to treatment. I am sure that if you explain things to your children they will step up to the plate. Aspergers is tricky, I get that, but you shouldn't use it as a reason to die.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed invasive ductal carcinoma.

Posts.Content: You could have secondaries.  You could have arthritis.  You could just be ageing.  You could have osteoporosis.  This is why we always say DON'T google!  (Random selection, could be a whole lot of other things!!) Honestly, it's probably a precaution to rule the secondaries OUT as much as rule anything else in at this stage.  What you will find is that because you are in the system, Drs tend to play on the cautious side and you will get speeded through any waiting times.  Be grateful that your health is being considered, but worrying won't change the result or make your life better. I saw something that says worry is the thing that takes away happiness.  Go out, be busy, enjoy your family, forget the scan and wait and see.

Posts.Title: NIpple reconstruction dilemma

Posts.Content: Hi Leen Already some great advice and info for you here! If you want to see my nipple tattooing being done, have a look at this video that shows it being done.  At the end they show you the result, but the skin is still bleeding, so it's not a true representation of the final thing but I can send you a photo of how they are now if you want (just send a friend request and a message). I had a double Mx and the second one was prophylactic (preventive).  I was asked if I wanted to retain the nipple and said no, because there is a 5% extra chance of recurrence.  The surgeon was very happy with this, and it did mean that the tattooist didn't have to colour match me, but I've never regretted it. I didn't have the nipple reconstruction, but could have had if I wanted.  The NHS tattooing does tend to fade, which is why I had mine done privately and permanently.

Posts.Title: first appointment

Posts.Content: My understanding is that you are not classed as disabled but you are covered by the Disability at work act so that employers cannot use it to get rid of you.   I've had several jobs since my diagnosis and I didn't mention it on any of them.  Only one asked me for a health screening where I disclosed everything (It was done by a third party) and they asked if I felt I needed anything particular as a consequence and if I would like it held back from the company which I said yes to.  It made it a clean start for me.  That said, if you had a job that was affected by your treatment, i.e., heavy lifting or something, then you would have to disclose it.   I would suggest you speak to the Macmillan people on this, as they are very clued up. Helen x

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen, hot flushes and night sweats.

Posts.Content: Hi Pat You are welcome.  I also have a thyroid problem.  I have been diagnosed for about 23 years now and it's only been the past 3/4 years that I bothered doing any research. Iron pills are probably ferrous fumerate that aren't readily absorbed by the body (but are cheap, hence from NHS).  I take Solgar Gentle Iron which I find non constipating and always take with Vit C for best absorption.  Then folic acid should be folate.  Not the same thing.  Vit D should be D3, and taken with K2 to transport the D3 to the bones otherwise it goes to places you DON'T want it like arteries.  B12 is best taken sublingually or in a spray.   Being in range isn't enough, you need to be in the right place in the range to be optimal so that all these things can work together.  Usually in the top quarter of the range.   When you get your results ask for printouts so you can check where you are in the ranges.  TSH should be 1 or below but it's hard to get doctors to medicate correctly because TSH only gives part of the picture (and is a flawed test anyway).   Sorry if you already know all this stuff, I usually PM it as it's not cancer related!

Posts.Content: Deedee - this is something only your surgeon can really advise.  I would probably say it's unlikely, but it depends on what you mean by small.  Short isn't an issue, but if you are slim then you're probably out of luck! I was a reasonable size 12 and was told it was possible but I would only get an A or B cup, but I opted for implants and have a very satisfactory C cup. I've never heard of a TRAM or DIEP with implants - frankly I wouldn't have thought it's worth going through all the aggro of a TRAM or DIEP if you have to have implants as well.

Posts.Title: Not responding to chemo or herceptin

Posts.Content: There are no machines, scanners, tests that can tell if every single cell in your body is good, so you have to just think yourself lucky that the equipment we have has found the cancers and your surgeon has found what he can so far.   There are people walking around who have cancer but don't know about it, we are the lucky ones who have been diagnosed and who are able to do something about it.  All the treatments we are offered give us more chance of life, so hang on to that and believe in your team. Good luck for the Mx, I had the same treatment and ended up asking for a double Mx and got it. My good breast was completely clear on examination afterwards.

I did have to wait for the second opinion, I think it maybe took an extra couple of weeks, I didn't have to see a psychologist, but I did see one as part of the genetic testing after the operation. I had a lumpectomy then surgery for further margins and they found more cancer, so all together diagnosis 3rd August and mastectomy was 23rd November.   A few weeks won't make much difference.
Posts.Title: Want to have bilateral mastectomy with one breast elective.

Posts.Content: You should be able to get a GP appointment within 48 hours (government guidelines)  (Not including weekends).  They may ask you if it's an emergency, and just say yes (it is, because you can't get an appointment within a reasonable time frame).  See a doctor.  Any doctor. Change your surgery if that really is the case.  Can you imagine this scenario in the US?  No, nor can I.   And make yourself heard.  Take someone with you if you feel that you can't express yourself well enough.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer Nov 14'. Lumpectomy no spread in lymph...

Posts.Content: commoner  All valid questions.   I think that 1, yes, it's likely to be bigger than the existing breast because they can't do very tiny implants.  And likely to sit more pert, too. This is partly why I asked for the double mastectomy with implant reconstruction. 2.  At first, all I could think about was my boobs.  it took about 8 months to really come to terms with them and get used to the feeling. They weren't exactly uncomfortable, but I was conscious of them and it was a bit like having a couple of flat pebbles duct taped to my chest all the time.  They DO soften in time, and I did not have a strattice "hammock" which is a more recent way of doing it, ask about that. 3. This is one reason I didn't want this! 4. No, you would have a mammogram as usual on the remaining breast. 5.  No, you can't do one on that side. In closing, I'm really pleased with my decision, I know that I would have hated being lopsided, so I asked for both to be done, which they agreed finally.

Posts.Content: Hi Pat I can't help with the brush, although I suggest maybe you speak to your hairdresser?  But I was going to say that if you have thin hair because of a Thyroid problem it may be that actually it is due to low ferritin.  Ask your GP to run a full thyroid panel, iron panel, folate, ferritin and Vitamin D and B12.  If you are deficient in any of these it stops you absorbing the thyroxine.  You need to be near the top of the ranges, too, not just "in range".
