Posts.Content: Hi Millie Unfortunately that is one of the side effects of Tamoxifen because it is stripping the body of oestrogen which the body needs to keep our bones in working order.   You could try a different brand of Tamoxifen, as some people find some brands better than other.  If you find one that suits you, get your GP to write that brand on the prescription so that you only get that one.
Posts.Title: RE: chronic back and hip pain after cancer treatments.

Posts.Content: Hi Carly  What a great daughter in law you are.  I can see your dilemma. Chemo can have long term side effects for some people.  The question I usually ask is "if your relative were in this position what woulcecd you recommend."  If your mother in law is in otherwise good health then it is harder to decide because it could be that another health condition would take her off before any recurrence occurred.  Unfortunately we all know what we would do either way but she has to make up her own mind.  All you can do is support her decision.
Posts.Title: Chemo Decisions

Posts.Content: If you find that you can't work, or your work is pressuring you to do things you can't manage, I would call the Macmillan helpline for assistance.  You are covered under the Disability Act when you have had cancer, so they can't force you to work, they must try to find work that you can do.  And if your hours are cut, you may be eligible for benefits or top up payments.  I'm no expert in this field, but the Advice team are. The number is 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm.
Posts.Title: RE: chronic back and hip pain after cancer treatments.

Posts.Content: Hi Margy I wouldn't have thought it's a problem, you could call the Macmillan helpline on 0808 808 0000 Monday to Friday, 9am-8pm for a chat with the nurses.   However, if you are taking Vitamin D, I recommend taking Vit K2 as well, as it helps the Vitamin D get into the bones and not in the arteries where you don't want it.
Posts.Title: cod liver oil/glucosamine for joint pain

Posts.Content: It doesn't surprise me.  But if you look into it, you will find that I'm right.  Most doctors know very little about how and why vitamins work in the body.
Posts.Title: cod liver oil/glucosamine for joint pain

Posts.Content: Hiya  I had exactly what you describe for all the reasons you give. I also had some family history although it later turned out that I didn't have the gene.  Focus on the effect on your mental health and the symmetry  they will ask that you see someone for a second opinion but don't go overboard  because they want you to be making a rational decision   Good luck, and whatever they decide, you must go through with the first operation for the sake of the kids   Let me know if I can help with anything.
Posts.Title: Want to have bilateral mastectomy with one breast elective.

Posts.Content: I had to go to another hospital to get a second opinion. I had some family history to consider and I definitely wanted symmetry. I also couldn't face going thrthro all the treatreat again, the constant wowor about finding a lump. However I didn't know then that cancer tends to recur elsewhere in the body.  GGoo luck with persuading your surgeon. I definitely went heavy on the psychological side of how it would affect me.
Posts.Title: Struggling to decide about reconstruction

Posts.Content: Because you have lymph involvement they may recommend chemo, but as you are ER+ you can ask for an oncotype DX test which will give the benefit to you.  HER- is good because herceptin can affect the heart, but you won't need it.
Posts.Title: Heart disease and cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Linda You are doing it right, but really you would be better off starting your own thread (new discussion button at the top of the page) so that people will reply directly. I've seen a few DIEP operations and they look great.  They can use the skin from the stomach so that they can avoid using your thin or damaged skin.  Good luck, try not to worry, it will all work out!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy with LD Recon - complete and back home

Posts.Content: Just one thing, what works for one, may not work for another.  All the generic ones have different fillers, so the main active ingredients are the same, however, sometimes these seem to affect the way that the body absorbs or reacts to the product.  If you get one and notice much worse side effects, take it back to your pharmacist and ask for something else.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice

Posts.Content: Sorry to say the new breast will be pretty numb.  They have to cut through the nerves and they don't really come back.   As to how you will be, assuming all goes well,you will be more or less the same, but it will take time.  You need to be patient with your body while you heal.  I had implant reconstruction and I was in pain and found sleeping hard for a good while, but in the end I gave myself a good kick up the bum and got on with life.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy & TUG flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Denise - I'm sure George will be along but meanwhile,  they inject dye into the tumour and follow its path to the nodes serving the tumour. If there are cancer cells then they remove them all
Posts.Title: Lymph Nodes - Question for Dreamthief

Posts.Content: CCS or Flexitol Heel Balm (needs 25% urea content), or Body Shop Hemp hand cream is fantastic.
Posts.Title: Hand Cream

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass  Whatever you do, don't let them fob you off with a pain clinic.  There are 100's of different pain reliefs and you must be able to find one.  I don't know what your pain is, although I was very uncomfortable with my reconstruction for several months.   I had tramadol, amytriptylene and gabapentin, all had their uses.  Stabbing pains are likely to be nerve endings regenerating, they are painful but usually short lived.  Gabapentin is a nerve painkiller, and you may find it helps. I think 8 months is plenty long enough. Hope you find some help.
Posts.Title: HELP......

Posts.Content: Call today if you want, just bear in mind that the employment experts may not be at hand immediately.
Posts.Title: changes in the workplace and having a hard time

Posts.Content: JackiRuss You are being amazing. But please don't put up with things.  There is a remedy for every side effect. You likely have thrush in your mouth, you can get Difflam from your doctor or there is a bicarbonate of soda mouthwash you can make at home (look at recipes on the internet).   No one gets a medal for being a martyr, get help!!
Posts.Title: First chemo was on 17th August

Posts.Content: Saved for future occasions!
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: moomy I'm not sure that Bedford Hospital have an oncocosmetic surgeon any more, the one I had definitely left.  He was very limited in his options anyway. I am the same as you with GAs, my first two were terrible, the third finally listened and gave me the good stuff. Be firm!
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Pfom Paula you don't have to lose your passport, you can just apply to update the photograph.
Posts.Title: Passport Photo

Posts.Content: Hi Lilian I'm sorry to hear you had such a bad reaction but at least you have a treatment now and specialists interested in helping and researching. Please do keep us informed, as all the information is useful to share if others have similar issues.
Posts.Title: Lymphangitis

Posts.Content: You are very lucky to be there.  Keeping Abreast run a meeting there monthly where you can talk to ladies who have had (in the main) surgery at that hospital!   Have a look at the Keeping Abreast website and see when the next meeting is, go along and meet the ladies and they will talk to you about what they had done and show you the results.  I'm sure someone will have had the TUG operation.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy & TUG flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: We're here to support you all, just post any questions you may have aan someone will have been there and done that  Glad to see you plucked uo courage to join us, moomy, it's always better to fight cancer in a group.
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: It's allowed, moomy, we all have to let it out sometimes, and that's precisely what Yoga is all about (I'm going this evening!). One thing to remember, although we are the biggest group here, we are also one with the best outcomes, so there are definitely worse places to be.  Try not to dwell on it, you will get through this, and we will all help.  I was diagnosed 6 and a half years ago, am fully in remission now.
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Well, whilst everyone should always put their affairs in order, there isn't that much pressure!   Hope your daughter has all her vitamins and minerals in order (and not just "in range", my most hated phrase!)!
Posts.Title: Found a lump. Sick with worry!

Posts.Content: Sillypen I wear both underwired and bandeau styles since I don't need support with the implants, as I had a double mastectomy.   You should be fine, but wear it around the house (under your clothes!) to make sure you are going to be comfortable.
Posts.Title: Underwired bras

Posts.Content: Links to Coping with fatigue and Late effects of breast cancer treatment here
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Poshquilter Sorry to hear you find yourself here but you will get lots of help and support.   Have a look at these threads - April Chemo Club and Tips for Chemo where you will find lots of hints and tips as well as fellow sufferers to commiserate with! There are lots of people here with mets also, still alive and kicking cancer's butt several years down the light, so good luck with your treatment, and hope all goes well with the wedding.
Posts.Title: Hello, I have just joined this group.

Posts.Content: Brillliant!  You have such a great sense of humour, and you definitely need that around here!
Posts.Title: I Wish I'd Felt Both Of Me Tits - (adapted from Pam Ayers)

Posts.Content: Hi Louise When I went to see my oncologist, she said that I wouldn't need RT OR Chemo, and that the risk associated with chemo was higher than the benefit from it in my case.  They should have given you the percentages to allow you to make an informed choice.  The younger you are, the more they throw at you to give you the best chance, I've noticed.  Some people say if you're offered it take it, just to make sure you've done everything possible.  Personally, I think it's a horrendous trial to go through and if you don't need to, why put yourself through it?  But that's just my point of view.  You need more information, I think.  Good luck with whatever you decide. Helen
Posts.Title: Confused.......

Posts.Content: Hi Townfan Your wife is lucky to have such a caring husband - well done for finding this site and asking the questions that you have asked!   I agree with what Cassie has said, but would add that anytime you feel you want to give your wife a hug, just flipping go and do it!  She may not ask for it, but you can bet your life that she'll appreciate knowing that you're there - I expect you will get to the talking stage, and your wife may well have not absorbed the full shock of diagnosis yet.  For some it's immediate, for others it can take until after surgery/treatment/even finish of treatment, and we all deal with things differently.   My BC support group (Bosom Pals - countrywide, look for your local one?) has a men's group so that people in your situation as well as men who develop BC can just talk about how they deal with it. There is no handbook really, although Macmillan do a booklet for partners which you may find very helpful. Good luck to you and your wife. Helen
Posts.Title: Hi

Posts.Content: Hi Flomay - sorry you find yourself here but you will get lots of good advice.  I know it's easy to say but try not to worry yourself sick.  And don't google.  You don't know what you are dealing with yet, and there's a lot of out of date stuff out there, so stick to here and breastcancercare.org.  Secondly, keep busy.  The worst part of this is the waiting for results, and at your stage it's even worse because you have no information.  You will break down in tears and feel your own mortality - we all do.  But most of us come through the other side without any long term effects.   Good luck, and fingers crossed!
Posts.Title: New to this,,,advice needed please.

Posts.Content: Do you mean lymphoma, seroma or lymphodema?  All different things, easily confused!
Posts.Title: Still Bleeding .....

Posts.Content: Maria W I don't know why you would take that route when you are only 55 and have the option to get the belt and braces treatment as suggested by your oncologist who has had lots of experience of women with breast cancer and other cancers.   Diet is only one small area, they don't really know what causes cancer, they just know what increases risk.  I hope you have made the right decision.  Did you know that secondaries generally commonly come back in the bones, lungs, brain or skin and not in the breasts?
Posts.Title: Anyone refused radiotherapy

Posts.Content: If it's a result of the hair not growing back you could try pseudophedrine to dry up the drips! Your doctor can prescribe it for you.  It's the active ingredient in sudafed
Posts.Title: Runny nose

Posts.Content: *waves* Hi Heather, hope you are doing OK!
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Hiya Heather, Yet even more waves  :) Lovely to 'see' you again - Wish you well  <3 Thanks for posting those links Helen,  there is another title in that set :) Breast Radiotherapy - Possible Long Term Side Effects G n' J   Ah well, I tried, it's not easy on my phone!
Posts.Title: R1 and R2 treatments for skin damage caused by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: You can have implants AFTER radiotherapy, or you can have them before but they MAY harden after RT.   Don't rush into anything until you have researched all the options.  You may wish to visit the Keeping Abreas t Website which has lots of information on the different options.  If you get the change to go to one of the meetings it is well worthwhile, even if it is a bit of a journey. The ladies will all share their experiences and show their reconstructions to you so that you can see and hear what really happens.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy & TUG flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Denise  I have days like this, sometimes.  It's perfectly normal to feel like you're living on the edge when you hear about other people who don't make it, but we have to make the most of now, because none of us know what is around the corner.  This applies to everyone, whether they have had a diagnosis or not, but we have had a wake up call so I believe we are lucky that we got the chance to make most of our time  Enjoy your family today.
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy  I'm sorry to hear that your employers have treated you so badly.  You are covered under the disability act having had cancer.  I think the best thing is to call the helpline here on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday 9am to 8pm and speak to the experts there about work and your rights.   Good luck
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: I'm not sure but it could be cording if you have been doing a lot. It can come on at a later date.  Otherwise you could be right about the lymphodoema.  I don't have experience of it so I can't say.
Posts.Title: pain running down inside of arm

Posts.Content: Hi adassarose  I don't know, it could be a number of things from holding yourself awkwardly, to indigestion (yes really!), to full blown who knows what.  The only way to know is to mention it to your surgeon or GP and ask them perhaps if they can do a scan or x-ray.
Posts.Title: Post-Op back pain

Posts.Content: ladyinred - I would think you are perfectly within your rights to ask for an MRI given your history.  Whether you will get one, I don't know, you may have to pay for it. Might be worth it for peace of mind.
Posts.Title: One Year On !!

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz There are many things it could be.  I would say rather than guess, wait until you see your surgeon and try not to google or worry about Try to have a nice weekend and enjoy time with friends and family, take your mind off it, and hopefully you will get reassurance on Monday. If you can't wait, call the Macmillan helpline tomorrow on 0808 808 0000 open from 9am to 8pm, Monday to Friday.
Posts.Title: Hard lumpy area in reconstructed breast

Posts.Content: I would say from the date of surgery as that is the most tangibly date. If you took it from diagnosis then the start of treatment varies, and if you take it from end of chemo then we all know that effects continue long after.
Posts.Title: 5 years all clear

Posts.Content: Plus one for Meetup groups. Something for everyone, and if there isn't, you can do your own event. I went looking for new friends as I don't know many where we now live.  As to partners, I think the days of just hoping to bump into "the one"  are gone, but there's Tinder, Badoo, etc. They are free to use, so give them a go!
Posts.Title: Happiness vs Meaningfulness - an interesting article

Posts.Content: BCNs aren't Macmillan.  They CAN be, but they aren't always.  Ours are paid and supplied by our local NHS trust.  One of mine used to be a Macmillan Nurse and said that it was very strict about what she could do, everything had to be around Macmillan.  I have no personal experience of Macmillan, so I can't say, this is just something she said. Also,  in relation to what others have said, my BCN said to me on the first day that it would take a year of my life.  That terrified me, and still does if I think about it.  She wasn't entirely wrong, although treatment was mostly over in 6 months, the psychological stuff went  on longer, but it wasn't necessary to say at that moment (or any moment).   Living day to day with the treatments was hard enough.
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: SpicedTea - Nicky, please don't worry about the surgery, you've honestly done the hard part! You will worry and waste time worrying and there really isn't a need, you will get through this much easier than the chemo!
Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Grapefruit is an interesting one.  IIt's not because of germs but because it can iinterfere with the action of many medications AAnd they often forget to mention it.  My husband takes prozac and he felt very odd one day  He read the leaflet in the box and guess what? Yep he'd drunk grapefruit juice!
Posts.Title: Yogurt

Posts.Content: Angie If you haven't already contacted your BCN, RT unit or GP, please do so first thing tomorrow.  You need to be careful that you put the right product on there and it may be that you need something on prescription.  But you need to be careful to avoid infection in the area as well. In the meantime, some cooling packs wrapped in clean tea towels in the area to cool down the burning might help.
Posts.Title: After radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Purplerules I'm sorry you are having to go through this again. I think something may have got lost in translation with the woman you know with breast cancer and a brain tumour.  Breast cancer can metastasise in the brain, but it's unlikely that radiation was the cause.  I had a lump in my neck a few years after breast cancer.  I had an ultrasound and a biopsy, but it was just an enlarged node due to having had a cold not long before.  This is what they are designed to do, so probably why you were told it was 90% unlikely to be cancer.  TNBC can be sneaky though, and it's possible you are facing a recurrence.  It's also possible that you have some odd cells but they are not cancerous.  Fingers crossed.  Try not to dwell on it until you have results, keep busy.  You won't change the outcome and you will stress yourself silly.  And stress is not good for us.  If necessary, get something from your GP to calm you down for the duration. Good luck, and do let us know the outcome.
Posts.Title: Suspicious cells

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear this, Jeanie. Just when you thought you were at the finishing line it got moved. Still hopefully you are now out the other side.  Eat healthily and get some fresh air and I'm sure you'll be ready for your operation.
Posts.Title: Going out with a bang

Posts.Content: Don't push yourself too hard, you've had a major operation!  Walk to the end of your road and back to start with, or invite someone around for tea (tell them to make it and bring cake!), one step at a time.
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: Hi Sally I'm concerned that your thyroid isn't being treated/monitored properly.  If you have untreated hypothyroidism for a length of time it can lead to all sorts of problems, including organ failure.  Also, TSH can vary during the day, the time you have the test done can make big differences to the results.  Also, TSH only as a guide is a very unreliable method of checking.  Ask for your T4 and T3 to be monitored also.  T3 is often not checked even when requested when TSH and T4 are within "normal" levels.   The very nature of your posts makes me think that your brain is confused and this is another side effect of hypothyroidism.  The tablets don't really have side effects, only the level of your hormones will affect how you feel, unless you are actually allergic to the fillers.  I'm thinking that you felt crap because your levels were wrong.   If you want more information, visit thyroiduk.org.com.  Lots of info there, although it takes some getting through.
Posts.Title: New Cancer patient

Posts.Content: Crazycatlady26 sorry to hear that you have received a definite breast cancer diagnosis but as you probably will have read it's not the end of the world and if you are truly concerned about losing your hair which we fully understand then have you asked about the cold cap. If you put cold cap into the search bar at the top of this page you will find lots of people's experiences. Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Waiting biopsy results!

Posts.Content: You are most certainly not wasting anyone's time. That is what they are paid for. Frankly I am appalled that you were not scanned before. These people don't have x-ray vision, so how can they be sure.  Insist on a mammogram or ultrasound and do not be fobbed off. If you do get a diagnosis, please make a complaint about your initial appointment.  Let us know how you get on. We are here to help and we are all hoping it's nothing serious.
Posts.Title: Should I get a second opinion??

Posts.Content: Hi Maureen  I assume you are on levothyroxine which can cause lots of these types of symptoms. Especially if your GP goes on TSH and you are just "within range" which may mean you are undermedicated. Have that checked, as you need to be below 1.  You may want to do some research on this.  I don't know about ESRs but hopefully @Dreamthief will drop by with information.
Posts.Title: Mets

Posts.Content: Well whatever it is, you need to get it checked for your own peace of mind.  I'm sure you had a mammogram on both breasts, but it doesn't always pick everything up.   Call your breast care nurse or surgeon and make an appointment to go in and have it checked.  The thing is, if they find something you can have both breasts dealt with at the same time.
Posts.Title: Bloody cancer!

Posts.Content: Pretty sure it has happened to all of us.  Cancer is one of the last taboos so no one talks about it.  Anyone who has a close personal experience is either going to think their outcome will be the same as their relative or friend. Whereas the reality is that 85% of us make it through and are around at least 5 years later.  For me I have made the decision to make the most of the now and let the future go look after itself.
Posts.Title: Thought i was going to die

Posts.Content: Mandy - Mx is the abbreviation for Mastectomy.  My other breast was clear but I wanted a matched pair and also was worried about recurrence/new tumour in the other side due to family history.  If you aren't sure about reconstruction at this point, you can ask for a skin sparing mastectomy so that they can use your own skin to create the new breast. Also, I don't know where you are in the country, but check out keepingabreast.org which gives lots of information.  There may be a group near you - check out the list, but if not, call the national office and ask because it may be that one is about to be set up near you.  Ladies can show you the results of their reconstruction in real life.
Posts.Title: Round block mammoplasty

Posts.Content: WORRIED2016  If I had a £1 for everyone who comes on here and says they are the one who runs things, who helps others, who doesn't normally need help, I'd have £1,000s of £s.   Women do run things, as you know, because men are pretty useless at the small stuff, and we are great at multi-tasking.  You're probably in your bath, washing your hair, crying, thinking about what is for dinner tomorrow, if someone has the right kit for school tomorrow, how you can get the school pick up done, etc etc.  See?   We live on our own crazy roundabout but now is the time to step off it, let others help you, and once you are ready, make very tentative steps back but don't end up back in the situation you are in now.   Oh and contact your kids' father and make him look after them for a week or two while you are having your surgery.  It's only fair on you and the kids.
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Rome you should go to your company's occupational health or hr department, but yes,  most people visit their GP or oncologist and get a phased return.   You are covered under the disability act, so don't be bullied.
Posts.Title: Return to work - advice please

Posts.Content: What you are feeling is perfectly normal, but you learn to cope after treatment has finished.  For now, concentrate on treatment, and getting well.  Just wanted to pop in to say this before I go to work.
Posts.Title: Hello, I have just joined this group.

Posts.Content: Looks well written.  Hopefully the compassion she thought she showed before will be real now.
Posts.Title: Breast Surgeon With Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: FoxySash Thank you very much for your reply, think I'll wait and see how I feel. I've had offers of help taking me there but I'm an independent sort of person, but there again I wouldn't want to cause an accident. I know a man who had treatment for 8 weeks and drove there himself but I expect it affects people differently.  And I know someone who crashed her car because she fell asleep at the wheel during rads!
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: FoxySash you can drive but do be very careful that you don't get too tired. Radiotherapy can have a cumulative effect so if you can get hospital transport for  the later weeks it might be a plan.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: I think it depends on the severity of the cords whether they go on their own or not.  I had  bad ones and my BCN gave me the name of a specialist physio and told me to get my GP to refer me urgently.  I had several sessions and he popped several each time, and I haven't had any recurrence although once you have had them they can recur at any time.
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: I was like you, weeping and wailing all over the place, sure it would be like it for ever, worst mistake of my life, etc etc.  Once the scars start to soften and the muscle starts to relax it does get easier.  Get lots of pillows and make a nest to lay on with a gap for the boobs.  Hang in there
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: You don't say you are having chemo, and if you are hormone negative you won't be able to take tamoxifen, so you could ask to see the Predict tool to see if you really need to have all your nodes removed.  It will give the chance of recurrence as a % whether you have the nodes removed or not.   As to playing hockey, you will find that priorities change.  After all, if the predict tool says you have a 40% chance of recurrence if they are left or a 5% chance if removed, then it's an easy choice.  If it's a couple of per cent difference you might decide it's not worth it.  (Figures are random and plucked from the air!)  Being alive in 5 years, or not.  Easy choice?
Posts.Title: New Cancer patient

Posts.Content: Hi Little Miss Organised Although your expanders have more to go, I suspect that your surgeon will have started with a small amount of saline. I think mine put about 100ml in to start with. When you first have them, they are stretching the muscles that they are placed under and it does feel like you have two large flat pebbles strapped to your chest.  I remember it being so odd, you just can't think about anything else for ages.  But the good news is that once you get used to it it really does become like part of you.  It will take a while.  I actually really like the smoothness of mine (I didn't have nipple reconstruction, just tattoos) and my husband likes them better I think (although he wasn't much of a boob man, he is now, weirdly!).   It took me about 8 months to make friends with mine, one tip is don't let them fill you too quickly.  Better to go little and often.
Posts.Title: Falling to pieces

Posts.Content: I would avoid linseed as they contain natural oestrogen as to several other seeds (sorry I forget which!)
Posts.Title: New Cancer patient

Posts.Content: LondonLass sometimes being honest with ourselves is good for the soul.  Sometimes we just have to pretend. Whatever works for us at the time is perfectly OK. Good luck with your next appointment.
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hi Mandy I've just had normal double mastectomies and reconstruction using implants.  Both nipples were removed although one Mx was prophylactic, I was asked if I wanted to keep the nipple, but there is a 5% chance of recurrence in the nipple, so I had both removed and now have had them tattooed on.   HTH Helen
Posts.Title: Round block mammoplasty

Posts.Content: I thought about having a heart of a flower, perhaps a daisy, or a curled up lizard, but in the end, I took the conventional route.  I'm glad I did now.
Posts.Title: Re. nipple tattoos, can you help?

Posts.Content: Hi Scribblinglady I wouldn't think you'd have to wait long, the main thing is to be able to safely wear a seatbelt and to be able to stop quickly (emergency stop).   I would allow a couple of weeks, but you will know yourself if you are ready.  If in doubt, ask your surgeon.
Posts.Title: repair to lumpy scar

Posts.Content: Hi Pat  Make sure your chemo team know the issues you are having and they will sort you out with some omeprazole or similar. Don't suffer in silence!
Posts.Title: Chronic indigestion

Posts.Content: Sounds like you have been very sensible, adassarose.  Enjoy your week off and don't overdo it, remember you continue to "cook" for a few weeks after treatment finishes.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Jessica70louise  I'm so sorry that your mum has been ignored and fobbed off and obviously she was right to be concerned all the time.  Although the oncologist has suggested palliative care, there are actually a number of treatments that, whilst palliative, can give many years of life with cancer.  It may be that at this point your mum has lost faith in the team that is treating her, and she could ask for a second opinion at a different hospital to see what they recommend.   We do have a secondary breast cancer group which might be worth exploring on your mum's behalf.  Do look after yourself, I know ronstar has already signposted you to our friends and family group, which I heartily endorse.
Posts.Title: Life after breast cancer (posting for my mam)

Posts.Content: bevbumble My doctor will no longer prescribe Femara as its too expensive and I dont know which cheap brand to try,any suggestions?crazy when they have said they will prescibe more painkillers and anti-depressants to help with side effects,so the end cost will be the same, Bev Ask them for Sandoz by Novartis. It is the closest and made by the same company.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Letrozole & Joint Pain

Posts.Content: OCRKate Do you have an appointment coming up?  Since you have now finished rads, the chances are that you have continued to "Cook" but if you don't have an appointment in the next few weeks, give your BCN a call.
Posts.Title: Itchy Nipple - Normal or Something Bad?

Posts.Content: nikonblue anything's worth a go, but the pain you are having does sound a bit like sciatica, have you been checked for this? These tablets are the devil's own!
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Letrozole & Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Hi SuzyJane  I wanted to say thatI totally know how you are feeling.  I had implants but the tightness and the mis-shapenness is the same.  The good news is that it does soften and become more part of you. It is still very early days and you will have some residual anaesthetic in your system which can make you feel depressed so don't be too hard on yourself.  I must admit I have had lots of operations and I have never been asked to walk in, so I would definitely complain if only so that it doesn't happen to others.   It will improve, I promise.  Keep doing the exercises, they are painful and uncomfortable but they are important.
Posts.Title: Anyone had bilateral masectomy with immediate LD flap reconstruction...

Posts.Title: Ladies living in the Weymouth area

Posts.Title: Itchy Nipple - Normal or Something Bad?

Posts.Content: WORRIED2016  If I had a £1 for everyone who comes on here and says they are the one who runs things, who helps others, who doesn't normally need help, I'd have £1,000s of £s.   Women do run things, as you know, because men are pretty useless at the small stuff, and we are great at multi-tasking.  You're probably in your bath, washing your hair, crying, thinking about what is for dinner tomorrow, if someone has the right kit for school tomorrow, how you can get the school pick up done, etc etc.  See?   We live on our own crazy roundabout but now is the time to step off it, let others help you, and once you are ready, make very tentative steps back but don't end up back in the situation you are in now.   Oh and contact your kids' father and make him look after them for a week or two while you are having your surgery.  It's only fair on you and the kids.
Posts.Title: Have I missed anything?

Posts.Content: Hi, Samggo and welcome to the site. You will find lots of helpful advice here. Firstly, about your mum. It's a hard decision to make but I don't know if your mum has been informed that if she had a mastectomy, she could have a reconstruction. She should have a look either at the macmillan booklet here, or at keepingabreast.org which explains the options. At the end of the day, whether it comes back is something of a lottery but the oncologist would be able to give her the statistics either way if that would help. So it's worth asking the question. Secondly, there is a group here for carers. You may find some support here for you as you are holding the family together. And if there is a support group at your local hospital, do encourage your mum to go along. With the best will in the world, cancer is something that you can only understand if you have been there. And talking to people who get it can be very helpful. .
Posts.Title: My mum is unsure what op to have

Posts.Content: You are most certainly not wasting anyone's time. That is what they are paid for. Frankly I am appalled that you were not scanned before. These people don't have x-ray vision, so how can they be sure.  Insist on a mammogram or ultrasound and do not be fobbed off. If you do get a diagnosis, please make a complaint about your initial appointment.  Let us know how you get on. We are here to help and we are all hoping it's nothing serious.
Posts.Title: Should I get a second opinion??

Posts.Content: There's never a good time to here you have cancer. We've all been there and it's horrendous.  I had to go back for a second incision and it was a shock.  I would go back about the tiredness and depression though,  because it's not really a symptom of cancer. Older people's metabolism can develop hypothyroidism and it is worth asking your doctor for a blood test to rule out this and other basic functions.  i wouldn't just take antidepressants unless you really feel depressed. It can be a symptom of hypothyroidism though.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy - week 3 of 3

Posts.Content: Judy, you have had chemo and surgery, so the cancer has been removed.  The radiotherapy is belt and braces, so really the delay won't make much of a difference.   The tiredness could take up to a year to return to normal (the "new" normal!"), but hopefully you will continue to improve over the next six months.  Good luck with your radiotherapy and your next op.
Posts.Title: Delay in radiotherapy

Posts.Content: It's only radiotherapy you can't have twice on the same area.  Chemo is a movable feast. Several types, but don't think they won't treat you aggressively now, they will throw it all at you.  I think you need to stop looking for excuses and start making practical arrangements.
Posts.Title: Chemo - long term implications for treatment

Posts.Title: Yeeeaaaah - Yippeee Christmas Came Early!

Posts.Content: Hi Gill  I believe it's about 6 weeks after the nipple reconstruction but it needs to have completely healed first,  so it's a little individual.  I just had a piece of swab over it in my bra and was given a salve to rub on but I didn't have it done on the NHS.  Be aware that the NHS ones use biodegradable ink, which fades fairly quickly.  Do ask the question.   As with anything that pierces the skin,  infection is always a possibility,  but it is rare.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Re. nipple tattoos, can you help?

Posts.Content: Kat40 - one of the side effects of Tamoxifen is deteriorating eyesight.   I would have an eye test but also call your oncologist.  Mine said "most" people's sight improves once they stop taking it (although she didn't say how long after), but as my mother already has eye problems, I was reluctant to get much worse, and stopped it.  Your oncologist might change you to another drug.
Posts.Title: Tired eyes

Posts.Content: Do you know what the hospital have given you in terms of B vitamins? You probably need a very high dose of B12 and a very good quality B complex as they all work together.  Also it is best absorbed sublingually (dissolving under the tongue) or by injection. See if they will give you a fee loafing injections.  Have a look on the packet and let me know.
Posts.Title: Peripheral neuropathy

Posts.Content: Hi Trudi What SS1 says is very true.  Hell, I remember before I had cancer I would avoid talking about it or to anyone with it.  But if you want to talk about it, and have it recognised, then you should ask your husband to include you in the conversations, and not to ignore the fact that you are there.  Although it would be lovely to think he would be sensitive enough to know that you need this without asking or telling him, I think we all know that most men need a damn good prod before they realise anything!   I think Cancer makes us all re-evaluate how we look at our lives and relationships and things we would have put up with in the past, we're no longer able to let go and we feel we need to stamp our feet and be recognised.  It could be time for a long hard look at life, and what you want from it. I don't know if anyone is local to Felixstowe here, but in the meantime, feel free to come here and moan!  As to the peripheral neuropathy, hopefully as time goes on it will improve and you will get  back to normal.  Do let the GP and/or oncologists know what you are suffering as there are often things  that might help and certainly if they don't know then they can't help.  As soon as you are well enough, get on that bus and get yourself down to the support group - they really can help.  And if you are able to ask someone to drive you, all the better.  In fact, if you contact them, you may find someone lives just around the corner and can pick you up.   Hope you are feeling a bit better for getting it off your chest! Helen x

Posts.Title: Feeling upbeat today

Posts.Content: Hi, Vickster and welcome to the forum.  I would say be honest withOccupational health and don't try to do too much too soon.  Tell them exactly how you feel, because it isn't just about physical health, but mental and emotional health too. How would it be if it just overcame you during class and you had to be comforted by students? It would affect them and you.   As to how long, unfortunately everyone is different.  Rads continue to cook you for several weeks after and your skin could yet break down.  The tiredness is not to beunderestimated either.  I would say that you definitely wouldn't want to be going back this side of half term,  then see how you are, perhaps do part time until Xmas but let your body dictate. You are not a malingerer!

Posts.Title: Anastrozole/Letrozole & Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Hi Denise I would ask to see a different doctor at your practice.  Obviously for you there is sufficient difference for it to affect you, since you were able to notice a marked improvement within a short space of time. Yes, it may be more expensive, but you are entitled to a quality of life, and if you already have arthritis, it is bound to make it a lot worse.  You will end up costing the country a lot more if you become disabled and claiming benefit, not being able to work, etc etc.  I would explain that if you need to, but don't be afraid to be tearful in the surgery.  I said to someone earlier, be you on a bad day.  Perhaps take the prescription and go in on a really bad day and show them exactly how you feel.  If they had to feel like that, they'd get something prescribed.   Just a quick google, you can get them for £203.57 for two months supply, so if you need to, there are options.  Be careful where you get them though.  And I'm not saying that's the cheapest, just the first one I found. Hope this helps you feel better.  But don't put up with crap drugs.
Posts.Title: GP will not give me Arimidex on Nhs

Posts.Content: OMG TracyTD, I can't believe that your BCN was so awful. I would put in a complaint, that's plain offensive.   Honestly, you cannot get back what you had, you know that.  Those of us who have had reconstructions of various types are not the same as before, whether we have implants, LD flap or DIEP/TUG/whatever reconstructions.  Mine are OK, but they have no feeling. Yes they are all right in clothes, my husband likes them, so that's good, but they can sometimes be painful, or uncomfortable. I hardly ever wear a bra, because I don't need to, but also because I find them painful if I wear them for any length of time. Be very careful if you go down the private route, because you need a plastic surgeon who is a member of BAPRAS, don't be tempted by someone because they are cheap,  Before going down this route, though, do ask your GP to refer you for some counselling. Because whatever your breast look like, unless you are happy with you, you will never be satisfied.

Posts.Title: returning to work and it isn't the same

Posts.Content: My understanding is that if you have a mastectomy, rads aren't necessary because there is no breast tissue to irradiate. Unless the cancer is extremely close to the chest wall.  There are statistics for radiotherapy, and for some people it is purely a belt and braces approach. Surgery will have removed the cancer and the precancerous cells, so it would be zapping healthy tissue or tissue removed from elsewhere.  If you go for a staged reconstruction you would have twice the risk of infection and if your skin is irradiated, it may not be suitable for reconstruction due to a change in structure.  These are all things you should discuss with your surgeon.  I'm sorry if I have thrown even more confusion into the mix, but it is as well to be informed!

Posts.Title: Scared about my mums chemo!

Posts.Content: Hi Matthew Just to add to the great responses your wife has already had.   If your wife is on any kind of hormone therapy, that can lead to joint pain.  Also, as she has had chemotherapy, if you don't get any reassurance from the oncologist or surgeon, then get your wife's GP to run a full set of blood tests, including a full blood count, thyroid panel and Vitamin D levels.  All these can be knocked out by thyroid and lead to these problems.
Posts.Title: Back Pain Post Radio?

Posts.Content: Hi Purplegoose I don't really have any answers for you, just wanted to reply to your post, but suggest you give the nurses on this site a call in the morning.  Your mum is lucky to have you to support her, but you have already found that googling is a bad idea.  Bear in mind that most things are well out of date, so stick to this site for good information. It may be that they have seen something that the CT scan will define, and they're not ruling anything in or out at this stage.    Also, bear in mind that even with secondaries, treatments are coming on all the time, and people are still continuing to live a long time with all kinds of cancers.  Do come on and let us know how your mum gets on.  Helen xx

Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Title: Farewell to Chemo!

Posts.Content: Chance, even if it is something that needs treatment, the chances are that your holiday won't be affected.  It takes time to diagnose and then organise treatment, and unless you have a very fast aggressive cancer, a couple of weeks away won't make much difference.   If you do get away, don't spend the time worrying about what will happen when you get back - when I was diagnosed in early August, we were due to go away at the end of August for two weeks with our daughter.  I asked that any treatment could be arranged for after the holiday, and the MDT said yes, it wouldn't affect things, so I went.  I was fine during the day, but every night my poor husband listened to my weeping and wailing over the what ifs.  It didn't help, it didn't make it go away, and it just upset him as well.  I should have put it out of my mind and decided to deal with it when I got home.

Posts.Title: Info please HELP

Posts.Content: Gail - I think you may be confused - they don't usually use implants with a DIEP flap?  That's a free flap using stomach fat and tissue (not muscle).  The one that usually has an implant is the LD flap using muscle from the back, because these muscles aren't usually big enough by themselves to give enough volume.  The implants in these instances are very small and (I believe) sit under the muscle so you would barely be aware of them.   Good luck with your surgery. Helen

Posts.Content: Binny - please call your BCN or oncologist tomorrow morning.   I know the nurses here would tell you in general terms, but I think you need to call your team and find out specifically what it is that they expect to find and why you need these tests.   It's unfair to leave you in suspense like this, they can't possibly know how awful it is.  It's all very well for them to keep their ideas to themselves until they have results, but you need to know where you stand.  I'm sure that if they were in the same postion as you they would understand much better.
Posts.Title: Need more help girls....

Posts.Content: Kimberley  - I honestly don't know what to say.  I do think you are doing the right thing, and also please don't have any guilt over this - your daughter's choices are her own and the only thing I would say is please please do not give them more money.  My sister's first husband was similar in that he spent more money than they had and my parents helped them out time and again.  In the end, they realised that they would never get their money back so they decided to give us a similar amount so things were fair, which was obviously good for us, but the good thing is that things were out in the open and finally she left him.  I know parents feel that they should help financially, but actually I think they should help by making people face their own finances and giving money only alleviates the situation in the short term. You could tell her that you need the space to get away from the stress as stress is one of the things that can trigger cancer, and you can use that as a reason/excuse if she refuses to understand anything different.   At the end of the day, you and your husband need to stick together for each other.  Keep lines of communication open with your daughter, but discourage visits from the husband.  I'm sure the lovely Dorothee will be along with sage words of advice soon.  In the meantime, have a glass of mulled wine and a mince pie, and enjoy your Christmas.  If your traditions always involve your children/grandchildren, make a new tradition.

Posts.Title: A good cry

Posts.Content: Dear Skye First of all, a massive hug from me.   Second of all, as everyone has said, it's not you that has the problem, it's them.  Well, they are your problem.  I know that.  But yes, you can choose your friends but you can't choose your family, as my parents said to me often as we were growing up.  (We now don't see each other much, can you tell?) I hope you have some good friends who will help you out.  But in the meantime, when you speak to your family, say to them "Yes, I'll put my daughter in foster care, because my family obviously don't care enough to look after their own, she'll probably be better off".   Honestly, I would be ashamed if my own sister had to do that rather than me help her, and I'm surprised that your family aren't.  Your mother sounds like a selfish person (sorry, had to be said), thinking about herself all the time.  Yes, she's 70, but that doesn't excuse poor behaviour.  If she's not well enough to look after your daughter, then say so. Don't make excuses. As to the party, well, everyone will ask why you're not there and they will have to say "because you're too ill" and it will look bad on them that they went ahead with it anyway.  I do wonder if your mum is feeling a kind of guilt and therefore pushing it back on you.  Your sister has no such excuse though. Anyway hopefully you can sort it all out.  If you really can't, call the Macmillan helpline (open 9am to 8pm Monday to Friday, 0808 808 0000) and ask to speak to someone about arranging help during chemo. Good luck, and know that we are all with you.  (If I was close to you I'd help).

I guess he is used to doing as he pleases without the need to consider others, but guess what, that's got to change now   That said, if he's always been like this, he's unlikely to change overnight. Be your own advocate here  if you feel like you need help, call your chemo unit or 111 and they will send an ambulance if they think it's needed. Posts.Content: Hi SuzyJane It may not be what you want, but I can totally understand that after 2 and a half years your husband might need a release, and frankly watching porn might not be your choice, but it could have been a lot worse.   That said, I agree with Julia, I think your marriage needs some work, and you could both usefully use some counselling.  It may be that your local church offers something, or relate, or your GP might be able to recommend somewhere.  But it's fairly clear that you can't go on the way that you have been.  Lack of communication is one of the biggest causes of marriage breakdown, and there seems to be a big barrier here.  Don't take it personally, as Julia so wisely says, it takes two - sometimes you need a bit of a push to get you where you need to go. If you feel that your husband would benefit from talking to another husband who's been there, my husband has volunteered to speak to other men in the past, just send a friend request and a PM.

Posts.Content: Being brave isn't something you choose to do.  Facing the disease and the treatment is not a choice.  Next time someone says your hair will grow back ask them if they would shave theirs while you are undergoing treatment.  Bet they shut up then! Posts.Title: New to all this

Posts.Content: Dear tammj  Firstly, welcome to the group.  I know that this is a very worrying time, but please try not to google or you will really go out of your mind.  You will get lots of help and support here, because we've all been where you are now, and we know how terrifying it can be. I know it seems like an eternity, and it is pointless me telling you not to worry, but hopefully we can reassure you a bit.  NICE guidelines say that you must commence treatment with 31 days.  Most people are inside this, but it might be close.  They are only guidelines, however, but be reassured that cancer cells do not generally rage out of control and go rampaging through the body in a few weeks.  I was very lucky to be screened and diagnosed in a one stop shop, even though it took an age on the day.  When people have to wait, it should mean that you get all the results at once.  If you are HER+, these results take a while longer so it would be understandable. Now, you haven't got a diagnosis yet, but let's assume you do get a cancer diagnosis.  90% of all patients survive for 5 years.  That's how long the statistics go for.  Of the other 10% there is usually a secondary reason, such as elderly, or in ill health, or possibly a very late diagnosis.  Treatment isn't a walk in the park, but it is doable.  So please don't start planning your funeral just yet, chances are that you will have plenty of time for that much much further down the line!  My aunt was screened early and had breast cancer at age 49, she's still with us at age 75.  I draw comfort from that.  Also if you need a mastectomy, reconstructions are amazing and there is no need to worry about how you might look.  Do ask any questions you might have, as there is no such thing as a sill question.

Posts.Title: ER+

Posts.Content: Anyone who says your sister should be your best friend is obviously very lucky with theirs.  My sister suddenly convinced herself that she was going to get cancer and it was all about her!  Frankly, these negative people are better left to get on with their own lives, and god forbid they should get this awful disease, but I do believe in karma. Radiotherapy is very wearing, just the to-ing and fro-ing is bad enough, but after all the other sh*t we have to deal with, it's probably the last straw.  Your oncologist should be able to give you statistics for your type of cancer if you really want to know.  Bear in mind, though, that these statistics are already 5 years out of date by their very nature, so it really is a worst case scenario, as treatments are improving all the time.  (If you can't go back to the oncologist, you can do it yourself using the Predict tool - google it - but bear in mind that you won't probably have quite an accurate result as your onco.) It never quite goes away, and the people who expect you to the be same as before are the ones with the problem, not you.  I've decided that I will do what I can when I can and not beat myself up when I can't.  Cancer is one of those illnesses, like depression, where you can't "see" the problem, and if someone looks "normal" then they are presumed well. We all know differently, so come here and have a whinge anytime!  (Feeling like whinging myself right now!) Helen

Posts.Title: Prescriptions

Posts.Content: badgerbam the nodes act like little sieves to pick up the stray cells.  Like any sieve they don't always get every tiny bit, but in general they do.  I would assume that if they recommend chemo that it will kill off any stray cells if they are not planning to do a total node clearance.  That is good, because a total clearance can cause lymphodema, and if that happens it can cause lots of other long term problems.   On the plus side, your mum has had the most effective treatment, surgery.  I would totally assume that your mum is having a rough time at the moment but that she will get through it and in a year's time you will be looking back and celebrating with her.  Breast cancer treatment is very effective and 90% of all patients are still alive and kicking 5 years on.

Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Hair Loss

Posts.Content: It depends what chemo you are having, but usually people have FEC-T, and it comprises three or four sessions of FEC and three or four of T.  It's usually the FEC that makes you lose your hair, and it starts around day 13, so after the first session. Once it starts to come out, the pain often makes people want to shave their heads to relieve it.   Have you thought about trying the cold cap, if you are concerned about hair loss? You can put cold cap into the search bar at the top of the thread and see lots of threads about it.
Posts.Title: How many cycles of chemo before total hair loss?

Posts.Content: Optimistic  Try not to fixate on the details too much.  The ER goes from 0--8.  So you are in the top quarter with a 6.  That is good because the higher the score, the more effective the treatment.  What works for one may not work so well for another, there is no one size fits all treatment, and there are no hard and fast answers.  What I do know for certain is that stress is not good for you.  And when you are spending the time after you have been given the most suitable treatment for you worrying about the future, you are not living your life to the fullest.  You have been given a second chance, so don't waste it. Do try some mindfulness, you can download apps to your phone and they will talk you through how to do it. It's very empowering.

Posts.Title: how many people have had sisters who have also had BC

Posts.Content: Hi Denise Unfortunately a quick google has come up with this (the last line is the most important) Prepared from the dried leaves of the rooibos plant native to South Africa, rooibos tea has grown popular in western countries because it is rich in antioxidants, especially the polyphenols aspalathin and nothofagin (1), and low in caffeine. It does not contain any catechins, the major flavonoids present in green and black teas (2). In vitro and animal studies have shown that rooibos can modulate immune function (3) (4), exhibit anti-inflammatory effects (5), may prevent oxidative stress and play a role in alleviating symptoms associated with type-2 diabetes (7). Animal studies also suggest that it may prevent chromosomal aberrations (8) and tumor mutagenesis (9) (10). Topically applied rooibos elicits a protective effect against microsomal lipid peroxidation and may help reduce chemical-induced tumor formation (1) (11). Rooibos also appears to protect against damage caused by radiation (12). However, these effects have not been confirmed in humans. Rooibos was shown to inhibit angiotensin-converting enzyme in healthy volunteers (2), which may benefit cardiovascular health. Further research is needed. Because compounds isolated from rooibos leaves demonstrated estrogenic activity (22), patients with hormone-sensitive cancers should use caution before taking rooibos. However it does say that it leads to tumour reduction in mice although not tested in humans.  I would suggest that you limit your intake to a couple of cups a day for now and speak to your oncologist.

Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Lynn - you've already had some good advice.  I would listen to it, and don't rush into doing anything. To be honest, your implant is the least of your problems right now - let them fill it a little, and see how little faff it is.  Having it out will mean another GA at a time when other things need priority.   Secondly, you need real hard information.  You may find that a good hard dose of chemo will blast whatever it is into oblivion - these things can and DO happen, and I truly hope that they do for you.   In the meantime, enjoy the fact that you feel well in yourself, go out and enjoy things.  Try to keep from dwelling on it, easier said than done, I know.  And you WILL get through it. Massive hugs from me  Helen xxxxx

Posts.Title: anastrozole versus tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Just to let you know my story - I was diagnosed with Grade 1 DCIS with some lobular involvement which following WLE and further excision resulted in mastectomy.  I opted to have a double mastectomy, as I wanted immediate reconstruction, and have seen some horrendous asymmetric pictures, but my main reason was for my peace of mind.  I was 47 and my children are grown, I'm not sure whether I would have made the same decision had I not had them, but for me it was a no brainer.   Reconstruction isn't for everyone, and depending what you have, it can be hard to adjust to.  So give yourself the time to research and be happy with your decision.  I've never regretted the decision to have them both removed, only the option that I took for reconstruction.

Posts.Content: Hi Heather If you are uncomfortable, I'd go back to the BCN or physio and explain exactly how it feels.  I am sure there must be something more that can be done.   Do as much exercise as you can and try to go just beyond what is comfortable.  Exercises are very important to maintain mobility.
Posts.Title: Post surgery issues

Posts.Content: Considering how many hundreds of these operations there are each year, you'd think people would have heard of them, but unless you are in your position, Jane, the chances are slim! Have a look at keepingabreast.org for lots of information on this and if you live near one of the support groups you can meet and talk to ladies who have been through it.  I know that Jacky2108 has just had it done and it looks great!   If you are lucky enough to be offered this option, do give it due consideration - it's a great outcome and the gold standard in reconstruction.  However, there are downsides - the length of the operation, the length of recovery are all long and it will take you a while to get back to normal.  BUT it's worth it in the end!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: DIEP reconstruction

Posts.Content: Claire I cannot stress this enough.  You have had a MAJOR operation.  You need to give your body time to heal.  Make the most of getting others to run around after you. Do the things you've been putting off because you didn't have time - watch that movie/box set, chat with friends but DO NOT overdo it.   You need to give that scar time to heal.  Once you are undergoing treatment, your first port of call is probably the hospital - BCN or surgeon - unless it's something very straightforward.  You can go there any time, call them, or go to A&E if urgent.  The GP surgery isn't specialised and this is what you need at this time.   Hopefully a few days rest (by which I mean a week or so!) will help that wound to heal.
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: @october17, I just wanted to add my gran was diagnosed with leukaemia aged 88. Her doctor decided not to tell her and to give no treatment as she also had the beginnings of dementia. She died aged 95 from dementia related illness. Here's hoping your gran enjoys life as long as she can.
Posts.Title: Triple negative breast cancer in elderly

Posts.Content: Clarkie22 There are no prizes for bravery! What you are feeling is, unfortunately, very normal.  The good news is that things do settle down and soften and relax after a few months.  It's still very early days, you have had a major operation! The dip at the top of the implant may need to be filled with some lipofilling (taking fat from somewhere in your body and injecting it elsewhere).  But it's not the end of the world.  However, I am concerned that the new breast is already  bigger than the other one, it may settle, or may not, or you just might have too big an implant.  As to arm movement, please do keep up with the exercise, but that elastic band in your armpit could be axillary web syndrome (AWS) or cording.  Make an appointment with your BCN to get this checked.  If it is, ask for the name of a competent experienced physio and get your GP to do an urgent referral.  Some people do find that massage helps, but the physio "popped" mine and it was instant!  Why suffer it any longer than necessary!  You do need someone with experience though.

Posts.Title: Had a lovely evening but.......

Posts.Content: Hi Judith I don't know if this will help you or not, but this is what happened to me.   I was given a 97% chance of recurrence without Tamoxifen, and a 98% chance with it.  Now 1% isn't much either way, I had Grade 1 cancer and a double Mx, so not much left for the cells to grow in (although I now realise that it can grow elsewhere), but I decided that I'd try it and if the SE's were too bad, I'd stop.  I took it for about 20 months, with my joints getting worse, night sweats, moodiness, eyesight getting worse (always had 20/20 vision until my 40's and then only slight shortsightedness), probably some other things that slip my mind.  Anyway I decided to come off it and see if things improved, and they did.   I was told that the first 2 years were the most important, which I almost did.  I was given it for 5 years, although I now understand most are given it for 10.  I know you've always advocated quality of life over length, and I have to say that I agree with you, although I'm now only 51, with hopefully a long way to go! I also had a BRCA test, although 3 of my aunts have had breast cancer, I don't have the gene.  Two have sadly died, but one is still going, and she's in her 70's.  She was also given Tamoxifen but didn't get on with it.  Hopefully some of this will help you to make a decision!
Posts.Title: Femara ( Letrozole) V Arimidex ( Anastrozole) advice please !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Dilys I suspect it's not per tablet but per pack. That said, I think he's confusing Sandoz with Femara.  Femara is the original patented drug and Sandoz is also made by Novartis and has an almost identical recipe, but should be much cheaper.   I would say give it a go.  The doctor would put Letrozole on your prescription, which means that the pharmacist can give you any brand that they have in (usually the cheapest, but you can get lucky).  Ask around various pharmacists to see what they stock (phone. if you can!) and try each one, noting which side effects you get.  If you find one that suits, ask your doctor to put that brand on the script.  If you can't tolerate any, ask for a trial of Femara.  If that works, then you need to persuade your doctor to prescribe it by name.   And if you really can't tolerate any, go back to your oncologist and see what options there are.  Ultimately, it's your decision, the statistics for you are also important, so find out what yours are (ask the onco) and consider the options.

Posts.Title: Don't blame yourself

Posts.Content: Always ask for a copy of your results. You are entitled to them.  MCHC is the size of your red blood cells. If they are high, it could mean you pernicious anaemia (you can have it anyway due to low iron which can mask MCHC). This is as I understand it, anyway. (see disclaimer below!)  If they did a full blood count they probably did it.
Posts.Title: Neuropathy getting worse

Posts.Content: So, I went to London and saw the consultant at the Royal Marsden (eventually, but another story!).  Basically he doesn't think much of these so called permanent expander implants, he doesn't use them and although he said looking at these they are a good result for what they are, he doesn't think they are a good long term solution.   And this bears out everything I can find out, as no one on any site I've read about seems to either have them or keep them.   He had a look at my stomach area, and said that I would be a good candidate for the DIEP if I wanted it, although it would be a long op (8-10 hrs), and 2 months recovery time.  This is mainly for the stomach to recover, not the boobs!  But also to take care over the boobs so that they can heal both externally AND internally.  BUT I would only get an A cup possibly a B cup out of the stomach material that I have at the moment.  :(  I really like having these perky boobs, biggest and perkiest they've ever been!  But the rippling is coming back again a bit, so something has to be done. His recommendation is that I have them swapped out for silicone ones, they can adjust them a bit so they're more equal (atm one is slightly to the left, one is more in the middle!), and see how that goes.  If I'm happy with it, then I'm good for another 15 years (longer if I have no problems with the implants), if not, I can still do the DIEP route.  And maybe have lipofilling to supplement a bit.   Anyway, there's no rush to decide, things are OK at the moment, I'm off on holiday in May, so nothing is going to happen before then.  But might have it done after that - the horses are easier to do in the summer, riding is a pain with flies, etc, and the ground gets too hard as well.   But after that?  Will probably have them swapped over.  ;) And another thing that may interest you.  They are not keen on the LD flap as a method of reconstruction.  They're not THAT keen on the TRAM either, but they do some, but he told me that they do less and less of the recons involving muscles.  And get a much better result. So that's something to think about.

Posts.Title: I have a dilemma with my mastectomy

Posts.Content: Shelley and Sascha Rose  I can tell you that you have two things going on here.  Firstly, you have partners who care but who don't know the right way to go about helping.  And to be honest, if they were all over you, making you tea, fetching your slippers, fussing over you, you'd probably scream at them to give you space!  It's one of those no win situations for them.   I suspect that what they're trying to do for you is to keep life as "normal" as possible, not draw attention to the fact that you are upset, let you deal with it quietly and deflect attention so you can return to the party composed and ready when you are able.  Yes, you probably just want a hug, but you can see it from their point of you, can't you?  And men do like to "fix" things, and when they can't they are just stuck with no coping mechanism.   Secondly, as we all know, unless you've been where we are, you CAN'T actually understand, and there's no point railing at people who are trying their best when it's just not possible to explain and for them to fully take on board how we feel.   Pushing your partner away is fine, we've all done it, and if they really care, they know that it's not what you really want, it's just what you need at the time.  It might be worth just explaining this to them, though, so that they do know that things will improve. Finally, I'm here to tell you that life does improve.  You will have days when you don't even think about cancer anymore, you will enjoy life, join in and forget that anything was ever any different.  Not all day every day, I'm sure, but some days will be better than others.  Your new normal will be OK. Helen xx

Posts.Content: It's common practice to removed IUS's but IUD's don't have a hormone element.  If you had a Mirena coil with a hormone element then yes, you should have it removed.   If you have the BRCA gene then ovary removal is recommended, along with double mastectomy if not already done.   You could ask for a genetic test before making this drastic decision.
Posts.Title: OVARY REMOVAL ER+ BC

Posts.Content: as12 have you had your B12 checked? It could be a good idea and you really need it to be around the 800-1000 mark.  You need methylcobalamin, not cyanocobalamin, and a sublingual form is more easily absorbed. I take Jarrows 5000 iu, you can't overdose, any excess is excreted.  If your MCHC levels are also high, you could have pernicious anaemia, so it would be a good idea to get a full blood test. I always suggest people get a print out of the results for their own records, and learn what they mean.  Good luck

Posts.Title: Biopsy today - waiting for results again!

Posts.Content: Hi Anna I think they feel that trying to use muscle to build breasts is the wrong way to go unless there is no other course of action.  It's not so much that it doesn't give a good result to look at, but that the muscle is just that, and you will always have muscle memory there, which can cause twitching of the boob (!) and that you will also lose strength by moving the muscle around.   The DIEP flap just uses skin and fat tissue from your own body, without involving muscle, therefore there is quicker healing and less invasive surgery than the TRAM flap which uses muscles from the stomach.   I was basically told by the BCN's that people who go for the ops that take longer and have longer recovery time are ultimately MORE pleased with their final results. Bear in mind that how they look is only one part of the equation - how they feel to you is also part of it too, and I personally discounted anything using muscle due to the fact that I want all my strength and also know someone who had LD flap and is still struggling with it 2 years on.   I know that there a no guarantees with any of these options, but I've been told that there will be a lot LESS chance of rippling than I currently have.   I'm still torn between just going for the DIEP and smaller boobs or having silicone implants though!  If I could just put on a bit of weight, I think I could go for it!

Posts.Title: Seroma problems

Posts.Content: It really does depend on whether you feel you can live without a breast for the rest of your life.  Or perhaps you could give it a go now and if you later decide you aren't happy then have it done once you are healed.  I have a Becker expander implant - some surgeons don't use them, but they come with integral ports to put more fluid and expand the skin, and they are supposed to be permanent.  It might be worth asking your surgeon to put one of these in so that it is one less operation to have?  The ports can be removed at a later date (just a small op) if you want although mine are still in and I had mine done about 16 months ago.   There is a branch of Keeping Abreast (dot org if you want to look online) in Bristol - a lovely lady called Jackie runs it, so do get in touch with her (if you struggle PM me and I'll get you details).
Posts.Title: I have a dilemma with my mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Jane Louise I had immediate reconstruction with implants in November 2011. I have to say that I love them now but it took about 8 months for me to come to terms fully with them. To answer your questions, you can't really feel the implant as such, and depending which type you have, depends how much you are aware of it.   Because mine are Becker permanent expanders, they are silicone shells with saline centres, so they do feel a little like fluid filled plastic bags IMO.  But, if you have silicone implants, I think you probably don't get this effect. I can now sleep on my tummy though, surrounding tissue isn't affected at all. Can I ask where you are in the country? Helen

We are here to help, so do let us know how your appointment goes, and if you need us, just post. We all know that the waiting is the pits.

Risk of lymphodema is increased with full clearance and can be difficult to live with, but not living is also an option if the nodes not taken are later found to be cancerous and not removed.  I don't envy you the decision, but at Grade3, I would probably do the above.
