Posts.Title: Cycling to Help Recovery - British Cycling Breeze Network

Posts.Content: Hi Kerryanne I've just read your profile and Paget's disease does look likely from the symptoms you describe.  Now please don't panic, I know you have had a lot of cancer in your life, but that was them and this is you.  You have gone to the doctor, which was the right thing, now you need to get a diagnosis and start treatment.  I know a lady with Paget's and she had a mastectomy with reconstruction and has been fine for years.  It sounds as though your mum may have been in denial about her symptoms until it was too late, so hopefully you have got in earlier and treatment will be successful and you can enjoy your little girl for many many years to come.  In the meantime, why not get some nipple pads that you can use when breast feeding to pop inside your bra to keep them clean and not have to worry?  You have definitely come to the right place, as you will get lots of advice and support here.
Posts.Title: Discharge from nipple

Posts.Content: Ruby Rose I just wanted to take issue with this: They said I didn’t choose to be Sick , it’s not my fault , I’m not a failure ( sorry but I will always feel one but keep that to myself) How can you be a failure? You didn't choose to be ill, you couldn't have prevented it, and you are doing everything you and your team can to stop it.  Please stop beating yourself up about being a failure.  It's just ridiculous.  If you had a child, or a grandchild, who got sick and said they felt a failure, what would you say to them?  Say it to yourself.
Posts.Title: Help/Emotional support/what to do next / Brest Cancer

Posts.Content: Great news, enjoy the fizz!
Posts.Title: Lump in breast - what to expect at breast clinic referral?

Posts.Content: ranorton I found out today that it's Her2 positive. I'm devastated. I'm 65 and I thought I would have some more good years. ranorton If you are Her2+ then you are able to have Herceptin which gives very good results for this type of dancer, so you probably will have many more good years.  OK, so maybe this year won't be great, but by Easter of next year you will be planning the next stage of your life.  Don't forget that many of us have been through this treatment and are still here some years later! Chemo isn't fun, but it's doable.
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Pain most certainly IS a symptom of breast cancer, and I wish they would stop saying it.  Grrrrrr. Ask your GP to refer you to the breast clinic.  Even if nothing was found last time, ti doesn't mean there isn't anything. Fingers crossed.
Posts.Title: Breast pain - what would you do?

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass Whilst I totally get that you are p****d off that you have been lied too, there is nothing you can do at this stage.  I would wait until you are actually in the consulting room with the consultant before you take her to task personally. In the meantime, please don't let the not knowing spoil your weekend, everything will happen eventually.  If there is one thing that this disease tells us, it is to be patient.
Posts.Title: So now my BCN is lying to my face...............

Posts.Content: Ah on that basis, I agree with Julia.  You can always call the oncologist's secretary, if you can't get hold of another BCN.  If necessary march down there and refuse to leave until they tell you!  OK, maybe not that.  But certainly make those calls.
Posts.Title: So now my BCN is lying to my face...............

Posts.Content: I agree it's too soon.  I had my Mx on 23rd Nov (2011) and first fill up was 6th Jan I think.  That was ok because they only put 50ml in each.  The next time I had 100ml and it felt all right lying down but by the end of the week, I was in agony.  By the following week I had to go back and have some removed.  So my tip is take it slowly, don't rush it.  But it's your call, you can say no, you don't want it tomorrow.
Posts.Title: tissue expander implants

Posts.Content: Hi Fireopal  It's good that you are getting checked out. Even though you are stage 1, you need the reassurance from the scan that there is nothing else going on, so whilst there is no point in worrying, as it will just ruin the time between now and then, I know it is easier said than done.  However, breast cancer is very treatable and you have been caught early, so hopefully it's just stress and anxiety that is causing you to be tense, causing the pain. Fingers crossed for you.

Also your Breast Care Nurse may well know someone who has had it done (even by your surgeon) and may be able to arrange for you to talk and/or meet up.

Posts.Title: CA125 blood test

Posts.Content: Of course you are scared, but you have had an x-ray and it would have picked up any tumours in your lungs or bones.   There are some really horrible coughs around this year - I don't normally get things like that but I had one that lasted a good few months and completely floored me.  I'm not 100% even now.  So put that idea out of your mind, trust your doctor and your health team, and forget about the secondaries.   There is no point them keeping things from patients, their job is to inform, and where possible, heal.

Posts.Title: A bit of good news

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah I hope you managed to speak to someone.  You may be developing cording, or axilliary web syndrome.  Have you taken any painkillers? Can you feel a cord running from the armpit to the inner elbow or wrist?  That is the most obvious sign.  If you do have this, you will need specialist physio, but in the meantime do keep doing the exercises as much as you can (and a little beyond).   Hope you have a good Christmas.
Posts.Title: Post Drain Pain

Posts.Content: Chances are that the people giving results will be the ones who gave you the news initially.  Your Multi-disciplinary Team (MDT) will usually be the same throughout treatment, and your BCN is likely to sit in with you. Mine took notes and went through things after the meeting, she was there throughout my treatment. Things do change sometimes, as people come and go, but they do try to keep some form of continuity. Good luck with your results.
Posts.Title: Results day looming

Posts.Content: What great news!  The cost of the test has to be cheaper than the cost of unnecessary chemo both in monetary terms to the NHS and to the welfare state in terms of days lost at work, allowances etc, so it just makes perfect sense.   Big gold star for Dreamthief, too!
Posts.Title: My test was funded!

Posts.Content: Don't worry, we love good news stories here! Good luck!
Posts.Title: Waiting is nearly over

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine  Yes, the ports are a pain, aren't they? I found laying with a pillow under me and an extra one for my head helped.  That said, if you are at full inflation then you could have the ports removed until you have the permanent implants and I am told that they are much more comfortable.  I had permanent expanders and still have the ports, they don't really bother me any more but I remember being where you are and wanting to rip them out with my bare hands.  Do get in touch with your BCN and ask for help.
Posts.Title: expander implants hurting

Posts.Content: Hi boneyem1, you aren't stupid but you do need to learn to deal with this.   Now I'm going to tell you information you may not know.  You can have both breasts removed and still get breast cancer.  Recurrence can occur in the lungs, liver, brain or bones, and even the skin.  So are you going to have all your skin removed?  Of course not.   We must learn to be vigilant but not paranoid.  Cautious but not terrified.  Learn the symptoms to look for, give your self one day a month to check yourself and the rest of the time learn to live the life that you have been given.  You might benefit from counselling as has been mentioned, or you may decide to try some mindfulness, learning to live in the moment.   Don't let your fear rob you of the life you have been given, worry really achieves nothing except to lose the joy in the day.
Posts.Title: Thinking of breast removal

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlettem I assume your chat has happened now and hope it went well.  We all feel a bit better once we know what is going on.  As Michael has said, the Chemo Club is the place to be for all chemo related questions, lots of people are varying stages of chemo and some great hints and tips in the first post. Good luck with your treatment and may your side effects be minimal! (And don't suffer, there are drugs to counter them all!)
Posts.Title: Chemo chat today

Posts.Content: Be careful with green tea - yes, it is good for you, but it does strip iron from your body, so too much can leave you anaemic. Everything in moderation!  White tea is the best, if you can find it.  Tastes lovely too.  Clipper do one, you can get it in most supermarkets.

Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: Just to clarify, the Oncotype DX test is for HER negative patients.  As Herceptin is licensed for use with chemo ONLY, there is no point doing the test, as chemo is essential to have with it.  So HER negative patients in areas where this is now rolled out might have the option to be tested and in the event that it is high risk, they will received chemo, if not, they will not benefit from chemo so will just proceed with hormone inhibitors if appropriate.
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Hi Lilt80  It's not unusual for cancer cells to show up in the lymph nodes. This doesn't mean that you have secondary cancer though, it's part of the original diagnosis.  The nodes are like little sieves that scoop up cancer cells and it looks as if yours have done their job.  Of course sometimes they can escape the net and that's when it gets a bit more difficult. it's very common to have an MRI as well, this is more of a base line to work from and helps to see how the rest of you is doing.  They aren't pleasant but take a favourite CD or memory stick and ask them to play the music while you are in the machine because they give you headphones as it is quite loud.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Metastatic Lymph Nodes

Posts.Content: Glad all has gone well, and look forward to the updates!
Posts.Title: Finally!

Posts.Content: Check they are D3. Adcal are OK but you need to add K2 to transport the calcium where it is needed the bones, otherwise it can deposit in the arteries and cause blockages.

Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: I had two WLEs, and a double mastectomy. No rads as no breast tissue left.  Tamoxifen was offered and I tried it, because at that point I was still terrified. I gave it 20 months with a few breaks here and there.  My stats were 98% chance of being alive in five years with tamoxifen and 97% without. That nearly 5 and a half years ago and I'm fit and happy.  I know it could come back but doesn't prey on my mind.

Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Yeah, I know that attitude! I was fortunate to have Alison and Rachel for most of my significant treatment, but I now have her for my follow ups which frankly are a bit of a waste of time.  Mr M always comes to see his celebrity patient though! :) Annoyingly though, she may be right.  There is no point worrying about recurrence because if it comes back it comes back, and worrying just robs you of the joy of today.  I look at it that I've had a great life, great kids, great husband, lovely animals, and if I had to go now I wouldn't regret anything.  But I'm not ready yet, so I won't worry until I have to.   When I was diagnosed, I remembered my husband's aunt who had died after two rounds with breast cancer.  I spoke to my mum who reminded me that although two of her sisters had died from it (one from stupidity, actually), another had had a mastectomy aged 49 and is still alive and kicking.  I met my aunt on Monday, she's now 72 and still very active and healthy. A short course of psychological help might be what you need, or a kick up the bum, or something in between, only you will know what will work for you.
Posts.Title: Now the treatment is over

Posts.Content: Hi Alex I had carpal tunnel syndrome but mine was caused by hypothyroidism.  Make sure you have this checked before you go down the route of surgery!  It was almost an overnight relief once I started on the tablets.  You should ask your oncologist about the sore tongue, although if it is scalloped that can also be a sign of hypothyroidsm, so well worth checking out.  If you have had chemo, or the fact you are on hormone inhibitors can mean that your hormones are all out of balance, including all sorts, not just oestrogen and progesterone. Hope you can get it sorted.
Posts.Title: Side affects - GUK !

Posts.Content: Hi Adassarose, you probably won't be able to drive for a couple of weeks.  You may well have a drain in after surgery, so going out and about you may need a bag to put the drain in with long handles so you can put it over your shoulders and don't forget it!   You won't be able to lift anything for a while either, usually about 3 weeks, so no heavy shopping bags, handbags, or ironing, hoovering.  If you can get someone to do that for you for a few weeks that would be a massive help.  Do do the exercises they should give you (if they don't, shout, there are some online we can link you to), as it is important to keep the shoulder and arm moving otherwise you can have real problems.  Start the day after surgery and do as much as you can stand.   Those are probably the main things.  If you have pain, let them know so that you can go home with sufficient painkillers, although most people can manage with ibuprofen and paracetamol, sometimes you need something much stronger.  I had cocodamol, amytriptylene and tramadol for ages but I did develop cording.   Good luck with the operation and keep posting here so we know you are OK.

Posts.Content: Don't you think that the consultants should have to live with them before they can make these pronouncements?! Mine are above the bra line and in fact I don't wear a bra most of the time because there's no need (depending on what I am wearing). I think you do get used to it and they settle. Posts.Title: Diagnosed this week - helpless

Posts.Content: Dear Kim I'm sorry you find yourself here where none of us wanted to be.  But you are amongst friends here and we can all empathise. I'm going to give you two pieces of advice that will go against what you have said.  Firstly, do not try to stay strong for your family.  They need to see your weaknesses so that they will know how to support you.  Take all the help offered as and when you need it (and you will).  This is the time to think of you and allow others to help.  This is also a way of helping them cope with your diagnosis as well as helping you. Secondly, strange though it may seem, not talking to your husband will be adding to his stress, because he will (if he has any sensitivity at all!) have realised that you are worried and the fact that you aren't broaching the subject means he can't.  Keep the lines of communications open.  He will probably say stupid things, because you look OK you are OK, and all that stuff, but please. just keep talking.  It's a tough time for families as much as the patient, I often think. Finally, you are doing so well, you will get through this,  I'm sure all the old chemo hands will be along to tell you about that aspect of it.  Good luck with your treatment. Helen x

Posts.Content: Congratulations,  Heather, I hope you can make some nice plans for the future now.

Posts.Content: Not much to add to this really, except to say that I think men find it hard to talk about cancer or anything bad happening and whilst we look ourselves there's an element of denial whereas when your hair falls out there's no denying it.  Agree with Kacang, get the guys involved and they feel less helpless.  Sorry for the generalisation.
Posts.Title: oncoDX result

Posts.Content: Warrenb39 Hi this is myfirst time here my wife was diagnosed last yr with breast cancer all treatments are finished what I would like to know is if she was to have breast reconstruction surgery using implants will the do both so they look the same or jst one can anyone please help thank you.   Hi Warren  I asked for a prophylactic mastectomy when I knew that a mastectomy was on the cards.   I had some family history but I was more concerned about having a matching pair.  There was no cancer in the good breast and as I found after I don't have the BRCA gene, but I had to persuade a second doctor that I really wanted it.   I did say that I would have been constantly checking myself and my mental health would be affected.  They agreed in the end and I haven't regretted it. These are the points your wife should make to her surgeon although a new primary is unlikely under these circumstances, secondary tumours usually occur elsewhere in the body so not a reason to have a mastectomy.

Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: Diana I've never heard it called remaking the breast!  Prosthetics are false boobs that you tuck in your bra. Implants are put under the skin and muscle.  If you are having reconstruction, you should have a consultation with your plastic surgeon who will give you a list of possible options depending on your body.  Depending where you are in the country, there may be a support group local to you where you can go and see real women with reconstructions?
Posts.Title: what to expect just before and coming out of mastectomy surgery!

Posts.Content: Hi Snowys Mum  K2 (Mk7) is the natural form and is needed to be the transport for D3 to the bones, otherwise it goes to other places where it does more harm than good.  Most GPs and Oncologists do not understand the importance of vitamins and minerals in the body and how they interact.  This is where I got my information from If you take Vitamin D3 you also need Vitamin K2! Niki Hussey·Thursday, 14 May 2015 If You Take Vitamin D, You Need K2 This is a really crucial point: If you opt for oral vitamin D, you need to also consume in your food or take supplemental vitamin K2. Vitamin D is a fat soluble prohormone, Vitamin K a fat soluble vitamin. Both need to be consumed with some kind of dietary fat, so take with your fattiest meal of the day. Don't take it before bed as it temporarily pauses the production of melatonin, studies have shown if taken late it decreases REM sleep and the number of hours slept. This is a really crucial point: Vitamin D3 should never be taken alone. Always take a combination Vitamin D3/ Vitamin K2. This is because vitamin D3 improves calcium absorption across the GI tract and vitamin K2 is the cofactor needed to transfer calcium into your bones, and not your arteries. Vitamin D deficiencies lead to SLEEP DISORDERS. And to correct vitamin D-related sleep disorders, you have to be careful about the amount of vitamin D you take and when you take it.Take 1000 IUs of Vitamin D-3 per 25 pounds of body weight, but not more than 10,000 IU’s. Sufficient vitamin D can also help reduce pain and control inflammation, among an assortment of other health benefits. In addition to talking a vitamin D3 liquid emulsion with your evening meal, taking the right dose to raise your Vitamin D (25 OH) levels up to your goal is also important. A few small studies have shown that 2000IU vitamin D3 taken over three months, will raise Vitamin D (25 OH) levels by 20ng/ml. This may be the reason that many doctors prescribe this dose. Clinically, this doesn’t play out. Some people will need a lot more vitamin D to raise their levels over time. If your Vitamin D (25 OH) is 25ng/ml and your goal is 45ng/ml, move to a liquid emulsion, taken with dinner and try a 2000-4000IU dose for six months and then retest. Assess how much your vitamin D level moved during that duration and then work with a licensed health care provider to reassess your dose. Once you reach your desired level, you will likely need 1000-2000IU vitamin D3 a day to maintain these levels. A healthy human body utilizes about 3000-5000 IU of vitamin D per day. ***Too much vitamin D can cause headaches and inflammation in the body. The US Government’s upper intake level (UL) for vitamin D is set at 4,000 IU per day. Other experts disagree, the current consensus states it should be 10,000 IU. (7,8,9) This is the amount your skin would naturally produce from maximum exposure from the sun. (10) An even better way to figure out what your optimal vitamin D levels are, is through testing your body’s responses. "There are so many people on the vitamin-D-mega-dose bandwagon, taking more and more of vitamin D. And it could absolutely be causing harm if you are lacking the K2 to complete the job to get the calcium where it's supposed to be," Rheaume-Bleue warns. "We don't see symptoms of vitamin D toxicity very often. But when we do, those symptoms are inappropriate calcification. That's the symptom of vitamin D toxicity. And it is actually a lack of vitamin K2 that can cause that..." While the ideal or optimal ratios between vitamin D and vitamin K2 have yet to be elucidated, Rheume-Bleue suggests about 150-200 micrograms of K2 will meet the need for the "average" healthy person. "My earlier recommendation was not taking into account people who were doing high dose of vitamin D supplementation," Rheaume-Bleue says. "That's where it gets a little bit more technical. It seems that for the average person, around 200 to 280 micrograms will activate your K2 proteins and do a lot of good for your bones and your heart. If you're taking high levels of vitamin D... then I would recommend taking more K2." The good news is that vitamin K2 has no toxicity. No toxic effects have ever been demonstrated in the medical literature. "The reason why K2 doesn't have potential toxic effect is that all vitamin K2 does is activate K2 proteins. It will activate all the K2 proteins it finds. And if they're all activated and you take extra K2, it simply won't do that. That's why we don't see a potential for toxicity the way we do with vitamin A or D," she says. Vitamin K2 is an important fat-soluble vitamin that plays critical roles in protecting your heart and brain, and building strong bones. It also plays an important role in cancer protection The biological role of vitamin K2 is to help move calcium into the proper areas in your body, such as your bones and teeth. It also helps remove calcium from areas where it shouldn’t be, such as in your arteries and soft tissues The optimal amounts of vitamin K2 are still under investigation, but it seems likely that 180 to 200 micrograms of vitamin K2 might be enough to activate your body’s K2-dependent proteins to shuttle calcium to the proper areas If you take oral vitamin D (always take only D3), you also need to take vitamin K2. Vitamin K2 deficiency is actually what produces the symptoms of vitamin D toxicity, which includes inappropriate calcification that can lead to hardening of your arteries. Vitamin K is actually a group of fat-soluble vitamins. Of the two main ones, K1 and K2, the one receiving the most attention is K1, which is found in green leafy vegetables and is very easy to get through your diet. This lack of distinction has created a lot of confusion, and it's one of the reasons why vitamin K2 has been overlooked for so long. The three types of vitamin K are: Vitamin K1, or phylloquinone, is found naturally in plants, especially green vegetables; K1 goes directly to your liver and helps you maintain healthy blood clotting Vitamin K2, also called menaquinone, is made by the bacteria that line your gastrointestinal tract; K2 goes straight to your blood vessel walls, bones, and tissues other than your liver Vitamin K3, or menadione, is a synthetic form I do not recommend; it's important to note that toxicity has occurred in infants injected with this synthetic vitamin K3 It also plays a role in removing calcium from areas where it shouldn't be, such as in your arteries and soft tissues. "K2 is really critical for keeping your bones strong and your arteries clear," Rheaume-Bleue says. Now, vitamin K2 can be broken into two additional categories, called: MK-4 (menaquinone-4), a short-chain form of vitamin K2 found in butter, egg yolks, and animal-based foods MK-7 (menaquinone-7), longer-chain forms found in fermented foods. There's a variety of these long-chain forms but the most common one is MK-7. This is the one you'll want to look for in supplements, because in a supplement form, the MK-4 products are actually synthetic. They are not derived from natural food products containing MK-4.The MK-7 – these long-chain, natural bacterial-derived vitamin K2 – is from a fermentation process, which offers a number of health advantages: It stays in your body longer, and It has a longer half-life, which means you can just take it once a day in very convenient dosing How Much Vitamin K2 Do You Need? The optimal amounts of vitamin K2 are still under investigation, but it seems likely that 180 to 200 micrograms of vitamin K2 should be enough to activate your body's K2-dependent proteins to shuttle the calcium where it needs to be, and remove it from the places where it shouldn't. "The most recent clinical trials used around those amounts of K2," Rheaume-Bleue says. "The average person is getting a lot less than that. That's for sure. In the North American diet, you can see as little as maybe 10 percent of that or less. Certainly, not near enough to be able to optimize bone density and improve heart health." Hope all this helps in some way!
Posts.Title: Dexa scan

Posts.Content: Hi Cass You're not a coward but it is a scary time.  I would perhaps just ring the hospital tomorrow and ask if they have your notes for an appointment.  You may get passed back to the surgery, but government guidelines say that women should start treatment within 31 days of diagnosis, so you want the diagnosis as soon as possible.   Fingers crossed it's nothing, but better prepared.  Well done for going to the doctor - don't be a patient patient! Helen
Posts.Title: mammogram ..??

Posts.Content: Abandoned, lost, scared?  I think that's pretty normal.  You've been on the rollercoaster for a while and it's suddenly stopped and you have to get yourself off and find the way out.  Take your time, don't rush it because you're still giddy from the ride and you could still fall down the steps.  When you make it out and into the light, go and sit in a cafe and have a rest.  Take life slowly for a while and take time to smell the roses. You are now ready for the next part of your life!
Posts.Title: All my treatment nearly finished, weird feeling.

Posts.Content: Warren, all I can tell you is they did both for me.  You need to know that there is no sensation in reconstruction so this might be a consideration also.  I think it depends on the hospital, but if it is what she wants, then it is worth being persistent.   Obviously there is a cost issue, and I think non essential surgery is being clamped down on, if there is any family history then use it as a bargaining tool.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: I didn't have radiotherapy but one of mine is slightly higher than the other too, RebeccaT. It might be that you were slightly uneven before and didn't notice?!  Or that's the way it's positioned?!
Posts.Title: Effects of Radiotherapy on Breast Implants

Posts.Content: RebeccaT A bit of both, I think, along with the RT! Haha well no one is perfect!

Posts.Content: Warren, all I can tell you is they did both for me.  You need to know that there is no sensation in reconstruction so this might be a consideration also.  I think it depends on the hospital, but if it is what she wants, then it is worth being persistent.   Obviously there is a cost issue, and I think non essential surgery is being clamped down on, if there is any family history then use it as a bargaining tool.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: hi - if you feel like 20 questions, here goes minus the Beer!  : 1]  It would be reassuring to know how the hospital procedure works just before and after surgery, how long does a single mastectomy take in a straight DCIS [non-invasive] operation, would it be 2, 3 or more hours? They should tell you but it can be between 1.5 and 5 hrs.  Depending if you have any kind of reconstruction could be longer. 2]  With a simple DCIS mastectomy is the underlying muscle cut, I'm still not certain about that? Having had a discectomy years ago, a five hour operation for a fractured lumbar disc, that time after anaesthesia I felt extremely weak, it took a day to just get a little strength back. The underlying muscle shouldn't be cut unless they find it is affected.  You may well feel the same but you just have to go with the flow!   3]  Would I be able to move my left arm at all  [left breast mastectomy]  -  and would there be  need for a bed pan if needed in the first few hours after operation? Yes, you should be able to move your arm although it might get stiffer for a while.  Do the exercises they give you.  If they don't, have a look on here, I'm pretty sure there are some (or on breastcancercare.org).  You might have a bedpan if you aren't feeling up to much, but most probably the nurses will help you to the toilet if you need it. 4] Is there a difference with the initial recovery period depending on age, say in 40's, 50's and 60+ years? Who knows?!
Posts.Title: what to expect just before and coming out of mastectomy surgery!

Posts.Content: Hi Helen I can only agree with what people have said so far, but on the reconstruction side of things, you are entitled to an uplift and reduction on the other side as part of your treatment.  If they flat out refuse it, you can go to your GP and ask for a second opinion.  Pick one of the large cancer centres of excellence and you will get a good idea of what is and what isn't possible.  At the end of the day, you are still alive, but you have a right to a quality of life too. Helen
Posts.Title: what drug better than anastrozole?

Posts.Content: I think Boots sell them, Maggie, and maybe Amazon
Posts.Title: LadyCare Menopause Magnets

Posts.Content: Big girl panties,  Mo!  The chemo has largely gone by two months but if it hangs around or you feel worried then it's always worth getting checked.   Once we've been through this treatment we are naturally cautious and that's right, but unless it becomes anything more than a cold then you should be fine. Hope you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Got a cold

Posts.Content: You have probably been holding it with tension and now you have relaxed a bit, it feels heavy. If it persists longer than a week, pop along to your GP and mention it.  I wouldn't have thought it's to do with the mammo unless you were forced into a very unnatural position.
Posts.Title: Had my breast clinic appointment today

Posts.Content: You should always get discharge checked out.  That was how my hypothyroid was diagnosed, so it isn't necessarily something related to BC!
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: I expect it's because you will be given local anaesthetic as a minimum and you may feel woozy/nauseous afterwards.  (just guessing here) I think you'll appreciate someone being around, too. Here's hoping that they just find it's something simple. xx
Posts.Title: Bronchoscopy........

Posts.Content: Long may it continue!
Posts.Title: Had my breast clinic appointment today

Posts.Content: ollie45  The fact that the majority of nodes taken on one side means that they are doing their job, filtering the cancer cells from entering your lymph system. The second operation to remove more nodes is to check that there aren't more of these in your body and remove any that may contain cancer. You don't know until they've had the path report if they have cancer, so they just decide how many they are taking and go from there. Usually chemo would start around 6 weeks after an operation, the fact that you have to wait another 3 weeks for the second op means it should start around mid November, so I'm surprised that it is taking this long - you can ask for a cancellation if you feel you would like to progress things sooner.  No guarantees, of course, there may not be any, or there may be lots on the waiting list ahead of you. I hope this answers your question, but if not, do come back.
Posts.Title: further lymph Node operation after double mastectomy

Posts.Content: JayJay999 I absolutely hear you.  As if any one of the things you are going through isn't enough, all at once must been a nightmare.   I suggest if you haven't already, you tell your oncologist everything you have written down here, and tell them how you feel about it. If you break down in the telling, all the better, as you need some support and hopefully they will see how what they have done has impacted you.  It's bloody unfair, and if I could do anything to help, I would.   In the meantime, do give the helpline a call, if you need to speak to someone, they are very helpful, they are on 0808 808 0000, open Monday to Friday, from 9am to 8pm.  Just talking it through with someone may well help, and I hope that putting it all on here has helped you too.
Posts.Title: Frustrated...(don't read, I'm simply having a moan :( ...)

Posts.Content: Hi Cathy Sorry I can't help with most of that but I have given my horses Biotin for years and it is great for their hooves, bones and coat!  So your nails will be helped, your hair should grow glossy and hopefully your bones will be strengthened too! :) Helen x
Posts.Title: Herceptin and supplements to boost hair growth - advice please

Posts.Content: You most certainly do NOT have to take what you are offered on the NHS!  You have the right to choose your consultant/surgeon/oncologist/hospital!  My BCN's were adamant about this, and kept repeating it - you don't have to be treated at your local hospital, you can go to a centre of excellence if you choose to!
Posts.Title: When does grieving for your breast stop?

Posts.Content: The periods may or may not be related to your treatment.  I think it is reasonable to ask for tests, an ultrasound of your womb may establish that you have fibroids, or there could be some underlying cause.   In addition, because of the blood loss, you may become anaemic and very tired - check the inside of your eyelids for a quick check - if they look very pale, then it could be a problem.   If they check there isn't another problem, and the issue persists, go back to your oncologist. HTH Helen x
Posts.Title: Ridiculously long period

Posts.Content: Great news,  Mumra!  I would phone up about the parking, because you may be OK for the planning appointment but by then it could be too late depending on how your hospital works!
Posts.Title: Oncotype Dx results ...

Posts.Content: nikonblue I had a hysterectomy before I got breast cancer. It was a keyhole op, home in. 3 days, riding horses by the end of the week.  They left the cervix so I still need to have smears, and my ovaries, but I have no regrets. I will be interested in what the doctor says.
Posts.Title: /Tamoxifen and Letrazole and bleeding?

Posts.Content: Hi LM Welcome to the club no one wants to join ...  I had a double Mx last November with immediate Recon (permanent expander implants).   Waiting for things to start is the worst time - try to live as normal a life as you can and keep busy! You should have a meeting with a Plastic Surgeon to discuss the options for reconstruction - there are pros and cons to it all, and you need to know ALL the options even if they are not done at your hospital.  BAPRAS do a good leaflet which tells you ALL the options, and a list of surgeons I think - you can probably google it.  Also depending where you are, you can join the Reconstruction support group Keeping Abreast or visit their website.  Lots of info there.  It does depend to a large extent where you are as to what your hospital offers - some will not do immediate reconstruction if they need to do chemo/RT but legally you have to be offered it.  I'm currently considering my reconstruction options, since I am having a few minor problems with these.  Research research research .... and if you want to PM me, please do.  I felt rushed into my decision, and I'm now regretting it - I'd be on the home straight by now if I had listened to my gut ... Helen
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: One thing - if you go for the DIEP flap on one side, and you develop cancer on the other side at some later stage, you've burned your bridges.  So unless your belly only has enough to create one breast now anyway, just  bear this in mind.  You may, of course, never develop anything ever again, and god knows none of us want this scenario, but I'm just playing devil's advocate a bit ... ;)
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: Sounds easy to say, but worrying about it won't change things.  Keep busy - chat with friends, watch TV, read a book, DO YOUR EXERCISES!!!, because wasting time worrying is simply that.  A waste of time. At the end of the day, you can't change it.  So accept what is and will be, and makes some plans for the not too distant future.
Posts.Title: anxiety between mastectomy and lymph results

Posts.Content: Sascha I just wanted  to say that you have received a lot of good advice and support from this forum, as well as giving it yourself.   I would just like to ask you to consider this - by posting your comments here, what do you hope to achieve that you have not achieved?   I appreciate that you are not in the UK, but it is not our fault that you don't have access to the same services as us, many people here have tried to give you links to other support services where at all possible, including Kate.   Often the reason I do not reply to your posts is that I simply don't feel I can say anything that either has not been said, or that would help.   I wish you well and hope you can look beyond the physical.  If you can, google Nick Vujicic - perhaps his story will give you hope.
Posts.Title: Two years....!

Posts.Content: Hi Edie Sorry to hear that you have mets, but it's good that they have shrunk/stabilised on the chemo.  I'm glad to hear that you have help coming in - definitely time to make the most of the good days, let the bad days happen around you.   Helen
Posts.Title: Breast cancer with lung liver and bones secondaries

Posts.Content: hammie Just wanted to add my own welcome to the community  I was diagnosed over 7 years ago and I am fighting fit although just like you in the beginning.  You will get through this, 90% of all BC patients are doing well 5 years from diagnosis when they are discharged! Try to keep busy  don't dwell on the worst case which is unlikely to happen, be positive and when you have a down period, put a timer on for 10 minutes and then do something different   Good luck
Posts.Title: Waiting, waiting, waiting

Posts.Content: Oh Jenny, I'm so sorry you feel this way.   Can you speak to your BCN about this, and see if there is anything they can do to help?  Are you having the subcut Herceptin, because this can cause problems that don't occur if you have it intravenously.   Yes, medication is making you feel like that at the moment, but that medication is given to prevent recurrence.  Of course you can always refuse more, if life really is intolerable, or you can say OK, I've got x months of this, I'm going to swallow all the painkillers I need until I get to the end and with luck all these side effects will disappear. I hope you feel strong enough to take the second option, but do talk to someone.  Ring the Macmillan helpline if you have no one or can't get hold of a BCN.  0808 808 0000, Monday to Friday, 9am to 8pm.
Posts.Title: feed up

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy I think having a CT scan is quite normal.  It's just to check that they've not missed anything, and that they know what they are dealing with once you are having the operation.   The good news is that because you are young, you will have the works thrown at you to give you the best possible outcome, and the statistics for breast cancer are very good.  The worst bit is sitting in the rollercoaster car waiting for the ride to start.  The nerves kick in, and you imagine all kinds of worse case scenarios, but it's never as bad as you think it is going to be.   If you have any questions, do ask her, as someone will have been through the exact same as you, and know the answer.  There is a facebook group for young women with breast cancer where you can share stories and get support, too.  Just search on your page. Good luck with your operation, you will be fine.
Posts.Title: 30 AND JUST DIAGNOSED WITH BREAST CANCER

Posts.Content: I thought this was a place to add this response from my MP regarding an recent email about the use of biphosphonates in primary breast cancers. Further to my secretary's email regarding the availability of bisphosphonates, I now enclose a copy of the letter I have received from the Health Minister, Lord O'Shaughnessy. I understand from the Minister that national prescribing arrangements already allow for bisphosphonates to be prescribed for the treatment and prevention of secondary breast cancer. Decisions about the commissioning and funding of bisphosphonates for this use are taken by local clinical commissioning groups which are best placed to know what local need exists.  The Manual for Prescribed Specialised Services 2016/17 makes clear that clinical commissioning groups are responsible for commissioning adjuvant drug treatments, for example, drugs affecting bone metabolism including bisphosphonates. I am, therefore, currently making further enquiries with Bedfordshire Clinical Commissioning Group regarding this. I am also aware that the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence is currently updating its advice to the NHS on the diagnosis and management of early and locally advanced breast cancer and this includes the use of bisphosphonates. I hope this is helpful and I will write to you again once I have received a response from Bedfordshire CCG. Kind regards Alistair Burt
Posts.Title: biphosphonates

Posts.Content: Pollycat - I really think it just has to be an individual choice - as you say, some people know immediately what they want, some just want to get rid of the cancer and think about the rest later, and some plain don't know.  And even if you do know you want reconstruction, there are then options and choices to consider, most of which aren't immediately offered or explained.  Which is why we need help with decisions. I have a lot of respect for anyone who has had any kind of treatment whatever their decision subsequently.  And saying someone who chooses a reconstruction has a fake boob feels less than respectful.  It's not their choice to lose a breast, and some people couldn't live with the alternative.  I couldn't, you could.  It's just each to their own.  Information is power, that's all.
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: I must admit we usually eat fish and chips cooked at home, but frankly anything cooked in boiling hot oil is going to kill any bugs, I would have thought!
Posts.Title: Risk of infection

Posts.Content: I do totally understand actually.  I would try closing your eyes and listening to an audio book or some music. Hopefully you will drop off and tomorrow will be another day.   One day at a time. Hugs
Posts.Title: anxiety between mastectomy and lymph results

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly I'm sorry to hear about your friend.  I know it's hard but please try to respect her decision and just enjoy the time you have left with her.   No one wwill be able to answer your questions but it might help if you call the nurses here on the free helpline.  If your friend is already in a lot of pain then I suspect it could be quite far gone.  Make some good memories.  HHelen
Posts.Title: breast cancer spread to bones

Posts.Content: Good luck! Glad to hear you're fighting for yourself

Posts.Content: Hi Jenny I do understand.  We all have these days when we want to scream.  I would say don't hide how you are feeling from your family, let them help you - Let them make the tea!  And do get stronger painkillers.  You don't need to be suffering.   I hope tomorrow is a better day for you.
