Posts.Content: Cancers related to the BRCA gene are Breast, Ovarian and Prostate.
Posts.Title: Genetics

Posts.Content: Fame at last!  LOL!
Posts.Title: The Macmillan Community - invaluable and a lifeline...

Posts.Content: Has anyone mentioned cording? Or its technical name, axillary web syndrome? This is the rope like vein on the inside of the elbow even as far as the thumb.  Being referred to a physio is the next step to resolving this if this is the issue. However you do need someone who knows how to treat it.  Ask them about it and see if they have been trained.
Posts.Title: UNSIGHTLY ARM DUE TO VEINS.

Posts.Content: Good news!
Posts.Title: Hard lump post mastectomy

Posts.Content: No, it's the other way around!  DIEP flap is from the stomach.  And only uses fat and tissue,  not muscle.  The Latimuss Dorsi flap is the one using muscle from the back.  The TRAM uses muscle from the stomach.  Any op that uses muscle will cause weakness in the area it is taken from.  The DIEP flap shouldn't leave any significant weakness.  Hope that explains it properly?  Ask away if not!
Posts.Title: Hi, I'm new

Posts.Content: Helen - I've put mine up before, you go for it.  To add a picture, it needs to be a certain size so you may need to resize it.  Once done (try it first, might be OK), Click on the picture with a little circle bottom right.  then follow the instructions to attach it.
Posts.Title: Minimising radiotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: There are cancer specific tumour markers that can be tested, you can get this done at your surgery, but I would say that most people do find their secondary issues themselves which is why follow up has been reduced. Every time we have a test, we worry about the results  The more tests  the more worry, the more worry, the more stress.  Reducing stress in my opinion is the best thing you can do for your health.
Posts.Title: Screening once treatment is all finished

Posts.Content: Hi Secondtime It's such a nuisance when all you want to do is get on with living.  Please keep going back and making sure they know a) how much pain you are in, b) how inconvenient it is and c) how much it affects your life.  All those things are KPIs for GPs and consultants.  It's simply not acceptable to be referred to a pain clinic to manage the pain.  Things can and should be done.
Posts.Title: pain under arm and breast site

Posts.Content: I'm sorry, I'm with Dreamthief on this one.   If this were the case, vegans wouldn't get breast cancer, and we know this is not true.  As to hormones in food, perhaps if they stopped feeding large doses of hormones to animals to make them grow bigger faster then less would get into the food chain.  We have to face up to the fact that our food is too messed about with by the big food corporations and say no to those foods.  Unfortunately, the animals pass the hormones into the ground/water table and we are going to get them even through this, so we cannot win this battle without addressing the root cause.  Asian women probably suffer less cancer because they can't afford to feed these hormones to the food they eat and it is therefore more "pure".   There are as many theories for as against, you only have to pick up a newspaper, as someone said earlier, to find a "miracle superfood" that will "cure" cancer/diabetes/heart disease/pick disease of the moment, and a week later another article will be printed saying that one is bad for you. Stick to as pure and organic food as possible, create your own dishes rather than buy ready made things, and know what is going into you.  But don't beat yourself up if you fancy a chocolate bar, or get offered a cream slice.  Everything in moderation, but whatever else you do, live your lives, don't get hung up on it - you could be run over by a bus tomorrow ...
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Grrrr sleepless nights are a PITA! I keep having them at the moment.  Hope you can put the anxiety in a box until 5.
Posts.Title: 2hrs Sleep....

Posts.Content: As Maggie says, you're not alone.  It's very normal to feel this way.  I would get the antidepressants and keep them for when you really think you need them. But you probably don't and a few decent night's sleep will work wonders.  Dunno why I am awake at 4.30 grrrrr
Posts.Title: Today has been a blurrrr

Posts.Content: Hi Pat Don't worry, we've all been where you are, so we all understand.  Not surprised you are down after losing your Mum so recently - you will still be grieving for that without any of this other stuff to deal with. Try to live your life as normally as possible and put it out of your mind for now.  Keeping busy will help.  The system will take care of you, you will find a way through this, and prognosis is so much better these days.  I'm just recovering from a double Mx with implants, and I have to say some days it's been worse than I thought and others much better, so try not to have any preconceptions, write down any queries or worries so that you can talk to the Breast Care Nurse (or Macmillan nurse) about them. It's very normal to have worries, but you will come through this. Helen xxx
Posts.Title: Waiting game

Posts.Content: Of course, and you are entitled to! Hernias aren't nice and being in pain is horrid, I really feel for you.  Do see if the GP can give you some different painkillers to get you through.
Posts.Title: Hernia following DIEP surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Gail I've been through WLE, further excision and finally mastectomy.  I also had a prophylactic mastectomy on the unaffected side because I never wanted to go through this process again.  I had immediate reconstruction and am now 10 weeks on from the op.  I have to say that it was uncomfortable to start with, but I am getting more used to it and whereas I was conscious of them 100% of the time for quite a while, I now have periods when I forget them entirely.  I've had Becker Expander implants btw, and my surgeon says if I am happy with them they can stay in for life.  The ports will probably be removed under a local anaesthetic, when I am ready.   II've also got family history, and I know that I would still be worrying about the other side if I hadn't had them both removed I wouldn't have been able to relax. That said, it's not an easy road, you will be different, and all the reconstructions have their own advantages and disadvantages.  You haven't said if you're going for reconstruction, but if you are, and you have the option, an immediate recon will save you a lot of problems later on.   Good luck with whatever you decide, and as someone said earlier, you have to do what is right for YOU. Helen
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy or double masectomy

Posts.Content: Try not to worry about thinking straight, it's one of those things that the more you try to do it, the worse you are.  Don't make any important decisions at the moment, and just focus on you. I am fine, thank you for asking, I was diagnosed almost 7 years ago, and I am No Evidence of Disease (NED), I was signed off a couple of years ago.  There IS life after cancer!
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Sonia They don't scan it, because there is nothing to scan, even after reconstruction.  If there is anything unusual, the chance are you will spot it, so that's really how they work.  They will take a look at the area, feel your lymph nodes, run their fingers over the reconstruction and if there is anything unusual you might have an ultrasound and possibly MRI.   Glad your results were OK.
Posts.Title: After one year scan, what now?

Posts.Content: big bird 70  It's such a confusing time, isn't it?  Once you get started on treatment you will feel  better. And if the husband wants to help, let him. Take advantage, if you like.  if he clears off again afterwards, then you're no worse off, and if he doesn't maybe he realised how much you mean to him.
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: It can still be all kinds of things, you are being checked out so please hold on to that.
Posts.Title: Found lump under arm 5 months after double mastectomy and lymph node...

Posts.Content: Hi skippyfinn If your sister is not using the cold cap and trying to keep her hair then now could be the time to have it either cut short or shaved off. It's the weight of the hair pulling on the scalp that causes the pain.  Ladies here have found that dissolvable paracetamol gently massaged into the scalp does help.
Posts.Title: Hair loss - sore scalp

Posts.Content: HI Dolina  If you look at it as around 12 weeks, that's pretty good for the NHS, to be honest.  I know you are in pain, and want it done asap, but unless you have private medical insurance, or a small trust fund, you will probably have to wait. What you could do is let them know you are happy to take a cancellation.  Call the hospital and make sure that it is added to your notes.  Take the Tramadol before bed and make the most of the sleep.  Low dose amytriptylene might help as well.
Posts.Title: Hernia following DIEP surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Tibby I had a lumpetomy and ended up having a mastectomy.  I opted for a double mastectomy as 3 of my mum's sisters have all had BC although not that young.  But mainly because I didn't want to have to go through the agony of being told I had breast cancer again.  I know there's still an outside chance it could come back, but I've done everything I can do for now. I'm going through the genetic testing now mainly for my daughter's sake but also my sister and her children.  My daughter's risk looks high to me, as my husband's side has several incidences.  It's not a painful test (just a blood test) and the thing I always feel is knowledge is power.  If it's negative, you'll find a cloud lift, and if it is positive you will be able to make an informed decision.  As you've already had two instances of cancer, and ovarian and breast cancer are linked in the gene, I'd definitely go for it.  Good luck whatever you decide. Helen
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy or double masectomy

Posts.Content: Thinning hair can be a side effect of reduced oestrogen as can aching joints unfortunately. This is one reason that many people give up on the treatment   Try different brands by all means  but do bear this in mind  One other reason for hair loss is low iron  so do have it checked
Posts.Title: Letrozole Brands and side effects

Posts.Content: Just popping in before I go to bed to say that although I know it won't help with contracts, you can try calling the Macmillan help line on 080 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm.  Their financial advisors can tell you what you may or may not be entitled to.   They are very helpful, so please give them a call.
Posts.Title: Hi im newly diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, scared and looking...

Posts.Content: mistyblue firstly, massive hugs to you.  How anyone can say that to a friend is beyond me. I think you have found out that cancer really shows who your real friends are and it's often not the ones you expect, but it is best to find out early.
Posts.Title: Really bloody angry !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca Just to reassure you, lots of people here have had the cancer spread to nodes.  It doesn't mean the end is nigh!  The nodes are cleared, you are having a Mx, the chemo and radio will mop up any strays and you will be fine.   No one is ever completely cured, because on a cellular level, no one is able to view every cell in a body, but you will be "No Evidence of Disease" NED and that's as good as it gets.  After all, everyone who's not diagnosed may well be walking around with things going on that they don't even know yet.  So, get through the treatment, get off that rollercoaster, and make sure that ever second, every day with your lovely family count. We should all do that, diagnosed or otherwise, but few of us do.  I think we are the lucky ones, because we re-evaluate our lives and decide not to put up with the stuff that doesn't matter, the people who bring us down, and we have a better life as a result! Helen
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer has spread to nodes, panicking

Posts.Content: Hate waiting  Nausea could be caused by stress or anxiety, so don't read too much into it. However, just because you have had a period doesn't mean that you aren't pregnant. Have you done a pregnancy test?  We all know that waiting for results or appointments is the pits.  Do keep busy and try not too Google, come here or phone the helpline on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm.  The team are very knowledgeable and supportive.
Posts.Title: Waiting to be referred to breast clinic

Posts.Content: Jenny - I would talk to your team.  It may be that something can be done about your side effects, and if this is definitely normal for you, then you need to make a fuss.  Don't let them tell you it's normal, or your age, or anything, because most people breeze through Herceptin from what I've seen.  OK, not everyone, but the side effects are minimal compared with chemo.   What you need to know, though, is that Herceptin is for a year.  So if you postpone, it may mean you don't get as many doses.   And of course all treatment is up to you, no one can force it on you.
Posts.Title: Herceptin break

Posts.Content: If you think about the anatomy of the breast, there are a lot of milk ducts and they each have as much chance of becoming cancerous as each other, so in this case, multi focal doesn't really make much difference to the outcome. Hopefully the information you have gained so far here will have put your mind at rest but do call the free helpline here on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm. They can answer all your questions and are good listeners too.
Posts.Title: Girlfriend has been told she has a mammogram result of M5

Posts.Content: I found a thin pillow just below my bust helped me to sleep and I can highly recommend a memory foam mattress or topper.
Posts.Title: Getting better but can't sleep at night

Posts.Content: Descat  if you type phyllodes into the search bar for the group at the top of the page you will see all threads about it.
Posts.Title: Phyllodes/sarcoma

Posts.Content: That's strange, I thought there was something more recently, sorry. It's not very common, so if you post on some of the earlier threads, the people may get notifications especially if you tag them, and be able to update you. Sorry I can't be more helpful. Dreamthief can you help?
Posts.Title: Phyllodes/sarcoma

Posts.Content: JustLittleMe you have had a MAJOR operation!  It will take time to get back to normal, even a new normal, so firstly you need patience. Secondly, as it's only a week, you are feeling the results of the anaesthetic leaving your body and you will probably be all over the place for the rest of the week.  Finally, be kind to yourself. Don't beat yourself up by trying to do too many things too soon.  Hope the operation has otherwise gone well.
Posts.Title: Recovery after mastectomy/diep

Posts.Content: Interesting. I also had a hysterectomy for fibroids a few years ago.  Although I still have my ovaries.
Posts.Title: Removal of ovaries

Posts.Content: Callie69 don't worry. Doctors often advise having a month's break to see if side effects lessen, so I'm sure a few days won't make any difference either way.  If you are concerned, you can ring the nurses on the helpline, 0808 808 0000, open today until 8pm (I think, not sure if they are closing early today, so sooner rather than later!) Merry Christmas, and I hope you are feeling better soon.
Posts.Title: Sickness bug / Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Crikey, ladies, you are all being so hard on yourselves - you've been through a LOT and you need to give yourselves a break!  Let it out, tell people, stop being strong - I don't think you'll surprise many people, in fact.  We're not always as good at hiding things as we think! GP's time may be limited but hell, they are well paid and you deserve as much of their time as you need.  Make sure they know it's a talking appointment, not just nipping in for some pills.  You will get a longer slot then.   I've not even had the chemo or RT, but there are days I could just howl for hours.  I'm trying not to too much, because it doesn't make me feel better (usually gives me a headache) but if I need to I do.  I think writing down how you feel helps, and if you can get some counselling, then do.  The NHS should offer you some.  I've had an offer which I thought I wouldn't bother with, but then this morning I thought you know, actually, I think I will.  I'll have a long drive to do it, but I'm worth it, right? H xxx
Posts.Title: So close to the end of treatment yet finding it so hard

Posts.Content: Fantastic. A reasonable request met with a reasonable reaction. Good luck with the job and the appointment.
Posts.Title: Looking Positive :)

Posts.Content: Hi Maria, I can only agree with the excellent advice that you have been given.  I'm glad that you are getting some counselling and I hope you are able to accept that none of this is your fault.  Don't be embarrassed about your mother,  she should frankly be ashamed of herself, but I always tell my kids if something upsets them,  don't get sad, get mad.  Fight back,  you have nothing to lose. Good luck with everything xxx
Posts.Title: Extended family have turned their back on me

Posts.Content: I think I know too. It really is a good feeling when you read these stories.
Posts.Title: The Macmillan Community - invaluable and a lifeline...

Posts.Content: Very true.  Im in Beds so if you fancy meeting up anytime, PM me or email helen.glanville@gmail.com.  Friend of mine is a counsellor but she's in Corby (anyone wanting her number let me know!).  She may know someone to recommend in Bucks - I'll ask.
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting Tina - I've been told I need a mastectomy on my right side and have asked for them to do the left one.  All been agreed now and I am just waiting for a date for surgery very soon.  I was having a bit of a wobble, but the reason for having them both done is precisely what you have said - I know that I would be like this, worrying about every tiny cyst or spot.   From what you've said, I think you could do with some counselling though - can you contact your BCN and ask them to recommend someone with experience in this field?   One other thing that you said about not burdening your family - a friend of mine is a counsellor and she said one of the biggest things she comes across is trying to shield the family from things which makes it harder on the patient.  Share your feelings with your family if you can and try to find someone who has been through this that you can chat too (because we all now know that you can't understand until you've been there).   For now, you have worries, but you know that you're on the road to recovery, and don't waste your life worrying about what may or may not happen in the future ... Helen.
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: Hi Karakeys and welcome to the forum.  Firstly you have done a great thing by joining this group at the beginning because lots of us waited until after everything had happened before we joined.  You will get all the support and information you need here. Secondly, the waiting is the pits.  You will find that once you have a defined treatment plan, things start to fall into place.  We all hated this period with a passion and I think being a control freak must be a precursor to breast cancer because we all hate the being out of control bit.  (That's a joke, although maybe there should be a study!).   The good news is that treatment is very doable.  OK, so it's not fun, or pleasant, but it is manageable. There are lots of hints and tips here, and when you are about to have your Chemo, which will probably be in October, keep an eye out for the October Chemo Club thread which will appear around 30th September.   I know that others will come along with their own comments and support but any questions please just fire away.
Posts.Title: Hi im newly diagnosed with invasive breast cancer, scared and looking...

Posts.Content: Congratulations!
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hello Calm15 I had a bilateral Mx with implants following a WLE and second op for margins (unsuccessful).  I wanted symmetry and the peace of mind from not having to check myself and find anything a second time.   I didn't know at the time that breast cancer can come back elsewhere in the body, but this is something that I now know, yet I would still make the same decision.  I am very happy with mine and I am complimented often! There is no sensation, however, and if this is important to you, investigate the uplift because I am not sure how much more you would have but it must be more than none.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy - Single or Double?

Posts.Content: No one is going to pretend that chemo is fun, but you know not everyone gets side effects and there are medications for any that you do get.  Fingers crossed you don't need it, I didn't, and they won't recommend it if you don't need it.
Posts.Title: Hi I've just been diagnosed with dcis I'm 31 and am awaiting an op...

Posts.Content: I agree with you, keyfeatures.  I had the same, and although I wasn't a particularly religious person before, I wasn't particularly anti either.  Live and let live.   But since my cancer, I'm now really atheist, and possibly humanist, and people saying they're praying for me winds me up.   So I suggest that religious people should perhaps wait for the patient to ask for prayers rather than insist on forcing them on others regardless.  If they wish to pray for someone, they can do it privately and not have to brag all about it.  Not at all helpful, IMO. Helen
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: I don't know the answer, but you should definitely speak to one of them.  I don't know if you can add ibuprofen or diclofenac gel?
Posts.Title: Advice on Pain Relief...

Posts.Content: Millyimp - I can't really help, other than to say read the labels, but I just avoid things that overtly contain soya, not the odd bit added here and there.   I think you have to take a view, sometimes, none of us are going to live forever, it's more important that your time is good quality of life, not length.  Surgery is the most useful tool in the cancer toolbox, then rads and chemo, then hormone therapy.   Everything in moderation.
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Hi Jane I know that this can be a side effect but I have had carpal tunnel myself and it's not nice.  Especially when you are constantly waking and getting exhausted. Mine was due to being hypothyroid, it's a known symptom, so worth getting a blood test for this.  If you get your test results and you are near the top of the range (but they say you are "normal"), keep on keeping on!
Posts.Title: Carpal tunnel syndrome

Posts.Content: It's especially worth having a thyroid panel if you've had chemo because when your system gets out of balance it can go haywire.  It's unfortunately very common, especially in post menopausal women,
Posts.Title: Carpal tunnel syndrome

Posts.Content: Hi Clare  I'm sorry to hear that you are still suffering with this after so long.  When you say the doctor, do you mean your GP? You might be better asking your BCN or oncologist because they may have better ideas.
Posts.Title: 2 months after chemo

Posts.Content: As always sensible advice from Dorothee! I wwould add that if you have 4 hours in the day then you won't need 8 at night.  Instead of having a day time nap have a break.  A cup of tea and half an hour with some crap tv. Or if you can't keep your eyes op set an alarm for half an hour or so and move when it goes off.  YYou need to readjust your sleep pattern because you will be tired in the day if you are not sleeping at night.  I found a tramadol at night helped me sleep.
Posts.Title: Getting better but can't sleep at night

Posts.Content: AngieD you need to ask the oncologist for the statistics. If you have a copy of your husband's medical notes, you could speak to one of our nurses on the free Macmillan helpline on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm. They will be closed over Easter but open on Tuesday.
Posts.Title: Decisions to make, all so overwhelming

Posts.Content: Hi Shaz, I suffered a lot of headaches on tamoxifen. It is a known side effect.  Do visit your GP to get checked out, it's what they are there for. They may be able to suggest options for you.
Posts.Title: Headaches

Posts.Content: Congratulations!
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Enjoy it, Denise! It sounds delightful! I've just had a day out at an Italian car and food festival - same thing  .... nearly!
Posts.Title: Just saying hello ....

Posts.Content: If you aren't already taking it, get some Vitamin D3 and K2 to take.  It may really help. Get quality products though, not the H&B or Boots ones.
Posts.Title: Joint pain update

Posts.Content: DoraD, your reconstruction should never have felt like that.  I am sorry that your surgeon dismissed you, you are the only one who knows how you feel. The arrogance of some cosmetic surgeons gets on my nerves. Mine was so pleased with himself, and when I got my implants over filled, it was my fault, apparently.  I am fine with them now, but it just took a few months for it to settle, and I don't think about them much.
Posts.Title: Fed up due to failed implant. Next steps help please?

Posts.Content: Hi.  None of us are keen on recurrence.  You don't say why you don't want reconstruction, but a friend of mine had nothing for a few years and finally got fed up with nothing fitting, and decided to go for it.  So that's something to bear in mind.  Plus unless you have a double Mx then there's always the option of recurrence.  They won't know if the nodes are affected unless they do a biopsy.  Reconstruction has come on in leaps and bounds - I don't know if they have discussed it with you at all, but there are many options available. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed, less problems than most, but need help with op decision...

Posts.Content: Cheekicow  People are odd, aren't they?  Perhaps they know someone that had it and didn't have any issues, or they saw something on TV and everyone continued as normal?   You just have to put a smiley face on and go along with it, because unless they've been there, they don't get it.  You can vent your feelings here!
Posts.Title: Loved ones' strange reaction

Posts.Content: Hi vjb I agree, there's always that nagging voice saying is it all gone, and will it come back?  That's why as I've now got to have a Mx after two operations, I've asked for the other one to be done for peace of mind.  That's my personal decision, but I know what I'm like, I'll constantly be wondering and although it's not a 100% guarantee, it's my best shot at this time, and I'm going to do everything I can to minimise future risk.   You're young and you've been through a lot already, but I would talk the symptoms through both with your oncologist and your GP and your BCN if you can.  It may be that they're completely unrelated and there's something else causing them!  I've got low thyroid and my symptoms started with pins and needles in my arms ....!
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: You can get the Cinnamon Trust to help with the dog short term, a charity that helps people with their pets in it and not just for the terminally ill! Also there is a site called Borrow my doggy that can match you up with someone who can walk the dog (for a small fee).
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi Boothl986 Sorry to hear that you have had this diagnosis but the good news is you found this site and we are all here to support you Breast cancer is very treatable and has a very good success rate. I was diagnosed over 6 years ago and I am still here!  I know lots of others will be right along to add their words of encouragement!
Posts.Title: Hi I've just been diagnosed with dcis I'm 31 and am awaiting an op...

Posts.Content: Funnily enough, everyone says that about me, how I'm a strong person, how I'm able to cope with stuff, but if that's so why am I spending so much time in tears?  And if I'm strong, how are the weak able to cope?  I truly believe that only we who are going through it can understand truly how it affects us.
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: Fabulous, littlesusie!   For you and AliG58
Posts.Title: Another Neddy passes the finish post!

Posts.Content: Hi VJB - sorry it's taken me a while - firstly it just took a while and secondly I forgot who asked the question but have done a search and found this thread again! You were asking for counsellors in the High Wycombe area.  I asked my friend for a recommendation and she said not quite that area, but if you can get to Oxford,  she really recommends someone called Michael Soth.  You can google his clinic.   Hope this helps - I know it's a way to travel, but she assures me that he is excellent and would have no hesitation recommending him. Helen
Posts.Title: emotional after effects

Posts.Content: The sentinel node is the one nearest to the cancer.  The blue dye if used is injected into the tumour and goes to the sentinel node.  The surgeon takes it out (there may be a few) and the tissue is biopsied.  If cancer is found in the nodes they usually clear the rest as a precaution.  It doesn't mean it has spread, it means that the nodes have trapped cells from moving into the body.   As a side issue, chemo is usually recommended as added insurance.
Posts.Title: Sentinel node - what is it exactly????

Posts.Content: I had glue and dissolving stitches too. The scar was very neat.   You probably feel down because of the anaesthetic in your system which can make you feel depressed and negative. If you can keep busy focus on the positive, you will find it much easier to bear.
Posts.Title: Feeling anxious....what can i expect?

Posts.Content: Hi Carole I'm sorry to hear that you have received this blow. As Julia has said, there are others here who have had this happen to them and are living their lives with good new medication that has show great results.  You have secondary breast cancer rather than bone cancer, it's breast cancer that has spread to the bones, rather than a new cancer (At least this is my understanding from what you have said, but do check with your team).  The drug is denosumab, although I think there are various options.   Hopefully one of the ladies will be along soon to tell you all about their experiences.
Posts.Title: Breast to bone?

Posts.Content: Hi Scoobytwolips I haven't had that myself but I do know a few people that have had necrosis like this.  The surgeon will want to operate again, I suspect, to remove all the affected tissue.  I don't know if they removed your nipple and reattached it, it sounds most likely from what you said, but a new nipple can be formed from the skin as well.  At this point, I think it's rather academic, you need all this tissue removed and cleaned, a course of antibiotics, and a clean wound.  If you are still keen on a nipple after all this, you could have a 3D-areola tattoo that gives the appearance of a nipple without further operations. Be prepared to have a quick stay in hospital in the next day or two.
Posts.Title: Hello,failed nipple reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa What reconstruction did you have?  You can either wear a sports bra or crop top, or you can wear a normal unwired bra.  You should avoid wired bras.
Posts.Title: Which bra after surgery?

Posts.Content: Flamazine is a cooling cream that is used for burns. It is safe to use for radiotherapy and is often given out by radiotherapy units. It's a shame that your hospital didn't recommend you starting with R1 and R2 creams as this seems to avoid the problem, but not every NHS area has got up to speed with it.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy burns & blisters

Posts.Content: I had a reconstruction, so never bought mastectomy bras, but do remember that you can reclaim the VAT on mastectomy bras. Ask the shop for a form to complete while you are there.
Posts.Title: Pretty post mastectomy bras????

Posts.Content: You're a star,  George.
Posts.Title: Full Range of Breast Cancer Related Books To Read/Download

Posts.Content: Great news! I'll keep an eye out. Contrary to previous statement keep your scars out of the sun for six months or they won't fade.
Posts.Title: Nearly there

Posts.Content: A68, I am sorry that you have had to find us, but you will find it's one of the best things you could have done.  So far we know that they have noticed changes in your breast but no one has mentioned cancer. They always deliver results in person, good or bad, imagine only ever giving bad news? Finally  if  and it's still a big if, you have cancer  then it has been found and it is treatable. Obviously we all hope that it's a cyst  but if not, let us know what they say and we'll help you through the next steps.  It's not fun, but it's doable.
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results and have had appointment letter .

Posts.Content: Is it worth asking about the Oncotype Dx test? It may say that chemo wouldn't be beneficial.
Posts.Title: Dreading results

Posts.Content: Great news, Bev!  So pleased for you!  Plan something nice for when you are feeling back on top of things!
Posts.Title: yahooo

Posts.Content: Congratulations, Kipper!  And after all this, I think radiotherapy is a walk in the park, so bite the bullet and you will be able to tell yourself that you have done everything possible to kick the beastie into touch! :) Helen
Posts.Title: Some good news!

Posts.Content: If you are thinking about St John's Wort, don't do it.  I think it interacts with other things and unless it's the only thing you are taking, it can be dangerous.   I would go back to your GP and ask what you can take.  It seems to me that your oncologist is being very shortsighted, because you are going to crash badly.  Lack of oestrogen (which is what the tamoxifen does) can cause depression and if you are already prone, then you need some other help.   I know that my GP had a note on the file that said do not prescribe SSSIs due to Tamoxifen but there are other types of anti-depressants.  Hope he can help.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: I'm sure that lots of ladies here are taking citalopram and tamoxifen.  If they knew that it was reducing the effectiveness by 40%, I'm sure that they would be very worried!   Where did you get this information?
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: Right, I've just had a VERY quick check and I'm no doctor, but the other meds don't decrease the effectiveness, but they do have other side effects, usually heart irregularities, although they are not necessarily applicable to everyone.   Have a read of this and perhaps see if you are able to make a judgement call?   Do you have the statistics with and without tamoxifen?
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: I truly hope that you haven't got IBC. But at least you are to be seen asap. Unfortunately there isn't always a rhyme or reason to who gets what when, so much aa I would love to say it's impossible, the truth is that until you are seen, no one will really know. IBC symptoms can be the same as cellulitis so I have everything crossed for you. Do please keep us posted. We are all with you.
Posts.Title: Awake and scared

Posts.Content: Congratulations, Badgerset , first hurdle over!  Enjoy your cake!
Posts.Title: WLE and SNB, check!

Posts.Content: Great news, Ali! Hope you have some fizz on ice!
Posts.Title: Another Neddy passes the finish post!

Posts.Content: That's no problem, I was given one bra by the hospital, it was an Anita (can't remember the brand) which came with a strap to keep the implants from rising. I don't know if you have been given one of these? FYI, I now have quite a few Ann Summers bras and they are really comfortable!
Posts.Title: Which bra after surgery?

Posts.Content: Tracy I'm not surprised you are at the end of your tether. Any one would be with all that to cope with, without the stress of worrying about cancer returning.   I do feel that you need help now, both practical and psychological. You have already said that you are going to contact help the aged which is great.  There is also age concern and social services.  You shouldn't try to do all of this on your own.   As for you, I think it would be a good idea to talk to your gp. It sounds as though you need some counselling, and possibly something to calm you in the short term while you are waiting.  The fact that you are posting here shows that you recognise you need help which is the first step to getting it!  I hhope you can get an early appointment and start to feel better soon.  HHelen
Posts.Title: im so tired can someone help me please.

Posts.Content: You poor things both of you - have you compared notes as to where this happened?  It could be that you're at the same hospital and they've got an incompetent doing the chemo?  (Certainly looks that way).   I really hope you both start to feel better soon.  Oh and sue their arses off ... :D  It's not good enough, especially when they've been told.   H
Posts.Title: ghastly chemo injury

Posts.Content: Thinking now is that five years on your risk is back to before diagnosis.  Personally as I have had a double Mx with implants I don't get any scans/mammos/ultrasounds, and they just look and feel.  I can look and feel as much as they can.  So next year they will send me on my way.   It can be a scary thought to be released to the wild, but they are always there if you have any concerns, you are in the system.
Posts.Title: mammogram results?

Posts.Content: Kismet Eye problems ARE a side effect of Tamoxifen, unfortunately.  My oncologist said that most people's eyes recover when they stop taking them, which obviously means that some people's don't!  Mine haven't been the same and I stopped taking it after about two years.   Keep an eye on your eyes and if you are unsure refer back to your oncologist.
Posts.Title: Letrozole from Manx healthcare

Posts.Content: Hi Helen I can't help with the chemo question, but I would suggest if they're bites then they are incidental!  Have you had a new pet?  Visiting animals?  Or if there is a bird nest outside your window, it could be bugs from there (my stepmother had this).  Give the support line a ring as well for more help? Helen
Posts.Title: BUG BITES

Posts.Content: Hi Susan If the Piriton doesn't work, then it may be worth taking a different type of antihistamine.  I haven't had this myself, so I can't be sure if it's an allergic reaction but it seems likely.
Posts.Title: Allergic reaction??

Posts.Content: o focus on the good and let go of hating other people's bodies, they aren't being smug, they are just fortunate and we were there too a few weeks or months or years ago - showing our breasts in bikinis or whatever - that wasn't being smug ...just living ...life goes on after losing one or two breasts. But it's a choice whether you sink or swim....i KNOW where I am Nail on the head, Sassy.  Totally agree with everything you have said.
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Judith - it doesn't surprise me that the consultant didn't know. Their training is woefully inadequate, and they really don't do their own research.  Did you get your K2?  I really notice if I don't take mine.
Posts.Title: Joint pain update

Posts.Content: Hi Jemima  I just wanted to pop in and say that I was diagnosed almost 5 years ago. I am 52 and fit and healthy, doing two jobs, have horses and dogs as well as being here.  Once you start talking about it, it is amazing how many people you know have had and survival cancer. Apart from the practical stuff, the best thing you can do for your mum is to get the best degree you can. It may be a tough year but you can do it.
Posts.Title: Mum diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Oh Binny, sometimes it feels like two steps forward and one back, doesn't it?!  You can try reaching up on to the top of a door and letting the weight of your body hang, which is painful while you are doing it, but it can work. I fell off my horse and held onto the rein and pulled mine and it definitely helped, but I don't recommend it as a treatment!  It's worth ringing the hospital, and saying that your condition needs emergency treatment and you will take a cancellation.  Also make sure you get a physio that specialises in Cording because a lot of them don't know what it is. Good luck!   PS I'm still hear 2.5 years later ... :)
Posts.Title: Help Needed.

Posts.Content: Unfortunately you can still get it at any time after if you have the operation.  If you have had it you can get it again so be careful and don't overuse the arm.  If you have it properly popped by a physio then the links are broken and I think it's less likely - exercises aren't really enough to completely break the cords.
Posts.Title: Help Needed.

Posts.Content: Definitely one for your GP or oncologist.  Please get checked asap.
Posts.Title: Chemo induced menopause and then .....

Posts.Content: Lou I'm so sorry to hear about your mum.  It's so hard to be the carer and not the patient, you know.  It is scary because you're not in control and you can't make any decisions.  But she's being well looked after by your dad and all the medical team, and you just have to be there as often as you can until she goes.  She'll appreciate it, and so will your Dad.  You are doing everything you can, and thank you for running for Macmillan.
Posts.Title: Mum's secondary breast cancer

Posts.Content: I think you have no choice unless you decide not to have the recon.  Trying to do a recon using tissue that has been radiated isn't going to be any easier to do than using existing healthy tissue and then radiating it. I was told that having implants and then RT would mean a much greater chance of capsulation.  The consultant PS I saw the other day kept asking had I had RT or chemo when he was giving me my options.   At the end of the day, it's an impossible decision.  I have to make one too and I really am in about 12 minds about it!
Posts.Title: Immediate reconstruction followed by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm sorry you find yourself in this position. There are a few members here who have been in your position.  I'm sure they'll be along in due course to support you. This is a busy group, and I am sure you will find help and support for your own cancer and any questions, please post away. I hope you will find lots of support if you just give us more than half an hour.
Posts.Title: All about face!

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy I wouldn't try to second guess it, although something like Hodgkins or non-Hodgkins is nagging at my brain.   Do call the nurses, but remember that they have caught things early again, and hopefully will be able to treat it effectively.  Helen
Posts.Title: Help please enlarged lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Hi Lindsey Anne Firstly take some deep breaths.  And welcome to the group that none of us wanted to join.  The reason we all seem strong is that IF you end up with a cancer diagnosis, it isn't a death sentence.  Breast cancer is definitely the one to get if you are going to have one.  Survival rates are amazing, and the treatments are all doable with various medication and painkillers along the way. There is no point in dwelling on the what ifs. What if I went to the doctor earlier.  What if I die.  What if .... etc etc.  Deal with it one step at a time.  One treatment at a time, if it turns out that's what you need.  You will, if you look, see a post from today from someone who was worried like you and it has turned out to be nothing.  And another from someone's husband.  So there's always the chance that you are the 50/50 that turns out to be nothing.   Also, one thing I like to keep in mind - all the things you worried about that never happened .. they just took up the time when you could be enjoying life and having fun.  Try to remember that! Good luck with your tests, and if you need us we'll be here.
Posts.Title: Breast thickening and further tests

Posts.Content: Hi Gina Yes, it's perfectly normal to a) feel like this and b) not get results until after surgery.  Biopsies only take a very small sample of tissue, so they only get a snapshot of what is going on.  Following surgery they will be examining everything very carefully. I liken it to queuing up for the rollercoaster, being pushed on and hating every second.  When you finally get off, you are a bit disorientated, but you do come round.  Good luck for your op, are they offering reconstruction?
Posts.Title: It's confirmed.....cancer

Posts.Content: Good luck for today and well done for not googling. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Awake and scared

Posts.Content: Companies hate it when you complain on their Social Media.  Especially Twitter, so try tweeting @marksandspencer and see how you go!
Posts.Title: Pretty post mastectomy bras????

Posts.Content: Baki even if you have a recurrence there are still lots of treatments you can have.  Your son needs his mum,  hang on to that.   Good luck for the PET scan
Posts.Title: Devastated breast cancer recurrence

Posts.Content: A68, I am sorry that you have had to find us, but you will find it's one of the best things you could have done.  So far we know that they have noticed changes in your breast but no one has mentioned cancer. They always deliver results in person, good or bad, imagine only ever giving bad news? Finally  if  and it's still a big if, you have cancer  then it has been found and it is treatable. Obviously we all hope that it's a cyst  but if not, let us know what they say and we'll help you through the next steps.  It's not fun, but it's doable.
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy results and have had appointment letter .

Posts.Content: Hi Isingbass It's such a shock, and yes, we have all been through it, but it does get easier once you know the treatment plan.  You may find that your team become more sympathetic once they know what you are up against.  If not, you can find another surgeon and ask your GP to send you a referral, but it would delay things somewhat, so you may wish to consider this carefully.   If you have a high degree of family occurrence then as Julia says, it's well worth getting a BRCA gene test done.   We are all here to support you, so ask any questions that occur to you, and know that 90% of all breast cancer patients are still here 5 years later (figures are not available for longer), and of the other 10%, there are either other health reasons, old age, or late diagnosis.  You're in a scary place right now, the waiting is the worst part, but once you get your treatment plan things move quickly and you can start to see the light at the end of the tunnel.
Posts.Title: DCIS - hospital /surgeon choice / advice please ?

Posts.Content: It does sound like cording to me. It can happen anytime after surgery although immediately (within a few months) is more common. Get a referral to a specialist physio who can "pop" the cords. It's instant relief, and I've never had a problem with mine since they were popped!
Posts.Title: Cording 15 months after surgery!

Posts.Content: Why would you come off tamoxifen to take anti-depressants?  You can take them both?
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: That's good news.  There's a whole list at the bottom of that article, so you don't have to read all the medical stuff to get to the point.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi Jellytot I didn't have chemo, but I have read a good few posts after the 5th one where people feel really down, so I suspect this is the cause of most of your feeling low.   You might feel that you haven't had much interaction with your Onc, but be assured that you are in the system, and will be discussed at all the meetings.  and don't forget, you don't have to wait for them to contact you - ring your BCN even if it's just for a chat, that's what they're here for, they don't mind talking and putting your mind at rest.   And you're right, the girl in the blog isn't you, but you can identify and empathise.  We all have these moments where we feel that things are bleak, we're going to die, and leave our families behind.  But for the vast majority of us, the reality is that we will live to ripe old ages, and live to terrorise our families in our dotage ... at least, that's what I'm planning to do :) I don't know whether your OH would have locked the door, but I would have gone in and just hugged him if not.  Keep talking to each other, perhaps bring up that you heard him, and let him talk about his feelings - I think sometimes it's harder to be the relative than the patient.  Here's a long distance virtual (((((((hug)))))) for you - now take it and hug your OH right now .... :D Helen x
Posts.Title: Feeling Low

Posts.Content: I really hope that this is a temporary thing and that your body will eventually recover.  However, for nerve pain, you need something like carbemazepine, gabapentin or others.  They are specific to nerves.  You don't say what you are given, but these are the type of drug to insist upon.  Although they will probably make you sleepy at least they do help with the pain.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: unbearable pain

Posts.Content: It's not science, but going from the posts on here, I'd say that the biggest cause of breast cancer is either being a control freak or being indispensable.  So many people here are one or the other!  So time to learn to let go, allow others to do things and stop being a perfectionist! This is a bit tongue in cheek, but not completely.
Posts.Title: Having a mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne  I think it's time to make a stink.  You have been messed around enough.  I would either visit your GP and get them to chase things up, or if you don't have a good relationship with him, then ring your BCN and mention that you are looking into making a complaint to PALS.  That normally does the trick.  Good luck and hope you get a date soon.
Posts.Title: Fed up, still waiting

Posts.Content: I remember someone saying that they had their tumour removed after chemo and although it hadn't shrunk, all the cells were dead.  So don't be disheartened.
Posts.Title: Can't tell if its growing or shrinking

Posts.Content: First stop googling, even on here if it's making you this worried.   Secondlly, dose yourself up with enough painkillers that your boob doesn't hurt.   Thirdly, this is the place to rant and scream, talk about your worries, and you know deep down that all these "What ifs" are not helping you at all.  I nearly cried reading your post, and just wanted to hug you - it WILL be OK, even if there are other things going on, there are so many different treatments that you can have.  Eat that elephant one teaspoon at a time ..... ((((((((((((((((((((((hugs)))))))))))))))))))))))) Helen  PS - I can tile your bathroom but I don't know where you are!
Posts.Title: Feel like I am back at square one

Posts.Content: Why do we say yes when we mean no!  RRattle some cages.  The booking person obviously didn't realise that it wasn't your fault you missed the appointment or the significance of a delay.  The administration side of my hospital was horrendous and just piles on extra stress!
Posts.Title: What a palaver!

Posts.Content: Oh I see.  Do keep us posted then.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: Exactly right.  Quality over quantity.  And there are no guarantees.  You could take it and get a recurrence, you could not take it and not get one.  Or vice versa.   Citalopram and tamoxifen can cause heart palpitations, but as long as you are aware and go to the doctor if there are signs, then I guess it's like any other side effect.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen advice needed

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlercrab  I totally understand this feeling. I was totally p***ed off with them not telling me that they would put the implant under the muscle (no strattice here), and they still flex when normal pectoral muscles would, when brushing my teeth, for example.   They gave us a silicone implant to feel and said it would feel like that.  no, it doesn't, it feels solid as the muscle is what you can feel.   HOWEVER. The good news is that the muscle DOES soften.  I used to be aware of my implants 24/7 when I first had them.  it took about 8 months to make friends with them and about a year later I had permanent tattoo nipples done.  It took me this time to work out whether I was going to have a DIEP flap or not.   Anyway, keep on exercising, don't over do it, though, and you will get there.
Posts.Title: Just how impatient am I being?

Posts.Content: Hi missavis and Debbie1949  I'm sorry that you have to face breast cancer again.  Cancer in the other breast can be a new primary or a recurrence of the first cancer.  Do you know which yours is?  Either way, you have beaten it once, and you will do it again.   This forum is great for help and support, any questions or just plain rants, just let it out.
Posts.Title: Hi I am so so sad today my breast cancer is back

Posts.Content: GPs are naturally cautious, but you can have topical oestrogen creams.  If your GP is concerned, either ask your oncologist, or get him to check with them.   I was prescribed Gynest cream, which is acceptable (not all are).  I was ER+.
Posts.Title: Letrazole side effect

Posts.Content: People who haven't been where you are will dismiss your fears because unless you have been through it, you just don't know. You think you can empathise, but you honestly don't know the fear.  And without wishing to make your worries worse, breast pain was how I found my cancer.  So it can be a symptom.  But all that said, try to keep busy with things that occupy your mind as well as your hands. It might be worth getting something from the GP (Tamazepam?) or similar to take the edge of your anxiety.  Just as a temporary thing.  We're still here.
Posts.Title: Breast thickening and further tests

Posts.Content: That sounds better.  Glad you got sorted out.
Posts.Title: Hello,failed nipple reconstruction

Posts.Content: I've managed my 10,000 steps AND I've used a hand bike for the first time ever!  I was invited to take part in a spinal study on the link between a sedentary lifestyle and cardiac problems in people with back problems which covers everyone from paraplegics to people with a bit of a niggle (like me!).  Most steps were done walking the dogs, and a bit walking around the university and Sainsburys, but all count! Keep going, everyone!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Flamazine is a cooling cream that is used for burns. It is safe to use for radiotherapy and is often given out by radiotherapy units. It's a shame that your hospital didn't recommend you starting with R1 and R2 creams as this seems to avoid the problem, but not every NHS area has got up to speed with it.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy burns & blisters

Posts.Content: I got lots of steps in yesterday because we parked a distance from the venuv we thought our gig was at. It was at a ddifferen veven, so we had to walk more and then after the gig  walked back!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Anna I had the same as Janice, immediate recon with expanders although my were intended to be permanent.  They're not going to be, but that's another issue.  In all honesty, I could have managed a couple of toddlers who'd been well briefed in advance that they had to help mummy and be good for a few weeks.   If I were you, I'd have the immediate recon.  RT is the thing that really affects tissue, so having had the recon in advance will give you the benefit of healing before treatment.   What part of the world are you in?  Is there anyone here would be able to offer to help out?
Posts.Title: Immediate reconstruction followed by radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I forgot to add that mine was very early stage too!  So it seems that pain is good!
Posts.Title: Breast thickening and further tests

Posts.Content: Looks great, Denise!   I'm sure that a different style does take getting used to, but honestly, I think it suits you!
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: Silvercloud it sounds as though you know what you want to do  You need the reassurance that you have done everything you can to prevent recurrence. Chemo isn't fun but it is doable. There are plenty of ladies here who have gone through it and they will help you with hints and tips.  Now I would call your BCN and see if you can ask the questions in your mind and maybe get an earlier appointment.  Good luck
Posts.Title: Making the right decision

Posts.Content: Must be a big weight off your shoulders. Well done.
Posts.Title: Feeling in control...........

Posts.Content: @charcor  firstly, welcome to the community, and I'm sorry you have had to wait for an answer, we are still having some technical difficulties following a recent upgrade (can't believe it was actually 4 months ago and we're still having problems!) It's very hard to know what is the best answer for your mum, because we are all different. But in general, surgery is believed to be the best solution to beating cancer. Surgery is relatively straightforward, and if your mum is in otherwise good health, she should survive it without issue. Obviously if she has memory problems, depending on the severity , that may have a bearing on the decision. Be guided by your mum's medical team and trust them to put her interests first  but be prepared to advocate for her too.
Posts.Title: Any advice for worried daughter.

Posts.Content: KEM63  I'm sorry to hear that you are both struggling after treatment. Your husband might find it helpful to join our friends and family group here, it helps just to know there are others in the same position and share tips on how to cope. For yourself, I hope this group will help you   You don't say if it's physical or emotional support that you need, but you could call our helpline on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm and see if they can suggest anything you may qualify for
Posts.Title: Deminishing support

Posts.Content: Suze - cancer patients are covered by the DIsability Act. Please phone the helpline and ask their advice on this, and perhaps if you explain to the new job they will find someone to fill in until February? If you don't ask, you don't get.
Posts.Title: Hi ... and help please!!

Posts.Content: Hey, Little boo boo  I didn't have nipple reconstruction, but I did have 3D nipple tattoos.  I had mine done at Adrenalin in Luton, they specialise   Any q, just ask. Pic attached
Posts.Title: Permanent nipple tattoo with implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Mogal129 I'm similar to you, found in one breast early stage and have had double mx - no other treatment - but am now on Tamoxifen.  I was told that I could take it or not, it doesn't increase my chances by more than 1% so I gave it a go.  So far (I've been on it for nearly 4 months) I've not noticed any side effects.  I'd already had a hysterectomy, so that's one side effect I couldn't get!  I'm 48. My suggestion would be to start taking it and see if you get any symptoms.  If you don't, all well and good!  If life becomes miserable on it, then you can make an informed choice to stop if you want to.   Hope this helps Helen
Posts.Title: Anastrozole - to take or not?

Posts.Content: Hi LJ-star All of your feelings are normal and natural.  We are all scared of the unknown, and watching things happen to our loved ones is almost harder than going through things yourself.  Giving patients choices is difficult.  If your mum can bear the chemo and doesn't have other health problems then it is probably a good idea to give it a go.  But the side effects aren't to be sneezed at, so I can understand if she is hesitant.   The oncologists can give statistics for either treatment to help make up her mind, and at the end of the day whatever she decides it is her decision, and you must support her.  You need to talk to your family, not talking is a recipe for disaster sooner or later.  For some reason cancer is still one of the last taboos, we are frightened of it, so we don't discuss it.  I make a point of talking about it whenever necessary so that it becomes normal.  I used to be frightened of people with cancer before I had it myself, so I do understand how it can feel.   What you must not do is worry.  It is a waste of time, and just robs you of today while you worry about things that may not even happen tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Newbie - feeling useless

Posts.Content: I know you will be very worried. I am sorry that your GP was not as tactful as she might be but from the symptoms you describe she probably has cause for concern.  The good news is that if you do get a breast cancer diagnosis then you should know that it is very treatable these days. Once you have your results do come back to us and let us know how you got on.
Posts.Title: "Suspected Breast Cancer"

Posts.Content: Christina100  Welcome to the community from me too.  Please don't go on Google, there is a lot of information but much of it is out of date and the rest is plain wrong!  Stick to the reputable sites like this, cancer research and breast cancer care. And don't waste today worrying about tomorrow. The chances are that you will be fine, it never does any harm to have things in order, but honestly, the likelihood is that you aren't going anywhere! Once you have the treatment plan, you will start to feel more in control. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer stage 3

Posts.Content: Any honey is particularly good for healing skin.  If the manuka honey is too grainy, get some clear honey.  Anything will do.  Then put some plastic over it so it doesn't go everywhere.
Posts.Title: dry peeling sore skin

Posts.Content: In the first instance, I would call your BCN.  GPs tend not to be good at these things,  and I think the BCN will have more idea although if you have a good GP, then it may be worth going.   Definitely don't leave it though.
Posts.Title: SWOLLEN FEET AND ANKLES

Posts.Content: Hi Dendy Do you have ER+ or PR+ cancer?  Or HER2+?  if none of the above, and you are triple negative (TN), then it does have a higher risk of recurrence, unfortunately, but that doesn't mean that you have no hope.   It does mean that you don't have to take Tamoxifen and/or Letrozole, so don't have the side effects that go with those, but you have to be vigilant about any pain or lumps that you may find.   I would check with your BCN if this is the case and we can give you more information.
Posts.Title: reacurrance

Posts.Content: Yes, kathleen37, that's where I went.  Unfortunately Richard, who did mine, sadly died a year or two ago, but he trained up Marek to do the 3D tattoos.  I know he has done some good work, worth giving them a call.
Posts.Title: Breast tattoo

Posts.Content: Sounds like negligence then to me.  Might you be able to have a different type of reconstruction, such as LD flap?   I went to the Royal Marsden in Chelsea for a second opinion - they were very helpful and informative.  I highly recommend them.  I do understand about scar tissue being an issue - radiotherapy can change the consistency of the skin and it does make things difficult.
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Val36 there is something like a 10% risk of chemotherapy doing more harm than good so if the chance of recurrence is 5% then it looks like a no brainer, don't you think
Posts.Title: What to do for the best

Posts.Content: Hi Alexandra Sorry to hear you got an infection, but these things happen sometimes.  Keep an eye on the area, but if you are seeing the surgeon Wednesday that should be fine.  If your underarm starts to feel like you have a rope under it, you have developed cording and will need to see your BCN for a referral to a specialist physio.  The GP has to do the referral, but you will need to be directed to the right person.  Keep doing the exercises as much as you can, because it really does help. Helen
Posts.Title: Post op infection

Posts.Content: Hi sue62  Firstly, don't worry about rambling, we are here to listen! I think the shakes are probably the steroids, but I strongly recommend you ring your chemo unit tomorrow and let them know how you are feeling. It may be that your meds need tweaking, or you need something else to help.  It's very normal to be teary, so just be gentle on yourself.
Posts.Title: Shakes and tears

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that you are struggling, Strong96. Definitely see your oncologist, as it isn't any good swapping one set of problems for another.  As for the cysts, you need to have them checked out.  Give your BCN a call and get an appointment for a scan just to check there isn't anything worrying going on. Have a good weekend while you wait.
Posts.Title: problem with everything

Posts.Content: I hope you managed to contact your bcn.  I don't know about chemo but it could be that or lymphodaema causing the swelling.  Either way it needs checking out.   Hope Iit improves soon
Posts.Title: swollen arm

Posts.Content: Make sure you read the small print!  But we found something with insureandgo which was a similar amount.  We went for an annual policy as we travel a lot.
Posts.Title: Holiday insurance Nowicantravel.co.uk

Posts.Content: Great news!  Please go out now and enjoy life!!!
Posts.Title: Fantastic News and thank you

Posts.Content: Canton there are lots of options.  Your best bet is to visit keepingabreast dot org which will explain the various options. Not everyone is suitable for every type, and not every surgeon can do every operation either, but if you are suitable, you can always find someone who can do the one you choose.
Posts.Title: Following Mastectomy and Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Irish Girl Definitely agree with Julia, push for more information and an appointment.  If you get nowhere, get your GP to chase things up for you.
Posts.Title: Feeling list

Posts.Content: Wow, Tinkers, when I remember when you first came here you've truly blossomed! So glad for you, enjoy your birthday!
Posts.Title: Finished my treatment today!

Posts.Content: Hi Lou Were you given a strap to wear over the top of your expander when you first got it?  This is precisely to stop this sort of thing happening.  It is a known issue, which is why the strap is important.   I would ask if your surgeon could reposition the expander before you have it filled.  There doesn't seem much point expanding it in the wrong place as the wrong skin would be expanded.  Was it a temporary expander, or a permanent one?
Posts.Title: breast expander has moved

Posts.Content: Just to add to Lynn's advice,  if you have any concerns get a GP appointment (same day), call your chemo hotline or get to A&E because pulmonary embolisms can be life threatening.
Posts.Title: Swollen legs and feet??

Posts.Content: Pollyp - obviously being pushed and pulled about has unsettled something.  It may or may not be anything to worry about, but please call your BCN in the morning and explain what has happened, as you obviously need reassurance if it is nothing or treatment if it is.
Posts.Title: Reddening of breast 4 weeks after op.

Posts.Content: Hi Wearymum I'm sorry to hear that you have to go through all this sh*t again.  They will look again at the "clear" mammo to see if they missed anything, but I had a clear mammo in Oct 2010 and was diagnosed in Aug 2011, so it does happen.  I  believe you only have rads once in any given area, so that's why you won't have it again.   As you have been through treatment once, you will know what to expect.  One slightly good bit of news is that the Mx itself is relatively painless, so that's something.   I have everything crossed for a good outcome for you.
Posts.Title: Recurrence

Posts.Content: I'm definitely up for it. I seem to have muted this thread though, accidentally *facepalm* H x
Posts.Title: Amazonian Warriors - Challenge - Who wants to be in a calendar ??

Posts.Content: Hi Pam Breast reconstruction is something that many of us have had here.  I don't know what sort of advice you are looking for, do you have anything in particular you would like to know? You can get more information by visiting the KeepingAbreast website which has information on the various types, and if there is a group near you it is worth a trip to meet the ladies who have had surgery, see the results and talk to them about their experiences.   Macmillan also have information that you can read here.  If you have any specific questions, please ask away.
Posts.Title: breast replacement surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy Sorry to hear about the BRCA1 results.   I suspect that the bowel being moved and the anaesthetic being still in your system are both playing a part.  If you can manage some gentle upright exercise, such as walking, you will probably find things settle down but if you are at all worried or symptoms change then do go back to them - there are occasionally repercussions from surgery, and don't be fobbed off.
Posts.Title: Risk reducing surgery after BRCA1 positive result - concerns of symptoms...

Posts.Content: That's OK, nobody reads terms and conditions!  It's for your own protection although the risk is small, there are thousands of members, we do get spammers and there are programmes that troll the Internet for email addresses.
Posts.Title: Scintigraphy

Posts.Content: I've lived in support camisoles since I had my reconstruction!  I do have bras, and they are fine, but I just don't really need them anymore since I had implants!  Anyway, your boob will change shape/size as the swelling goes down, so there is no point trying to be prepared for this. Wait until everything has settled before you go spending money.   Lipomodelling can be very successful but it tends to be a repeat process as the body will absorb some of the added fat, so you need to top up until you get it right, and of course, if you lose weight, you lose it from there as well as other places.  Implants have a bad reputation, but I'm really pleased with mine.
Posts.Title: Bras post reconstruction

Posts.Content: I think you're right, we try to smile and look like we're just getting on with things, and people say oh you're so brave when frankly we have no choice.  I like your comment though.  What a bitch!
Posts.Title: How to make a woman going through chemo feel so much better...

Posts.Content: Congratulations, you guys!  Life does get better and I think you appreciate it more,   Have a great day - hope yo have a better day planned this year. l
Posts.Title: It's our anniversary today

Posts.Content: Congratulations Yvonne, and good luck for the last one!
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: If you feel you would like a second opinion, you would have to go to your GP and ask for a referral.  They will then meet you and have to ask your current consultant for the notes to date. I don't know about the medical stuff I'm afraid, but you could try calling the nurses on the site on Monday.
Posts.Title: worried about misdiagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi bat  It is possible that it could be hereditary.  But the only way to know is to have a genetic test.  I am not sure whether HER2 indicates a genetic fault or not.  But you can ask to be referred to a genetic counsellor who will take you through the options and go through the family tree to see if a test is indicated.  You could also try calling the free helpline here on 0808 808 0000, Monday to Friday, 9am to 8pm and speak to one of the nurses about it.
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed too

Posts.Content: I would suggest you ask your GP or midwife.  Maybe they can advise you.  In the meantime, congratulations on twins!!!!
Posts.Title: Advice needed breastfeeding / double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Hobbs I wish I'd known it was possible to request copy letters from the hospital, I paid £45 to get copies from my GP! I would question this, they are not allowed to profiteer from you, they are only allowed to charge for the actual cost of printing and a small amount for administration.
Posts.Title: Hospital letters

Posts.Content: Don't scream at us, scream at him!  Lazy beggar!!!
Posts.Title: Husband response - not that interested?!

Posts.Content: It may help if you have some statistics.  The number one treatment for breast cancer is surgery. You've had that and the cancer is gone, all being well.  90% of breast cancer patients are around 5 years after diagnosis. You are going to be one of them. I am here five years on.  Now if you spend your time weeping and wailing, that's what your family will remember. I really do not think it's helping you either, so get down and spend precious time with your family.  There is nothing anyone can do until your results are in, so give your kindle to your husband and forget it as much as possible. You're not going to die (well, you know, not yet or for a good while!)
Posts.Title: Depressed

Posts.Content: There are lots of posts here regarding dental treatments after cancer. Type dental treatment into the search box, I'm sure you will find lots of experiences.
Posts.Title: Teeth after treatments

Posts.Content: Hi Bellee I had the same, and I think it took about 6 weeks for mine to feel anything like normal.  I didn't have strattice though, they put mine under the muscle, I'm not sure if they do this when they use strattice, although I now feel that they should have done this, as I have some rippling where it isn't under the muscle.   I also find that my left one "slips" to the side if I lay on my back or left side, and becomes painful after a while.  I had mine done at the end of November - mostly they are liveable with now. Helen
Posts.Title: implant question

Posts.Content: At least you know now, and things are getting sorted.   I don't know all the technicalities, but if they're saying it's good then it's good.  Only a week to go and it will be gone, so hang on to the positives!
Posts.Title: good news and bad news....

Posts.Content: Hi @rockfan Give your children the link to riprap www.riprap.org.uk (sorry, stupid phone won't tag or do links Jess E - MacmillanAdmin) It's for teenagers with parents with cancer and they can go online or chat to each other or a specialist.
Posts.Title: New to online community

Posts.Content: Taking hormone therapy or not is a personal choice. But it does depend on lots of factors.  Age at diagnosis is one. Statistics and type of cancer another.  I gave up tamoxifen but there was a 1% difference for me so it wasn't much of a difference.
Posts.Title: Side effects of medication

Posts.Content: I had a double mastectomy for the same reason you want one, not to have the fear of recurrence in the other breast.  I didn't realise at the time that breast cancer can come back elsewhere in the body even if you don't have breasts.  However the other reason was for balance, and they eventually agreed to a double mastectomy with implants.  I'm happy with the way they look, they look great clothed, they don't look bad naked, they'll never droop like normal breasts, I don't have to really think about them, and I've had plenty of compliments on them too. Just another option to add to the mix.

Posts.Content: I love the way you answer your own questions, Yvonne!  You KNOW that you aren't losing it, and it's perfectly natural that once you have been touched by cancer that every little lump, spot or sore area is going to worry you.  Your body let you down once, it could do it again, right?  Well, yes, it could, but it's unlikely.   As Wendy says, get the dentist to check it out, but in the meantime put it out of your mind.  It's probably just a cyst or something.  As to starting there and moving to your breast, your breast cancer was biopsied.  If it had been a secondary (started elsewhere), it would be different to the breast cancer they found.  So that is highly unlikely.  The white spot could well be a mild infection but let the dentist check it all out to put your mind at rest.

Posts.Title: Hello can anyone help?

Posts.Content: Hi LittleWren Firstly, welcome to the forum.  We're sorry to see you join, but it will be one of the best things you did.    Getting a diagnosis is always a shock.  Even when you go with a lump, most of them WILL be cysts or fatty lumps, so your brain goes into defensive mode and you hope for the best even if you might suspect the worst.  Keeping busy is the best thing you can do, if you have a free weekend perhaps go and visit your sister and the new baby, or your parents, just so you have things to do.   The good news is that you will get a treatment plan soon and once that starts you will start to feel better.  Try not to dwell on the negative stories that you may have seen, because the truth is, 90% of breast cancer patients are still alive and kicking 5 years after diagnosis (no stats for longer).  The other 10% are generally either late diagnosis, elderly in the first place, or have other health issues.  So please don't waste time thinking dwelling on the negative and focus on the positive.   As to living alone, you may want someone to stay with you for a few days or so after the operation.  You won't want to be lifting heavy shopping or doing the ironing for a few weeks.  If you have a friend who can stay, even overnight, for the first few nights, just to be on the safe side, then that would be great, if your family can't manage at this time. Be assured that this IS doable, whatever the results of the tests, so once you have your treatment plan do come back if you have any more questions.

You may find it helpful to join the Friends and family group where others may be able to help with hints and tips on how to get through the next day or week or month.  My small tip is "How do you eat an elephant? One spoon at a time." Don't look too far ahead, cope with each stage as it happens and try to create moments of joy.  I wish you both all the luck in the world.

Posts.Title: Swelling at top of breast bone

Posts.Content: Lacomtekp ........and if you can't for some reason get the R1 or R2 from your doctor  or oncologist, my prescription was for a cream which is 100% acide hyaluronique which we think is hyaluronic in English. I have just completed 33 sessions of radiotherapy, without a mark or skin discoloration. I was blond with very fair skin( maximum factor sun cream all my life) I used the cream twice daily as recommended, washing it off in the shower every morning before the next session, with a 'savon surgras' which appears to be a soap free bar but it is recommended for dry skin and does remove any excess cream. It was stressed by the technicians at my unit that your skin must be clean and creamfree for the actual session. As it worked, I guess they knew what they were talking about. I chatted to other ladies waiting for their treatments. Most had no problems like myself, a couple a very small, light burn on the scar tissue and three ladies who had misunderstood the instructions and creamed before the radiotherapy, burnt badly. Personally, having had a few nasty chemo side effects, I found the radiotherapy, apart from being time consuming when the hospital is nearly an hour from home, cery easy.  If my cancer comes back, I might think twice about having chemo again in the doses I had this time but I wouldn't hesitate to repeat the radiotherapy. Love to all Karen I Unfortunately, Karen, you can only have radiotherapy in the same area once.
