Posts.Content: Info19 I'm sorry to hear that your mum is so scared of these treatments. Unfortunately, if she had had them in 2016, we would probably not be needing to have these conversations, she would have forgotten the side effects and be enjoying her life.   Now being Stage 4, this is the highest stage, and spread to the liver is not good, but chemo can shrink any secondaries and she could well have a good few years left with the right treatment. There are many people who have secondaries living with cancer now, rather than dying from it, but it is time for her to accept conventional treatment and remember that for every side effect there is a medication. Good luck with talking your mother into the treatments, I hope she sees that it is her best hope.

Posts.Content: vicky9989 Firstly, welcome to the breast group. We're a friendly bunch, and the best thing you could have done is join.  We are here to support you and we have (mostly) been where you are right now. So secondly, breathe.  Even if you have a lump and it turns out to be cancer, you are very unlikely to be planning your funeral.  Breast cancer has a very high success rate (90% of breast cancer patients are still alive and kicking five years after diagnosis - figures are only really available for five years, but the 10 year figure is still good).  If you get a diagnosis, you will get a treatment plan and then things will just flow by themselves.  But we are jumping the gun. There are lots of reasons why you might have these symptoms, and lots of people are sent away with cysts or other issues. So don't jump the gun, stay away from Dr Google, as a lot of the information is out of date or just plain wrong, stick to reputable sites like this, Cancer Research, etc.   Finally, don't catastrophise.  You have got this. You have an appointment, we are here day and night, so just post your worries, we know that the waiting is the worst part of it all.
Posts.Title: Waiting on scan for lump in left breast, worried sick.

Posts.Content: My husband was very anti me having the LD flap because apparently one of his colleagues' wives had it two years previously and was still struggling. That said, I know a lady who had it had not problems and a fabulous result, so there are two sides to every coin. I would suggest that anyone having it talk to someone who was worked on by that surgeon and then see how you feel.  Some do many many operations and can do it right in their sleep, whereas for others it's less normal and they are not as practised.   Go with your gut. I had implants and it took a while for me to be able to swim because it was a weird feeling, but I was able to!

Posts.Title: pain in ribs and trying not to go mad

Posts.Content: Ah ... how long is a piece of string?!  There is no right or wrong way to feel.  What you feel, or don't feel, is perfectly fine.  It may hit you later on, but for now, you have just received the news, processed it, and moved on.   I think we find it hard to jump for joy, because we're never 100% sure that we're not going to get it again, or we're perhaps on hormone therapy that isn't exactly a walk in the park.   We are all just trying to get through to the end, one way or another.   I was in a room the other day with a few other people and someone said "I think I'm normal, but I don't know anyone else who is ..." and I think we're all a bit like that.  We're assuming that we all fit into the same shaped holes, when it actually turns out that we only fit into our own, peculiarly shaped hole.  Looks like I blabber as well....!
Posts.Title: How are you supposed to feel

Hopefully someone else in your situation will come along for more support.

Posts.Content: Jen - I had Grade 1 breast cancer so I was given a lumpectomy supposed to be followed by radiotherapy.  When I got my results they hadn't got clear margins, so I had a further operation which found cancer on the opposite side of the margin, so then was advised to have a mastectomy.   I asked for a double mastectomy and after jumping through some hoops, I was allowed to have a double mx with immediate recon.  It took some time to recover, more emotionally than physically, but I'm glad I did it.
Posts.Title: bilateral mastectomy with one healthy breast??

Posts.Content: Hi Shelly I had a double Mx with Becker expander implants on 24th November.  I think I was unhappy with them for the first six weeks, and after that I've got more and more used to them.  I drove after about four weeks, I think, but it's a strange sensation (still is, but less so, and I'm more used to it) when you change gear, as the muscles in your chest contract!  Other than that though, it's fine.  You didn't say if your implants are expanders or permanent gel implants?  (Or saline?) Things I have learned over the last 4 months .... they do soften and as the scar heals (both INSIDE and out) things become easier.  If you have expanders, don't let them put too much fluid into them at a time.  They do kind of "squeak" if you move them around, but you know this is something you get used to.  (No one can hear it, you just kinda feel it!)  Mine are rippling again, and I am going to have to either change them for silicone implants, or have smaller breasts with a DIEP.  (Or wait and grow more fat ... ;) ) It does get better, things take time, make the most of being looked after because it won't last :D

Posts.Content: Hiya Just popping in to say that I was told that last year the target to raise was £220m and the previous year it was £200m.  I know they smashed it in 2014, and I'm sure they did in 2015.  The target for 2016 is almost certainly more.   There has to be some marketing, this is things like posters, TV campaigns, t-shirts and sales materials, that you can buy from the website and at fundraisers.  In addition, the wages of some of the people at head office will come out of the £10m.   Frankly I think, although I believe that this particular campaign has been ill advised in some respects, particularly with the name, the fact is, people are doing this anyway, and all charities spend some of the monies raised to make more money. That's just how it works.  Macmillan publish their accounts for anyone to check, so if these figures are incorrect, I apologise, just what I was told by the CEO.  We are ultra sensitive, but the money does go to great causes.  You can apply for funding, grants, visit the Mobile Information Service, read the booklets, I could go on and on.  Sometimes you just have to look away and choose not to be offended.   Tags
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: I may not have made my point correctly.  Whilst obviously there are staff costs, the publicity materials, fundraising packs etc all have to be produced but lead to funds being raised.   Without being visible, there is no marketing and less fundraising.  If you, say, spent £1,000 buy t-shirts and having them printed, but you sold them for £5,000 total, then you would actually raise £4,000, but the books would still have to say £1,000 spent.   At the moment, there is a campaign being promoted which tries to spotlight the Online Community.  The one you are using.  A group of professionals were hired to produce this, the models were all volunteers although expenses were incurred, such as travel which some may have given as their "donation" and some chosen not to.  Then the professionals created the campaign and hopefully people who need us will join the community that they may not have been aware of, and found the help and support that you have. Now this doesn't raise funds, but it does provide a service, and without it we wouldn't be here, many of us, becautse we wouldn't have known of its existence.  But people have to eat, put fuel in their vehicles, wear clothes, etc, and you cannot expect agencies to work for free.   I actually don't have any issue with the amount spent, having witnessed some of it, because I know how committed people who are paid by Macmillan are.  They do a great job, often doing free overtime, because they want to help.   Now I don't really think any further discussion on this will be helpful, everyone has made their point.

Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Hi @lucy-b This is absolutely 100% normal.  You've been holding it in and now the operation is done, you are allowed to breathe and let it all out. You can't help your emotions, but you do need to keep them on a lead or they'll go wandering off in places you don't need to be right now.  You can't stop any of your family getting cancer, being run over by a bus, or any number of undesirable other outcomes, so please do not start going down that road because that way madness lies. Anaesthetic plays havoc with your system too, and will mess up your emotions for a bit.  It's not you, it's the anaesthetic.   Whinge away here, that's what we're here for, the hugs, the support and sometimes the tough love when needed!

Posts.Title: Menopause after Hysterectomy

Posts.Content: It's so hard to come to terms with it all.  When I had to do it, I google imaged all the types of recon that they said I was suitable for.  If you want to talk it through, then I'm happy to chat - just sent me a friend request.  It's a real minefield, and something that until you're in the situation you have never had any information about. I'm now in the process of helping set up a group in this area (Bedford) for the charity Keeping Abreast which is all about reconstruction - their website KeepingAbreast.org has a lot of info.
Posts.Title: Date for Mx and feeling low

Posts.Content: Firstly, we all have a tendency to think inwardly when talking about someone else's cancer.  It's human nature to think "I'm glad it's not me" even if it's your mum, but your mum is trying to help you because if it is genetic you may also carry the gene and she's trying to prepare you.  She probably feels guilty that she may have passed something on to you, but clearly she couldn't have known at the time, and it is still possible that you may not carry the gene.   Not telling you that her cancer is genetic is not an option for your mum.  That's like not telling someone not to walk across a road when a car is coming.  You have to have the information in order to work out the best thing for you.  Sometimes we have to be brave and face up to things.   You have the option if you DO carry the gene to have treatment before the cancer appears.  Your mum couldn't forget you, you are her child and a mother will always put her children before herself.  It's just how it is, and when you have children you will understand.
Posts.Title: Is it selfish of me to tell my mum if my grandma she can beat it too...

Posts.Content: Hi Becci I'm very sorry you find yourself here, but it's a good place with lots of support and good information.  At your age they will throw everything at you, so you will have a good a chance as possible of a long and happy life after BC.  However, there is a group on breastcancercare.org that is specifically for young women, and also a facebook page too (can't remember the name but I'm sure if you search it will come up and/or someone else will know!). Also you don't say where in the country you are, but there may well be other people locally you can meet up with and/or discuss the options.  The options for reconstruction are mindboggling, but check out keepingabreast.org and see if there is a group locally (if not, contact the national group, as there may be a new one about to launch near you).   Finally, although you say the lumpectomy will leave you with a smaller breast, you could then have cosmetic surgery in the form of a small implant or even lipofilling with your own fat.  Ask your cosmetic surgeon for more information and/or come and ask here.  I've had a double mastectomy with implants and I am happy to answer any questions you might have.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer at 24

Posts.Content: Hi Gill   I can't really answer your question, but I just wanted to say that you shouldn't feel that your problem isn't important just because others have different problems.  How we feel about ourselves and how we look can have a big impact on our psychological well being. I have two implants following double mastectomy and both are slightly capsulated.  I'm hoping that they can be improved but I'm not very hopeful (they inject your own fat around the area to fill it out).  You may find that you can have this procedure if you have any fat.  Also mine are expandable, so they may expand me more, although I am happy for them to do this, I'm not sure if it will fix the problem. Try ringing the helpline to see if any of the nurses here can help?

Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: ektebb That doesn't sound right. I have perfectly flat scars across my breast and my node scar is flat although not as pretty. It may mean you need to go back for some remedial surgery.  Some people do get keloid scarring, which, if you are genetically predisposed, means that scars can heal with ridges.  This is more common in coloured skin, although some white people may have coloured ancestry from way back and it may come out this way. Do speak to your surgeon, as if you are unhappy with the cosmetic results, there are things that can be done.  My stitches were dissolvable internally but glued externally.

Posts.Title: Wig business

Posts.Content: Luthien  I'm sorry that you've had to join this group - I see you already joined to support your mum, so you have got plenty going on at the moment, and I'm sure you are going to have to work out a strategy for coping with it all.(EDIT, apologies, I see that your mum passed away a while ago - I'm sure that stress is a contributor to cancer, but that's just my opinion.  Sorry for your loss).  But for now, focus on one day at a time, try not to stress about the job, I would start on Monday as expected, don't say anything until you have a treatment plan, so that you can then go to HR or your manager with the full story.  Cancer is classed as a disability under the Disabilities Act, so you are protected to an extent, although obviously you will still be on probation, it would be very bad form to let you go under the circumstances.  I would definitely recommend talking to the helpline here, the employment people are great and have all the information you may need. The number is 0808 808 0000, and they are open Monday to Friday, from 9am to 8pm.  I don't know if you can hold off telling your husband before he gets back, but if you can, face to face is always best.  Facetime is a second best, I suppose.  Anyway, at the consultant appointment, they will have another look at you, probably, and they will give you the results of the biopsies. They will be testing the tumour for stage/grade (which is only confirmed upon surgery), the ER/PR (hormone) status, and the HER2 status. If any of these are positive then you have either hormone treatment, Herceptin (and chemo because Herceptin is only licensed with chemo), and if all are negative (known as triple negative), then chemo is given as there are no other treatments. If your nodes are positive then you may have an axilliary clearance, along with either a wide local excision (WLE) otherwise known as lumpectomy, or a mastectomy. If you are offered a mastectomy, you may be offered reconstruction, either immediate or delayed, depending upon other treatment options.  There is also radiotherapy, which is offered depending on other treatment options.  What you will learn is that no two cancers are exactly the same, and no two treatments, because we are all different, age, health, fitness and other items are all taken into account depending on what is found. I wish you luck, and please know that breast cancer is extremely treatable, you have been found early, it seems, so that is in your favour, and over 90% of us are still alive and kicking 5 years from diagnosis, the only period for which there are statistics.  I was diagnosed 6.5 year ago, and I'm as healthy as the next (fat, inactive) woman!

Posts.Title: masterctomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Becci I'm very sorry you find yourself here, but it's a good place with lots of support and good information.  At your age they will throw everything at you, so you will have a good a chance as possible of a long and happy life after BC.  However, there is a group on breastcancercare.org that is specifically for young women, and also a facebook page too (can't remember the name but I'm sure if you search it will come up and/or someone else will know!). Also you don't say where in the country you are, but there may well be other people locally you can meet up with and/or discuss the options.  The options for reconstruction are mindboggling, but check out keepingabreast.org and see if there is a group locally (if not, contact the national group, as there may be a new one about to launch near you).   Finally, although you say the lumpectomy will leave you with a smaller breast, you could then have cosmetic surgery in the form of a small implant or even lipofilling with your own fat.  Ask your cosmetic surgeon for more information and/or come and ask here.  I've had a double mastectomy with implants and I am happy to answer any questions you might have.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed with breast cancer at 24

Posts.Content: Totally agree with everything everyone has said! We're all fabulous, dahlings!
Posts.Title: This is the best BC forum!

Posts.Content: Lynn I'm so sorry that you have had this sledgehammer hit you so hard.  All I can say is that once you have absorbed the information, you will know that the sooner the blasted cancer is out of your body with the Mx, you will feel so much relief. It's not a perfect science, but so many ladies are here because of what they can achieve, and have so much more life about them because they have been given this second chance.  Have they talked about reconstruction? Or chemo? Or RT?  All these things should be discussed before commencement of any treatment, including surgery.
Posts.Title: Date for Mx and feeling low

Posts.Content: Tamoxifen is known to increase the chances of a blood clot. I don't think the other AIs have the same risk but check the leaflet with your package
Posts.Title: Flying while on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Linkj  Once your next chemo is done and dusted, complain to PALS. They should be based in your local hospital.  You are right to complain to help others in future.  It's just not good enough.
Posts.Title: Disappointing consultation

Posts.Content: Love it!
Posts.Title: See profile pic for wig no. 4!

Posts.Content: Hi Smithy You have found the right place for help and support because we have all been on the roller coaster you are about to get on.  At the moment you are sitting waiting for it to start and the anticipation is scarier than the ride. No one who hasnt been on it can know how you feel.  It's very selfish of your daughter to make it all about her but as mothers we try to protect our children and perhaps she is used to you being strong for her.  Hopefully once she has come to terms with it she will be a rock for you because you will need all the support you can get along the way.  As far as the actual operation goes, that's the easy part.  You don't say if you are having reconstruction but the recovery depends on that and if so what type.   You don't say where you are in the country but there may be someone local to you here that can reassure you over a coffee or on the phone.   Also of course your husband is scared.  He's helpless at the moment and we all hear the worst when cancer is mentioned. It rreally is the last taboo.  If he would like to chat to another bloke my husband is always happy to reassure guys.  Send a friend request if any of this would help.  I'm near Bedford if that's any where near you.  Helen
Posts.Title: Just joined op on 12 may

Posts.Content: I had Grade 1 cancer in the right breast. I had a WLE, further surgery for clear margins when they then found more cancer and recommended a mastectomy. Because I really felt that symmetry would be best for me, and also because I had a lot of family history, I asked for a double mastectomy. They do not like to remove healthy tissue,, but I saw a second surgeon for a second opinion and they agreed. So you can ask and you might get.
Posts.Title: Double Mastectomy privately?

Posts.Content: I have flown several times long haul since my op.  I think the first time was about 4 months after though.  I think you'll be fine - if your surgeon said no, then take his advice, but he didn't so go with it.  Just make sure you drink lots of fluids, take aspirin, wear flight socks and walk about as much as you can (or do the seat exercises).  Have a fabulous time! Helen
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: After the catalogue of disaster that you have been through, I am surprised you have any confidence in Broomfield Hospital. I would go to your GP and ask for a referral to the Royal Marsden and take your case to them. They do these operations every day and the success rate is good.  If you think making a complaint will help, go ahead. But I personally think they are only good for those who come along after, not the patient involved. What good will it do you? If you think it is about jumping the queue, I think you will be disappointed.
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Liddi I think you really need to have it looked at by your surgeon again.  It could be that you have some capsular contraction around the implant, and this can be made worse with rads, but the timeline of the problem is important.  Did it come before the rads, or during?  Also, things may become worse during rads and then improve, which is possibly why the surgeon wasn't concerned, depending on when you spoke to the BCN and surgeon.   There are other possibilities as well, so it's very important that someone looks at you and checks you over properly.   I do have some slight contracture of mine, but they mostly occur when the muscles are contracted.  If it's simply a cosmetic problem then some fat can be injected under the skin (from another area in the body) which is called lipofilling, and you may need several sessions of this before your body looks the way you want it to.   But please, do have it checked now, don't wait until the end of rads "just in case", better to be safe than sorry.  And they won't mind you asking.  Further, if it is decided it's something you have to live with cosmetically, then ask for a second opinion, because most surgeons are very concerned about the aesthetic side of their work. Kep us posted.
Posts.Title: Help please has anyone got breast concavities / valley type scars...

Posts.Content: Hmmm. I would just call the RMH and ask them.  If you try for a second opinion, I'm sure that they will want your notes sent across and the planned op may be pushed to the back. I didn't know for certain that these cutbacks had been announced, but it actually doesn't surprise me, given the state of the NHS. When people say "oh I can always have recon later if I decide I want it", I think that will be the case less and less. Really hope you can shout loud enough to be heard.  BTW they do the pre-op I think a max of 14 days before the op, so why they did the last one without a date I have no idea.
Posts.Title: Still waiting for DIEP reconstruction! Help!

Posts.Content: Hi Honey Bea I would suggest as George says that you need further investigation.  You may be suffering Pernicious Anaemia or B12 deficiency, simple to remedy but will not go away by themselves.  It could also be as George says, once of the more complicated nerve related diseases. Good luck getting an urgent appointment, but definitely do not leave it!
Posts.Title: Peripheral Neuropathy and twitching.

Posts.Content: L C D  Firstly welcome to the forum. I have hypothyroidism and I know how desperate you can get when you are undermedicated.  Doctors are (mainly) useless with the endocrine system and unless you are diabetic you do have to become your own advocate and learn about the disease.  People on levothyroxine are something like 200 times more likely to contract breast cancer.  Double whammy. On your question, if you need them you cannot have autonomy.  If you don't, then you don't have a problem.  Can you pay someone to help you with a few things until you move? On the question of hypothyroidism, it is worth reading through a few links.  Thyroid UK is a very useful website, as is HealthUnlocked, and the Stop the Thyroid Madness site.  One other thing, letrozole will reduce your oestrogen which is a feel good hormone.  So you may need to think very carefully about how to proceed with the family, because if you are having a down day, shouting at them might just drive them away. You could try some venlaflaxine to see if that helps. Good luck
Posts.Title: loss of autonomy

Posts.Content: I just wanted to add to the advice you have already been given that you could do a lot worse than read this post written by a member of this community.   You may not believe it all now, but I felt it was a good explanation of how you may feel now and how things will likely be a lot less bad than your imagination telling you now! Any questions you have post away, someone here will have been there and done that and can help.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis

Posts.Content: Whatever else he is, he's your husband, C, and if you want him back for you and your sons you need to get him to understand how you feel.  If he has some kind of ASD then you need to take this into consideration.  I would suggest since talking to him can lead to misinterpretation that you write him a letter and explain exactly how you feel about the whole thing.  He can still choose to misunderstand/not take responsibility for his actions but at least you put your side clearly and concisely.   I wish you all the luck and IMO infidelity isn't the big thing that everyone seems to hold it as.  It's how you choose to deal with it that matters.
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hi Leona,  It most certainly is likely to be a side effect of chemo.  iwould call your chemo unit and see if there is a proprietary cream that you can take. You could try a piriton or similar antihistamine in the meantime?  I often itch,  it's really annoying! And I often itch on my reconstruction boobs, but I can't feel the scratch aaargh!
Posts.Title: Itcy skin rash post chemo

Posts.Content: Mags - they never know until they have taken it out and it's been examined under a microscope.  They should have an idea of stage and grade by then.   Hope you are coping OK, looking after your mum.  You are a great daughter!
Posts.Title: Stage after chemo?

Posts.Content: Obviously the child is looking for attention that it feels is lacking.  However, perhaps attention when it's being well behaved is the answer (a bit like dog training!). I would be worried about anti-depressants as they can cause young people to be more depressed and suicidal.   As the non-parent, it's perhaps clearer for you to see, but you can't really be involved.  I suggest you show these responses to your husband who clearly must have some responsibility.
Posts.Title: 13 year old given Prozac. Your help.please.

Posts.Content: My motto these days is If in doubt, check it out.   Try not to be paranoid, but if you get an ache, pain or abnormality, get it checked by your GP or breast care team.    Don't let fear rule your life, but use it as an indicator of how your body should be.
Posts.Title: How do you know?....

Posts.Content: Enjoy your Pimms, try not to stress, you can't change anything now, so go with the flow! And post here if you have any queries.
Posts.Title: Just back from follow-up appointment after mammogram - bad news!

Posts.Content: Are you in the UK, Wendy?  You shouldn't be paying for dressings if so! Green is not good, usually indicates an infection.  Are they keeping an eye on you?  Do kick up a fuss tomorrow!
Posts.Title: leaky breast

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey Just adding that my implants felt like a large stone duct taped to my chest too!  I'm used to them now, but they do soften with time.  And I was also allergic to anything sticky!  I've been slightly allergic for a good while, but obviously BC brings it out in people, as we're not the first to mention it! I've also been given Amitriptylene for migraines/headaches that I've been suffering and apparently this is not unusual for post menopausal women (thanks, Tamoxifen).  Certain packs have helped and others not so much, so be aware that like T, brands can affect different people different ways.  Gabapentin makes me very dozy, Amitriptylene also, but only on 10mg per day when required and I take it around 8pm and sleep like the dead, but wake up alert! I think they don't tell us everything because frankly there are downsides to every treatment.  But long term, they're probably worth it. Good luck with the Race for Life!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Jlo It's always tough if you get this kind of news, especially a close relative.   Your mum has come to terms with it though, by the sound of it, and 82 is not a bad age, although it's unfortunate that she's the carer for your dad too. Take the lead from your mum - if she needs help, I'm sure she knows you can ask for her.  And while she can do things she feels useful.  The weight loss is worrying, but as you know, that can be a symptom of the cancer so probably not much she can do about it.  I'm sure the team are keeping an eye on it. Lots of hugs Helen

Posts.Title: Mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction

Posts.Content: Make sure that the physio you see knows about cording.  They don't all.  They "pop" the cords and it's a sharp pain but with immediate relief.  I had it in my right arm and it was agony.  Get an urgent referral too, or it will be 6-8 weeks before you are seen.
Posts.Title: Cording in arm - any advice

Posts.Content: Jo - it can sometime change when they check the tissue.  It doesn't always, but sometimes.  As you are already ER+ then that won't change, but sometimes the HER2 can be found when it wasn't under biopsy.  This is fairly rare though. Staging and grade can also change, but it's best to wait for the actual results and not to worry about what ifs.
Posts.Title: Post Op results

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline Do you have your full details?  Or path lab results?  It might be worth ringing the Macmillan nurses and asking them about recurrence rates/predict tool? I know you're in France but there is a normal phone line somewhere (I'm sure someone will let you know what!).   The question I always ask when there is a question mark is "If I were your wife/mother/sister, what would you advise?!" And never apologise for moaning, I would too in your shoes and if you can't moan here, where can you?! Helen
Posts.Title: Pathologic complete response/ Residual Disease

Posts.Content: Please stick to this site for information or breast cancer care as the information there is up to date whereas it isn't always elsewhere.   And ask any questions you have.  There's no such thing as a stupid question, we've all been where you are now and someone will have been there and done that.
Posts.Title: Which Treatment 1st??

Posts.Content: Hi ann82 I'm sorry you have been diagnosed with the BRCA2 gene.  As you have already had breast cancer once, I would suggest that it could indicate you are likely to develop it in the other breast.  With this in mind, risk reducing surgery would make sense, don't you think?  We do have a separate BRCA group, which you can find here. Ladies there may have more advice for you, although it tends to be quiet. You can have reconstruction, so you would look pretty much the same.   Hopefully others will pop in with their thoughts as well. Good luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: treatment.

Posts.Content: Karen  You may need to tell them that you are considering this to get them to take notice. I am appalled by the treatment you have had so far. To be honest, chemo is all about pill popping, so you may have to just accept that for now, not too long to go.

Posts.Content: spudster it's to be expected for a while, I think. Your skin has been stretched and any additional pressure from inside will likely make you feel "tight". That said, if you have an appointment soon, bring it up, and if not, give your BCN a call.
Posts.Title: Tight abdomen

Posts.Content: I think you need to be gentle with yourselves. It is a major operation and it will take a while to get back to normal.
Posts.Title: Tight abdomen

Posts.Content: Hi Sue I guess it depends what your nipples were like!  Mine were never prominent or large, and I decided I didn't want them permanently "erect" as it were!  So I just went for a 3D Tattoo and everyone says they look amazing!  I'm happy with them, although obviously if you have one real one then getting a match is important.  The nipples do flatten somewhat over time, I believe, and the NHS tattooing generally fades, but mine are permanent. There are definitely options.
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: That's OK, that's what we are here for! Any questions or worries, just ask.
Posts.Title: leaky breast

Posts.Content: Well there's that, of course!  But you know from this forum that no two regimes are the same, even for the same diagnosis, so I think that tells us that they don't know everything for sure, and some people go for one theory, others for a different one.  It's a little like the Freud/Jung/insert psychiatrist of choice theories.  No one knows which is true, in the same way some people are Catholic, others believe that C of E is the way to go, some people follow Wesley and the Methodists.  End result seems to be similar!  But not exactly the same! Helen

Posts.Title: Cancer is our own fault

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy  My husband's aunt went through the exact same thing when she was diagnosed. She actually survived that although it did return later,  but she had been stubborn about the initial treatment, so there were reasons for it.  I would say in your case, you are a different person to your mother, and treatment has moved forward in leaps and bounds since your mother died.   We none of us know when our time will be up, so enjoy life now, make the most of being alive, and never put off doing your bucket list.
Posts.Title: frightened of dying at same age as my mother

Posts.Content: Avoid it.  Chicken pox is nasty if your immune system ISN'T Compromised.  If it is, it can be fatal.  Just don't take the risk.
Posts.Title: Risk of infection?

Posts.Content: Me too.  At one point I had to just say to people "look, I'm happy to talk about it, but please, can we not make it the ONLY topic of conversation?!"  People still ask me in hushed tones how I'm doing (unspoken words are "has it come back yet?") and I want them to forget about it and just treat me like a normal human being!   And mine was 3 years ago!
Posts.Title: Fed up of cancer being the focus ...

Posts.Content: vonnie1 my mother swears by glucosamine and chondroitin, buy a good one though, the cheap ones aren;t usually great. It's usually one tablet a day.  You can get them from online health stores.   It will be interesting to compare your results with last year.
Posts.Title: Hair and Nails and galloping Osteoarthritis

Posts.Content: Hi Claire I'm sorry to hear you have another lump.  It could be purely psychosomatic pain, you are more aware of every little twinge but it could be that your lump is touching a nerve and giving you pain.  I never had a lump as such, but I had shooting pains in my breast (where they found the cancer) so I went to the GP and the rest is history.  But painkillers won't touch nerve pain.  Get your oncologist or GP to prescribe some amytriptylene or gabapentin which will dull the nerve pain.  It will make you sleepy, so just take it at night, about 8pm so you will be dropping off by about 10 but still able to wake up in the morning. And I agree, in light of what you said before, don't bother telling the family unless they ask. Helen
Posts.Title: pain in nipple on breast with new lump

Posts.Content: You can still get it if you had it before, and he could also get shingles.  If he's stepped down then you should be fine.  You don't know if he's incubating it (as indeed you don't know if anyone is incubating anything, but you can't live in a bubble!), but the risks are higher knowing about his child. As to shopping trolleys, you have to eat, you have to live, just take the sensible precautions.
Posts.Title: Risk of infection?

Posts.Content: Pointer, you have the same diagnosis as me and that was six, nearly seven years ago now. You have already had a lot of support here  and don't forget you can call our community helpline on 0808 808 0000, open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Content: Biotin is good for hair and nails

Posts.Title: Bloating and taxol

Posts.Content: Well you can just give it some time.  I actually disagree, you are at the same risk of infection with each operation, obviously the number of ops increases risks by that number, but since you have come through the last two OK, you are at the same risk as any other operation.
Posts.Title: treatment.

Posts.Content: After my surgery (Double Mx and reconstruction with implants) I was given a bra and band to wear to stop the implants rising.  I wore this for about two weeks.  They don't give them out now and were about £85 each and definite the least flattering thing ever!  I then mostly wore camisole tops with a bra support bit inside and still wear these often.  I don't actually ever need to wear a bra but for cosmetic reasons I do sometimes (probably 2/3 days a week depending what else I am wearing.  I do have some pretty underwired ones now but didn't wear any u/w for a good six months after surgery.
Posts.Title: Bra recommendation, post surgery

Posts.Content: Good news, Caroline!  Look after yourself, take things easy for a while. Helen
Posts.Title: home after masectomy

Posts.Content: Doing it without all the facts is just pointless and making them up is going to scare w.. My oncologist gave me 98 and 97% with and without Tamoxifen. That's good enough for me. I really don't want to know if I'm going to die tomorrow, I live life as though I am going to be here for at least the next few years and frankly most people don't plan that far ahead. We have holidays booked to the end of November next year, after that, who knows?!
Posts.Title: Predict

Posts.Content: Great news, Mags and Regina! Have a good weekend
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: Totally agree but start small.  Do you want any cancer patients or just breast cancer? If you can find somewhere that you can meet for free, all to the good.  Why not find out if a local church has a coffee morning and if there is a spare room.  If you all buy coffee and a cake, they will probably be amenable.  A public café isn't ideal, as some people find it hard to relax and open up.  I would start with monthly and then see if you need to meet more often.   I would also get a couple of other people to help manage the group,  as it can be a big responsibility.   Perhaps ask at the local hospital if you can put out feelers and if they will promote the group for you.
Posts.Title: Should I start .......?

Posts.Content: Hi Niche I don't know whereabouts you are in the country, but if you can get to a Keeping Abreast support group, you would get to meet and see the surgery results of ladies who have had all different types of reconstruction. If you are not, then ask your BCN if there are any ladies near you who would be prepared to talk to you and perhaps show you the results they have had. Helen
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: toxophilite  I appreciate that all information is good ,but my belief is that this is tinkering around the edges, there are major problems at THEIR end and blaming end users is very unprofessional.  It used to work, they made changes, now it doesn't.  Surely it would be better to go back to basics, get a siimple working version out there and work on improvements later, than let us all work in the dark for an indefinite period? If you have his number, I'll happily call him!

(((((((hugs)))))))) Helen
Posts.Title: Tumour on my shoulder

Posts.Content: That's a tricky one.  Because if you need RT then it affects not only the tissue underneath but also the skin, so it's not as pliable.  That's not so much of a problem if you go for the secondary reconstruction, because they can use more of the skin from your stomach but it will leave bigger scars.   Of course you may not need any RT and then you would still have to have the second op, but they won't know until you've had the Mx so it's a tricky decision.  Good luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: decision to make - immediate reconstruction with tummy tuck or have...

Posts.Content: You should ask your Breast Care nurse how long you are likely to be in, as it will depend entirely on what you are scheduled for.  I had a double mx with immediate implant recon, had the op Thurs and was out on Monday which was quite long but I had a few problems.  They had said probably next day.  Also it depends on your hospital whether they will send you out with drains in. When I had my hysterectomy, I was in for 3 days - that was keyhole though, so again it may well depend.  I could have come home after 2 days, probably, but I was in a private hospital and it was nice to be looked after with good food! Someone posted about what to take earlier so will let them repeat themselves or you can search the site! Helen x
Posts.Title: Mastectomy help

Posts.Content: It's good that you asked the question and acted on the recommendations! Good luck with the next cycle!
Posts.Title: Short of breath

Posts.Content: Hiya - I assume you are now more or less flat then?  I do know of a few people this has happened to.  If you are able to explain a bit more about the problems, others might be able to add their experiences.  Have you been given alternatives?  You can always say no to further treatment until you feel ready - chemo or radiotherapy won't matter if it's delayed a week.  Your health is more important.

Posts.Title: New Breast Cancer Centre in West Midlands: The Haven in Solihull.

Posts.Content: Once you are past the infection stage.   The reason for the diet is to avoid infection from bacteria that might be present in eggs, soft cheese, etc.   If you feel well, and your chemo has finished then you should be fine to eat what you like!
Posts.Title: When Can I Go off the Avoidance diet?

Posts.Content: Hi Sharon Just wanted to say that the DIEP is the gold standard in breast reconstruction.  If you are near a Keeping Abreast support group ladies will show you the results of their surgery and we talk about our experiences.   I have had a double mastectomy with expandable implants like Rebecca. Have a look at their website keeping abreast dot org and see if there are any groups near you.  There is also a lot of good information there. Helen
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: I would add that when I was on tamoxifen, taking vitamin D3 with K2  helped me massively.

Posts.Content: I think your BCN was out of order, to be honest.  None of us actually know and cancer that has disappeared through chemo is unlikely to have spread and rads is a mopping up operation.   However you have to think what would happen to your kids if you went against medical advice, waited, and then the cancer did come back.  I'm sure that postponing a holiday would be preferable to losing a parent. What does your surgeon say?  Can you bring the holiday forward or back?

Make sure you are doing your exercises, they really help, but don;t overdo it.

Posts.Title: out of hospital today and really feeling low

Did you have all of the thyroid out? Some people have a partial thyroidectomy and it can grow back.   You could try asking in the thyroid cancer group which may give you some answers,  but try not to worry and do let us know how you get on
Posts.Title: not sure were i should be

Posts.Content: Ah that explains the confusion then.  They were rushed into it as an emergency.  At least you have a chance for the infection to heal now.  I suppose you could see what other treatment is next and then think about reconstruction later - you have kept some skin, so it could be better, because if you have radiotherapy, it can damage the reconstruction, so having it replaced  later, might give a better result overall.
Posts.Title: After 6 weeks implant removed

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum. I had to have further excision and they found cancer on the opposite side of the original mass so it was mastectomy for me.   Fortunately nodes were clear.  If you are concerned, speak to them again, but bear in mind that if you have more nodes removed then you then run the risk of developing lymphodema which is not an easy thing to live with. I would go with the expert view, he's seen you and made a decision that he is happy with, so go with that and trust the chemo and radio to do its job.
Posts.Title: Results of surgery

Posts.Content: Tracey - drink lots of wine and eat lots of cake.  You'll soon have enough! You are worth the bother!
Posts.Title: Breast reconstruction

Posts.Content: Definitely get it checked. If it's nothing to worry about then no problem. If it is you are on the way to getting it sorted. Good luck.
Posts.Title: A new lump

Posts.Content: Wendy A lot of surgeons seem to that having rads is a reason not to have recon but there are many people who have successfully had it done. Even if the implant is affected you have preserved the skin and it is fairly easily replaced whereas if you lose the skin it is a much bigger operation afterwards.  If you are not happy and they refuse to do it you can have a second opinion.
Posts.Title: Had MX, wish I had stayed in over night

Posts.Content: I was exactly the same.  First time - it's a small lump, we'll get it all out, then oh we didn't get it all, need to do a bit more, then finally, we've got unclear margins on the other side, need a Mx.  I got them to do a double Mx and immediate recon, which has helped me a lot although it's been a painful process none the less.   You could also try phoning your BCN and asking if there's anyone else who's been through the same that is willing to talk to you.  Mine found me a couple of people who'd had the recon before I did it, and it really put my mind at rest.
Posts.Title: out of hospital today and really feeling low

Posts.Content: There you go, Amanda865, if you'd left it a few weeks, you'd have had a few weeks or worrying, probably convinced yourself you have secondaries, planned your funeral, picked your flowers and all for nothing! Once we have had cancer, we must be vigilant but don't put off having things checked, or you'll just end up worried, often for nothing!

Posts.Title: Milk Thistle

Posts.Content: It's so infuriating, isn't it? I had a series of admin mistakes during my treatment, including one where I turned up to the ward for my operation, was told that I wasn't on the list until the afternoon, I knew u was booked for a wire but they said no, and was called back half an hour later.  When we are constantly told how cash strapped the NHS is, I could save them a fortune.
Posts.Title: Bit frustrating

Posts.Content: Hi Traci Welcome to the club no one wants to join.  There are many young mums who have been diagnosed here and I'm sure they'll be along to offer their support but I wanted to say please don't google, stick with this site for info and if you have any questions, someone here is likely to have been through something similar.   Also please remember that breast cancer is a treatable disease and most of us (85%) go on to live long and happy lives so please put away the notion that cancer = death because for the majority it just isn't true, and especially for you as you are young, healthy and have three children to live for. If you can give a bit more information on your treatment plan, those in a similar position will be able to help you more specifically.
Posts.Title: just diagnosed with breast cancer,need support

Posts.Title: Mastectomy Choices....Any Thoughts?

I believe RebeccaT was using something like this, I've tagged her to see if she still is. I was prescribed Gynest at one point but all back to normal now, fortunately.   Aspen , I know it seems like a little thing, but don't leave things too long or it becomes a massive hurdle.  Husbands can be very understanding, but most do have their limits.

Posts.Title: Logging on problems. Is it just me ???

Posts.Content: Rach1969, I don't know if you mean Fragmin tablets or something like warfarin.  My daughter worked for Pfizer who manufacture Fragmin.  She said that there is an antidote for the Fragmin injections, but not for the tablets, and therefore she didn't recommend them, because if you start bleeding out there is nothing that can be done.  If you can't take Tamoxifen you can often take Letrozole which more or less does the same thing but without the clotting side effect.
Posts.Title: Menopausal or not?

Posts.Content: BiBi 44 Please put that link  I don't see any reason for it to be a problem.
Posts.Title: Estriol Cream

Posts.Content: I was on Tamoxifen.  I had a few problems with my eyes - was always 20/20 before this - and it was one of the contributing factors to my giving up. My mother has glaucoma and macular degeneration, so sight is something I am very careful of. My % improvement was only 1% was it wasn't really much of an issue, so that is something to bear in mind. Since then, my distance vision has got worse and I now need glasses for reading and for driving/watching TV/cinema.
Posts.Title: Letrazole and cataracts

Posts.Content: I was on Tamoxifen for nearly 2 years.  Decided to come off due to a number of factors and it being the straw that broke the camel's back as it were.  My risk of recurrence was only 1% either way so quality of life won out.   I don't know if you had any premenopausal signs before you started the Tamoxifen, but it can tip you into menopause.  I had the test, and it came back that I am post menopausal.  I was 49 at the time.  I had a hysterectomy in 2009 but left the ovaries in.  One thing I wanted to add is that anti-depressants usually take 3 weeks before they kick in so be a little patient!
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen second time around

Posts.Content: Hi Rosie I'm sorry to hear that you've not had the best experience through all of this.  I just wanted to add my five pence worth regarding hysterectomy. I had one in 2009 and it was a sub partial laparascopic hysterectomy.  That means it was keyhole and they left the ovaries and cervix.  (cervix was optional, I still have smear tests).  I had fibroids, and was bleeding very heavily all the time.  Nothing coped with it.   I can tell you that the surgery was fine, the worst bit was the air they fill you with to see what they are doing which works its way to the shoulder blades and can get trapped until it is absorbed.  I was walking about day 2 and 3, and went home day 3.  I was riding my horse within a week of going home.  I was lucky enough to go private through my husband's work, but I don't think it would have been much different on the NHS except the food was a lot better ;) Hope this helps allay any fears.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and endometrial changes

Posts.Title: Mastectomy -1day to go

Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: It's very normal to feel like this.  We are happily living our lives and long comes this big bomb dropped right into the middle.  We are literally shellshocked.  And then we are rushed through treatment, necessarily, and afterwards ... nothing.  We feel abandoned, no one understands how we are feeling (unless they have been through it, and even then not always), everyone expects us to go back to "normal".  We could be taking Tamoxifen, or Letrozole, or some other hormone inhibitor, but no one appreciates the toll these take on us both physically and mentally.   It's a lot like PTSD, and it's not your fault.  Have a read of this  http://www.cancercounselling.org.uk/Peter%20Harvey%20-%20After%20the%20Treatment%20Finishes%20then%20What.pdf?openElement which might help to explain some of it to you. Oh and if you want to cry, give yourself permission to do it for 15 minutes.  Wail as much as you like until the timer goes off, then go and do something completely different.  I guarantee you will be looking at the timer and thinking it should have gone off by the time you are done crying and there will be 5 minutes left ... ;)
Posts.Title: How should i be feeling??????

Posts.Content: Over the moon,  WORRIED2016! I would say all that worrying was for nothing, but in your case, it has made you realise exactly what you had to lose and will make sure that your life is lived to the full!  Having a glass of wine to celebrate!
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby Yes, I think it's fairly common to feel down on Tamoxifen.  When you were first on it, you were probably on the branded product as others weren't available, but now you could be taking any one of many generic forms so it's worth making a note of which one makes you feel worse.  Hope you find one that suits you, if not have a word with your GP. Helen

Posts.Content: Hiya V That moment when you get that diagnosis is a shocker, isn't it?  Especially when you've done everything in your power to get diagnosed. Now that you have your diagnosis and things are starting to move, you will find things much easier in a way, although the post surgery pains are a nuisance.  Exercises are very important, try to push yourself a bit more each day without over doing it.   I don't know if your children's father is around to step up and take some of the load while you are on chemo?  Good friends are worth their weight in gold.   It's a great idea to take your sister with you, when you get home and remember things you wanted to know, ask her, they may well have answered your questions already. If not, ask here and someone will be able to help.

Posts.Title: Got bras you aren't wearing any more?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that it's not the news you wanted.  Speak to the Macmillan helpline about the protection that you are entitled to under the Disability Act as cancer is included under this.  Don't offer to resign or do anything rash until you have all the information you need.  Fairness doesn't come into it at this point, you have to do what is right for you. Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: not the news I wanted today!!

Posts.Content: Hi Lizz Our instincts are an amazing resource, we need to be able to listen to ourselves and take note.  When you get the results of the Oncotype DX test, be very aware of your reaction.  If it's a no to chemo, you will feel relief and be able to move on.  If it's a yes, listen VERY carefully.  Do you go into blind panic?  Does it make you more determined NOT to have it, or do you start to accept that it's for the best.  As you said yourself, only you can make this decision.  As long as you are happy with it, then that is the main thing.   I know you are slightly older than some of us, so this can be a factor, as well as any other health problems that may be exacerbated by the chemo.   I wish you luck and peace with your decision.
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Content: I was told I could ask for a second opinion (and transfer if I wanted) to the Royal Marsden in London. Carolyn28 transferred her treatment from Bedford to the RMH, so it is possible.   Depends where you are, I think. I agree, if you are being offered TRAM, it is a bit outdated, unless you have no fat to be used.
Posts.Title: referral to another hospital/NHS trust?

Posts.Content: Hi Barbs What a shock for you.  I'm not surprised that you are terrified.  No one can ever tell you why, sometimes it's just one of those things. Unfortunately TN is unpredictable, and can pop up unexpectedly.  Focus on the treatment and beating this, not on the things you can't change.   When you say what will be offered, do you mean type of reconstruction, or treatment?  If you are having a reconstruction, you will be assessed for a suitable type for you.  If you have enough extra, you could opt for the DIEP flap operation using your own stomach tissue which supposed to be the best option if it is suitable for you.  Otherwise, you could be offered TRAM (using stomach muscle), LD flap using a muscle from your back, or you could be offered implants.  How long it takes depends on which op you have - obviously the implants are the quickest, LD flap next, TRAM, then DIEP which is a long op, but either way, it won't matter to you, you'll be under the anaesthetic!  The longer the op, the longer the recovery, but the better the result.  It's your call, really. You won't be offered radiotherapy, because you have already had it in one area.  You may well be offered chemo again.   Hope some of this helps, any other questions, please yell out.
Posts.Title: Help with recurrence

Posts.Content: OK, here I am!   If you have a look here you will find lots of useful information.  If you are anywhere near any of the groups, do try to get to a meeting - the ladies are very friendly and informative, and will give you an good idea about what happens during and after surgery and will show you the results.  It might seem like a lot of time and effort, but it IS worth it.   I don't know if you have an appointment with an oncoplastic surgeon yet, but you do need to speak to him/her and find out what your options are.  It is important not to get set on one particular type of operation, because it may not be suitable for you.   As to whether to bother - there are ladies here who have decided just to stay flat, there are some who have had immediate reconstruction, and some who have had delayed recon due to chemo/rads, etc. As you are not having rads, that will help, as immediate recons have the chance of being altered by them.  Living flat has advantages, and disadvantages.  Living with a prosthesis is not always easy, but some prefer it to extensive surgery.  And don't opt for implants as the "easy" option - they're not as easy as you might think.  Sometimes a bit of short term pain for long term gain is worth it.   Talk to as many people as you can.  If and when you decide what you would like, make a post and people who have had it will tell you their experiences.  I can put you in touch with people from KA who will talk about theirs too, once you narrow it down.
Posts.Title: Help with recurrence

Posts.Content: Hmmm I agree, they think there is lots of support but personally I didn't find it so.  We have a breast cancer support group that meets once a month approx and a few odd trips out here and there, but to be honest it is more of a social group than focussed on cancer support.  I can see why this has happened, as some of the ladies have been members for over 20 years!  However for newly diagnosed people it's hard to start a conversation about what you need, because there's a raffle, there's a speaker, etc etc.   We started a reconstruction support group but I think it was too specialist for a small hospital catchment.  When we lost our breast care nurse/medical advice (she left her post and felt that her knowledge would quickly become out of date), we decided that we would resign en masse.  The group now functions from a larger (attached) hospital, and I hope will do well.   Good luck with your group.
Posts.Title: survivorship

Posts.Content: I've been told Gynest is OK with Tamoxifen but I don't know about Letrozole.   Rebecca - have you had an iron panel done lately?  Low ferritin can make your hair thin/fall out.  Also, try taking biotin, it works beautifully on my horse, it works on hair, nails, and skin.  Totally natural.
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: Not great news, but at least they are getting on with it.  Good luck for tomorrow.
Posts.Title: One stop breast clinic

Posts.Content: Hi Deb  I am going to guess that apart from finding the lump, you were fine? And apart from the terror, you still are? Chances are that you will be absolutely fine after treatment too, although you may have to go through a rough few months.  I had diagnosis six and a half years ago and final  surgery six years last week. My aunt was diagnosed at 49,still with us at 75! Breast cancer is very treatable and not usually the death sentence everyone seems to think.
Posts.Title: Devastated and petrified diagnosed with 2cm lobular breast cancer...

Posts.Content: Hi Pmcd I'll try to answer questions in order.  Because you had chemo and rads to do, that's probably why they didn't offer recon at the time.  I'm surprised it wasn't mentioned at all, but we are where we are now.   There are various types of reconstruction, as George's booklet will show you.  You can also see if the Keeping Abreast Website has information that may help, and this is one time when Dr Google can be helpful - have a look at Google images breast reconstruction.  There are various options there and whilst some haven't been as successful as others, you have a good idea.  I think you need to tell your surgeon that you expect to look good naked, not just in clothes, as I think sometimes they do think that clothed is sufficient.  They will look at your body type and size and previous surgeries and let you know what, if any, types of reconstructions are suitable for you.  Don't fix on one type, because you may find that it isn't suitable for you, but you can have preferences.   All have pros and cons regarding surgery/recovery/look.  Don't go for implants on the basis that they are they easy option, as they can need replacement over time, and you can get capsular contracture around the implant.  Equally, the operation is quick and recovery is relatively straightforward, but the body can reject them as foreign bodies very occasionally.  I had permanent expander implants and I am happy with them, but it took a while. If you are a candidate for a DIEP flap reconstruction (using fat and skin from the stomach), this is considered the "gold standard" in recons.  The operation is long, and recovery can take a while, but the results are amazing and lifelike.  Also the Latimus Dorsi flap taking muscle from the back and bringing it to the breast is fairly commonly offered, but is losing favour. The TRAM flap uses the muscles from the stomach but is also losing favour.  This is a possibility where there is insufficient stomach fat, however. If you are anywhere near a Keeping Abreast Group, it's well worth going along even if it's a bit of a drive, because you get to talk to ladies and see the results of their surgery in the flesh.   If you want more information, just shout.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction advice and info please.....

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic  Don't be hard on yourself. This journey is HARD.  It's made harder by the attitude of others, mind you, so surround yourself with people who care. You do sound depressed, so please do start taking the antidepressants.  They take around 3 weeks to kick in, so don't panic if you don't feel better straightaway.  Also make sure that if you are taking tamoxifen that they are compatible, as some aren't. Plan some treats for yourself, things to look forward to.  Instead of saying I can't, say I can. Yes, instead of No.  You can get your lovely life back, but you have to work for it.  It's not going to happen by itself.  I know you can do this, we are here to support you.  Focus on the good things in life.  Live up to your name.
Posts.Title: Ptsd

Posts.Content: I had a double mastectomy with implants. One was elective and I lost both nipples. If the nipple is retained it increases the risk of recurrence by 5% or so.  Symmetry was important to me as well. My nipples are tattoos and quite realistic.

Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result

Posts.Content: Hi Syers I believe that the pain is from the bone marrow being told to make more white blood cells to fight infection! it should ease soon but it's worth trying moomy's tip, before you abandon them altogether.
Posts.Title: Neulasta

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy I've not had chemo myself but have read lots on here and often seen this.  If it gets any worse your oncologist will probably reduce the amount of chemo, as I think this is the start of peripheral neuropathy and you don't want that getting worse as it can become permanent numbness.   Don't be fobbed off.  I'm surprised he thinks it's not related.
Posts.Title: Pins and needles in fingers

Posts.Content: As always, great advice from Dorothee! Why should you be the one doing everything?  They're young, fit and perfectly able to do things to help and perhaps what you need to do is look at what you do around the house, and decide that some of it is unnecessary.   Have a family pow-wow and explain to them all how the Zoladex makes you feel.  Explain also that you don't want to stop taking it because of the risk of recurrence, lay it on the line.  Perhaps they won't be able to help but will say pay for a gardener or an ironing service, whatever will help you.   The time for being strong has gone, now is the time for you to tell it like it is.
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: iwannaliveforever mistymoley Hi Lizz Our instincts are an amazing resource, we need to be able to listen to ourselves and take note.  When you get the results of the Oncotype DX test, be very aware of your reaction.  If it's a no to chemo, you will feel relief and be able to move on.  If it's a yes, listen VERY carefully.  Do you go into blind panic?  Does it make you more determined NOT to have it, or do you start to accept that it's for the best.  As you said yourself, only you can make this decision.  As long as you are happy with it, then that is the main thing.   I know you are slightly older than some of us, so this can be a factor, as well as any other health problems that may be exacerbated by the chemo.   I wish you luck and peace with your decision. Your reference to my being slightly older was the first thing that has made me feel like me! The surgeon and oncologist keep going on about my young age and bizarrely I was upset (not very!) when you stated the bleedin' obvious - I'm NOT young anymore. (how young are you, btw?) The pre-cancer me is jealous, but considering how badly I'm handling it at 53 (firmly in denial) , I'd never have coped in my 30s or 40s. Love, and thanks for the reminder of the old me! Love Lizz x Oh fiddlesticks, I think I may have mixed you up with someone else!  I'm 52 and I don't consider 53 old!  But it still applies, we're not spring chickens!  We probably have a good 10-25 years without further problems, and then it's anyone's guess.  Your username says you are a fighter, so perhaps that will help the decision!
Posts.Title: Thinking of turning down chemo

Posts.Title: Help with recurrence

Posts.Content: Helsjw Please try not to catastrophise. 90% of all breast cancer patients are still alive and well 5 years from diagnosis  They don't do statistics after that, but I was diagnosed over 7 years ago and my aunt 25 years ago, we are both fine. You are going to be fine, once you have your plan, we will help you through it.  Now go and enjoy today.
Posts.Title: Morning after diagnosis.....

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline, yes it does sound like you could have some cording.  You can do the exercises and stretch it, but the best thing is to get on the phone to your BCN, get the name of a specialist physio, then get an appointment with your GP and ask for them to do an URGENT referral.  It needs nipping in the bud and only specialist physios know what to do.  Unfortunately it can happen at any time after surgery and can recur, so it's something to be aware of.  Hope you can get it looked at soon.

Posts.Content: Oh dear, what a shame.  Still, you can get it back and resized, just be careful not to lose it if the swelling goes down! If it's any consolation, I have had a new wedding ring for about 13 years, as my original one got too small and it wasn't worth getting resized.  I've also had a new "engagement" ring as the original lost the stone and was yellow gold and not white like the new wedding ring.  It makes no difference to the marriage, my vows or the way I feel about my husband.  xx
Posts.Title: Had a bit of a traumatic morning

Posts.Content: Debs - You didn't say how long you have been on your journey, but I remember my BCN saying to me that people finish treatment  and expect to get on with their lives, but they can't and get depressed.   Bear in mind that you haven't been able to do so much, and you won't be as fit as you used to be.  Give yourself time to build up your strength before you try to get back to "normal".  A year from diagnosis is not uncommon.   Hugs Helen
Posts.Title: When do i get "Me" back

Posts.Content: Kelly38 I'm sorry to hear that you have to have chemo but it is very doable  I highly recommend that you join the monthly chemo club (just pop chemo club into the search box at the top of the page and choose the current month). There are lots of tips on how to deal with the side effects   Your daughter will only have a problem if you make it one. Children are remarkable and you just explain that you need to take some medicines that will make your hair come out but while it does that it is also making you better  You could also try the cold cap which can really help keep your hair if it fits tightly and is cold enough  If you don't go for the cold cap, involve her in choosing a wig or buying scarves  learning to tie them and maybe even getting her to shave your head once it starts to come out  I know that people who have been through this will be along with their tips soon.  Good luck with the treatment.

Posts.Title: Need help with decision

Posts.Content: Hi Pea I have had implants.  I'm quite happy with them now, but I really wish I'd had the DIEP flap at the beginning,  My surgeon doesn't do it, and he steered me towards the implants.  If anything happens with them, I think I'd opt for the DIEP.  So I would say yes, I'm told it is the gold standard in reconstruction, much more natural than implants, and because you are using stomach fat, as you lose and gain weight, they change with you so you don't end up top heavy/bottom heavy as appropriate.  I've seen a few and they've been very very impressive. I would only advise anyone against if they were a smoker, simply because you need a good circulatory system for the blood vessels to work properly and do their job. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Arm pain, numbness, pins & needles, only at night.......?

Posts.Content: Hi Sally I'm sorry it's taken a while to get to you-been decorating all weekend in the land that internet forgot ... LOL Anyway I wanted to say that as you are on Letrozole, you could be getting what they term menopausal migraine - triggered by a change in hormone levels.  I've suffered from some horrific migraines in the past few years, due to actual menopause, so imagine it must be worse being on AIs.  I'm not sure about the twanging popping thing, could just be a nerve trapped, but as with all these things, it's always worth getting it checked.  The GP/BCN/Consultant never mind you checking just in case - better safe than sorry, and we that have already been diagnosed are unfortunately more prone to further problems down the line in due course, so anything you can catch at the start has to be better than waiting and seeing.  Good luck.

Posts.Title: Still waiting for mammogram results

Posts.Content: Many ladies have a breaat reduction following surgery and while I can see your point,  it's more of a long term solution than implants that need changing after 10-15 years.   That said,  you can always ask for a second opinion.  One thing I have learned is that no two patients have the same treatment even if they appear to have the same diagnosis.  And different surgeons do things differently.  Ask your gp to refer you to an onco plastic surgeon.  You may have to travel a bit but you should get answers to your questions.
Posts.Title: breast augmentation.

Posts.Content: I think if you put horses into the search bar at the top of the page you will find lots of us who have horses and who have gone through treatment. Fortunately I didn't need chemo but I did need a lot of help with the horses for several months just because I wasn't physically strong enough to do mucking out etc I did ride in between some surgeries but I did also fall off which wasn't so good. It did break the coding that I developed however so that wasn't so bad! As toxophilite says  if you have a high standard of hygiene, then you could try, but I definitely be wrapping in favours for the chemo week at least and maybe cover yourself for all the first two weeks from chemo and just do the third week if you feel up to it.
Posts.Title: Onco Test Results

Posts.Content: Hi Heather I'm sorry you've been treated this way.  Unfortunately Oncologists tend to treat us patients as  numbers - I think if they got involved with everyone they couldn't do their job as they would be too upset.  But we have a right to be treated with dignity.  I suspect the Onco thought he was  being funny about the heat.  Let's just hope that he never has to go through anything like this, eh?! I've found that people who have been there understand much more than even the professionals, so coming here is a good place to start.  It looks as though your treatment is starting to work for you, and hopefully you will get away with less invasive surgery, so that's good news.  Give your BCN another call tomorrow afternoon - if you have to leave a message, say you've tried several times.  Make sure you leave your number clearly.   Unfortunately being on Letrozole will make you feel a bit emotional and down probably, so everything seems worse than it is.  You're doing well!!! Helen
Posts.Title: Confused with lack of support and not enough information

Posts.Content: Interested to see you are  thyroid meds and blood pressure.  I am also on those (Been on thyroxine for 20 years, BP for 2 months ish) and never had BP problems before!  In fact, I've always been very "normal" in all medical respects (apart from the thyroid!). When I was diagnosesd I had surgery (3 times), then given tamoxifen for 5 years.  I got worse and worse and in the end I stopped the Tamoxifen.  Decided on quality of life over quantity, if you like.  I now wonder if the Tamoxifen affects the thyroid absorption and although I am officially now post menopausal, as you said, the body still retains some oestrogen, whereas these chemicals wipe it out entirely.   It doesn't take much to knock your thyroid out of whack, so I would look into that as well.  Hope you have a good GP who doesn't just look at your TSH and tell you that it's are normal!

Posts.Title: Appt on thurs but should I cancel?

Posts.Content: It's the supraclavicular node - a gland similar to lymph nodes under the arm. If you have had an infection or cold or anything lately, it's probably that.  I had one come up about 7/8 months ago.  It wasn't long before my check up so I asked the consultant and he got the ultrasound doctor to do a biopsy on it.  It came back clear, but they did show some concern until I said I'd had a throat infection not long before.   Worth having it checked, but probably not too much to worry about.   Mine is still up though, and I don't know if it supposed to be.  I guess I should get it checked again.

Posts.Title: I think I am a NEDdy

Posts.Content: I had the genetic test.  My mother is one of four girls and the other three all had BC.  Her elder sister was in her 80s (and refused to acknowledge she could have cancer because her sisters had had it so she couldn't - can't work the logic myself, can you?! She died), Her twin sister had it twice and eventually died after about 10 years after initial diagnosis, and her younger sister got picked up on her first mammo, had a mastectomy with implant and is still alive and very much kicking aged 73.   Even then they said it was still unlikely, and as it turned out, I don't have the gene.  It was a blood test, there was a counselling session in which the lady took down all my family relations as far as we could, and the sample was sent off.  Two months or so later, I went back and they gave me the results.  They take a lot of care about you during this, because a positive result can be earth shattering.  But most come back negative.  I didn't realise I was holding my breath until she told me the results.  Phew.  Good luck, the lady who is probably the same one you will see was very nice.

Posts.Title: Christmas - lonely ? tag me @carolyn28

Posts.Content: Hi Jessie I think we've all been where you are right now.  Firstly, stay away from Google!  In this case it is not your friend  Stick with this site,  breaat cancer care and CRUK. Other information is likely to be out of date and inaccurate and will,  as you have found,  just frighten you.  Secondly,  none of us know how long we have.  We all go around thinking that we will live for our three score and ten but the good thing about cancer is that it actually makes you live for the moment and make the most of life.   Finally,  you are in the right place. The sscan will show what is going on,  which hopefully is nothing,  and the chemo is there to mop up any stray cells.  And then you will be ready to move on with your new life.  Things you used to stress about won't be important.  Good luck with your appointment  You can do this!
Posts.Title: Pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi sue62 sorry you have had a problem, but glad you have been seen in time.  Unfortunately this can happen, as you found out and why we encourage people to post any problems so we can advise you to call your unit during chemo as they are the experts. GPs are not, unfortunately.  Chemo through a line goes straight into the vein. Using the cannula means there can be leakage and therefore damage as I understand it.  Personally I would wait for the Hickman line or even insist on a port.
Posts.Title: Blood Clot in PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline It sounds like it's your parathyroid levels from what you said.  You can have a quick google but I would think it's bad luck rather than being connected to the DCIS.  Parathyroid glands sit on top of the thyroid and are pretty important.  I'm not an expert in this at all, but I have hypothyroidism and this does crop up on forums occasionally.   I would have a quick look at this link which will give you some more information.

Mine came with a band separately that went across the top of the boobs to stop implants from rising.  I wore it for 2 weeks day and night.  Highly recommended.
