Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi chloecat I have read this thread with interest and thought you might be interested in this anecdote. My husband's aunt got breast cancer when she was 52.  I'm not sure how she found it, or even if it was a mammogram that found it for her, as she was a large lady with large boobs.  However, I do know that her reaction was that she didn't want a mastectomy.  So adamant was she that she had radioactive implants put under the skin to kill off any stray cells after the lump was removed rather than any other treatment.   She recovered and lived another 6 years before it returned with a vengeance and killed her.   I tried all the options and ended up with a double mastectomy (one preventative).  I truly believe that I've given it my best shot.

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Lulu If you really want a double Mastectomy, ask for a second opinion.  I agree with you, it would be cheaper for the NHS, easier to recover from, and easier for you to live afterwards. I had cancer in my right breast and when they said (after two failed ops) that I needed a mastectomy I said, fine, take both.  They said, as you have been told, that they would not remove a healthy breast, and I had a scan to prove it was, but I said that for my mental health, (plus there was a high family risk although subsequently no genetic link) I wanted both done although I did have reconstruction.   I was also concerned that I would constantly be checking the other breast for lumps and eventually they agreed to do it.  Good luck and I hope you achieve your objective.

Posts.Content: Nutmeg56 My mum was diagnosed in the summer and I found going to appointments with her helped both of us, as I knew what was going on, and it reassured her that I could talk her through it in the car afterwards to explain that it was all normal process. When she went to the GP with a lump, she thought that because they'd seen her quickly, that she had aggressive cancer and started to plan her funeral. I was able to reassure her what was normal. And although it was a different hospital, I knew what would be done and how.   We'd discussed the various possibilities and agreed which treatment options she would be happy with.   I hope that you are able to support your sister and that you both benefit from it.  I am sure her daughter will be fine, but get the treatment plan before discussing it, so that you have the answers to the questions she will have.  Good luck to you all.

Posts.Content: Hi Bjez  I can't find anything about it, but to be honest, I don't really think these things are the best way to lose weight. I've had a weight problem for years, but have finally managed to lose quite a bit, just by moving more and eating a bit less.  I still eat pretty much everything but have smaller portions, and if I eat too much rubbish I just skip a meal.   The walking is the important thing.  Also I have a fitbit which tells me how many calories I have burned and it's always shockingly few!  We all eat more than we really need.  And of course being told you can't have pudding until you have eaten your main course just means you learn to eat more than you want!   Stop when you are full.  Treat yourself but don't overdo it.  Gentle exercise but often.

See if it tastes as good if you do that!  If you are concerned about cholesterol, I highly recommend "The Great Cholesterol Con" by Dr Malcolm Kendrick.

Posts.Title: Our Arron's Death Certificate came yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi Jan and Louise No, not just a scare at all.  All cancer is serious, and should be taken as such, and people saying that are obviously misinformed (and possibly a bit stupid).  *zips mouth before says something really rude* LOL I understand that Grade 1 is the early stage of a cancer.  Cells are starting to mutate into cancer cells rather than the normal cells that they should be.   They are starting to cluster and make small lumps/tubes of cells.  The good news is that as an early form, it shouldn't have spread too far (if at all), and removal should be a much smaller operation.  I presume you've had a WLE?  SNB?   I didn't even find a lump, just had some random sharp pains in my boob.  Turned out to be Grade 1 DCIS with some lobular involvement, but luckily all nodes were clear.  I had WLE, which didn't find clear margins so had a further excision, but then found there was more on the other side, so ended up with a Mx.  By this time I just wanted the boob off anyway, and actually opted for both so as to avoid going through this again.  Originally I was told just WLE followed by RT and Tamoxifen, but having had the Mxs I was told RT wasn't necessary, and the Tamoxifen was offered as a precaution but I was told that if symptoms became too bad then it wouldn't be the end of the world if I came off it.  So far I've not really had much in the way of symptoms that I've noticed, so it's been OK. And don't feel that you have to hold back as second best to patients with higher grade cancers.  You are important, your treatment is important, and you must put yourself first in this.  We women are inclined to hold back and in the case of breast cancer (and treatment) this is definitely a no-no.  You have every right and as much right to proper information as anyone else, the BCN's are there to help everyone regardless of grade.   I had to wait ages for the oncology, but she was very thorough, went through all the permutations and options and scenarios, so don't worry too much about questions, as they'll probably cover everything before you get the chance to ask!  Questions might include what are your chances of recurrence, options for treatment, length of time of treatment, but I'm pretty sure they'll cover all of this anyway. My other tip is take a book to read while you wait - our oncologist is regularly running 2 hrs late ... :) Helen x

Posts.Content: Hi Icy Firstly I'm so sorry to here about your poor dogs.  Such a trauma may well have caused the headaches, but you don't say if you are having Tamoxifen/Letrozole etc?  I found that I had very bad headaches for a while on that.  If you can get your GP to prescribe cyclizine taken together with paracetamol it may well help.

Posts.Title: Stopping homone therepy

Posts.Content: don't feel you have to wait for appointments to find out things, either.   If you don't want to ring your BCN (breast care nurse), call the macmillan site - it's free and open 9-8 most days - they will answer your questions.  However your personal BCN will have your notes so will be able to answer specific questions. some places only talk about Grade not Stage (or vice versa?).  Anyway focus on the fact that it's caught early, and has a VERY good survival rate!   The trouble with telling people before you know the answers is that they will ask you the questions!  They just mean to help, but it can be very frustrating at times.   Some abbreviations WLE - wide local excision or lumpectomy SNB sentinel node biopsy where they check the nodes for spread Mx Mastectomy BCN as above Can't think of any more ... LOL
Posts.Title: looking for grade 1 to share info

Posts.Content: This is not true, you will need an UNWIRED bra for some considerable time.  I'm six months post op, and I can wear one now (although not officially sanctioned), but don't wear them all day every day.   Wilkinsons and BHS do something similar to the Ahhhh bra (google images) but much cheaper which I believe is very comfortable as it has no seams.
Posts.Title: bras for reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Scarlettred123  I am also a horse rider and I was riding between every operation (had a WLE, margins and MX), even fell off once, and it helped with cording - keeping hold of the reins! I don't know if you have tried a different brand of Tamoxifen yet, some are definitely worse than others for joint pain, but everyone is different, and what is good for one might not be great for another.  Sandoz (Novartis) is as near to the original Femara as you will get. You can also take some chelated magnesium, which I take before bed in a glass of orange juice - really helps you sleep and good for the joints.  Ask your oncologist if you can take glucosamine too.  (I checked it here but I would always double check. Also the Bodyshop Hemp handcream is very very good for being outdoors!
Posts.Title: Clicking joints - tamoxifen.

Posts.Content: People want you to be well.  They're scared, like cancer could be catching.  And a lot of people really don't like anything "nasty" or "unpleasant" in their lives.  The problem is, what can they say?  Nothing of any use, really.   I think your attitude is very noble, Daft Bird!  I just wanted to punch people who said things to me.  And even now, 2 .5 years later, I still get the enquiries "So are you all right now?!"  I just smile and say Yes, I'm fine thanks, as far as I know.  That shuts them up.   Do you know the ones that make me laugh though?  (Although they didn't when it was very raw).  "Oh yes, Mrs Soandso had that.  She died."  Really????!
Posts.Title: Another "dumb things people say" video

Posts.Content: Haha!!!!  Can you IMAGINE the fuss he would have made if he DID have a boil on his bum????!!!! Worse than man flu!!!
Posts.Title: Another "dumb things people say" video

Posts.Content: Caroline - I don't suppose most of us knew what was really involved until we had to deal with it.  The last taboo, I think.   I'm glad your husband has (finally) stepped up to the plate now though and hopefully will be more supportive for you. Daft Bird - You could still wear the hairband on your bald head!!
Posts.Title: Another "dumb things people say" video

Posts.Content: Tracy  The human body is an amazingly resilient thing. But sometimes you have to listen when it is telling you to slow down.  Take some time out.  If you can, possibly work part time for a bit.  Grief and cancer both take their toll on the body, and if you don't acknowledge it, you eventually break down.  I would suggest you take up yoga, or try one of the Macmillan courses to help with coping after cancer and the death of a loved one.  All these things are worth doing, if only to make you take time to look at you.   I'm not at all surprised you are exhausted.  It might be worth you visiting your GP and having a few weeks signed off work.  But do take some time for you.   Hugs Helen
Posts.Title: advice please somebody

Posts.Content: Hi Jules and welcome to the group. It's full of people just like you who have been diagnosed, or treated or out at the other side so we can totally identify with how you are feeling.   As to chemo,  it rather depends on what drug you are having.  FEC tends to be fairly quick acting so you may want to stay local for a few days,  but taxotere or doxetaxel  have a few days grace so you can get home.  Either way I'd get someone else to do the driving if you can.

Posts.Title: Recurrence before end of treatment?

Posts.Content: Thanks, Trish, some good info there.  I've not had a CT scan of my abdoment - had my knee and my boobs, so another one to add to the collection!   The expander has settled over the 12 weeks I've had it, and it has got less firm as the scars have stretched and eased.  I had to have a proper row about it to get this information though - you wouldn't think so, would you?  It was like I was insulting his professional integrity or something ....  To be honest, if it wasn't rippling, I'd probably put up with it, but I don't know whether that can be sorted out.  I don't know whether having had the implant under the muscle it would now be too stretched for the DIEP.  These are all things I've got to find out. To help you, I had an op when I was 16 which cut right along the whole side of my neck.  It was deep, and I lost sensation right up to my cheek for a while, but it has regenerated and I have 99% normal feeling, so you never know!   I'm ambivalent about the nipple, but frankly I'm not even thinking about it until everything is sorted finally! Helen x
Posts.Title: Chemo at Home

Posts.Content: Brilliant news! So pleased for you!  Have a great weekend!
Posts.Title: breast clinic tomorow im worried sick

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you are well and thriving, SaxxyD!
Posts.Title: Life does go on

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed in early August this year.  I hadn't felt a lump, but had experienced shooting nerve pain in my breast for 3 days, followed by a 4 day break, then another 3 days of the shooting pains, then it all stopped.  I went to the GP who organised a mammogram appointment, although I'd had one the previous year.  They discovered a 5mm lump deep in the breast which couldn't be felt even when they knew it was there, so I had to have a wire localisation when the operation was done.  Had a wide local excision and sentinel node biopsy on 11th September, and within a few days had pain down the inside of my arm, at some points extending right down to the base of my thumb.  Also had the rawness and sensitivity under my arm, and it felt as though my bra was lined with sandpaper.  After about 10 days I was driving though, and riding my horse although had to take it a bit gently. A fortnight ago, I had to have a second op  as the margins weren't clear.  Whilst waiting for the results of this, my inner arm became more and more painful and now I have been diagnosed with cording or axillary web syndrome.  Very little information about this, but the main thing I've come up with is to have some form of massage by someone who knows what they are doing.  I'm still waiting for the appointment for this, but it's important to have this done correctly, as doing it incorrectly could cause more problems. Unfortunately the results of the second op have come back that I now need a mastectomy.  I'm trying to get them to do both, as there is a family history, and I can't face having to go through all this again.  It's a hard decision though, and not entirely up to me. Going to have an MRI scan of the normal breast on Monday.   Helen
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: Take some magazines, phone and charger, ipad, bottle of squash, snacks,baby wipes  Pretend you are going to a spa and just relax and enjoy a rest. After all, you have no choice, so just breathe.  Hope you managed a ride this morning. You will be fine, they do this every day.
Posts.Title: Surgery Tomorrow

Posts.Content: I'm lucky in that I've been told that if I have this I won't need radiotherapy or chemotherapy, just Tamoxifen although it sounds as though that's not a walk in the park - drugs affect me quite badly, so I shall have to see how it goes.  I have a family history, so that's my reason for having them both done at the same time ....    H xx
Posts.Title: Pain after axillary clearance

Posts.Content: I found that intensely annoying, Sue.  Yes, the worst is over, but there's that constant nagging fear, isn't there, that they've not found everything, or there's a rogue cell that is waiting in the wings (until the RT sorts it out).   All of these thoughts are very natural, but the bad dream does stop and you will start to enjoy life again.
Posts.Title: looking for grade 1 to share info

Posts.Content: Hi Whiskers I'm so glad you came here and told us how you are feeling.  You've had a lot to deal with, so I'm not surprised that you've finally cracked under the strain.  I'd be fed up too (I was, a couple of years ago, in a similar place).  If you have a BCN, please call her and tell her about the rib pain.  You need to have it checked for your own peace of mind.  And if there's a problem, then it can be dealt with, if there isn't, you can relax. You haven't said what kind of reconstruction you are having but to put your mind at rest, I had a sub total laparascopic (keyhole) hysterectomy which, admittedly, left the ovaries in, but I was riding horses within a week and walking about with no problem in 3 days.  So it shouldn't put you back.  If you are having a DIEP reconstruction, you could ask if it could be done at the same time?  Even if you are having implants, I don't see why it wouldn't be possible to have the surgery done at the same time.  Especially since you already had the Mx, the hard part is already done.  It would save on anaesthetic and theatre time, so it makes sense.  As to how our friends cope, it makes me fume that in the midst of all the crap, we have to worry about how OTHER PEOPLE are coping with OUR diagnosis!!!  This is why I talk about cancer in everyday conversation, making it normal. It's still a taboo, it's as if it's catching!  And to be honest, if they can't deal with it, then that is their problem.  You certainly find out who your friends are on this lovely journey.  I'm sure you are as much of a lovely person now as you were before but your outlook will have changed.  There's no getting away from it. You will find people you didn't think were bothered become great friends, and others you thought you could rely on will melt away.  It's their loss.   Benja - if your thyroid got destroyed you need to be very careful that your B12 is above 75% of the "normal" range, not just within in, because you won't be able to convert your levothyroxine to T3 the active hormone, also make sure your ferritin (stored iron), folate (folic acid) and Vitamin D (D3) are all in the top 75% of the ranges for the same reason.  If you want more information on this send me a friend request. Helen x
Posts.Title: never ending :(

Posts.Content: I haven't had a grant but I have heard that people have for specific things.  Why not ring them and see if you are eligible? You don't ask, you don't get!
Posts.Title: Macmillan grants

Posts.Content: Before my Mx, I used to get weird sensations in my right nipple, like it was turning in then out then in all the time.  Recently, I've started to have sensations in the same area again, even though the nipple and all the ducts and tissue was removed!  I'm guessing it is the nerve endings mending, and I also have the itching, which I can feel, but I can't feel myself scratch the itch .... :D
Posts.Title: phantom feelings

Posts.Content: Trish - I'm so glad you posted this!  I had a double Mx in November and expanders.  My PS wants to leave them in but they're already rippliing, and I know that in six months time I'm going to have to do something.  I could have had a DIEP at the time but was talked out of it.   I'm definitely going to explore this route further.  Can I ask if your boobs feel like they did before?  I don't mean the numbness, obviously, but the texture?  And did they put the tissue under the muscle or on top?  I really can't find this one out.  I know it's not an easy option, but then I honestly don't think there is one.  Implants certainly aren't.  And the more I read, the more I think they'll need replacing in the not too distant future regardless.

Posts.Content: Sorry to have hijacked your thread, June ...

Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: If they are near the nipple then I would have thought they could be dealt with during the mastectomy. We cannot give medical advice but you can ring the Macmillan free helpline open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm on 0808 808 0000. Nurses will be able to help  You can also post in our ask an expert section and they aim to respond within 48 hours.
Posts.Title: Internal Mammary Nodes - can they be removed ?

Posts.Content: Rach1969 the risk of lymphodema is from infection.  So a sterile needle through previously sterilsed skin and then covered with a sterile dressing SHOULDN'T cause a problem!  But there's always a small risk.
Posts.Title: Frozen shoulder, Cortisone injection, lymphedema risk.

Posts.Content: Hi MargaretLynne There are several schools of thought on this, but if you are unlikely to need rads then there is no need to delay the reconstruction. I've never heard that there is back and neck pain without one though!  I could see why there might be (temporarily) with reconstruction, but in the longer term these things balance out.   What sort of reconstruction are you thinking about?  If you need more help, you could look at KeepingAbreast.org which has lots of information and there may be a group near you where ladies meet and show their results of surgery and talk of their own experience.  I know that Macmillan also has information, but personally I found that site more informative.  And there's nothing like personal experience to help make up your mind. Chemo wouldn't affect your reconstruction, although it may be delayed due to poor healing if there are any difficulties in this area.
Posts.Title: Immediate versus delayed reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Sue Think about it like this - whether you cry or not isn't going to make a difference to the outcome.  If you really want to cry, set a timer for 15 minutes.  Give yourself permission to cry until the buzzer goes off.  I guarantee you will be done well before.  Crying is exhausting and in all honesty, you know it's not what you want.   Now know that even if there is spread, cancer is very treatable, and you don't need to start planning your final days!  I don't know what sleeping pills you have been given, but if it really is too overwhelming, perhaps some anti-depressants, such as diazepam, could be useful.  They stop your brain from focusing on negative thoughts, so perhaps it could be worth a trip back to your GP. As has been said, once you understand the results and your treatment plan, you will start to surface, and things will start to become normal for you. Good luck.
Posts.Title: How can I stop myself crying?

Posts.Content: I think they tend to assume that we don't have any medical knowledge and will panic at everything they tell us rather than treating us as individuals.  The problem is, if they give as much information as possible to people who can't cope they are doing the wrong thing for them.   And sadly they deal with so many patients that they don't have time to get to know us as individuals,
Posts.Title: Why?

Posts.Content: I love posts like this! Open the fizz tonight, Helen!
Posts.Title: 1st Annual mammo clear.....I am so happy

Posts.Content: You've got to laugh, or you'll cry!!!
Posts.Title: Another "dumb things people say" video

Posts.Content: It's just bad luck, sometimes, June.  My reaction was "Right, I'm going to make the rest of my life count" and never mind rainy days, every day should be lived for itself.  After all, we could be run over by a bus tomorrow!  So get through it as quickly as you can, and make the most of being alive.  The alternative is a lot worse.
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: It could be that during the surgery, a nerve was damaged or caught and now you have been moving it, it is tingling. Or you could be developing cording, which might go right to the inside of the thumb.  Keep doing the exercises and stretches and hopefully you will not develop it, but do mention it at your appointment.
Posts.Title: Strange pain after slb

Posts.Content: basonk  It's unfortunately quite normal for treatment plans to change as time goes on.  To be honest, it IS better this way, although it doesn't feel like it at the time. If they hit you with everything at once, your brain can't process it. Every time I went for an appointment something changed.  Fortunately it all worked out in the end.  Your oncotype test may come back that you are low risk for chemo so you don't have it. Better to know one way or the other than have it unnecessarily.   Good luck!
Posts.Title: Thought I knew my treatment plan until today

Posts.Content: Have you had a look at this link?
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: I find one of the best ways to get a good night's sleep if I'm struggling is to take a rounded teaspoon of chelated magnesium in a glass of orange juice about 8, ready for bed around 10 and sleep like a log.  If your sister is going for the bath option, a good spoonful of epsom salts will have the same effect, but don't stay in for more than 20 minutes.
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi both Yes, perfectly normal, I'm afraid.  You can ask for some counselling from your hospital/GP although there is often a wait for it.  Some cancer units have their own counsellor though, depending where you are, so worth asking. As to the exercises, they are very important to get back the full range of movement, but if you are in a lot of pain doing them you may have developed cording, which feels like a rope under the skin from the armpit to the thumb (sometimes not all the way).  If you have this you should ask for specialist physio treatment and make sure that the therapist understands about cording.  If you're not sure, there is an excellent video on YouTube here  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DhseruhnMUc&feature=related if the link doesn't work, paste it into your browser, or google axilliary cording and lymphodoema. Finally, if you let us know where you are, there may well be one of us that is just up the road from you and can meet up for coffee and a chat.  The only people who will understand how you feel are the people that have been where you are.  There are literally hundreds of us here, so there's bound to be someone, or your local hospital may have a support group - ask your BCN.  I'm in Bedford if that helps.
Posts.Title: Discomfort and general low feeling after mastectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Catchpole  Were you offered reconstruction? It's entirely your call but it should be offered.  I was able to request a prophylactic mastectomy at the same time although I had to be approved by a second surgeon at a different hospital.  There was no cancer found in the breast but I had a strong family history so it was agreed.  Good luck with your surgery.
Posts.Title: Saw Surgeon

Posts.Content: I agree. It's got me really wound up today - I mean who wants to know they've got cancer but perhaps they'll just leave it and see if it's a bad one?  FFS. I had no lump, just some pains, and frankly nearly didn't even visit the doctor. OK, so mine was grade 1, and no lymph nodes, but I still ended up with a Mx and I am grateful for it. It's such a small price to pay in the scheme of things, and I didn't have to undergo chemo or RT because it WAS so early Irresponsible is the word, and BCC and Macmillan should be coming out and drawing attention away from this.  My feeling is that people will either not go for scans or leave the results and not go back.
Posts.Title: BBC Report

Posts.Content: It sounds like you have nerve pain which opiates and NSAIDS and normal painkillers won't touch. See if they can give you some Amytriptylene or gabapentin, they may be more effective. Morphine doesn't work for everyone.
Posts.Title: Painkillers, alternatives when the standard ones don't work after...

Posts.Content: Spot on, Optimistic! Except you don't need to go to the profile, if you hover of the name it brings up a box with the option to "Add friend".  Then, when accepted, you can message.
Posts.Title: making friends

Posts.Content: That's quite unusual. Usually you would be treated at the hospital you have the biopsy.  Was there a reason that you were given this list?
Posts.Title: Selecting hospital

Posts.Content: EMLA cream is lidocaine, which is an anaesthetic. It does work, I've actually got some here and it's "magic" cream!  You can put it on kid's knocks and the pain disappears ... :)
Posts.Title: Scared of needles

Posts.Content: Have you thought about hypnosis? A few sessions might cure your fear or at least make it easier for you.  If you are in the east or England I have a friend who has trained to do this.
Posts.Title: Scared of needles

Posts.Content: Hi Emma SSorry to hear your bad news but im glad that Alison has posted some helpful advice and also that at least the cause of the pain has been found and is now being addressed.   Here's to cancer research for the future.  Helen x
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Get some Eurax cream for now (from any supermarket or chemist) and get your doctor to prescribe Doxepin Hydrochloride ointment. They probably won't have this in Stock so that is why I say get the other one.  Eurax does sting a little when you apply it but it does work.  The other is better though.
Posts.Title: Lost pubic hair. Very uncomfortable!

Posts.Content: Thanks, Kacang Rach12, I think you should really go to A&E or a walk in centre if you have one  near you.  What you want to avoid is infection setting in, and you probably need the area dressed properly.   If you can, then, bind the area and restrict it so that the body doesn't see a void, it may be that the fluid starts to reabsorb.  Don't forget to keep up the fluids, though, you don't want to be dehydrated.
Posts.Title: Axillary node clearance - 1 week on feeling worse

Posts.Content: Fantastic, well done! We are on 29 years this year, my in laws are on 62 years ago today!
Posts.Title: Celebration today ...

Posts.Content: I think more tests need to be done, but it looks psychological if they work in hospital, don't you think?
Posts.Title: SICKNESS / NAUSEA 5 MONTHS AFTER CHEMO & RADIOTHERAPY

Posts.Content: I had bilateral mastectomy with implants and both nipples removed.  I waa happy enough with no reconstruction of the nipple but after a while, something was missing although I didn't want more surgery.   My husband put some Haribo fried eggs on for a laugh and I was amazed at the difference.  I had seen some good and bad nipple reconstructions, I knew that they mostly flatten a lot. I also knew that the NHS tattoos fade quickly and requires ongoing maintenance. I was used to wearing a lot of t-shirts or camisoles and didn't want the nipply look! I was directed at a specialist nipple tattooist and had them permanently done.  I won't say that my boobs look 100% realistic but they are a lot better than they were.
Posts.Title: Nipple reconstruction....or not?

Posts.Content: Hi Littlesusie I used to do Yoga.  I have to say I haven't done it for a few years but you would have to tell your tutor that you have had breast cancer and ops, etc.  It takes a lot of core strength to do properly, and you might not be able to do all the exercises, but find a basic beginner class and call them up.  Explain what you have had done and see what they say.  It's great exercise and leaves you feeling great and relaxed.   Just to make you giggle, my husband said to me when I started it, "Do you all sit in a room and go OMMMM?"  Yes, you do, but it's a lot more than that!
Posts.Title: Yoga

Posts.Content: Hi Rach and welcome to the group.  Cancer is a pain, isn't it? You feel fine, you are told you need treatment and then you have to struggle to recover.  The good news is that it does get better.  The bad news is that it can take a while. If you feel tightness down the arm from the armpit to the elbow or wrist then you may have AWS or axillary Web syndrome otherwise known as cording.. You may feel a cord like feeling under the skin. If you have this you really need specialist physio.  Ask your BCN for the name of a specialist physio and get your GP to refer to as an urgent case.   Otherwise do persist with the exercises as they do really help. Go just as far as it hurts and a tiny bit further. If you are due to have rads then you need full movement in the arm to make sure you can get it out of the way of the machine.   Do ask for help whatever the situation.
Posts.Title: Axillary node clearance - 1 week on feeling worse

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that, Wendy.  If you let us know which town, it's possible that someone may know of somewhere that is available that might suit?
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: What's your maximum budget?
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: Definitely get your bloods checked.  Your ferritin levels should be between 70 and 90 to be optimal, although if they are within range you may not get treatment.  You may need to supplement yourself if necessary.
Posts.Title: Frustrated lack of energy

Posts.Content: Topo There are several options, the LD flap and the TRAM flap use muscle for the reconstruction, the DIEP flap uses fat/tissue. The TRAM has fallen out of favour, possibly because it weakens the stomach muscles, possibly because the DIEP has much better results, after all, the breast are largely made of fat, so to use muscle doesn't make sense. Some implants are under the pectoral muscle but now more are being put into a "sling" to hang more naturally.
Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Content: One thing that can cause hair loss is lack of iron or being hypothroid. Chemo can really mess with the balance of vitamins and minerals and hormones in the body, so do have a blood test. For women the optimal ferritin is between 70 and 130, not just in range. Floradix or solgar gentle iron are easy on the stomach and need to be taken with Vit C.
Posts.Title: Getting hair back to normal after chemo

Posts.Content: Great news!
Posts.Title: 1st year mammogram

Posts.Content: Really think that trawling the internet can make things worse.  Obviously there are a lot of worst case scenarios out there - it's a bit like going on a rollercoaster to make yourself frightened.   There is a limit to how much information is helpful, so I think now just stop, take your mind off it by concentrating on something else.  Tomorrow is another day and you can deal with it then.   Helen xx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: You know the motto, If in doubt, check it out? I'd keep checking the temp, and if there is ANYTHING that you are worried about, ring either your BCN or chemo unit.  That's what they're there for.   I wouldn't go to the GP at this point, simply because the waiting room will be full of people coughing and spluttering, and you'll only increase your chance of coming down with something, but if you're not sure, ask to speak to them on the phone - they may be able to say you can wait in the car and they'll come and get you so you go straight in?   Having a delayed session can't be worse than having chemo when your immune system is fighting off anything? Helen xx
Posts.Title: help - what to do if i get a cold during chemo?

Posts.Content: I find one of the best ways to get a good night's sleep if I'm struggling is to take a rounded teaspoon of chelated magnesium in a glass of orange juice about 8, ready for bed around 10 and sleep like a log.  If your sister is going for the bath option, a good spoonful of epsom salts will have the same effect, but don't stay in for more than 20 minutes.
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: I've not experienced it but I have cyclizine prescribed which is an anti-sickness which your mum could take on a regular basis until the feeling subsides? It may be psychosomatic, if she was ill during the chemo, and maybe a break from the feeling would help her overcome the feeling?  Just a thought.
Posts.Title: SICKNESS / NAUSEA 5 MONTHS AFTER CHEMO & RADIOTHERAPY

Posts.Content: And this one has some places.
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: Hi Lynda Yes, it does sound normal.  I suspect it's some scar tissue.  It does settle with time, but even now, 2.5 years after my surgery, I find if I do too much I get an ache.   You have to pace yourself, and learn when to stop. Helen
Posts.Title: recovering from lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi tm680 Firstly welcome to the group, I can totally understand your shock and I honestly think that they don't tell us all the information at once so that we can just deal with one thing at a time.  I know it seems like a long time now, but a year will go by before you know it.   I assume that you are expecting reduction surgery on the good side, to even you up?  I don't know why there would be such a long delay in that case, so I would ask for further information, and if necessary, seek out a second opinion from another hospital so that you can be sure that this isn't just your hospital policy but what is in your best interests.  It may be that the surgery you have had needs to settle to know how much to reduce the other breast by, but I would doubt this would take a year.   Here's a massive cyber (((((hug))))) for you, and please stick around, you will find yourself with lots of help and support, and if you have any wobbles along the way, just post and someone will reply.
Posts.Title: Help! surgery after radiotherapy on other boob - when, How long?

Posts.Content: Thanks, Kate, but even though they know a lot, unless they've actually been through it, I don't suppose they know how it would feel?   That's why I was hoping someone on here had been through it and could give me the benefit of their experience.
Posts.Title: DIEP Flap after implants

Posts.Content: silkpainter31 Hi Everyone I visited the BCN last Friday for prosthesis fitting , that went well . I saw the physiotherapist yesterday and that was OK too. Expect both of them with no prompting from me said I might like to think about more surgery to correct the hard scars and "hole" at the sternum end . As I had a seroma for awhile my scars have stuck to the chest wall whilst healing. It's ugly & pulls all the time . Has anyone else experienced this please, I thought I'd finished with hospitals for a little while ! Hugs to all the ladies going through worse than me xx Hi Silkpainter Hmmm this is a tricky one.  If you weren't in pain and happy with yourself I would say leave well alone.  However it does sound as though you have issues and I would revisit your onco-plastic surgeon, as he may be able to help.  You could also get a second opinion from another surgeon, as sometimes they have experience that others don't.
Posts.Title: Scarring

Posts.Content: Hi sweetcheeks I had this and you have my sympathy!  You need specialist physiotherapy to pop the cords. Ring your bcn and see if they can give you a name then you have to get your gp to refer you. Make sure they know to mark it up as urgent or you can be waiting for weeks.  WitWithin a week you should ring the physiotherapy department and insist on an early appointment.
Posts.Title: Cording after Mastectomy and node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda  I'm so sorry that your concerns weren't addressed properly.   If you can,  ask someone to keep calling for you so that you don't have to. Contact every one you have a number for and perhaps make a GP appointment as they should have access to the hospital records.  Morphine can be very constipating so make sure you take measures against that and perhaps ask the GP if you can get stronger painkillers..  The support group is a good idea if you feel up to it,  otherwise call the organisers and ask if they have a buddy system,  or if not, if you say roughly where you are, perhaps one of us are not to far away.
Posts.Title: Not sure where I belong anymore

Posts.Content: I don't use any seed or vegetable oil to cook with anymore.  I use olive oil cold (or very occasionally to cook with), otherwise I use coconut oil.  It's the only one that doesn't change properties when heated.
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Have a look on Rightmove. My sister used to live there, there are three at least in good areas in budget
Posts.Title: let down again

Posts.Content: I've found it absolutely spot on with my experience. Everyone trying to be understanding and getting it so wrong. I have always loved Cold Feet, and I think it's so well written.   Obviously, like with the Mac advert at the cinema, it all depends where you are in your treatment, but I think in terms of how others treat cancer patients and also how patients push away their loved ones, it's spot on. Hopefully it will promote understanding. I read an article in a magazine that Fay Ripley felt she had to play the role as well as possible not to let patients down. I think she can be justly proud of her performance.

Posts.Content: Jojo4  Do you know when you start chemo?
Posts.Title: Recipe for mouthwask

Posts.Content: Hayley it's the pits when you are always waiting for something to happen but unfortunately that is what tends to happen once you have a cancer diagnosis. Your results may not be ready simply because it does sometimes take a bit extra time to check your her2 + status or simply that they want to be sure. Good luck and whatever happens, we are here to help and support you.
Posts.Title: Pathology results after surgery

Posts.Content: Firstly ,don't panic. You may have to go to hospital but far better than having an undiagnosed infection , don't you think?  As you are seeing the nurse, see what she says. If she advises you to go then you know what to do.
Posts.Title: Advice re drain fluid has become dark red last 36 hours

Posts.Content: In an ideal world, possibly.  However a biopsy only looks at a small amount of tissue and doesn't give the full picture.  I had a similar diagnosis although grade 1, stage 1, and although original plan was WLE and radiotherapy, eventually it was mastectomy and no radiotherapy because there was no tissue to zap.  So I would ask why you are being offered the radiotherapy.  I don't think chemo affects implants, but willing to be proved wrong if anyone knows different.
Posts.Title: waiting for mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy - what about reconstruction...

Posts.Content: No idea, beevergirl but fingers crossed it will be all right.
Posts.Title: Deja vu- another lump after 6 yrs

Posts.Content: M - please try not to panic.  It's entirely possible that it's damage due to radiotherapy, or some form of rearrangement of the tumour cells (I.e, they've died within the breast) and created a lump, or simple scar tissue from the lumpectomy. The radiologists see things all the time, and they know that it's rare to have recurrence so quickly so trust your team but do let us know when you find out the options. Your team would biopsy any suspicious area and test to see what would work for it, so it's impossible to second guess it.  Mastectomy isn't necessarily any more effective, it really depends.
Posts.Title: Possible recurrence

Posts.Content: Just wondering if anyone has had a DIEP flap done after previously having implants?  I have Becker expanders, and I'm seriously considering having a DIEP. My concern is with what happens regarding the muscles that have been split to hold the implants - do you get normal use back?  Do they contract back to "normal"?   I keep going round and round this all in my head and it's spinning quite honestly.
Posts.Title: DIEP Flap after implants

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne Yes it's perfectly normal for the area to be numb.  They have cut through a lot of nerves and unfortunately they take a long time to repair and you will probably always be a little numb there.  You may experience some tingling or stabbing pain there as well.   If the tablets aren't helping you sleep perhaps go back to the gp because some don't work for some people.  He can give you something else.  Try to be busy in the day as well so you are actually tired at bedtime.
Posts.Title: Sleepless nights

Posts.Content: Since this is a Bank Holiday weekend, I know that there won't be people to call apart from NHS Direct (who IMHO are usually fairly hopeless) but you could give them a call.  Otherwise, and what I would do, is head to your local A&E.  It does sound as though you need it looked at, and you don't want to wait until Tuesday.  Take proper care of yourself first!
Posts.Title: Advice please-wound leaking

Posts.Content: You can ask the Keeping Abreast team, they have groups around the country so may be able to help. Check their contact us page.
Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Content: Hi Scaredmum It's good that you are being checked quickly. You won't have surgery at your appointment, you will be examined and have a mammogram, possibly ultrasound and even a biopsy.  You may get results straight away, but not all hospitals do this. I'm not going to say don't worry, because I know that's impossible, but keep busy and do bear in mind that treatment for breast cancer (if you have it) is very successful with a 90%+ success rate. Good luck and let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Lump in my breast, confused about referral

Posts.Content: Hi AngieD, welcome to the group, even though none of us wanted to join, it was the best thing we could do. Glad to hear that your husband is doing well so far.  You haven't said how old he is, which may have a bearing on any future treatments, but I would have thought that his oncologist will take the PD into account when determining his treatment pathway. They may have to involve a PD specialist in the MDT meeting (multi disciplinary team) when they discuss and agree the future treatment, which may mean it takes slightly longer to get on to the next stage, but it is best to be safe than sorry. If you have any more clinical information it may help people to comment.  This may involve stage, node involvement, type of cancer. You may also find our Friends and Family group of help yourself in dealing with the patient. Hugs for you.
Posts.Title: Male breast cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear it's been so crap, Jackie. Definitely make sure that you drink lots of water through the next one, as it helps in many ways, including headaches, getting the chemicals through your system, and getting it out again too.   It's rotten when things don't go to plan, but it will all come right in the end.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: That's terrible. If you have the name of the consultant then ring the hospital and ask for his secretary.  It won't do any harm to stop, they are always advising breaks to let people recover.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and surgery

Posts.Content: Just wanted to pop in that implants have a bad press, mine are fine, although have capsulated slightly, no one but be notices. DIEP recon looks fab, very natural, but the recovery time is longer and there are more complications.
Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Content: Liz - you could ask the oncologist for the statistics for and against radiotherapy.  That might help you come to a decision.  Given that you have already had chemo, herceptin and mastectomy, I would have thought that radiotherapy would probably be overkill, especially in the light of no cancer cells being found, but you obviously have to make the decision and be happy that you have done all you need to do.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy 3 weeks ago & now Cancer Free! Yipee!!

I don't, I would try some of the larger cancer centres, like the Christie, or Royal Marsden, to see if they can help?
Posts.Title: Advice with reconstruction: implants verus DIEP

Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: There's a lot of it about at the moment. It might be worth a call to your BCN, just to let them know, but hopefully it will have gone by the date of your operation.
Posts.Title: Is it just after effects of chemo??

Posts.Content: If you have pain without a reason, do get it checked out.  A friend of mine has recently been diagnosed with secondaries in a few places, one of which she had pain in.   None of us are immortal, but we must make the most of now, because life is precious, too precious to waste on worrying.

Posts.Content: I believe you should stop for around a fortnight before but I suggest you ring your BCN or oncologist or surgeon for more accurate advice.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and surgery

Posts.Content: Oh Tinkers, that is so lovely!  I'm practically in tears just reading that!  (and I'm like you but I do blub at the drop of a hat!) So many people have been superb to me, offering help driving, or picking up shopping, whatever. One example - about a week after my Mx and only just after having the drains out, I was pretty drained (pun intended!) myself.  My neighbours had invited my husband and I to a Christmas drinks party/buffet.  Anyway, I excused myself, but sent husband on his own, as he would at least get fed!   Anyway, after a while, he came back with a tray and a plate of food from the buffet!  And a bit later, he came back with dessert .... It was so lovely of them to think of me - they had pressed him to bring me something, so he did.  And I don't really even know them well!
Posts.Title: Lovely things that people have done for me

Posts.Content: I clicked the link and it worked for me. I agree, it was really good to read. Acceptance is the state that I'm at too - I just want to get on with life, make the most of it now,and make sure that I don't regret not doing things.  Helen x
Posts.Title: Acceptance

Posts.Content: Emma If you are ssaying that things have changed since you were diagnosed then you should definitely contact your breast care nurse.  It could simply be bruising but it needs to be checked out as soon as possible. Please call them today.  Helen
Posts.Title: quite worried

Posts.Content: Great news, Liz, glad it has all worked out for you!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy 3 weeks ago & now Cancer Free! Yipee!!

Posts.Content: Pretty sure it's not possible!!
Posts.Title: Mammogram after mx?

Posts.Content: I presume you mean that you would have a diep flap operation as a reconstruction?  To be honest, that is the least of the problems, since you will be asleep and suddenly wake up however long you're out!  I'm surprised that your BCN advised against - I thought the rules were that they weren't allowed to advise.  However, if the nipple is conserved you a) may still not have feeling there, and b) there is a 5% chance of a recurrence in the nipple, since the ducts lead from there.  My story - I had a WLE to remove an infinitesimal lump, and SNB.   Nodes were clear, but not clear margins on lump, so had further excision.  After this, my boob was very puckered - they tried to avoid a big scar, so went in around the nipple, and I couldn't bear to look at it.  I could probably have had some reconstruction (lipofilling or something) to fill it out again, but when I went  back for results, they'd found more cancer cells, so it was MX for me.  I opted for a double with immediate recon with implants.  I didn't need further RT or chemo, and was put on Tamoxifen, but am currently off it.  Going back on later today as long as I remember! My  boobs don't look bad but they are a lot firmer than I was expecting, and can be painful at times, but I think that's just me, since one of them moves more than it should.  I'm currently contemplating having a DIEP flap procedure.  Good luck with whatever you decide.  Helen x
Posts.Title: Quadrectomy or MX?

Posts.Content: It's great that the aloe vera gel worked for you, and when cold it's lovely and soothing.  But always let your team know if what they give you doesn't work for you - there are lots of different options, so if the first one (usually the cheapest!) doesn't work, keep going until they give you the good stuff.  In the meantime, carry on!  LOL
Posts.Title: Advice for radiotherapy burns

Posts.Content: Hi lizgra  Yes you have triple negative breast cancer. The treatment for this is always chemo.  When you get to that stage, do join our monthly chemo club for hints and tips on how to get through it.  Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Confused about diagnosis

Posts.Content: I'm sure you are aware, Jo, but as a cancer patient you are covered under the disability act.  To start these proceedings whilst undergoing treatment is not only insensitive but could count as constructive dismissal.   I would give the macmillan support line a ring on Monday and ask to speak to their advisors, as they will be able to give you the most up to date information.  The number is 0808 808 0000.   The union is a good idea, too.  If you have one, get them to work for you, that's what they're for, allegedly!
