Posts.Content: Oh dear!
Posts.Title: Slimming world/ weightwatchers while on Chemo??

Posts.Content: Congratulations Carol, it's such a relief when they pass!
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Kerryanne I'm sorry that your results weren't good.  I'm not going to lie, you will need help for a good few weeks after the op, but I am wondering if you are considering reconstruction, as you are so young? If you have reconstruction, you will take longer to recover, but as you are having chemo as well, you can take part of that time as well to recover properly.  You may have been advised to wait until after chemo, so in which case, physically you will be stronger sooner after the op, but then have to think about this later. There is a young women's breast cancer group on Facebook - it's a secret group, so no one can see you there, but you have to ask to join.  Perhaps someone here can invite you if they are on it.
Posts.Title: mri results in

Posts.Content: Hi Devon Dweller I'm sorry to read that so many things have been discovered.  Your wife is lucky to have you there to support her, but please ensure you get support too.  There is a group for family and friends (link) where you will find others going through this and will identify with what you are going through.   I hope that all the appointments come through quickly, I know you will chase them if they don't, because of the aggressive nature of your wife's disease, all treatment should start within a week or two to give her the best chance.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: That sounds about right.  The thing is, if you have a concern, ring them.  That's what they are there for and get paid to do.  And if only to put your mind at rest.  The sickness is probably just anxiety.  Try to do some deep breathing and then keep busy.
Posts.Title: quite worried

Posts.Content: Hi Kimlinda I wasn't working when I was diagnosed (we'd just moved and had projects to do on the house) and it took me a year from surgery to get off my butt and get a job.  I wasn't really ready to go back before then, so don't feel you are a wimp.   Everyone is different, but the thing you will get from everyone's stories is that everyone does it differently, and you need to take it at your own pace.  Plus we all get there in the end! Helen
Posts.Title: Wimp

Posts.Content: Unfortunately the numbness is likely to be permanent.  The itching is annoying, isn't it??
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Five years on and my armpit is still numb. My GP said that some areas of nerves just don't repair.
Posts.Title: Getting back to exercise. And underarm sensitivity.

Posts.Content: Definitely don't be sorry.  Your wife needs you to chase appointments, work out what is happening and make sure things don't slip through the cracks.  First thing Monday ring the hospital and kick ass. The government guidelines ssay treatment should start within 31 days of diagnosis so you will be at the end of it by then.   Mistakes happen but when they happen to you or your wife it's personal.  Good luck to both of you and if you need a rant feel free.  If you feel the need to talk to another partner send a friend request aa my husband has been where you are.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: So sorry for your loss, Devon Dweller. I hope it was a peaceful end.  Do be kind to yourself and give yourself time to come to terms.  When you are ready you may wish to join the bereaved group here.
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: I'm very sorry to hear about your friend.  Could she not stay with her family for the short time she has left?  I think it might be an idea to call the macmillan helpline to see if they can help in any way. Alternatively could she rent somewhere for the duration?  She will probably find herself in a hospice near the end so if it is possible to move first and transfer health care that may help.  I feel a bit helpless but you are doing a great thing on your friend's behalf.
Posts.Title: months to live. secondary cancer breast

Posts.Content: One of the members of our support group wrote this book,  Worms on Parachutes. Wortha read!
Posts.Title: Books you recommend

Posts.Content: Denial isn't just a river in Egypt, is it? Men seem to think that they won't worry until they have the "facts" whereas if it was them with the issue they'd be all over the internet, researching and planning and worrying about what they'd found on the internet until they were told what their treatment plan is.  Because it is mostly women that get breast cancer, and it is getting more and more prevalent, they need to accept that if it is suspected then there is a good possibility that it will eventually turn to a positive diagnosis.  However, there is a 90% chance of a good outcome of living for 5 or more years from these, with most of the other 10% being either late diagnosis, or elderly (and dying from other causes). So please don't spend time worrying about not being around for your children, at this point that is an extreme outcome, so work on diagnosis-treatment-recovery rather than the alternative.
Posts.Title: Tried and scared

Posts.Content: Hi Joyce I don't know about the pains, as I didn't have RT, but I would ask when you go back for any creams etc, because from what I have read here, better to keep moisturised during RT and prevent any drying out/cracking/burning.   You need to use the right thing though, so ask at the unit when you go back - they may have assumed that you have already been given something.
Posts.Title: Feeling better

Posts.Content: Hi all  I know you didn't have chemo, Toony but for others, a friend of mine had problems with bruising following chemo.  It turned out that it affected her ability to make platelets, and periodically she gets bruising and has to be checked with a transfusion if necessary.  I'm just mentioning it in case it's relevant to anyone.
Posts.Title: Bruising on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Lyn151  It sounds like you may have an infection.  Hopefully you have a number for the chemo unit that you can call 24/7.  Please call them straightaway. If you don't have a number, please go to A&E or call an ambulance if you don't have anyone to take you. This could be an emergency.
Posts.Title: Pain in arm chemo fec was given 9 dsys ago

Posts.Content: Ah, fair enough I suppose.  Losing a breast is definitely hard.  Some people are just glad to have the cancer out - because mine was so small and no one could feel it, plus I felt fine in myself, it was almost like a secondary consideration for me.  See if you can ask for an MRI - they're not fool proof but if there were mets anywhere they would likely show up.  It's probably just a chest infection, and you're worrying unnecessarily, but that's easy for me to say!  As has been said before on here, cancers really don't generally rampage out of control through the body, but there are so many myths about it that it's difficult to put this idea out of your mind.  This really is the worst time - once decisions are made, and you start actually going down the route of treatment, you will find things get easier.  Helen
Posts.Title: Quadrectomy or MX?

Posts.Content: Hi Daisy10  I had to go back for margins as they didn't get enough.  In all honesty, I should have expected it, as my breast surgeon came round after the surgery and said "I'm really concerned about you"!!!!! I suspect she tried too hard not to make a big scar, they made a incision around the nipple, but the cancer was on the side nearest the arm and I think she just didn't get it all and she knew it.  So, I went back to the clinic for results to be told that they needed to take more.  As it happened, with my type of cancer, they actually found more on the other side from the original site and I ended up with a mastectomy, but that was me and you are you.  Sometimes with cancer it seems that every appointment brings more bad news, but after a bit things start to be good news and then more good news until you are off the rollercoaster and back in the theme park.  Good luck, you will be fine, whatever happens. PS, this was all nearly five years ago and all is well!
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Rusty I had some real depressed moments when I was going through and after treatment.  All I can say is that it DOES get better, but it DOES take time.  Be gentle on your self, and if you feel down, put your timer on the cooker and give yourself permission to shout scream and cry for 15 minutes.  I pretty much guarantee you'll be looking at the clock before it goes off.  It gets the tension out of your system.  Then, pick yourself up, kick yourself up the bum and do something nice just for you!
Posts.Title: Fed up and depressed

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that you are both finding it so hard.  Fear is difficult to live with and along with constant pain and other symptoms, you can be forgiven for believing that death is imminent. Do keep posting here.  No one is letting anyone else down by feeling this way, it is what it is, and we will do our best to give you hope. You have been given a second chance, if you hadn't had treatment then you may have had a few years, this way you should have many more.
Posts.Title: Constant Anxiety

Posts.Content: Have you been tested for pernicious anaemia? Low B12, high MCHC low iron can be indicators.  Have you been run down recently? Fighting off a cold?
Posts.Title: Low neutrophils months after chemo

Posts.Content: Keep an eye on it.  If it's not any better by the end of the week, let your BCN know. You can bathe it with saline solution (just boil some water, add salt, allow to cool and dab the wound with it on some non fibrous swabs) and it should heal within a few days.  Keep it as dry as possible otherwise.
Posts.Title: Bleeding from incision

Posts.Content: Hi Bev Tramadol is quite a powerful opiate.  I would just take one at night to help you sleep and try to keep on top of the rest of the pain during the day with other drugs.  You could always try Solpadol, Cocodamol, or high strength ibuprofen during the day?  Even a mix as long as you keep the dose of paracetamol contained therein at a low dose. Hang in there, it won't last for too long.
Posts.Title: Docetexal

Posts.Content: One thing to be aware of is that your surgeon may try to push you towards his preferred method of reconstruction rather than the one that is best for you.  He may also not discuss options that he personally doesn't do - ask for ALL the options, and ask how many of that type of operation your surgeon performs each year.  That can have a direct bearing on the result and the recovery. You may find that for your ideal reconstruction you have to travel to a different hospital.  DON'T let this be a factor in making up your mind - in the scheme of things it's the least important thing! Helen x
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery - help!

Posts.Content: Well done, Joyce, that is brilliant!
Posts.Title: Feeling better

Posts.Content: Hi Petrosa I just wanted to pop in and add to the excellent replies that having found the nodes positive, means that they are doing their job which is to trap the cells from moving into the rest of the body. This is good news, so hold on to that, and believe that you are going to get through this and be around for plenty of years for your young one. When my aunt went for her first ever mammogram, she was 49, and not expecting to be told that they had found cancer.  She had a mastectomy and over 25 years later she is still alive and kicking.   Just as many of us here are, years after.  :)
Posts.Title: Stressed out!

Posts.Content: Typical it's the weekend.  I would call your chemo unit.  One of the rarer side effects of chemo is pulmonary embolisms so I think your GP was wrong to dismiss you. In fact I would bypass the GP and either go to the chemo unit or if it gets worse, A&E. If you can't get hold of your hospital, call the NHS number, 111. They will assess you.
Posts.Title: Breathlessness

Posts.Content: It's probably a seroma - a build up of fluid in the area.  It's very common to have these things appear even weeks after, so I shouldn't worry.  Give your BCN a call in the morning to put your mind at rest.  I had more trouble with my Sentinel Node Biopsy than any of the rest of my treatment!
Posts.Title: large swelling around node incision

Posts.Content: It doesn't necessarily mean you aren't healing - if there's no redness or heat in the area then it's unlikely there's an infection, it's just the body's way of dealing with a cavity in the body - if it gets too painful it can be drained, but if possible leave it and the body will reabsorb.
Posts.Title: large swelling around node incision

Posts.Content: My understanding is that lymph nodes are removed if the sample nodes show any cancerous cells.  The CT scan is just to check that there is no spread elsewhere,It's a bit of a belt and braces check, if you like.
Posts.Title: CT scan

Posts.Content: Hi Katie, hope all went well today.   I had the same issue, I had a WLE, a further op for margins,  and then a mastectomy.  Like JJ, I opted for a double Mx and I have implant reconstruction. If you have any questions, do ask.
Posts.Title: Treatment and Diagnosis constantly changing

Posts.Content: Unfortunately the wait is longer if you are in Wales.  I would call the breast unit if you don't have an appointment  as they normally ring within a week
Posts.Title: How long is it usual to wait for urgent mammograme pls xxx

Posts.Content: Good luck, Joyce, hope it all goes smoothly, and if it doesn't, well, it's in a good cause!
Posts.Title: Feeling better

Posts.Content: And completely opposite, I, like ronstar first had a lumpectomy, then another op for further margins and they found more cancer on the other side of the sample so I was told mastectomy was necessary and at that point they offered me reconstruction. I said that I wanted a double mastectomy, so I also had to have the psychological assessment and a second opinion, I had an MRI of my breasts and they said that the good one was fine but I have family history and they agreed to a double mastectomy with implants. It was great to wake up with a pair of matching breasts and I have not regretted it. I am slightly bigger but was asked what size I wanted and said the same 36C.  It seems to me that people worry about the fact that implants will need changing. My aunt had a single mastectomy with implant when she was 49, she is now 74 and no one has ever told her she needed it changed. In fact her other breast has shrunk, but that's another story!
Posts.Title: Advice on surgery

Posts.Content: Keep  an eye on your temperature, and if it gets high  call 111. Better to be cautious.
Posts.Title: Swelling after drain removed

Posts.Content: Katee, can you feel about rope like feeling under the skin? It could be cording.   If you rest it tomorrow and it doesn't improve, get your BCN to recommend an experienced physio who knows about it.  Your gp will have to refer you, but if you have a name, it shortcuts the system as when the recommendation comes through they will fast track you. After the referral, ring the department about a week later to chase it as it is a priority.  Don't wait the standard 6-8 weeks to be seen.
Posts.Title: Tight arm feeling

Posts.Content: I think it's probably a delayed reaction to the radiotherapy, Mrs Beezley.   The scar tissue is slightly different to normal skin so will react differently.   It could get worse before you get better,  but if you are worried, get your BCN to check it out for you.
Posts.Title: Post radiotherapy effects

Posts.Content: Keeping busy is the key. Of course the worst part is during the night, but don't torture yourself, what will be will be, and worrying won't make it better, or happen quicker.   My favourite saying is worrying about tomorrow robs you of today.  Every day counts.  You could try the "Awake" thread in the middle of the night if you can't sleep.  Or get some diazepam/lorazepam/etc from your GP to knock you out at night.
Posts.Title: Worried about breast lump I’m beside myself with worry

Posts.Content: Good for you! That sea air will do you a world of good. Be naked on the boat and let the sun and salt heal you!
Posts.Title: I've done it - booked flight

Posts.Content: Hi Jamesy I had mine in November.  Double Mx and implant recon.  5 day hospital stay, drains were in for a week.  I would say that after about a month I was up and doing most things pretty normally.  Driving after 3 weeks, although the sensations were weird for a long while after.   Whilst I know that some people cope very well without, I wouldn't underestimate the emotional pain of having no breasts at all.  And it's easier for you and for the doctors to do it all at once.  One of lot anaesthetic, one lot of hospital stay, etc etc.  Yes, it's a PITA, but IMO any reconstruction is better than the alternative.
Posts.Title: Hospital Stay

Posts.Content: You'll get plenty of pain relief, so don't worry about that - it's not that bad, honest.  And it doesn't matter how long you're under - you're asleep!  It's much worse for those that wait!
Posts.Title: Hospital Stay

Posts.Content: Hi Jackie, good to hear from you again.  If you had the all clear 4 months ago and the kidney is a cyst, why are you panicking? Cysts are just like build up of fat or sebum internally, not a tumour!  Make an appointment for your peace of mind, but breathe!
Posts.Title: Scared its spread

Posts.Content: Karen I think there's a massive difference between a breast and a reconstruction.  And there's also the fact that you've had a long general anaesthetic, so that will add to any down feelings you are having. It's still very early days, and you will find that you have to make friends with your new boob.  And that will take time.  It took me about 8 months to come to terms with mine (I have implants) and was convinced I was going to have them replaced with a DIEP flap but I have now realised that they are OK, and that  if I had them changed, I might well end up with something that didn't look as good.  So it's about managing your expectations.  You don't have a new boob, you have a reconstruction.  It doesn't feel the same as your other one, and it probably doesn't look the same, either, especially at this point.   Having drains in is horrid, but at least while it is in you are not getting a seroma.  That's not fun either.  Don't forget to do your exercises. So you are not alone, and you are definitely not a freak!  Be easy on yourself, and give yourself time to adjust.   Whereabouts in the country are you? Helen
Posts.Title: Recon completed so why do I feel so miserable?

Posts.Content: You're welcome - shame you're on that side of the country, as we are just setting up a new support group for reconstruction here in Bedfordshire! But there is a Bristol group which covers quite a large area, so might be worth looking into.  If you go to KeepingAbreast dot org and look at groups you will find them.  The lady who runs one is Jackie and she's lovely! I really don't think that the medical profession realise the impact losing a breast has, and the grief that you have.  You might get the benefit of some counselling if it is available at your hospital, if not, ask your GP.
Posts.Title: Recon completed so why do I feel so miserable?

Posts.Content: Bjez do keep on top of the anti-sickness, it is so much easier than trying to get on top when it has got too bad. Fingers crossed it doesn't!
Posts.Title: New to this update

Posts.Content: Totally agreed, you will have up and down days like this for a while to come.  I had the same thing as you - went from "it's small, quick op and you'll be fine" to "need full Mx" within 6 weeks.  But they've got all mine out, and I AM recovering (although it feels like a slow process at times).   Keep popping in here - it really does help.  xx
Posts.Title: Just need a hug

Posts.Content: Welcome both
Posts.Title: Hi Spudzmum and Melancholy

Posts.Content: I agree with you about the funding. I had already heard this in some indication around the country.  I was originally told surgery and radiotherapy but after my mastectomy there was nothing to treat so I did not have it.
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: Susy First of all, I think you've discovered that actually the NHS is pretty prompt about diagnosing and treating breast cancer!  No need to go the private route.  But having done it, I'm really sorry you have had the run around from all the hospitals.  You haven't named the hospitals involved, but I know that there are surgeons  in other hospitals who would be more than happy to carry out the operation you want.  I suggest you do some research on breast reconstruction surgeons and ask for a second/third/fourth opinion, as there are a lot of "old school" surgeons who haven't moved with the times. Send me a friend request and PM if you want more details.
Posts.Title: New diagnosis - Scared and loosing faith in the system fast

Posts.Content: Which hospital are you going to?  Anyone nearby that might go with you?  I'd come myself if near enough!
Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: Tell them that if they can't get what you need, you will take Femara!
Posts.Title: Sandoz Letrozole - Boots unable to supply

Posts.Content: You can get a named generic on a prescription, I believe.
Posts.Title: Sandoz Letrozole - Boots unable to supply

Posts.Content: No, just sentinel nodes. They were all clear.
Posts.Title: Post-chemo MRI results & surgery

Posts.Content: I suppose both, although I did mean physical - it's a major operation, you are under anaesthetic for a long time (depending on the type of recon), and when you are under they do tend to treat you like a carcass, pushing and pulling you about, (there's a reason why surgeons are called butchers!) and you will have bruises in places they shouldn't have even been! But the mental trauma of losing your breast, even if you have reconstruction, cannot be underestimated.  Calling it an amputation is much nearer the mark.  I suppose if you have one of the autologous reconstructions using your own tissue then they may feel much more like your old ones (I don't know, because at the moment I've got permanent expander implants). I had my op 6 months ago (actually celebrated my boob's six month birthday on holiday last week!), and I am still struggling a bit with the whole thing.
Posts.Title: Hospital Stay

Posts.Content: Hi calador Just wanted to clarify that those were my stats, everyone is different so you need to know what yours are.   It's appalling that your GP is trying to keep you on the cheapest drugs.
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Argymargy, some people have had a generic brand put on their prescription.  The point about recurrence is that people get fed up with the side effects of medication so they stop taking them thus increasing the chances of recurrence.
Posts.Title: Sandoz Letrozole - Boots unable to supply

Posts.Content: seconding this, please call your BCN and ask for an appointment asap.  We cannot diagnose you over the internet (nor are we medically qualified), but your BCN can check you over and call a surgeon if she has concerns.
Posts.Title: massive panic! please don't hate me.

Posts.Content: I was in for 5 days with mine.  Don't rush to go home, because you will experience a lot of trauma through the op - let someone look after you while they can.  I had 2 drains when I came home, but the district nurse was able to deal with them at home for me.  Make sure you get plenty of pain relief from the hospital too.  If you want to ask any questions, feel free to message me.
Posts.Title: Hospital Stay

Posts.Content: Justin, you don't have to have a lump to have breast cancer. Inverted nipples and strange sensation are other signs. As you already have lymphoma, they will probably get you straight in for tests.  Good luck and do let us know what happens.
Posts.Title: Male breast cancer query..

Posts.Content: Good luck for tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: I think the main thing is to make sure that everything is thoroughly washed off before the radiotherapy so the radio waves can get through.  I can't believe your GP won't order you R1 and R2, but get some on next day delivery asap! Cabbages are in season!
Posts.Title: creams to use

Posts.Content: calador First of all, breathe!  Second of all, don't forget that 1,000s of patients have absolutely minimal side effects on these tablets.  The ones who post are the ones who have problems, if you are OK, you don't tend to post, so it skews the stats.   If you haven't tried some of the other brands, it's worth giving them a go. If you are going to have side effects, it's usually quite quick to show up, that said, persistence may mean that they dissipate over a month or two.   Finally, I think your BCN is wrong, it's not like you stop taking the drug and you go back to square one in a week or two.  My oncologist was happy for me to take a few months' break when things got too much and you do need to know what the statistics are for you. Often oncologists push patients onto the AIs and fail to let them know that the actual benefit is minimal. For example, when asked, my oncologist said that the chance of me surviving 5 years on tamoxifen was 98%, but by not taking it my statistics were 97%. Some people told me that for the extra 1% it was worth it, but for me, after I'd taken it for 2 years, I decided enough was enough.  I hadn't realised how depressed, achy and miserable I had become.  As to working to help your son out of financial trouble is admirable, but don't do this at the expense of your own health. You didn't get him into trouble, so it's not your responsibility to get him out.  Look after yourself first, first rule of first aid. Hope you can find something that works for you.
Posts.Title: supply of accord (Letrozole)

Posts.Content: Dreamthief Thanks for that Helen, I wasn't expecting to see you around for a few days :) Enjoy your break..... G n' J Bwahahahahaaaa I am always watching...!  Don't worry, Susie, there are other places! I'm sure other people will pop in with their experiences.
Posts.Title: 3D Tattoos

Posts.Content: There are risks to everything in life, getting in a car, a plane, my mother in law's neighbour broke a hip slipping on a lettuce leaf in Waitrose  and broke a hip.  You could have a saline implant, although the skin is still usually silicone, I believe
Posts.Title: Silicon Implants

Posts.Content: Hi sazmoz  You have done the right thing both by going to your GP and joining this forum.  As you have already found, googling symptoms is frightening and probably best left until you know what you are dealing with.  Hopefully it's just an infected duct or something, but do know that if it's cancer, treatment is very doable and you can beat it.   We are all here to support you and help you through.  The waitiing can be torture, but once you know what you are dealing with, you will find things a lot easier to deal with.
Posts.Title: Pain in breast and lump found by doctor

Posts.Content: Great news!  Woohoo!!!
Posts.Title: lymph node biopsy clear

Posts.Content: First things first, Weeble, congratulations!  Although it doesn't always feel like it at the end of treatment, you've come a long way.  Now you probably feel the relief from the results, but at the same time there is a feeling that you're on your own.  You're not.   Your BCN is at the end of the phone if you have any queries, and of course you have all of us!  Perhaps a hug wasn't quite right for the surgeon, but hug the nearest suitable person instead!  I'm sure he doesn't feel you are ungrateful, he knows that it's all a shock and even good news takes time to sink in at times. So you're not crazy at all.  You might like to read "After the Treatment Finishes" by Dr Peter Harvey.  Just click the green link.  You will realise that what you feel is perfectly normal.  You do get there, but it takes time.   Go out and live!
Posts.Title: Good news!!

Posts.Content: Oh gosh,  Karan, I wish I could help. Unfortunately without being medically trained AND in possession of the scans,  I don't think anyone can give you answers.   As to what they are looking for, it could be a multitude of things.   I don't think it's good enough that you have to wait for the MDT meeting.  I would turn up at the hospital and demand answers,  but that's just me! Take someone with you as well.
Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: Fabulous,  Mo! Don't rush back to work, and don't be surprised if you feel a little lost for a while after the merry go round stops.  Take a little time for you.
Posts.Title: Yippee I did it.

Posts.Content: Hi Victoria I'm going to have a double mastectomy with immediate reconstruction. Mainly because I have family history, I don't want to have to go through this again, but also because I've yet to see a matching pair of one natural and one reconstructed breasts! I know what I'm like, and I won't rest until I know that it won't come back in the other side, so that's my choice.  I go for surgery on Thursday next week. Helen xx
Posts.Title: Reconstraction.

Posts.Content: nicolaangie66  I am sorry to hear that you have a long wait ahead. Try not to dwell on it and just keep life as normal as possible. Worry never helped anyone.  Your other question is very technical. I suggest you ring a nurse on the free macmillan helpline here on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm. They may well be able to answer your question.
Posts.Title: Absorption of hormone therapy following gall bladder removal

Posts.Content: Happy birthday to you both, JJ and sister snail!
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY !!!!!

Posts.Content: Happy NED anniversary, Mike! I hope you are doing something to celebrate and I think your wife deserves a nice bunch of flowers.
Posts.Title: My last FEC treatment was a year ago today!

Posts.Content: Hi taylor0428, I'm sorry I can't really help, although I do think it's unlikely to be scar tissue unless it's a keloid scar under the skin?  None of us here are medically trained, but you could call the helpline on 0808 808 0000 and talk to some of the excellent Macmillan staff.  The helpline is open from 9am to 8pm from Monday to Friday, so there's time!
Posts.Title: Lump on Rib after Double Mastectomy

Posts.Content: I'm about to have a mastectomy and an implant to both  breasts although I don't have anything in my left breast (so far!).   I have chosen to do this and I think if you have them both done the same way, and at the same time, you have a far greater chance of a matching pair at the end! As to safety, for me the benefits outweigh the risks, but everyone is individual, so you need to make up your own mind.   Helen
Posts.Title: Reconstraction.

Posts.Content: Must be HER2- otherwise chemo would be a cert? The ER goes from 0-8 so you are highly oestrogen receptive.  As George says,  once they have analysed the tissue you will have a better idea of what is going on
Posts.Title: understanding letter received by GP

Posts.Content: Happy birthday to you both, JJ and sister snail!
Posts.Title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY !!!!!

Posts.Content: I bloody love sprouts!  Merry Christmas and a very happy new year to you all! May 2017 be your year!
Posts.Title: Xmas

Posts.Content: Try to keep busy and the time will pass quickly.  There's a common belief that breast cancer in men isn't as devastating as it is for women.  However cancer is frightening whatever it is and you can't help but worry.  HHopefully Russ will pop in but in the meantime we all understand how you are feeling so feel free to let everything out here and any questions you have will get an answer no matter how stupid you might think they are.
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: I'm absolutely thrilled for you!  What B*ggers for winding you up so much though.  If only they knew how agonising it is!  Still, hope you get a date soon!  I think you deserve this one ...

Posts.Content: Eddie Unless your GP has X-ray vision I don't know how he can say it's a cyst, especially as you have a history of Prostate Cancer (which, if you have the BRCA gene, can be linked) Please don't delay getting it checked out - I know you've been through a lot of treatments, etc, but putting things off (like a bloke!) isn't going to make it go away.   Good luck! Helen
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly I think you need to count yourself lucky!  I am beginning to think that the crappy side effects of chemo are to stop you wanting to rush through treatment!  In the long run, 7 weeks isn't long, you will be there soon. There is a reason why timing is what it is.  Take the opportunity, if you are feeling fine, to catch up with friends, have a short break, do the things that you don't normally have time to do.  Real life will start soon enough.
Posts.Title: Can I speed up treatment

Posts.Content: Just to add to the excellent advice received so far, I had a fortnight to South Africa booked when I was diagnosed. It was agreed that we could go, and I was booked in two days after we returned   I did not enjoy the holiday as much as I thought because it was on my mind every night but I had no real cause to worry   If you go, be assured that your surgeon will take all risks into account before agreeing, and trust them. Treatment is not fun but it is doable. You will get through it  so try not to catastrophise!

Posts.Content: I'm concerned that you are working in a school during chemo Schools are breeding grounds for germs and oncologists usually recommended not working in this environment during chemo  You cannot underestimate how vulnerable you at the second week of chemo, and antibiotics won't prevent viruses attacking your body. Please do talk to your doctor

Posts.Title: HOPE COURSE !

Posts.Content: I'm going to go to the original question. How should you be feeling?  There is no should, there is only what is and what isn't (to paraphrase Yoda!). You feel the way you feel and that is what is right for you.  Many of us went into this with no indication of cancer and came out of the doctor's office feeling numb. Our normal lives turned on their heads.  Our bodies have let us down. We were healthy and active and now we're not.  It's very normal to feel this way, and the good news is that it does get better. I was diagnosed over 5 years ago.  I am now fit and healthy, active and you will be too. Good luck with your future treatment.
Posts.Title: New to the group and Not quite sure what I should be feeling?

Posts.Title: Message for Sara-Jane !!

Posts.Content: Brilliant news, Caroline! So pleased for you! It's great to hear some good news stories to keep us all going! xx
Posts.Title: good news

Posts.Content: You may find that the hospital won't be happy to let you go home to an empty house for 24 hours after the op,   They may well be able to organise hospital transport or there may be a local good neighbours scheme where people give lifts for a nominal cost.  The last time I went on a bus any distance it threw me around a lot.
Posts.Title: Bus home after surgery?

Posts.Content: Also don't forget that cancer tissue can still be there even though the chemo stops it growing, the dead tissue doesn't just disappear in all cases.  So you may still have to have a large mass but it will be dead tumour rather than growing cancer if that makes sense. There are so many variables it's impossible to say,  but I do think it odd that you didn't have a scan before your consultant pronounced chemo not working.  I would question this LOUDLY.  And ask for another consultant if you aren't happy.
Posts.Title: Relieved but confused

Posts.Content: It all sounds much more positive, Fi LittleWren.   I totally agree with your friend, sometimes they lose track of the fact that although they've seen countless cases, for most of us it's the first time we've had to deal with cancer and it's damn scary! Good luck with the Tax and the rest.
Posts.Title: Relieved but confused

Posts.Content: Shelley - don't worry about the drains - they're really not that bad, I hardly noticed mine.  Even if they did get pulled out (and it's unlikely) nothing will really happen.  Take baby wipes, phone, charger, laptop/tablet if you have one.  I found I couldn't concentrate on a book but could go on my phone and keep up with what was going on.  Deodorant on the untouched side is fine.  Also take a bottle of squash - you need to flush out the anaesthetic, and hospital water isn't usually that nice.  Pjs rather than nighties preserve your dignity more when you need to show the doctor your wound!  You won't be catheterised, although you'll probably be given a bedpan for the first 24 hrs unless you recover extremely quickly.  Good luck - it's really not that bad! Helen x

Plenty of scare stories of people who put up with stuff and had much bigger problems as a result!  YOU HAVE BEEN TOLD!  :D

Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Just a thought, you may have been given a different brand of Tamoxifen which makes you feel worse?   The original form of Tamoxifen was made by Novartis and when it became generic they started to make a form called Sandoz which is as like the original as possible.  The others have different fillers which seem to cause different effects in different people.  It is worth asking your pharmacist if they can dispense this and see if it helps.  Some people tolerate different brands differently, so keep a track on which ones you are on and which ones are good or bad.
Posts.Title: Side effects from Tamoxifen after nearly a year

Posts.Content: HI LittleWren  If you are having radiotherapy then the chances are you will need a delayed reconstruction.  They can do an immediate one, but the radiotherapy can cause issues with it, so they generally recommend waiting. This might give you the time you need to decide whether you can live with the results or you want to go down the route of reconstruction. One word of warning though. Although your surgeon may have said "as many operations as you like", I am hearing stories about people being denied reconstruction as a "cosmetic" procedure on the NHS, apart from the initial operation.  So be very sure that you are going to be happy if you are denied it in the long term.

Posts.Title: Light Boxes for SAD any advice/info please.

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy Bananas are full of potassium, which helps with cramps, so have one every day (don't over dose though!). Also, if you take a spoonful of chelated magnesium in a glass of orange juice before bed it should help both cramps and sleep.

Posts.Content: Herceptin is usually given separately the first time so that they can see if you have a reaction, after which I believe it is given together.  Some places offer it by injection after the first time.  Picc lines save your veins so if you are given the option then definitely take it. It is given under anaesthetic.
Posts.Title: Having chemo and herceptin

Posts.Content: Two things.  For everyone else, if you offer help, don't say "Let me know if you need anything", say "What can I do to help?" Secondly, if you are on Facebook, make a list and post it, saying "To all my lovely friends who have said to let you know if I need anything, these are the things I would be grateful if someone would help with.". As an extra, don't feel bad for asking.  Our friends and family find it hard to watch us go through treatment, and giving them things to do helps them to feel that they are doing something.  Win win!!!

Posts.Title: ... started my journey today

Posts.Content: Hi Clarie Welcome to the site no one wanted to join.  We've (mostly) been where you are now, and it really is the worst thing.   The good news is that we've come out of the other side and are now here to help with our experiences. More good news is that mastectomy isn't that bad.  You may well be home the same day depending on the time of day you have your operation, if not the next day, and you should be given pain relief to take home, more as a preventative than necessary.   You should receive a sheet of exercises, it is important that you do them.  If you don't receive them and no one is around to ask, then come back and we can link you.  I don't know if you are having reconstruction, this is something that you may wish to ask about. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Post-mastectomy bra

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine It's easy to say, isn't it?  "If you need anything, just ask".   It would be better for people to say "Is there anything I can do to help?"  *Makes mental note to say this in future.* You probably shouldn't have to ask, but obviously you do, so the next time anyone says if you need anything, tell them "Oh yes, it would be great if you could do the washing/ironing/make a stew/pie/ come and do some cleaning for me, that would be a massive help"  The problem is, we women are so good at coping that when we can't we expect everyone to read our minds.  I think also you need to be selective about who you accept help from - it's no good if they're going to flake, you would be better asking someone who you know is reliable.   Good luck with the cat thing though ;) Helen

Posts.Title: Diep Reconstruction

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie It's true, some people have chemo first, and some after, that depends I think on how fast the chemo is growing and the stage, but for some it's surgery first and chemo after.   If you had a multi-focal cancer it is usually recommended to have a mastectomy, because they can't get it all without making a bit of a mangled mess of your boob.   What I can tell you is that you didn't have to keep going back and having multiple surgeries, because they got it all at once, and that the one thing I have learned is that everyone has a different treatment, even if, on the face of it, the diagnosis looks the same.  Even at the same hospital.  All treatments are tailored precisely to the individual, and I suspect your surgeon had an inkling, even if he didn't discuss it with you.   EC chemo is slightly kinder, and it may be that other health problems have meant that they decided the benefits of F and Tax part were outweighed by the side effects on your body.  In this journey we have to trust in our team, they work together, so if one proposes something on basis of cost that another feels wouldn't be as perhaps a more expensive treatment, they will have to put their argument.  I understand that MDT meetings can be quite heated, and they have to have a consensus. Herceptin is Dreamthief's area of expertise, will let him answer that one!

Posts.Title: 53mm lobular tumour. Boo hiss.

Posts.Content: Hi ClaireLou Welcome to the forum and as you have already been told, it's the best time to find us.  Until and unless you are told that your lump is cancerous, there's probably little point in looking for the information that you will need if it is.  Instead, do try to focus on the fact that 90% of all breast cancer patients survive for 5 years or more (that's how far they do the figures) and of the other 10%, they are usually either very late diagnosis, have other health issues, or are elderly on diagnosis (and probably die of some completely unrelated illness, although data isn't separated).  You have a 10 year old, so you need to focus on being strong and turning the anxiety into fight power, to kick cancer's butt if need be.  Don't feel guilty, there are always people worse off or better off than another, it's not a competition, a person with Stage 1 cancer diagnosis is still allowed to be as shocked as someone with a Stage 2 or later.  None of it's fun, there's never a good time, but the treatment is doable and however long it takes, it will be worth it. Fingers crossed for you that you have some simple cyst or similar, but if not, you know where we are.

Posts.Content: simba4me I am sorry to hear that you have had a cancer diagnosis on top of having your husband to care for. If I were you I would be angry and upset, I think. Posts.Title: Feeling alone

Posts.Content: Hi Future I suffer from Hypothyroidism and one of the symptoms is brittle nails.  It's worth asking your doctor to do a TSH test - have this done first thing in the morning, by why I mean as soon as the blood clinic opens!  This will show the highest TSH reading, and lead to a more realistic diagnosis. HOWEVER.  I did a quick Google and found this ... Nail issues are a concern for many people. Weak or brittle nails are prone to slow growth, breaking, and peeling. The medical term for this is onychoschizia. There are multiple potential causes of flaky brittle nails ranging from benign to potentially more serious conditions. Weak nails are a very common symptom of menopause due to fluctuations in hormones. During menopause the level of estrogen is lowered. Estrogen is involved in water regulation so lower levels lead to dry flaky nails. The most common cause of brittle nails is actually frequent wetting of the nails through cleaning dishes, washing hands, etc. Brittle nails can also be a sign of vitamin and mineral deficiencies, in particular B complex vitamins such as biotin, calcium, and zinc. It can also be sign of certain medical conditions such as anemia (low blood count), thyroid disorders, and skin disorders such as psoriasis. It is important to see your primary care provider or dermatologist to determine the cause of your brittle flaky nails and discuss the most appropriate treatment. In the meantime protect your nails by wearing protective gloves while washing and cleaning, take a multivitamin, avoid nail polish and remover, avoid prolonged exposure to water such as swimming, and apply a moisturizer to your hands and nails. Now I'm not saying this was from a factually reliable source, it was on a US site, not that there's necessarily anything wrong with that, but it makes sense.  I would definitely have a word with your GP next time you are there.  Unfortunately taking Tamoxifen sucks all the hormones out of your body, but they were there for a reason!
Posts.Title: Fingernails!

Posts.Content: Hi Stoatie  Sorry to hear you're having problems when things have seemed to be going so well.  It may be that the anaesthetic has taken a bit longer to leave your system and it's been hiding any pain you may have had. And consequently you may have done a bit more than you should have.  Seromas can be really uncomfortable as well so although there may be clear fluid it could still be that there is some infection in there somewhere because every time the skin is broken there is a risk.  Keep a careful eye on it as three times a week is a lot.  Most people have it once a week or fortnight.  It seems to me that perhaps you should have had a drain left in longer. But I am not medically qualified so this is just my musings..  If oramorphjust makes you sleepy, perhaps gabapentine or amytriptylene might work.  Take them at night as they do make you drowsy but they are for nerve pain so could help if that is what is causing the pain.  Hope some of this helps. You've been through a major op and your body has been pulled about a lot so be kind to yourself.  Helen
