Posts.Title: Tattoo on nipple.

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne You're bound to have ups and downs, no parent should ever have to bury their child, it's not the normal way of things.  But eventually you will find a way to move forward.  Perhaps you could volunteer for the AA or find something else that will allow you to feel better about his loss.  You will never get over it, how do you get over things like this, but you need to find a way to make his life having been worth living, short though it was.  He gave you pleasure growing up, remember the good things. You will get information directly from the Coroner, but it is really a formality. They will open the proceeding, call for the post mortem results, then decide on the cause of death, and it will be natural causes, probably, caused by the level of alcohol, then it will close and be over.
Posts.Title: Good days & bad days????

Posts.Content: Have to agree with chloecat45 on this one.  It might be back, or it might not.  Obviously the radiographer noticed something, but it wasn't their place to say.  You stressing out won't help anything, and may in fact make things worse.  You will lose every day that you spend worrying by not doing the things that you should be doing with your children, enjoying their childhood and innocence while you can.   As and when you know what you are dealing with, then you can deal with it.  In the meantime, try to keep busy, put it in a box for now, I do know how difficult this is, but for your own health and your children, make your best effort.
Posts.Title: Ultrasound. ...it might be back !!!

Posts.Content: Lol at your mum,  Nicky!  At Christmas, my husband and I and both kids and partners were at hers for lunch boxing day.  We'd eaten and suddenly my mum piped up with "when was it you had your hysterectomy?! That's how long I have been wearing these knickers!"  Everyone was horrified, except me, because I am immune!
Posts.Title: Am I being Oversensitive?

Posts.Content: The short answer is it's extremely unlikely.  There are, of course, no guarantees, but please don't waste your time worrying. Go out, meet friends, keep busy.
Posts.Title: Delay in treatment

Posts.Content: Absolutely there has to be something wrong!  I don't consider it lucky to be alive but in constant pain?!  Keep going back and pester them until they find out what is wrong.  You have rights.
Posts.Title: Severe shoulder pain

Posts.Content: All points of view are welcome toxophilite, especially one's from the light at the end of the tunnel!
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Just to add that if finances do get difficult, both utility companies and Macmillan have funds for this purpose.  So worth asking.
Posts.Title: critical illness insurance

Posts.Content: When I first found out I had cancer, and I didn't know whether I was going to have chemo or not, I told my girlfriends about it, and said that if I did have to lose my hair, I was going to get a pink wig, and they all said they would wear one in support with me ... :)
Posts.Title: Just told I need chemo!

Posts.Content: Emma, I am afraid that your body has been shocked into menopause and the side effects may continue for a while  Some people find taking venlafaxine alongside does help with the side effects  others find taking it at night helps but everyone is different. Keep a note of the brand you are taking  because this can make a real difference
Posts.Title: tamoxifen - hot flushes

Posts.Content: Honestly, I could write a book!
Posts.Title: Am I being Oversensitive?

Posts.Content: Hi Fifi  I assume you have had a DIEP reconstruction? I think surgeons do sometimes advise patients to diet prior to operations but because both surgeons and patients are all different it depends.  I wouldn't put yourself under pressure to lose weight, just eat healthily and concentrate on getting to the finish line!
Posts.Title: Lipofilling and dieting

Posts.Content: Jenny - you could try massaging with soluble aspirin or paracetamol.  If that doesn't work, as it's nerve pain, you may need some gabapentin or similar that will numb the nerve endings.  It will get better though, it's just a bit over sensitive at the moment.
Posts.Title: Score scalp

Posts.Content: The short answer is sometimes.  If it's obvious then it's obvious.   I imagine that there must be a slight  abnormality on the X-ray but that it doesn't look like mets (could be an old injury or something) and that's why he's requested the MRI just to establish what exactly it is.  Fingers crossed that it's nothing important!
Posts.Title: Bone mets

Posts.Content: Lynn I'm so sorry to hear that you've got all this extra stuff to deal with.  Have you considered asking if they will do a double Mx for you?  It's up to the individual, of course, but since you've already gone for the one you know what it would be like. Chat if you feel the need. Helen
Posts.Title: Can't believe this

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona  The thing about chemo is that every little helps.  You've done five, surely that is enough, given the side effects that you have had.   Tell your family that further chemo will compromise your future health rather than help it. That should get them off your back.  Chemo can cause other different long term health issues if it doesn't like you, and your heart is pretty important too.
Posts.Title: May not manage last "T" chemo

Posts.Content: I'm sorry I can't help you with the medical information but you could try ringing the support line here 0808 808 0000 and asking one of the Macmillan nurses.  They are very helpful.  In the meantime, please don't panic.  Even if it is cancer, these things are very treatable these days, and you are unlikely to die, especially since you are already under the care of the genetics clinic. Please try not to google because you will just frighten yourself.  I had an inverted nipple for over 20 years and it was never a problem.  And even when I had breast cancer, that wasn't involved!  Keep busy and good luck for tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Nipple change

Posts.Content: Glad you had a good day, Susie!
Posts.Title: Another good day

Posts.Content: You are welcome!
Posts.Title: Tattoo on nipple.

Posts.Content: Hi Cheri I would say give your unit a call on Monday and make sure your oncologist knows that you are having these symptoms before you have any more treatment.  They may change your dose or regime.  There are a few things it could be, I'm not a chemo expert, but hopefully one will be along in a minute ... :)  Dreamthief?
Posts.Title: Sore fingers and toes after docetaxel

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that, KOP - I think you're partly a victim of the festive season, and partly a victim of the cumbersome admin system in the NHS.  That said, it's only 4/5 weeks, which in the scheme of things, isn't that long.  I was diagnosed on 10th Aug and had my surgery finally on 23rd Nov approx and started at 5mm and ended at 20mm.    The problem is that Mammograms and ultrasounds have their limitations, even MRI's aren't completely infallible, although obviously a lot more accurate.   Focus on the fact that they now know exactly what you have and will now jump into action to treat you .... and in the meantime, be kind to yourself, do the things you've always wanted to and plan some treats for the future ...
Posts.Title: 53mm lobular tumour. Boo hiss.

Posts.Content: Hi Mina I didn't have chemo but have read a lot about things on here over the past few years. Reading between the lines, it sounds as though you are having the FEC, taken the meds you have been given and waiting until the next appointment with the Onc before doing anything!  You don't have to be a martyr to the side effects - there are tablets for just about everything, and you can call the chemo unit anytime - you should have a number to call.  These people are paid to be on call 24/7, so make it worth their while!   And then they can give you whatever it is you need to get you through these next few tough months.   I'm sure someone else will be along any second with more personal advice!
Posts.Title: Feeling sick for 6 days post chemo

Posts.Content: The downside of the NHS, eh?  If you have a frozen shoulder you should be referred to a specialist and they will put you under anaesthetic,  Get your GP to refer you to a shoulder specialist.
Posts.Title: Severe shoulder pain

Posts.Content: Hi Nicky Have a look also at the Keeping Abreast website and see if there is any more help there.  You can also look up plastic surgeons on their association website, which, amusingly, is known as BAPRAS (British Association of Plastic, Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgeons) which might help you as well. I had implants but without strattice, so I can't help with the detail, although in hindsight I think it would have been much better, it simply wasn't even mentioned when I had mine.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with animal matrix and implants

Posts.Content: I had a double mastectomy with implant reconstruction under muscle. I wasn't offered strattice but if it is available I would say go for it.  My strength is pretty much the same as before now, but it was odd to start with. She needs to be conscientious about doing the exercises afterwards.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with animal matrix and implants

Posts.Content: My recon is fine - I don't know what sort of recon your daughter has, but I had permanent expander implants.  They're about at the point now 10 months on that I could keep them and be happy.   But I'm still considering having a DIEP flap.  Still not 100% sure though.   If your daughter needs recon info I'm happy to help - I've done a lot of research ... :)
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Monika, always get any niggles checked out.  They would rather see you and it be nothing than you leave it to be something.  If in doubt,  ch
Posts.Title: oncology appointment

Posts.Content: Also, remember, very few people come on a forum to post about the good things, so it's more likely you'd read about the worse side effects here.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - Side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Carrie For the exact reason you give, I had a double mx.  With implants you don't get a matched pair with one implant and one natural breast.  The DIEP and TRAM reconstructions do give a much more natural look, but of course not everyone is suitable for them.   Mine do sit high, and they have softened unbelievably now.  I was seriously considering having a DIEP flap but I'm pretty sure I'm going to keep these now unless something happens.  I'm actually rather keen on them now, and most people who make a comment are very positive ;) Actually, quite a lot of my friends will say hello and then something like "Look at those beauties"!  It makes me smile!
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: MayaMoo  Have you checked that you are taking the same brand of Tamoxifen? Certain brands do impact some people more than others although not all brands impact all people in the same way, if that makes sense. Part of the problem is that oestrogen is one of the hormones that our bodies need as the "oil" in our engines as it were, so anything you take to suppress this will have an effect on the joints to a greater or lesser extent.  I managed to take it for nearly two years before deciding enough was enough, but the % difference in recurrence for me was only 1%.  Did your oncologist tell you the statistics for recurrence with or without Tamoxifen?
Posts.Title: Early side effects of tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Shelly - I could have written your post word for word! Jazzmyne - If you ask your doctor and explain what you want, they should allow you to do it.  But you may have to convince them.  I had to have a second opinion, and my argument was the same as you - I would worry about it coming back (thus affecting my mental health), I would not be able to relax, family history was strong too.  My other argument (also with a basis in mental health) was that it's really hard to get a matching pair with one natural and one reconstructed breast.  With clothes on, people can't really tell, and for some people this is enough, but it wasn't for me.  Hope this helps, good luck in your journey Helen
Posts.Title: Too many wild thoughts!

Posts.Content: Absolutely there has to be something wrong!  I don't consider it lucky to be alive but in constant pain?!  Keep going back and pester them until they find out what is wrong.  You have rights.
Posts.Title: Severe shoulder pain

Posts.Content: Hi I asked the same question and was told it would be absolutely fine.  I've been away loads since, on several long haul flights, and not even thought about it.   Book the flights and enjoy your holiday! Helen
Posts.Title: Pigs might fly......

Posts.Content: Oh and I did have drains but I don't know if that was because it was an immediate reconstruction or due to the implants (I think the mastectomy).
Posts.Title: Expander Implant advice please

Posts.Content: Hi Spammie I don't know if this is any help, but I had a Mammogram in October 2010 which was clear.  I started getting some weird pains in my right breast in July 2011 and went to the GP and although he couldn't find anything, referred me to the Breast Clinic where I was diagnosed with Grade 1 breast cancer.  It was caught early, but I mentioned to them that I'd had a mammogram only in the previous October and they got a copy and checked it in case something had been missed.  They decided that nothing had been missed at that point, so carried on with treatment (ended up being more invasive than they thought and had 2 WLEs and a double Mx in the end). So you could mention it to the team and ask if they have checked it.  I was lucky in a way that I'd moved house and was then in a different health authority, so blame wasn't an issue, but you could say that you are concerned something might have been missed and that others might be at risk?   I'm not sure whether you would be able to get a copy of the mammo or not, that might be trickier.
Posts.Title: An uneasy question to ask about a previous mammogram

Posts.Content: If they are temporary expanders I believe they are much more uncomfortable but once you have them replaced with permanent implants they then feel much more comfortable so hang in there!
Posts.Title: Expander Implant advice please

Posts.Content: Hi Tracy / myfriedeggs (love this username!) I would wait until you've finished your radiotherapy before you start anything new - remember that you keep "cooking" for three weeks after you finish, so that's when I'd start. As you say, everyone is different, and they have to write ALL the possible side effects on the leaflet, but not everyone gets them. As you may have read on here, there are lots of people that find one brand suits them best, so note which ones you get and if none of them suit, go back to the oncologist and see if you can try something else.   I was on Tamoxifen for around 20 months, but I kept giving myself breaks - I wouldn't take them on holiday for instance.  The difference for me was that my statistics only gave me a 1% improvement if I took them. Ask the oncologist for your statistics with and without.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen - Side effects

Posts.Content: Can't help because I don't compute enjoy and running in the same sentence!
Posts.Title: Anyone enjoy running post mastectomy?!

Posts.Content: Paging Carolyn28  CARDBOND - I didn't even have a lump.   Everyone is different.  Not every lump is cancer.
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: I'm no chemo expert, but I also don't take any medical expert opinion without asking them to justify it! You definitely want to avoid the peripheral neuropathy if you are starting to get the tingling, it can become permanent, but isn't always.  I would work on the assumption it might be, though, so I am inclined to say your oncologist is working out the best strategy for YOU as an individual, so don't worry about what others do or don't have!
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Brilliant, Mike_R. I don't even run for a bus!
Posts.Title: From cancer to cross-country. A positive post.

Posts.Content: I wish I could have gone private.  I have to say that although the consultants and the treatment has been OK on the NHS, the actual nursing care has been somewhat hit and miss and I think 95% of the staff have not had English as a first language, so communication has been a stumbling block.   Also, the food generally in private hospitals is better!  Having said that, the food in the hospital I was in was actually pretty good, no complaints apart from it being a bit cold sometimes. I don't think you get that much support on the NHS anyway, although I expect if you ask they will give you a dedicated Breast Care Nurse at the NHS who you can talk through any concerns through.
Posts.Title: NHS or private

Posts.Content: Hi Kate It depends whether you are having permanent or temporary expanders fitted.  They can be uncomfortable for a while until you get used to them - imagine having a couple of flat stones duct taped to your chest - but that feeling DOES subside after a while!   I had 150 ml put in under anaesthetic when they were implanted and have gone up to I think about 450ml.  Just don't get too much put in at once because the muscle has to expand and relax and it takes a while to do this.  Very uncomfortable otherwise.   The actual operation and recovery wasn't too bad - I think I was driving within 6 weeks but maybe a little less.  But it took me about 8 months to fully make friends with my implants.  I love them now, but some things can't be rushed.
Posts.Title: Expander Implant advice please

Posts.Content: Hi Gina sounds like you've been one of the "lucky" ones, but I think you would probably benefit from some counselling.  Even though you haven't had a Mx you still need to grieve for the loss of something, I feel, and if you haven't cried at all, I think you are maybe still at the shock phase.  I have to say that even 10 months on from my op I still cry for it at times.   And don't worry about not stopping, at least you were able to write in proper sentences.  Cancer seems to take some people's full stops away from them GRRRRR (mini rant!) H xx
Posts.Title: "Another newbie".........

Posts.Content: Hi jwoowoo As everyone has said, it is very early days.  A mastectomy is a major operation in itself, without the complications of an LD flap. Your muscles have been moved, cut and reattached all over the place so it's not surprising that your body needs time to recover.  Definitely do the exercises, and get stronger painkillers if you need them, if only so you can bear to do the exercises.  If you are still struggling when everyone else says you should be getting better, don't be fobbed off, as there can very occasionally be issues with the surgery. The good news is that you will end up with a lovely natural looking breast at the end of it all!
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort following a mastectomy and LD flap reconstruc...

Posts.Content: Hi angebow65 Welcome to the forum - we're all past and present patients here, so everyone can identify with where you are.   Unfortunately the Sentinel Node Biopsy does give more discomfort that the lump removal, and if your current painkillers don't work, ask your GP or surgeon for something stronger.   I don't know if you have been given any exercises to do, but it is important to do them as much as you can, to get full movement back in the arms.  The tingly feeling and numbness is because they cut through lots of nerves.  Nerves take a long time to heal (if they ever do), and so this can be permanent, but it should ease painwise.
Posts.Title: breast dancer er positive

Posts.Content: Hi Anastasia I posted a long reply yesterday and it has disappeared!  Oh well, here goes. Sorry to hear you have had a rotten time.  Friends and family don't like to see us down, so they do try to be relentlessly cheery, don't they?  I had to contact my close friends and just say that I'm going to keep my head under the parapet for a bit, because I couldn't deal with the sympathy and with the best will in the world, sometimes you just want to be on your own trudging through the mud, and not having someone gee you up to speed up.   Which is why this is a great forum - we can tell it like it is, get real sympathy from those who have been through it and know what it is like.  Rather than just going through polite conversation.   Anyway fingers crossed things improve for you rapidly.
Posts.Title: Hospital stay

Posts.Content: Yeah I'm sick of it now too.  I now have an untreatable autoimmune condition (on top of and possibly related to hypothyroidism which I've had for 20 years and never considered a disease as such). Suffice to say that having had a double Mx, I thought well at least my other bits still work.  Think again.  I'm totally p***ed off.
Posts.Title: Is cancer not enough?!

Posts.Content: I've had pretty much the same as you, Mishka, diagnosed end July/early Aug.  I've had a lumpectomy/WLE, followed by further excision to get the margins, and finally a mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.   I don't know what Quest is, sorry! I went through the same thing where I got very frustrated with people treating me as someone with cancer rather than myself.  Got very cross at points, and lashed out in a few cases.  The thing is, though, people feel they want to help and say something nice, but often they say the wrong thing.  Try to do as many normal things as you can, be with the good friends you have, be frank with your kids, but tell them you want them to carry on with life as normal, because that will help you have as normal a life as possible!  It won't be the end of the world if you cry in front of them, if they hug you, and make you a cup of tea or draw you a nice picture to make you feel better.  Let them be there for you too. Helen xx
Posts.Title: Starting to walk into my new world, small steps but moving :-)

Posts.Content: Sorry, forgot to add that am finally coming out the other side - you will get there too!!
Posts.Title: Starting to walk into my new world, small steps but moving :-)

Posts.Content: It's not necessarily genetic. My mum is one of four daughters. All three of her sisters have or had breast cancer and myself.  I was tested but they did not find a genetic link.  It could be a coincidence.
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: kayleigh39 i would go back to the GP and insist on a mammogram. And possibly an MRI  There are lots of ladies much younger than you here with a breast cancer diagnosis. You may well have something that can be watched but I'm sure you'd rather be "put through" a mammogram than be waiting for six months.  Grrrr some professionals really get my goat!
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: I think you have to suck it and see.  Keep a note of which brand you get and how you feel, bearing in mind that it is a gradual thing, so you may not notice much for a few months until the oestrogen in your system is suppressed.   Then if you have problems try altering the time you take your dose and see if it helps.  I did find it better at night but got totally sick of walking around like Mrs Overall in the morning.
Posts.Title: Taking Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Actually I disagree. If she had done her job and passed on the information in a timely manner, you wouldn't have needed emotional support because you would have known where you were with your treatment and staging.  I think I would write a very considered letter saying that while you know that you are only one of her patients, you are just as important as the others. You acknowledge that she is under pressure, but that having to deal with a secondary diagnosis is extremely stressful and that stress can be lessened by the speed of information being processed. If she were in your shoes she might have a bit more compassion and you have a right to be treated with respect.  There, I got that off my chest, hope it helps you!
Posts.Title: More unnecessary tears...

Posts.Content: As soon as the drains are out she will feel much more comfortable.  Unless of course she develops any seroma, but hit that hurdle when you get to it.  ;) LD flaps are muscle and muscle contains muscle memory which means that they will continue to act as they did previously.  Some physio can help with this, but IMO breasts aren't muscle and therefore muscle shouldn't be used to do reconstruction unless there is no choice.  In which case, anything is better than nothing, I guess. All the best for your meeting with the oncologist - we all dread results, but here's hoping that he'll have good news for you. Helen x
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Lyn I've not posted or read all your thread, but just caught this bit - I had double Mx and immediate recon in November. I ended up having to have a transfusion too but felt so much better afterwards. Wishing you and your daughter all the best  Helen xxx
Posts.Title: Post Mastectomy Tops with Drain Pockets

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge and welcome to the group! You're right, everyone is very supportive and if you have any thoughts or queries ask and someone will have been there done that!   The waiting is torture though - just try to stay busy and keep your mind on other things if you can - dwelling on the what if's isn't helpful and at the end of the day won't make any difference to the outcome! Fingers crossed for your results!
Posts.Title: First post

Posts.Content: I'm sure she'd be great at it!
Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: Hi SIms I think some people start Tamoxifen as soon as they are finished with Chemo/surgery.  I suppose it is a timing thing, you will probably be given it when you next see your oncologist. Bear in mind that different brands suit different people, so take a note of the ones you are given and how you feel, then you can ask for the brand that suits you most.
Posts.Title: New member to the group

Posts.Content: If I was going to have RT then I would take it. I've not had a single bad thing about a reaction to it here or any other issues apart from the slight stickiness.  How are things supposed to be tried and tested if people aren't allowed to try and test them?!
Posts.Title: Confusion over R1 and R2

Posts.Content: Michelle, why not take the opportunity to visit a friend, impromptu weekend away, a day out doing something you enjoy?  Take your mind off it, and keep busy, that time will soon pass.
Posts.Title: Sorry, need a bit of a vent x

Posts.Content: Hi, Powderpuff, and welcome to the forum.  This is a great place for help and support. We have all been where you are and understand the fear that you are going through..  As Della has already said,  the nodes are there to catch stray cells,  so that they don't go floating around the body.  I don't know if you have been told whether you will have chemo or radiotherapy, but these are designed to hit any cells not removed by surgery, so you need to stop worrying about spread and trust your team to give you the best possible treatment so that you can get on with life.   Do ask any questions,  there's no such thing as a stupid question and we will do our best to help.
Posts.Title: Feeling Lost

Posts.Content: Helen and Gill Do get the pain checked out.  Chances are it's something like sciatica or arthritis, and if it is, there are things that can be done to alleviate the pain. IF it's mets, there are drugs that can be taken to slow and stop the spread, and the sooner you start on these, the better. Everything crossed for you.
Posts.Title: really scared about pain in pelvis help and advice please

Posts.Content: ali owl She just made me feel I was wasting her time I dint know It could take couple of years for your breast to look normal xxx Hi AliOwl  It sounds very unprofessional. I would also say that it's not just that it is not back to normal but that you noted a change and had it checked which is exactly the right thing to do.  Do get the scan just to be sure that there isn't anything hidden away.  If you have to see this person again and she is rude or unsympathetic then as above I think you need to tell her that you will be making a complaint and do it.   As if we don't feel vulnerable enough.
Posts.Title: bloody insensitive doctors !!!!!!!

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear that, JJ.  It's quite common that grades change following surgery and further margins are needed.  It's a setback but it is doable.  Join the chemo club to keep up with others going through it at the same time.  I had the same surgery,  no node involvement, but needed clearer margins which actually found more cancer so I had a mastectomy.  Ask about reconstruction, too.
Posts.Title: Gutted bad news

Posts.Content: Gdpt  Glad that you have found us and are already feeling reassured   I was diagnosed 7 years ago and I'm still very much alive and kicking  Treatment isn't fun but it is doable  Drs don't always realise that what they say can have such an effect on patients, you have to wonder why they went into the profession sometimes!  The thing is, worrying won't change anything, and whilst it's easy to say  it won't stop you doing it but it will rob you of today worrying about tomorrow. Keep busy  and meet each challenge as it comes.  Keep posting, and have a lovely day at the farm.
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Gdpt  Glad that you have found us and are already feeling reassured   I was diagnosed 7 years ago and I'm still very much alive and kicking  Treatment isn't fun but it is doable  Drs don't always realise that what they say can have such an effect on patients, you have to wonder why they went into the profession sometimes!  The thing is, worrying won't change anything, and whilst it's easy to say  it won't stop you doing it but it will rob you of today worrying about tomorrow. Keep busy  and meet each challenge as it comes.  Keep posting, and have a lovely day at the farm.
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: You said you had the usual 4 FEC but actually most people seem to have 3 FEC so I would be asking if you really need the last two.  Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Peripheral sensory neuropathy: how bad should it be allowed to get...

Posts.Content: No apologies needed, Wilson81 it sounds like the perfect place to ask.  Firstly I am sorry that you have had to go through so much already. But I'm sure you know that HRT is a risk factor for breast cancer. Everything you have said does point to needing further investigation, and your doctor should refer you to the breast clinic for investigation.  If you feel it would help, it might be worth taking your husband with you, as women can often be dismissed as hypochondriacs! I can't believe that I have just typed that in 2017, but there it is. I would start the conversation that you have found a lump and get the doctor to examine it. Protocol should be to refer and do not let them fob you off that you are too young, the fact that you have had a hysterectomy and are on HRT does increase your risk. And there are sadly plenty of young women who have breast cancer here with no risk factors.  If no referral is forthcoming, you must say that you would like to be referred. If you ask and they refuse and are later found to have a problem that could have been sorted earlier, that is negligence so they will do it. One other thing. If you can, get an emergency same day appointment. Although two weeks isn't going to change the outcome, the worry will be added stress that you don't need.  Good luck and do let us know how you get on.
Posts.Title: How to get taken seriously by GP

Posts.Content: Amanda865 not necessarily.  Do you have any more information? Are nodes involved? In any case, it doesn't usually mean that cancer is all over your body if that's your concern, it's just that the cancer is not contained within a certain area.  If you have more information, we may be able to advise you more.
Posts.Title: If I have a 2cm lump in my LIQ does it mean that my cancer is invasive...

Posts.Content: Take it easy, Bev and don't overdo it.  Cleaning will keep! Enjoy your night out tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Returned to work

Posts.Content: Love it, Pat!
Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: It reminds me of Spike Milligan - he has on his tombstone "I told you I was ill ..." or so it is rumoured!
Posts.Title: stupid comments part 1!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Baki  Femara is the best one, the patented drug, so make sure your GP continues to prescribe it! If you get on with it and you struggle to get it, you can also try Novartis (who also make Femara), it's the most identical.
Posts.Title: What brand of letrozole

Posts.Content: Unless they are all prostate, ovarian and breast cancers, they may not have any bearing on a genetic risk.  The BRCA test will look at these types only for risk.   It may be that your family DNA is more predisposed to produce tumours, but unfortunately those tests are a long way off being available, which is why we never say never, but there are new tests being found all the time.   When I was tested, they went back as far as I could tell them, said it looked unlikely, and they were right.  It seemed like a lot to me.  They do say that most men will die with prostate cancer (if they get to old age), but not from it, and most without symptoms.  They did ask for permission to retain my sample to test in future should a new gene factor be found and of course I have consented to this.   When you are diagnosed you tend to see cancer everywhere!
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: I forgot to mention that I have just taken my mum to the hospital for the same diagnosis. We are being very pragmatic about it and so far we are coping well
Posts.Title: My mum has just been diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine I haven't had experience of chemo, or herceptin, but I know it can affect heart function. If it's only a few seconds and goes away I would try not to worry as you are having the ECG on Monday anyway, but if it carries on longer and you are worried, call an ambulance.  Don't worry about wasting people's time, that is what they are paid for, and they would rather see you than have you keel over.
Posts.Title: central upper back pain

Posts.Content: No worries.  That's me, the voice of reason.  LOL :)
Posts.Title: central upper back pain

Posts.Content: Kelly - firstly, I'm sorry you find yourself here, but it's a good place to be in the circumstances.   Secondly, we all have gone through what you are going through now.  It's so frightening at the beginning, but hang on to this - Breast cancer is curable, you are young and fit, so they will throw every possible treatment at you, and you aren't going anywhere for a considerable time yet! The waiting is the hardest part - once you start on the treatment, you are on a rollercoaster that you can't get off, but you will come through the other side.  Yes, things are never quite the same, but you have a lot to hang on to, so keep smiling and beat this bugger! If you are really struggling, get some diazepam from your GP which will stop you focussing on things until you're in a position to move forward.
Posts.Title: I'm new and just been diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Hiya Highland Mum You have to do what you are happy with.  If you don't feel ready at this point, then let them know and postpone it for 6 months.  A year.  However long it takes.  Obviously if you decide you do want it, you will have to wait for a slot, but you shouldn't feel obliged to do it just because it's offered. Of course the one thing about having the DIEP is that yes, you get a tummy tuck and yes, you get some great boobs, but it is a long op, and the recovery will take some time.   If you are using a prosthesis, you would be able to forget about it, and just live life as before without the risk of it popping out at an inconvenient moment!  Or if you're just going flat, then clothes will fit better with a reconstruction, as they are obviously designed to take account of breasts normally.   Ask your team about spotting recurrence, because I'm not sure about this.  Whatever happens, make sure it's YOUR decision.
Posts.Title: To have reconstruction - or not!

Posts.Content: Just bumping this very useful post.
Posts.Title: Indexed Terms and Abbreviations Dictionary For Everything BC Related...

Posts.Content: Love it, Pat!
Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: I'm sure she'd be great at it!
Posts.Title: A smile to start today.

Posts.Content: Some people find it better at night, some in the morning.  I suppose everyone is different, if you are pre-menopausal you  may find that the flushes affect your sleep and taking it in the morning is better, or vice versa.  Unfortunately there is no easy answer, just give it a try and see!
Posts.Title: New member to the group

Posts.Content: You could call the hospital and ask for the surgeon's secretary.  Then you'd have a contact.  And I would think there is more than one breast care nurse, too, if not, Macmillan may have a contact there.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction after a conservation surgery

Posts.Content: You are entitled to a second opinion. If there is another hospital you can go to, ask to go there. You needn't keep going there once you have had the mammogram results. Where are you in the country?
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you feel this way, Jenny.  I knew I wouldn't deal well with losing a breast, so I insisted on immediate reconstruction.  I don't know if you have been given this option, but it is certainly something to consider.  As to upsetting people, we are all free to express our feelings here.  Sometimes it is upsetting to us, to realise that others have been less fortunate than ourselves, sometimes it is upsetting to realise that we are the unfortunates.  The thing about cancer is that it's totally random in how it affects people, and how the treatment affects them. Hang on to life though - things definitely do improve with time, and keep a dialogue with your surgeon.
Posts.Title: body image

Posts.Content: I think you can get stick on ones but depending on the weight it wouldn't necessarily be very reliable! Imagine you are walking along and it pops out of your blouse or falls out from your dress!
Posts.Title: Prosthetics without a bra

Posts.Content: Hi kayleigh39, I'm sorry you had to come back here, but you have done the right thing. I have to say that both the doctor and the nurse have behaved very unprofessionally, and I would be making a complaint if I were you. That said, the important thing is that they have sent you for an urgent referral.  Be prepared for things to move very quickly because from your description it sounds as though they suspect cancer and are doing the right things by sending you straight away. Unfortunately small lumps need to be monitored and it seems that this hasn't happened for you.  At least you are being seen now, and hopefully will be put onto a treatment plan as soon as possible, assuming a cancer diagnosis.   Do keep posting and whatever happens, we are here to support you.
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: Ah, tricky. You can still go anywhere in the country, I believe.
Posts.Title: Urgent referral

Posts.Content: Hi Daydream47  Absolutely normal.  The good news is that it does improve and you do eventually stop thinking about your new breast every second of every day. The more you use your muscles, the easier it becomes, honestly.
Posts.Title: Implant reconstruction and SNB advise please

Posts.Content: CJW - I suggest you give it a go.  Not everyone has side effects, you may be one of the lucky ones.  If you do have problems you can re-evaluate.  Also don't forget that different makes have different effects on people.  If you find SEs worse with one then note it that you don't want that one.  You need to give it a good go before you decide to stop, trying various options, and do keep your team in the loop as to what is good and what isn't.
Posts.Title: Anastrazole and its side effects

Posts.Content: The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel - brilliant film, great actors, and some lovely scenery!
Posts.Title: The Film Thread

Posts.Content: Hi  I had a prophylactic mastectomy and IDC. I felt the same way as you. What  I didn't know was that recurrence can take place in the bones, liver, lungs, brain and skin. so the mastectomy is only part of the story.  I don't regret my decision,  as I wanted a matched pair, but it's always good to know all the facts.
Posts.Title: Removing a healthy breast vs the risk of recurrence

Posts.Content: Great news! We love a happy ending.!  Now enjoy your life!
Posts.Title: New, just been referred for fast track tests after finding lump

Posts.Content: I would think it's highly unlikely that you would be up for it. I'd give at 6 weeks before you plan anything significant  That does depend on r type of reconstruction that you have, but even straight implants are not simple.
Posts.Title: Healing

Posts.Content: You can get temporary tattoos done by cosmetic tattooing artists.  They usually last about six months to a couple of years, and your eyebrows would grow back over them if you have them done before they fall out so they are in the same place.
Posts.Title: henna eyebrows

Posts.Content: Ah I see.  The waiting game is the pits, we've all been through it and to be honest it's the not knowing that you worry most, worst case scenarios, etc.  Of course when it comes to it, most things you worry about don't actually happen, and this is the same. The radiologist may have seen several similar scans in their work and they do get to know, so the fact is, it's likely to be cancer, but it's not necessarily the end of the world. Try to keep busy and don't dwell on the what ifs, they won't change the outcome and will just make you miserable.  Once you have a definite diagnosis and treatment plan, you wll start to feel better and move forward.  Let us know what they say and others will chip in with their own experiences.
Posts.Title: If I have a 2cm lump in my LIQ does it mean that my cancer is invasive...

Posts.Content: Hi, Fiona and welcome to the forum.   You may like to join the December Chemo Club when it starts up, we roll these over from month to month so that they don't get too unwieldy! Lots of triple negative ladies here, and I am sure they will pop up and say hello shortly!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed....saying hello!

Posts.Content: You're welcome, and in the meantime you can have a read of the November chemo club. I can't link you at the moment, but you can do a quick search for it
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed....saying hello!

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz and happy birthday!  I've had 5 birthdays since I was diagnosed and coming up to 6! I was a drama queen too!
Posts.Title: A birthday i thought I'd never reach...

Posts.Content: Sounds great, Mrs Pat, go spend those wages,  you've earned them!
Posts.Title: My new life.

Posts.Content: In order to undergo the test, you must have been diagnosed with cancer.  BRCA mutation can manifest as breast, ovarian or prostate cancer, so you need to factor these in as well.  If you do find that you carry the gene then your family can be tested.
Posts.Title: Hereditary breast cancer

Posts.Content: bougiecat I couldn't agree more about both management of the NHS and drug companies.  In particular, the NHS is being ripped off because, for example, I know of one medication that costs £120 per month and yet can be bought OTC in Greece for £3 simply because only one make is licensed here in the UK therefore there is a monopoly. Consequently people who need it, who generally have a genetic defect that makes it life threatening not to have it, are often denied it by their GP or CCG.  Makes my blood boil!
Posts.Title: Concerned about recent news

Posts.Content: I've never heard that it was done in two stages, plenty of people have had it done all in one though, unless you are having an uplift on the other side at some point? Are you sure your surgeon knows what he's doing?!
Posts.Title: complications following LD back muscle op

Posts.Content: Woohoo!
Posts.Title: STABLE.........

Posts.Content: Congratulations, Heather, on getting the surgery done and dusted!  Give yourself time to heal and don't expect too much of yourself for a good few weeks.
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy plus LD Flap

Posts.Content: Hi P.J.  Sorry to hear that your husband isn't very understanding at this difficult time.  I hope you are in enough of a good position to be able to tell your husband that you are doing your best to get a job (I hope you are looking for part time at this moment!), but that a) you can't actually force someone to give you a job, and b) actually the treatment has taken a lot out of you and you need time to fully recover.   Tell him that, chances are, at this stage, that if you get a full time job you will feel exhausted and he will have to do a lot more around the house, because on top of the job you won't be able to do all that stuff.  Now if he won't help you, you are going to have to pay someone, because you won't have much energy.   And, you know, sometimes people split up through cancer.  And sometimes it's for the best.  Only you know if this will be you.  But whatever happens, you need to do what is best of you at this moment.  Your health needs you to be strong and only by looking after your needs will you properly recover.   I'm here to tell you that 5 years on, I'm living life bigger and better than before.  I wish that for you too.  Good luck and feel free to rant here, it's very therapeutic!
Posts.Title: How to tell my husband

Posts.Content: Hi Rosalyn I've not heard of this either, but if it were me I think I would give myself a bit longer before resuming taking the Tamoxifen.  Aches and pains are well documented side effects, so you will probably get these again once you resume, but giving yourself a break just may help you to cope once you are ready.   If you are concerned about leaving it, speak to the onco and explain how it made you feel.  They may even prescribe something different, at least short term.
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and neutropenic sepsis

Posts.Content: I did sort of understand that! But of course it's ridiculous!  Worst case scenario - it comes back and you and your family have some lovely memories.  Best case, you celebrate having a crap year with a lovely holiday, punctuating the end of the crap, and the beginning of the rest of your life ... GO FOR IT!
Posts.Title: Tempting fate....ridiculous

Posts.Content: We used Insureandgo.  We had to declare both my husband's medication and my cancer and it went up (more from him than me!).  After 5 years I don't have to declare any cancer.  You need to weigh up the likelihood of any reason for your cancellation/hospitalisation/repatriation being cancer related as usually anything that may occur can wait until you get home for treatment!
Posts.Title: Travel Insurance - any advice

Posts.Content: You will get lots of support here, Ann. The most important weapon in the war against cancer is surgery, so that plus radiotherapy would be a good option for your mum.  And at your mum's age, it's about quality of life as much as quantity.  If you have any worries, post here and someone will answer you.
Posts.Title: MOM

Posts.Content: Well done, you made it! Welcome to the NEDdy paddock!
Posts.Title: End of treatment....!

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group, Morecombe.  IBC is a tricky beast,  but your team will be on the ball.  Don't hesitate to call them if you have any nagging questions,  but in the meantime,  I know these lovely ladies here will be full of help and advice on wigs,  scarves and all the things you need to know about chemo.
Posts.Title: chemo starts next week

Posts.Content: Just to add to the already  helpful advice , if you are on statins, they can cause many of the symptoms you are having.
Posts.Title: Herceptin Side Effects

Posts.Content: Welcome to the community Mo42  you'll find it a great source of help and support. Weekly taxol won't be as hard on your hair so you can get may not need your wig for a while, hopefully it will have cooled down a bit by then. Your positive attitude will certainly help you to get through treat, and remember the only silly questions are the ones you don't ask.
Posts.Title: MS. CLL and now breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Claire I really feel for you - the pain you feel from your posts is evident in the way you write. I just wanted to say that it's their problem that they can't accept you for who you are and support you through this awful time.  It says a lot about them.  It can be hard to be different, as you have found, but please keep in touch with them because they will one day realise that they are the ones who are missing out on your company.   In the meantime, be with people who understand - both here and perhaps at your local hospital support group?  Possibly spend more time with friends and if they are sparse at the moment, join the local LGBT group in your area.  Life is too short to spend time worrying about people who aren't worried about us.
Posts.Title: alone

Posts.Content: Best advice I can give you, Jamesy, is do the birthday things this weekend.  That way you'll still have the fun, and if you feel better the weekend after, do them again that weekend too - double the fun!  Never put off till after chemo what you can do before ..... :D
Posts.Title: chemo delayed a week ..so upset

Posts.Content: Hi Robs I remember when I had my WLE the nipple was going "hot and cold" if you know what I mean, all the time, every few minutes!  It was very unnerving!  I had to have a mastectomy afterwards, so never found out if it would have settled, but I imagine it would have eventually.  Hope yours does but if you are concerned, do mention it to your surgeon. Helen
Posts.Title: Post surgery sensitivity

Posts.Content: You won't have a mammogram but if you have any issues then you might have an ultrasound. I used to be felt and examined, but it wasn't really much.   They do say that you will go back with a problem if you think it has returned.
Posts.Title: Mama gram after mastectomy

Posts.Content: This may be true.  I didn't mention in my post, but all of my mother's three sisters (including her twin) have all had breast cancer, and I thought it was highly likely I DID carry the BRCA gene.  I had the mastectomy before the test, but they were happy enough that the risk could be high anyay. As it turned out, I don't have the gene.  The other thing was that I never wanted to go through the "You've got breast cancer" thing again.  On my first WLE op, the lady in the next bed to me had gone to her 5 year check expecting to be given the all clear to be told that there was a lump in her other breast.
Posts.Title: Fighting for a double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Fantastic!  Good for her!
Posts.Title: Positive news

Posts.Content: Hi Rily  You've already had some great replies from the lovely ladies here, and I would concur with everything they have said.  And couple of things to add though. Firstly, if your daughter does get a cancer diagnosis, you could encourage her to join this forum for support.  As she is deaf, she may well find it easier to "talk " here.  Plus the ladies (and the occasional gent) are founts of knowledge and help. Secondly, breast cancer has one of the best survival rates.  She's young,  so in the event that cancer is found, they will likely throw everything at her in terms of treatment.  This is where you can help and your own experience will come in very handyou. Finally, I truly think it is often harder for the family and friends who feel so helpless.  In a way your own experience will make it harder for you because you will know exactly what she is going through but in other ways it will help you do the right thing.   Post away with any questions - someone will have been there and done that!
Posts.Title: Daughter

Posts.Content: Judith, I can't remember,  but are you on thyroid meds?
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: I would have a read of Dr Malcolm Kendrick's blog.  It has some fascinating articles about statins and familial hypercholesterolaemia.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: Hi amy66  I'm coming in late to this as I've had a busy weekend.  I must confess to being one that quotes these figures.  But the people who mostly come here in panic mode need reassurance and it does actually give that to those people. To those such as yourself, please note that I try to pepper posts with might, could, should, etc.  It would be wrong and foolish to post definites because none of us really know what is going to happen.   People with 100% health and fitness with diets proscribed by the governent as idea can still find themselves joining us and their treatment can kill them.  There are no absolutes in health and I hope you are able to receive some kind of treatment that gives you the best possible outcome.
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne Tomorrow is another day.  Sometimes we all have to give in and just let the misery take over.  But you just have to tell yourself that tomorrow will be better.  And it will.  Anti-depressants can fuel the munchies so you might have to either try a different one or perhaps sort yourself some healthy munchies like carrots and celery.  But whatever happens, once the radiotherapy has past, you will probably be able to cut down or cut out the tablets anyway and move on.  It could be worth asking for some counselling now, because it will probably take a while to come through and after the treatment is often when you need it. Good sleep tonight xx
Posts.Title: I've had such a bad day

Posts.Content: In addition to the excellent advice from LondonLass I would just say get your B12 checked because could be low which can lead to impaired cognitive function. Of course it could be the drugs, but it could also be something else .You need a level around 800-1000 for optimal function. You can buy methylcobalamin over the counter and there are different strengths, any excess is excreted so you can't overdose. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Can I say 'no' to post breast cancer treatment drugs?

Posts.Content: Protocol is to leave them about 24 hours to ensure you have healed over,  so yes, you can take it off!
Posts.Title: Question about expander top up

Posts.Content: Hi Nicola The thing is, how would you feel if you have a recurrence?  Knowing if you could have taken something that you wouldn't be in that position? Ask your oncologist for the statistics for both with and without the hormone therapies.  I do know how you feel, because I am allergic to loads of things.  I would suggest that assuming the statistics say you would have a significant reduction in recurrence with the hormone therapies, that you give them a try.  If you find the side effects too difficult (after trying all the different brands, because many ladies find one that suits them over others) then you can decide whether you want quality of life over quantity.   I was 47 when I was diagnosed, and given tamoxifen after surgery etc.  I decided that the side effects weren't worth the extra 1% protection, but that was a tiny margin.  I would say think what margin you could live with, and if the onco says less then you will know it's the right decision.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy & Hormone treatment positive lymph node

Posts.Content: I was in your position.   I argued that for my own mental health, I needed to have them both done.  I've not seen a good naked matched pair, although I do think that in clothes you can rarely tell the difference (even if you know).   From an aesthetic point of view, I'm very happy with the look of my pair.  Yes, I have no feeling, but my husband isn't really a "boob" man so it's never been a massive issue for me.   I had to go and have a second opinion - a lot of surgeons won't do it on cost grounds, and they say that if it's not necessary for health reasons then it comes under cosmetic surgery rather than medical.  These are all things to bear in mind. I have to say that I cried quite a lot in the office.  This almost backfired because the surgeon said he was concerned that I wasn't in the right frame of mind to make the decision!
Posts.Title: Fighting for a double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Doctors often read in range as normal instead of actually looking at the results.  Always best to get copies of results and let a knowledgeable person interpret them.  The thyroid is delicate and can get knocked sideways byx-rays,  radiotherapy and chemo. High cholesterol can be a sign of undertreated or underactive thyroid.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: This is a link to the article I was talking about (now that I'm home and on my laptop!).  I'm not proposing you buy the book. The great cholesterol con.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole/ Arimidex: SE: Raised Blood Cholesterol ?

Posts.Content: Just popping in to add my experience. I had a double mastectomy and I have almost no sensation in the breast.  If you have a mastectomy with implant as I have, you would likely have no sensation in the nipple although this would depend on the route taken by the surgeon.  If I were in your position I would go for the lumpectomy and radiotherapy. Hope you can make a decision!
Posts.Title: Masectomy or lumpectomy? Advice please

Posts.Content: Hi Claire So sorry to hear that your partner couldn't take the heat as it were.  I suppose it's not much consolation, but better to find out now than later on.  Lots of people here have had their partners do the same, which is quite sad when you think about it, but luckily there are a lot of really good supportive partners around too.  You had some good advice about the LGBT group, but equally here, people have been through what you have been through, so will understand that side of things.  You may also find that there is a local support group - your hospital will be able to advise you.  I really honestly believe that unless you've been through it, it's so hard to understand.  I know I didn't understand before diagnosis, and that's why I try to be here for others now.   At your next appointment you will be checked over for any physical problems with healing, rads, etc.  But it's important that you also let them know how you are feeling.  Family can't really understand, and to be honest we all have such busy lives it's easy to just feel that patients are "milking" it but you will move on and find the new you.  This is why this forum is so useful. Do post away as we really all do understand. Helen
Posts.Title: alone

Posts.Content: Adassarose, it may help you to have some facts. I know it is a terrifying place because we don't talk about cancer, it's still a taboo subject. But we should talk about it because it reduces the fear. Once you start to talk to people you realise that cancer survivors all around you and you didn't know.  Breast cancer is very treatable and 90% of patients are still alive and kicking five years from diagnosis. The other 10% are usually elderly and die of something else, late diagnosis or have other significant health issues. Don't be a glass 10% empty person, it's easy to wallow and wail and say but what if.  Be the glass 90% full person. You will get through this. You will be one of the people in a few weeks that is welcoming newbies and reassuring them.  In the meantime, keep busy and pop on here if you have any worries.
Posts.Title: Sleepness nights

Posts.Content: The end result of a two stage operation is better, though. And the second part is a much quicker recovery. Don't end up living a life of regret because of taking some time for yourself now.  what do you do for work?  I doubt very much it will be months and months.  And hey, it was only just Christmas, and now it's Easter!  They really will go quick if that happens.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: Congratulations! Sounds like a complete pathological response.
Posts.Title: Happy news....

Posts.Content: Locums are always good, they don't care about the practice budget, they just do what is best for the patient, and are often more up to date with the latest thinking. I never had a lump either.
Posts.Title: Pains shoulder blade

Posts.Content: I'm reading between the lines but can I assume that you had quite large breast previously?   I ask because I was a 36C and had an immediate recon with Becker Expanders, and woke up with a pretty good breast shape right from the start.  I have had two fill ups now, and they are nearly at full size.  Be wary of expanding too fast though, as it is the muscles that have to expand, and this is a pretty tender process.  I've been told I'd need one further fill to over expand then a reduction to allow the natural droop to take effect.  Had to have some of the volume removed from one the other day though, as it was too tight and very bruised/sore.  the Beckers are supposed to stay in place and not  be replaced, but I'm not convinced yet. Helen x
Posts.Title: Recently undergone double mastectomy and reconstruction. How long...

Posts.Content: Hi Jj1 It's perfectly natural and normal to feel like this at annual checks.  The waiting for results is a nightmare, even when we don't think we are worried, the relief of the "all clear" in the post is massive. I assume that your husband hasn't had a life changing experience like this that would make him understand. I had the same thing with mine, he just didn't get it at all. He still doesn't completely.  I've given up trying to make him understand, as I realise that you need the depth of experience to totally get it.  Luckily you have found this place and we DO get it!   For yourself, I would say, plan some fun things for the next few weeks.  Don't dwell on negatives.  In the highly unlikely event that there is a problem, worrying for the next few weeks will just rob you of the joy of that time.  Your husband is right, the probability is low, but it doesn't help you in the meantime!   Fingers crossed.
Posts.Title: First year follow up mammogram

Posts.Content: For anyone who's GP says the R1/R2 is too expensive. It's about £75. The cost of additional creams, appointments, potential skin problems and infection from broken skin is much higher.   The short term view is not always the right one.  I've yet to read of anyone using it on this forum who has had any problems at all. Skin breakdown is NOT an acceptable side effect when it is preventable.  Rant over!
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy questions

Posts.Content: I would just give your BCN a call regarding the compression stockings but I have two weeks in my head for some reason.
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy plus LD Flap
