To those such as yourself, please note that I try to pepper posts with might, could, should, etc.  It would be wrong and foolish to post definites because none of us really know what is going to happen.   People with 100% health and fitness with diets proscribed by the governent as idea can still find themselves joining us and their treatment can kill them.  There are no absolutes in health and I hope you are able to receive some kind of treatment that gives you the best possible outcome.
Posts.Title: Could we give some hope to people like me please?

Posts.Content: OMG What a bitch! I mean, she may have a point, but what's the point in telling you that?  You're just gonna stress about it, and you know that stress is the worst thing for cancer!  Best to just say something like "let's hope so" and leave it at that?   I think if I were you, I'd go back and have a word. Or put in a complaint.  Honestly, it makes my blood boil!
Posts.Title: New here, and not sure if I should be - yet.

Posts.Content: I think I read about sage leaf?  Perhaps check with your team before taking but it might help?
Posts.Title: Hot flushes/sweats

Posts.Content: I feel for you, LondonLass  But whatever the results are, worrying won't change them, and will just stop you enjoying however long you have. Put it in a box for now and no stressing until the appointment!
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Florence  The answer is, no one knows. But if I were you, I would ask your GP to do a full blood test, including thyroid and B12, as these can make you feel this way. Get a print out of results for your records, you are entitled, and you will know what has been done. If your B12 comes back below 500, you should consider supplements (not a multivitamin), I take Jarrows 5000 iu, sublingual.
Posts.Title: is letrozole really to blame

Posts.Content: It does sound as if you may be suffering from nerve pain and that won't be touched by regular painkillers. Ask your GP to prescribe some nerve pain relief such as amytriptylene or gabapentin. Some great advice already, too.
Posts.Title: SNB post op nerve pain and dragging

Posts.Content: Hi ladies  I just wanted to add that October is Breast Cancer Awareness month so you will find more of it for the next few weeks.   As Julia says,  these ads raise money but also awareness.  Some people go around in a bubble, not believing that anything will affect them or their loved ones.Fundraisers are usually patients or relatives, not altruistic people, there are very few of them.  Be grateful for the charities and the laboratories are working for you, and for your future.
Posts.Title: Adverts!!

Posts.Content: Hi Eleanor Teenagers tend to deal with things differently than we would, I think.  Your daughter may well use the link without telling you, and going on about how unfair things are for her is her way of dealing with your cancer.  It seems strange, but I think she probably feels she needs to rail against something, the unfairness of your cancer, for example, but doesn't think that would go down well, so her birthday is the focus. You may well find that in the long run it will be the making of her and you end up with a daughter that you weren't expecting to be so proud of. Do keep talking and involving her without "going on", and with luck she will emerge a better person for it.
Posts.Title: Still in discomfort

Posts.Content: Hi Janey1508  I can't help with exemestane, and I'm sure that it is causing the joint pain, but have you tried adding some vitamin D3?  I found it helped when I was on Tamoxifen with joint pain (a bit, not massively, but every little helps).
Posts.Title: Exemestane vs Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Congratulations!  It's great to read positive news!
Posts.Title: Today I am a cancer survivor :)

Posts.Content: Hi Ali I know how you feel - you just want to get back to your old life.  Sadly that never quite happens, but I have to say that mine has actually improved no end, so it's not all bad! Wockhardt is the brand that most people seem to feel fine on.  Boots seem to do it and my local pharmacy mainly gives me that one too.  I've not really had masses of problems on it, so I think sometimes you hear only the bad things and not the people who've had a relatively easy time. So take it, see how it goes, you may find you have fewer problems than you anticipate.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen help please

Posts.Content: Ladies - it will help to massage the scar to soften it.  If you use something like bio oil it's a double whammy!  Also it may be helpful to wear supportive underwear.  Yes, I am talking Spanx here! I know they're not sexy, but it just might make a difference.
Posts.Title: DIEP flap

Posts.Content: Hi ayres1962  Welcome to our friendly group! I didn't have any lumps, but I did have a niggling pain in my breast. The good news is that it was over 6 years ago, and I'm good now.  You have an appointment, so that's good, hopefully you won't have too long to wait before someone can reassure you.
Posts.Title: Pains shoulder blade

Posts.Content: Hi Purpleheart I'm sorry to hear your partner has breast cancer, and that you are caught in this web not of your making! I will tell you that there is no right or wrong, your partner's family may have strong feelings one way or another, but it is your partner that is the important person here.  And you.   Your partner will have had a meeting with the oncologist (at which you may have been present?) and should have been presented with the statistics for or against the chemo, and I'm guessing that she decided that for her, the risks outweighed the benefits.  In my own case, there was no benefit whatsoever, so it was easy for me, but I know that if my OH had some kind of cancer and chemo was offered, I would be wary of pushing him into it if he didn't want it.   That said, it is a miracle drug for some, and has saved many lives.  What it is important for you to do is to make sure that your partner knows you love her, and that you support her in her decision (even if, deep down, you don't agree with it).  Because how would you feel if she was one of the few who reacted really badly, or who, despite the chemo, and having suffered the effects, had a recurrence anyway?   The thing is, we just don't know what will happen.  All statistics by their nature are at least 10 years out of date, treatments have moved on markedly, and breast cancer has the best survival rate of any cancer if caught early.    I think it's often harder to be the partner than the patient, and your partner will know why she decided what she did, but maybe you need her to explain it to you.  Good luck to both of you on this journey. Helen
Posts.Title: in search of wise words..

Posts.Content: I had implants and they were fine. I know of others who have had no problems at all. You do tend to see the posts where people have problems. DIEP has quite a high failure rate too.
Posts.Title: DCIS - DIEP or implant reconstruction?

Posts.Content: If you get worried about it or it gets any worse over the weekend, head to A&E.  These things can suddenly get worse and please don't wait.  Good luck with the other boob.
Posts.Title: In a right tizz now!

Posts.Content: Hi Flower Sorry to hear you had a bad day apart from the radio thing.  And good luck for your appointment tomorrow.  It's always a hard day, so make sure you have something nice to look forward to after! Just a thought about the ball, and I'm sorry if you already did this, but if you promote it as a fun night out rather than too much emphasis on the charity and fundraising side, you'll probably have more success with the tickets.  People are more inclined to part with their cash if they are going to enjoy themselves (not that they wouldn't, but you know what I mean).  Hope you don't mind me saying.
Posts.Title: Not Had A Good Day (apart from a special event talking about Cancer...

Posts.Content: I don't see why asthma should be a problem, but you must make sure that the hospital knows about the metal as the scans use big magnets!
Posts.Title: scans and asthma and metal pins

Posts.Content: So pleased for you!  The oncologist will give you the stats for hormone therapy (your chances of recurrence with and without) and that will help you decide.   Bear in mind that these stats are only stats and don't take into account you as an individual, your lifestyle or your make-up and are, by their nature, at least 5 years out of date! Helen
Posts.Title: Good News At Last

Posts.Content: OK,you can check for interactions at the Sloan Kettering website.  If you Google it, you will see the link.  If you do decide to take D3, get some K2 mk7 to go with it so that it is transported to the bones where it is needed and not left in the arteries where it can cause damage.
Posts.Title: Exemestane vs Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Kaz - I can understand where you are coming from - I had a mastectomy and reconstruction in November, and mine felt very similar for quite some time.  In fact, it's only been the past week that I've started to come to terms.  I had a double mastectomy which maybe why I think that mine don't actually look that bad.  Perhaps you are trying to compare two different things? I really don't think that your sister was helpful to say what she said, but then a lot of the people that we think should be there to support us actually turn out not to be on our side - that doesn't mean they are against us, just that they are on their own side looking from their own perspective, and not considering our feelings.  I don't think you can properly understand what it is like until you have been through it yourself anyway, so it's not exactly her fault.   anyway, focus on the good days - you are alive and you are getting through this!   Helen x
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosed for the second time

Posts.Content: Sorry for the delay in replying, Katie.  All the places you mention are lymph gland points.  Have you taken your temperature regularly?  It might be you have an infection, and these glands are the points that will be full of white blood cells and lymph fighting off any bugs.  It could also account for the soreness.  Your temperature could be normal but high for you if you aren't aware what it normally is?  If it is no better tomorrow I would phone your chemo unit and/or go to A&E to be on the safe side.
Posts.Title: Any one else had this side effect

Posts.Content: ninjaowl  It's definitely worth mentioning to your chemo unit on Monday, but not something to worry about over the weekend.
Posts.Title: Spotting / period

Posts.Content: Hiya modestmouse  I was told that the first two years of Tamoxifen were the most critical.  I almost managed it.  I decided that quality of life was more important than quantity.  That said, my statistics were 1% either way, and I was stage 1, so chances of recurrence were low.   Obviously we have to make our own decisions, but you are intelligent, and I know exactly what you are saying about the medical profession (yourself notwithstanding, obviously!) Good luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: time to stop tamoxifen

Posts.Content: It's because you can only have radiotherapy once so if it returned to the same breast they would know where you had had treatment exactly.   Don't worry about what ifs, you can't change them, so go forward and enjoy the rest of the life you have been given.
Posts.Title: Radiation tattoo shock!

Posts.Content: Hi chelseabun  I had bilateral mastectomy with permanent expanders.  They are fab, no problems at all once they settled, and everyone seems to think they are great! I wasn't working at the time, but I guess it depends what you do?
Posts.Title: Reconstruction with expanders

Posts.Content: LOL, Jacky!  I swear I haven't!   I think Spanx are more comfortable than skinny jeans!  I know I have to undo mine at the end of the day!
Posts.Title: DIEP flap

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne When you get a cancer diagnosis you go through all the stages of grief often several times if results don't come back clear.  You will get through it but my suggestion is give yourself permission to wail and wallow for 15 minutes.  Set a timer and let it all out.  I can pretty much guarantee that you will be looking at the clock before it goes off.  Then put it back in the box and go and do something.  Anything.  You are going to get through this and you will be fine.  I've been where you are and I wish I hadn't wasted my time on it.  Go do something nice even if it is for someone else.
Posts.Title: Feel so alone

Posts.Content: Hi mumofboys Welcome to the community.  You should definitely go back and ask for a referral to the breast unit, as it could be Paget's disease of the nipple.   Not all cancers present as a lump.  Please insist.   Let us know how you get on.
Posts.Title: Can I ask you opinions?

Posts.Content: You can always mention surgeons if you have a good experience!  If you have a bad one, we keep it private as we are liable to all sorts.
Posts.Title: How do I choose, one mastectomy or two, immediate or delayed reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Hi Alo I wouldn't worry too much.  Yes, IBC can be aggressive, and can be misdiagnosed as mastitis, but you ARE pregnant, which makes the likelihood of mastitis much more likely.  You don't say how long you are away for. but unless it is for longer than three weeks, I wouldn't think it would make much difference.   Two days isn't long for antibiotics to take effect, if you are there for another 5 days with no improvement, I suggest you go back to the doctor you have seen.  There is a Macmillan number you can ring from abroad, perhaps someone who knows will post it.   Please enjoy your holiday, put it out of your mind as far as you can, and see your GP when you get back. Helen
Posts.Title: Inflammatory breast cancer and pregnancy

Posts.Content: Hi Teresa  On the one hand, you've got a quick scan, on the other, no one wants to be in this position, let alone for a second time. Fingers crossed it's just cysts, but if it is a new primary then you beat it once and you will do it again.  Everything crossed for you. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Please....not again

Posts.Content: You're very welcome - I know my husband struggled a bit with my diagnosis and treatment - he was terrified of being left alone, which is completely understandable.  But we both talked and cried and held each other - I won't say it has been easy, but we've hung in there, and now, one year from diagnosis, we are coming out the other side.   The medical community are so straightened by procedure that any one trying to think outside the box just does not compute for them.  I know Sascha Rose has had some complimentary light based therapy which might be an alternative to look into?   As to her mum dying with chemo, I'm guessing that was some time ago, and I must stress that things have moved on a LOT, but that there are still so many things they don't know, that I totally understand her point of view.   You are lucky to have good friends - DO make the most of them, talk to them, take a friend to the pub for a drink and a moan, go for a walk with them if you are feeling weepy, and don't hold all your feelings in in front of her, as she needs to know how you feel too.   ((((((gentle hugs)))))) Helen
Posts.Title: in search of wise words..

Posts.Content: Hiya, I had a double Mx with implants too for the reason that it would have messed with my head to have one boob to check (I never had a lump but pain) and also for wanting a matched pair.  I was 47 at diagnosis and still wanted to look good naked.  I would have liked a DIEP flap but I didn't get the option as my surgeon talked my husband and I into implants.  Although a DIEP would have been a great look, I needed to keep mobile as I have horses and wanted to carry on doing what I'd been doing before as quickly as possible.   If you want to see what they look like, I'll happy send you a picture - just send a friend request and a PM saying you would like to see the photo and I will send it back.
Posts.Title: How do I choose, one mastectomy or two, immediate or delayed reconstruction...

Posts.Content: Great news, Matt, I hope you opened a bottle of fizz to celebrate! Hopefully you won't need us now, but we're here if you do, and enjoy that holiday, you've both earned it!
Posts.Title: All over, thank you x

Posts.Content: Birda  As you are lucky enough to be referred to a one stop shop you should get most results on the day.  I went to the GP on a Monday and they phoned me Tuesday to see me that Wednesday but I couldn't do that so I went the following Wednesday.  I was there about 3 hrs and they did a mammogram, then an ultrasound and then a biopsy. (It was at this point that I started to get worried).  They looked at the biopsy and then i saw the surgeon who was going to book me in the following week for a lumpectomy but I was going away so it all got deferred a bit.   I know it all feels a bit surreal at the moment, but do try not to worry, what will be will be and the treatment for breast cancer is very good these days.  By the way, all of this was over 6 years ago, nearly 7, so I do know what I'm talking about!
Posts.Title: Timescale confusion from gl

Posts.Content: Hiya Dindu. As Dreamthief says, the waiting is the pits. And in some ways it's worse for the family  than the patient because at least the patient is 'doing' something even it if's just laying there being prodded.  Being friends or family can be heartbreaking, watching your loved ones suffer is never great  You could join the "Friends and Family" group where others in the same situation can give you hints and tips on how to cope.   If it is Paget's disease then it is likely she will have her nipple removed.  And if she does this can be reconstructed at a later stage. I didn't have my nipples reconstructed, but I did have 3D tattoos which look pretty realistic from a distance.  And you won't care, anyway, I don't suppose. As to reconstruction itself, there are lots of options, the back one is less popular and in fact most of the muscle ones are falling out of favour unless there are no other options.  If you are (even vaguely) near any of the Keeping Abreast groups then it is worth a trip to one of their meetings where your wife will be able to look at the various reconstructions as the ladies there do a "show and tell" and can talk about their experiences.  (Unfortunately men aren't allowed!).  There is no substitute for experience in these circumstances.  I am personally not a fan of the LD flap (the back muscle) reconstruction, because, like you, I know of several people who have had long term problems with it.  That said, I do still think the DIEP reconstruction is a good one, even though I know several ladies have had issues with that.  It's about personal preference at the end of the day, and of course, not all reconstructions are suitable for everyone.
Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Hi Trish - thanks for the massive giggle - I now have a picture of Gollum in my head!!   Have a good Xmas, my preciousssss .... :D Helen x

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Swirly  I can't really help but I thought you might appreciate my experience.  I ride horses, and my most recent horse is a bit of a liability.  Anyway, he slid and fell, throwing me at canter. I landed on my side / front and it hurt a lot.  I wasn't wearing a body protector.  I was taken to A&E and x-ray showed no broken bones and implants were fine. The doctor said that they probably helped the impact.  So far from needing more protection you may not need as much! It may be you need to allow more time to heal though, don't try to do too much too soon.

Posts.Content: You'll be fine with ibuprofen.

Posts.Content: Sad to say, there are no guarantees when it comes to the crunch.  I agree, you need more information.  You could try the macmillan helpline.
Posts.Title: time to stop tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Not doing anything wrong, and the problem probably is that most people are out enjoying the weather! A lumpectomy isn't necessarily a better option - yes, you have some breast, but it could be disfigured or deformed, will almost certainly be a slightly different size, and you run the risk of recurrence. I appreciate that you are young, but you will be offered reconstruction, so that shouldn't be too much of an issue.  Personally I had lumpectomy, then further excision to get clear margins and then when that didn't work mastectomy.  I opted to have both breasts removed to avoid going through this all in the future.  And I was only Grade I.   Hope this helps
Posts.Title: How do I get advice and support?

Posts.Content: Neither,can I, Mark, I had no lump but at the end of treatment I was just glad it was out.
Posts.Title: Scary times ahead

Posts.Content: I think you should ask your oncologist but I personally would leave it alone.
Posts.Title: Can you use fake tan on head while on chemo? :0)

Posts.Content: Dreamthief that's one we all need to act on. My favourite saying
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hi Dindu,  Firstly, if your wife does has Paget's, it's likely the condition is limited to the area concerned, rather than floating around the body.  At this stage, it is too early to know, but this is what is most likely.  But that said, I can see the logic of postponing a relatively routine operation in favour of the more urgent one (and possibly doing them at the same time, this can also happen, but of course you need a diagnosis first.   The test turn-around ... the answer is, it depends.  I think for the HER2+ status it takes 3 weeks to grow the protein, (but I don't know where I got this from so don't quote me), but I think they can probably do the others sooner, but they have a system of biopsy-test-results-Multi disciplinary meeting-patient informed and that takes time.  We all appreciate that the waiting is the pits, though, and if doctors had to go through it, I'm sure the system would be better (and quicker). You can always call our helpline on 0808 808 0000, open Monday to Friday from 9am-8pm.  The nurses are very helpful.
Posts.Title: Padgets desease

Posts.Content: Hi CEC I'm sure all your friends think YOU are brave too.  The truth is, none of us have a choice, it's not brave, it's necessary.   You will cope with this, because you have to.  And please take one day at a time.  The chances are good.  Most of us (90%) are still here 5 years from diagnosis (the stats aren't available for longer), and of the 10%, they are mostly late diagnosis, elderly and die from other causes, or have other health issues.   So you will be back doing the horses and the dog before you know it although you may need help for a few weeks.  Any questions, just ask.
Posts.Title: How are you all so brave, I've just been diagnosed

Posts.Content: This is the Link . It's useful for both patients and relatives.
Posts.Title: All over, thank you x

Posts.Content: I found the same thing - the Breast Care Nurses were there at the beginning but they seemed to melt away after a week, and even though I was making a fuss (maybe that's why?!), just seemed to fob me off with platitudes.  Trouble was my case wasn't straightforward, but they're not equipped to cope with anything that's not according to the book, as it were.     I had a bit of a go, at which point they said they don't ring (unless there's a reason) but that you can ring THEM at any time, so Do make a pest of yourself - they're being paid to do a job, after all - and after everything, do complain to the hospital if you feel that you have not  been properly cared for.  They have guidelines which they have to conform to, but it seems that they see this as a maximum, not a minimum standard of care.     Hope this helps   Helen
Posts.Title: support before having your breast removed

Posts.Content: Hi Jamesy I went through lumpectomy and SNB, followed by further op with no clear margins and finally was told I needed a mastectomy.  I knew I wanted reconstruction, and had a good look around the internet at what the results were and decided that the best way of getting a matching pair would be to have both done at once.  I also felt the same as you, that I would always worry, and we know that cancer loves worry, so that was another good reason for having it done.   I was also lucky in that I was originally told I would need rads, but following the double Mx, I didn't need any further treatment.   Good luck with your decision, but I've not regretted mine.   Helen
Posts.Title: starting to think about a preventative double mastectomy..opinions...

Posts.Content: laura0403 - if you put travel insurance into the search bar at the top of the page you will find lots of suggestions.
Posts.Title: Mom diagnosed with invasive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: I think it's still very early days.  Radiotherapy is known to have a cumulative tiring effect and the effects of tamoxifen get worse at the beginning but do ease after a while.   I don't know if you are taking any Vitamin D tablets,  but they may help with the joint pain (make sure it's D3).
Posts.Title: Quality of life 7 weeks in??

Posts.Content: Julie - I could have written that post a while back.  I wasn't working when diagnosed because we were remodelling our house, but about a year after surgery I got a job (two, actually, both part time).  It really helped me to put things behind me because yes, everyone thought I was OK.  I didn't tell the new jobs that I had had cancer when I applied (one was a temp role, anyway) and it was nice to go somewhere where no one knew.   What I suggest is that you give yourself a little more time to get over things.  Get Xmas out of the way first, put your effort into making it a good occasion, and give your body time to recover from all the bugs.  When you feel good in yourself, that's the time to start to look for that dream job.  Keep half an eye on the job market, but don't stress about it. And if your husband joined the carers group here he could well find some support - if he's not really sure about that, you're welcome to friend me and my husband is actually happy to talk to other guys about it.  Nothing like a couple of blokes commiserating with each other about their miserable wives to make them feel better!  LOL
Posts.Title: Feeling very down one year after diagnosis for BC

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey Do you know what kind of implants you are having?  I have becker permanent expanders which have a silicone outer and a saline internal space which can be expanded.  Had no problems with leakage but if I did the saline is absorbed by the body naturally.  I wouldn't worry too much about it because cases are very rare.
Posts.Title: Breast implants

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear that, Caroline - I hope your husband has arrived by now and you have had a good cry and scream.   You proved that you should always follow your hunch, know your own body best and now trust in your care team to put you through the best possible treatment.  I wish you all the luck in the world.
Posts.Title: Freaking out slightly

Posts.Content: ask123  Doctors rarely use the word "cured" in cancer terms because cancer is so sneaky, so they will say treatable or "managed" and avoid the "C" word (cure) if possible  because they don't want to build up expectations. But in practice, you are probably going to be treated, and end up NED (no evidence of disease) which is as good as cured.
Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: I don't think GPs have much of a clue when it comes to these things, although I'm sure you're right, it could be scar tissue, but equally it could be a haematoma that hasn't dispersed yet (it's early days in some ways), or some other lump that has formed.  I would contact your BCN and/or Breast surgeon and see if you can get in to see them - they don't mind being bothered, and if something is on your mind, then it's better to sort it than spend 3 weeks wondering and worrying.
Posts.Title: Hard lump under lumpectomy scar ?

Posts.Content: I agree with Kacang I would rather have real sugar than sweeteners. I would rather have real butter and full fat everything.  Sweeteners have been shown to cause cancer in mice, I believe, not to mention that they taste vile   Green coke with stevia is OK apart from the ethical issues.
Posts.Title: Can i drink lucozade on chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Les10.  Were you anaemic before the diagnosis?  Is this an ongoing problem?  Or have you become worse since diagnosis?  Sorry for the twenty questions, but I'm trying to get to the bottom of the question.   Of course you are scared, it's only natural.  You are in the worst time, before treatment begins, when you don't know what is coming next.  Please don't panic, it will be OK.  Your anaemia will be taken into account when you are treated, and hopefully they will look for the cause (if they don't, pursue this!).  In the meantime you need iron, but see what happens tomorrow before you go taking anything.
Posts.Title: newbie

Posts.Content: Isn't it funny how men will do anything to get the attention back on them? Just kidding, as I don't know your husband but when our daughter was 13 weeks old my husband fell out of the loft and broke his thumb!
Posts.Title: Staying to get anxious

Posts.Content: Scarlett - I can't help because I've not been quite where you are, but know that you are NOT alone.  There's no point saying don't worry, it's going to be on your mind, but try to keep busy and think of other things if you can.  I know the night time will be the worst - can you see your GP and get some diazepam or something just to help you through the next few weeks?   Lots of hugs Helen
Posts.Title: soo scared and not sleeping i am having a liver ultra sound

Posts.Content: Jamesy - go for the lumpectomy but perhaps have the counselling after?  Then if you decide to go to down the Mx route you may end up needing less further treatment?  Depends on the grade/stage you have of course. H x
Posts.Title: starting to think about a preventative double mastectomy..opinions...

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with grade 1 over 5 years ago. I'm still here!  Any questions, just ask.
Posts.Title: Mom diagnosed with invasive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Go for it.  As has been said, just be careful with hygiene.  If you are not dealing with a puppy, you won't need to be cleaning up as much!  And don't forget that we need pictures!
Posts.Title: Silly Question??

Posts.Content: Hi Alicemay and sorry to hear you have been recalled.  Don't worry about what might or might not happen. There are many reasons for recall you could just have had an unclear mammogram   or there was a problem with the machine,  you could have some costs, or there could be an area of concern. Whatever it is knowing what is the first step forward.  Cyber hugs for you and please, keep us posted.  In the meantime, keep busy and try to put it out of your mind until you know what you are dealing with.
Posts.Title: Mammogram

Posts.Content: Dear Peace01  I'm sorry you have this worry at the moment. I expect you don't really feel like joining in the festivities but do try not to let it ruin your Christmas.  Even if the worst is confirmed, we have all been where you are now and are out of the other side. Breast cancer is one of the most treatable cancers and there is a 90% success rate. Of the other 10 % are often elderly, late diagnosis or have other health issues.   The waiting for results is the pits, we all agree on that, but hang in there, stay off Google and stay busy.  You can't change anything by worrying so enjoy your family over Christmas and do let us know what happens on Wednesday.   Hugs
Posts.Title: Petrified waiting for results

Posts.Content: I don't know how long it has been since your op, Amanda, but I had expanders following a double Mx at the end of November.  They are now pretty much expanded to their end size, but I did have considerable pain and discomfort for the first 8 weeks.  I'm now 11 weeks after and I have to say that they've settled down considerably.  If you CAN stick with it, it will be worth it.
Posts.Title: Anyone had expander problems ?

Posts.Content: Tramadol will help you to sleep and relieve the pain.  Be aware that it will make you constipated though, so eat lots of fruit and drink plenty of water.   As Kate says, your GP wouldn't prescribe it if he didn't think it would help. If you are getting sore mouth and throat you could try the Difflam mouthwash which many people find help.
Posts.Title: sore throat

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona I've not had chemo and no experience of fingernails etc, but I used to work for a podiatrist and people came with fungal nails and stuff - anyway we used to recommend the Gehwol range of nail products so it could well be worth checking out.   Helen x
Posts.Title: How best to treat lifting nails and nails that have already come ...

Posts.Content: Hi Lorraine You don't say if you are having chemo, or have had it, or are having reconstruction with the Mx so it's hard to say exactly.  However, the operation is pretty easy - you will be asleep and it will all be over ;) Seriously, the pain is minimal - you will probably have a few drains, and don't forget to ask for painkillers if you need them - there is no need to suffer.  I wore pyjamas and just lifted my top up when the doctors and nurses needed to check me. Don't forget to take something to read, an ipad or phone, and the chargers, baby wipes for freshening up, squash to make the boring water more palatable, and fruit is good to counteract the constipating effects of the anaesthetic and painkillers.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and lymph nodes removed

Posts.Content: Just to add that there is a facebook page for young women with breast cancer - it comes up if you do a search - and sometimes it's nice to know you're not alone (or wrongly in a group of old ladies!) Helen
Posts.Title: 28years old with breast cancer!!!

Posts.Content: I don't think GPs have much of a clue when it comes to these things, although I'm sure you're right, it could be scar tissue, but equally it could be a haematoma that hasn't dispersed yet (it's early days in some ways), or some other lump that has formed.  I would contact your BCN and/or Breast surgeon and see if you can get in to see them - they don't mind being bothered, and if something is on your mind, then it's better to sort it than spend 3 weeks wondering and worrying.
Posts.Title: Hard lump under lumpectomy scar ?

Posts.Content: Hi Steph and welcome to the site no one wants to be on!  We're a very supportive group here though, so anything you need to know, feel free to ask.   I think the sickness and hair loss might come from the F part of FEC chemo which you aren't having, so perhaps you'll be lucky!  Everything crossed for you and your baby.
Posts.Title: 28years old with breast cancer!!!

Posts.Content: Might be an idea to email the ones that still aren't working, Carolyn.  There was an issue this week, but I thought it had been fixed. Apparently so did the techies!
Posts.Title: Email links not working

Posts.Content: JillR You said it yourself, he had no immune system to fight the infection. He had AML, and chance are that the cancer would have got him if the infection didn't, eventually.   You do  have a choice regarding chemo, it's not compulsory. But lots of people have chemo every year and if you have been recommended it, then your oncologist will think that your chances are greater having it than not. I know it's hard to go through it, but if you join our monthly chemo club, you will be doing it with all the other ladies going through the same thing, and you should feel less alone. Hugs
Posts.Title: Irrational fear

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4  Funnily enough, I was just thinking about you earlier today. (So behind on emails, hadn't seen this). Glad to hear all is well!
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Pat22  Unfortunately the nature of cancer treatment is that things change.  They tend to drip feed information to avoid information overload.  It maybe that chemo has been a low possibility but during surgery they came across something that pushed it into a higher possibility category. Also they need to make sure that she is completely healed before either treatment, to avoid the risk of infection.  If you would like to talk to a nurse, you could try the free Macmillan helpline on 0808 808 0000, open Monday to Friday from 9am to 8pm.
Posts.Title: 2nd lumpectomy done

Posts.Content: Hi skopje.  I was there in Sept.  Nice place My ununderstanding is that it mops up any stray cells although in theory, the surgery and chemo should have got them.  The radiotherapy isn't painful, just tiring although the skin does continue to cook for a while after so keep an eye on it.
Posts.Title: Radiotherpy treatment

Posts.Content: I had a double mastectomy with permanent expanders five and a half years ago. I think I was in hospital for about three days but I has to have a blood transfusion which took a while. I went home with two drains  At first they were pretty much like my normal breasts but smaller as they had only put in 100 ml of saline. I had 50 added, then 100. This was a mistake because although at the time it felt fine, it started to ache and I got very depressed. In the end I walked back in to the unit crying and they took 50 out. The relief was instant.  They felt like having two flat round pebbles duct taped to my chest for a few months, but by month 8 I had made friends with them.  It's not an easy option except for the surgeon. If you can have strattice support instead of under the muscles it's a more natural less invasive procedure.  I love mine now! Plus I never have to wear a bra!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy,

Posts.Content: Personally I view early as not having spread and being treatable. Your friends probably don't know what to say and are just trying to be positive.
Posts.Title: When is catching Cancer early ?

Posts.Content: You are still in the cycle of your last tax. You will get knocked back by the surgery, but on the plus side, you will get the good drugs!  Just pace yourself.
Posts.Title: FEC-T recovery

Posts.Content: I really really hope that they mention pain.  I would never have found mine until much later if I'd ignored the weird tingling I got.  And I know that after my programme someone got diagnosed because of what I'd said on there.
Posts.Title: beating breast cancer

Posts.Content: Frankies_Ducky Get your son to log into Riprap. it's a resource for teenagers whose parents have cancer and there are lots of people in the same boat. I bet your son feels very angry, why his nan, why you, and he's lashing out. That's not surprising and very understandable. Do give your son's school a ring and explain your situation in detail.  Just saying you have health problems probably won't cut it, but if you explain you have cancer, and that his nan died not long ago from the same thing, then he might get cut some slack. Don't feel guilty at all, it's not your fault, nothing you could have done would have changed this. His nan most likely had some form of secondaries at diagnosis, since it developed so quickly.   And keep posting here, I know it's a bit of a pain at the moment, but it is improving slowly, hopefully it will get back to a useable functionality soon.
Posts.Title: Teenage moods

Posts.Content: Oh no, Highland Mum, that's really annoying for you.  I am afraid this is one of the problems with delayed reconstruction, it becomes non urgent surgery and other more urgent cases take priority.   Take the opportunity to do a few fun things that you may not be able to do for a while afterwards. It will help the time paaa quicker as well! Helen
Posts.Title: Reconstruction postponed -AGAIN!!!

Posts.Content: Imagine you are a nurse or a doctor. You spend much of your day giving people bad news so when someone has a genuine concern and you are able to give good news, then that's a good day.  Equally, giving someone bad news but then offering treatment means that person will get better and get on with their life in most cases.  Always always always, if in doubt, check it out.
Posts.Title: I know what the answer is but.....

Posts.Content: The article by Peter Harvey is here
Posts.Title: RT about to start

Posts.Content: I never knew I agree with Leolady56, you should definitely have it looked at again. However, you could go back to your GP and ask them to refer you for a second opinion, you can choose one of the big cancer hospitals, like the Royal Marsden, the Christie, or wherever is more convenient for you, or simply a different surgeon at your own hospital, but I don't think it's good enough that you aren't getting proper treatment, because you deserve to be seen and not suffer. I did have some saline removed and it did help, the relief was instant, so it could be worth a try, especially if you are going for a DIEP later.

Posts.Title: Just finding my way around...

Posts.Content: Yvonne1234  I think you've misunderstood! Yes they do a starfish type cut when they do the nipple reconstruction, but that is always done weeks after the reconstruction!  The skin has been left so that you have your own skin for the implant.  I assume they didn't recommend you had an immediate reconstruction and they will sort out how you look once you have had chemo/radiotherapy?  I hate surprises too - I'm sure my surgeon said I would have an expander and then a silicone implant, as did my husband, but I actually had a permanent expander.  It's fine, but if I need it replaced I would definitely ask for a silicone implant and maybe even a strattice mesh. Ask your BCN/surgeon what the plan is next.
Posts.Title: breast cancer surgery

Posts.Content: I think there are some really nasty viruses about at the moment, but I would mention it to your GP or oncologist to put your mind at rest.
Posts.Title: Coughing

Posts.Content: Hi JJ It's not really surprising, given all that you have been through.  Let's face it, if it could go wrong, for you it did go wrong.  But you are coming out the other side now.  And everyone probably expects you to be the old you.  I'm telling you, that old you has gone.  You may see glimpses now and again, but for the most part you are a different person.  But that isn't necessarily a bad thing.  The new you will appreciate things more, stop and smell the roses, be a kinder person.  It may help to read this which does give a bit of insight into why you feel this way.  You will get there, see the GP if you need to, speak about how you feel, but don't give up. You will be back to something akin to your old self soon.  A better new improved version.

Posts.Content: Keep an eye on the colour of the whites of your eyes and if they start to yellow, go to A&E.  I assume your husband isn't around?  Do you have a friend who could mind the children for as long as necessary?  (I assume he would come home if you are in hospital?!)

Posts.Title: depression -partner/husband

Posts.Content: I read your post and I didn't know whether to laugh or cry, honestly.   The truth is, he's an arse, but also having been through it ourselves, we can't help but be oversensitive. We identify with these women in a way your boyfriend will never be able to, and therefore all women in our situation have our sympathy and empathy.  That said, he ought to have a lot more knowledge and understanding than he is showing right now, and frankly if he was my boyfriend he'd be seriously in the doghouse!   Seriously, I wouldn't lose too much sleep over it - perhaps he wasn't really thinking properly when he made his comments, men always seen to think they have to answer questions even when they're not 100% sure what the right answer is, and perhaps it was just one of those things.  Not worth rowing over, honestly.  Unless it happens again.  Then find a suitcase and pack his stuff ... :p
Posts.Title: Am i just being touchy ?

Posts.Content: So sorry to hear about your loss, Judith.  92 is a good age, I'm sure she had a great life, and I hope you are reminiscing about the good times. Hugs
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: catlover53  I'm sorry to hear that you have found a lump, this period is very stressful and I'm sure that this is causing you tension which in turn will cause all kinds of aches and pains. Worrying won't change anything, the likelihood is that you don't have secondaries at this stage, so try to stay positive.  Stress and negativity are bad for us and certainly don't help us with cancer. Try to keep busy and do let us know when you get the results back.  Whatever the result, we are here to support you and do remember that if you do get a breast cancer diagnosis, the outcome is very good these days.  I was diagnosed 6.5 years ago and I am still very much alive and kicking.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: Secondaries

Posts.Content: Sublingual. Means it goes straight into the bloodstream without going through the stomach.

Posts.Content: If you have cording, you need specialist physio.  Get the name of a specialist from your BCN and get your GP to give you an urgent referral.  Chase it after a week if you haven't heard anything as the usual waiting period is 8 weeks
Posts.Title: Seroma and infection.

Posts.Content: Hi Patsy, I am so sorry that you have been treated like this.  There is no excuse for it, and if I were you, I would make a complaint to PALS because this is both unprofessional and wrong.  Please don't let her upset you, she obviously needs a lesson in patient communication, and knows nothing of your diagnosis or proposed treatment.   If you have questions, get an appointment with your BCN or surgeon and get answers.
Posts.Title: Confused and upset

Posts.Content: Hiya Fadima I could have written your post myself a few years ago. You find something of concern, except that you are otherwise feeling fine. You get a diagnosis and everything goes downhill for a while. Then when everything is visibly back to normal, everyone, including you, expect life to go back to what it was before. Unfortunately it tends not to quite work that way. The good news is that things do improve. You start to find there are longer and longer periods when you don't even think about cancer. And you definitely don't stress the small stuff as much. You realise that you have been on a hamster wheel and re-evaluate your life. You may find a counsellor helpful. But you will find a new normal. Maybe even an improved one! And remember that if you have a bad day, there's always tomorrow. Helen - class of 2011.

Posts.Content: Damn straight!  I've been looking for that "like" button myself!  Except I want a "LOVE" button!! I wish you all the best for your ball, I'm sure it will be a massive success, keep us posted with further details!!!

Posts.Title: Parabens, etc

Posts.Title: rads and pain!!!

Posts.Content: shezza1 You are probably best posting this on the September Chemo Thread and following the other ladies' posts there.  Lots of help and advice. As to generalised discomfort, we usually say take your temperature, and if you are normal, then you can take paracetamol or another painkiller.   Just take the opportunity to sleep/rest, next week will be better, and the week after, you'll be more or less normal until the next one.
Posts.Title: Generally bloated and abdominal pains

Posts.Content: Hi Jeu The pins and needles pains you are feeling are the nerves knitting back together.  Rads has probably irritated them as well.  Normal painkillers don't really cut it with nerves.  You need a nerve blocking painkiller, such as gabapentin.  These can make you sleepy, so take them at night and a good night's sleep is a good tonic in itself.   Give your GP a call on Monday morning and see if you can get these prescribed for you.  It IS an emergency, don't worry about bothering the doctor - that is what they are paid for! Here's a big hug for you ... working through treatment, you deserve it!
Posts.Title: Nerve type pain following radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Of course you can go back to your team. It doesn't matter what side anything is. Just do something!

I'm going to say that you are not pathetic at all.  I'm pretty sure that the majority of us are the ones that everyone comes to with their problems, they expect us to be the strong ones, the ones who can fix things.  And this time we can't.  We're not used to not being in control.  (I'm pretty sure that some of the stress of constantly being everyone's source of information and support is a contributing factor but that's just my personal view).   Take the diazepam, try to keep busy during the day, see people, do things that occupy your mind.  Friday will come soon enough and good luck for your results, I'm sure everything will be better than you imagine.

Posts.Title: Deciding whether to have reconstruction or not

Posts.Content: Hi Mintie I have permanent expander implants and they are under the muscle. They look fine apart from when I am flexing my pecs (no, I'm not a body builder, lol), but for normal purposes, no one really would know. You could ask about strattice, which is a kind of hammock attached to the skin which the implants sit in.  I don't really know about it, but your surgeon should.  They are usually make of pigskin of some kind.  I've not seen any results so can't tell you how good it is, but someone here has had it and hopefully will be along to tell you! If you want to see pictures of mine just send a friend request. Helen
Posts.Title: Reconstruction Help!

Posts.Content: I don't have experience of this but do make sure your team know all the side effects you are having.  They may change your drugs or be able to offer you effective treatment. If you don't tell them, they won't know!

Posts.Content: Oh my darling this is so unfair! Of course you're not making a fuss over nothing.  Imagine him being told he had to lose a testicle - would that be a fuss over nothing?  Of course it wouldn't! One option you could consider is to have a second mastectomy.  I don't know if that is possible with the rad treatment, but it's worth asking.  I don't know where you are in the country, but there might be someone who has had something similar who can support you, and if there is a Keeping Abreast group near you they can be very supportive. Posts.Title: BREAST REDUCTION AFTER RADS

Posts.Title: strike action REALLY

Posts.Content: Phaedra yes, the body is a very mysterious thing! It's a balancing act with lots of different things needing to be in the right proportion for everything to work correctly! Unfortunately very little time is spent educating doctors about this, so doing your own research is good, also the good old NHS will usually provide the cheapest possible vitamins which aren't always the best ones to take!
Posts.Title: Anyone become anaemic on chemo?

Posts.Content: I expect they will be checking your ferritin, which is stored iron.  There is iron in the circulating blood and ferritin which (i think) is stored in the liver.  You will probably be given iron tablets, at the worst case a transfusion.  They usually prescribe ferrous fumerate which isn't easily absorbed and causes constipation.  Always take a high dose Vitamin C with iron.  I prefer Solgar Gentle Iron tablets which are a full RDA in each tablet and are better tolerated. Some people take floradix, which is a liquid. Again take Vit C.
Posts.Title: Anyone become anaemic on chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Violet Sky  I haven't had this experience but I would have a word with your surgeon rather than the GP as I suspect you could have some lymphodaema and or an infection.  Write everything down,  because you have a long list.  You can always give the helpline here a call on 0808 808 0000 open Monday to Friday, 9am to 8pm.
Posts.Title: Intense Pain in Back, Arm & Hand

Posts.Content: Is it your own foot spa? I think the danger is from infection if you have any cuts or damaged skin where infection could get in.   If it's your own, give it a quick go with dettol before using and go for it.

Posts.Content: Hi I've been an emotional mess too - and I've not even got that far yet.  I think it is just one of those things that you need to go through on the journey - no one who hasn't had this diagnosis will completely understand how you feel, that's why it is so good to be able to chat to people here.   I think from what I've read that Tamoxifen can affect your mood, though, so probably talk to your BCN or GP/Oncologist/specialist. Helen
Posts.Title: Dealing with the aftermarth

Posts.Content: Do register any side effects of Letrozole and may your particular chemo drug at the yellow card scheme.  Just do a search on yellow card scheme.
Posts.Title: Eyes

Posts.Content: Heck, Sue, we all have the right to have a good moan!  And you need to feel good about yourself, or you'll end up depressed, and that's no good.   I think there's a thread here about lipofilling - someone has definitely had it done, and I've been told I can too to have mine smoothed out.   It has taken me 4 months to be pleased with the result - they're not that natural in many ways, especially in the way they feel, and I'm conscious of them a lot of the time, but I'm getting an idea my husband actually prefers them now to before!  Which obviously helps the way I feel about them!  Still pretty hard, and numb, but am now prepared to wait and see how things pan out. Have you explained about your holiday and asked them to start it earlier?  It seems wrong that your plans have to alter just because they can't get their finger out .... *sounds like my mother* Helen xx
Posts.Title: puckerred boob

Posts.Content: Annabel - I think with the lipo, they extract the fat from your body and inject it into the boob.  I think some of it gets reabsorbed, the exact amount can vary, and they may take several goes to get the right amount for you.  I'd certainly give it a go as a first choice - if it doesn't work, you've still got the DIEP option. also, at some point in the future, should you require a recon on the other side, I would consider the DIEP then so that they could get good symmetry.
Posts.Title: puckerred boob

Posts.Content: Whoop whoop! Congratulations, fantastic news!
Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: Congratulations on the clear scan,  Lou!  Unfortunately the aches are very likely due to Letrozole. There are lots of threads on the subject if you do a site search, you may find a different brand suits you more or perhaps switching to a different type of drug. I think we have to try everything until we find what suits us.
Posts.Title: Nerve pains and ache over body

Posts.Content: If anyone wants to send a private message, first you must add as friend (just hover over the name and the option will appear).  Once accepted you can can message each other privately. I bought a book by Sarah Jane Phillips who came to a talk for our group - it's called "Worms on Parachutes".  It's actually quite a scary story of what can go wrong, but it does all come good in the end.   You can get it on Kindle for free from Amazon - this is the link if you are interested.
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: Hi Suecubb It's not shallow at all - I had the same thing and my boob was very puckered and I hated it.  But they can improve these things.  First the scar tissue has to break down and it will do, it just takes time.  So the hardness is temporary.  It will help if you can bear to have it massaged (or do it yourself).   After things have healed, they can inject some of your own fat (assuming you have any!) into the area to plump it up.  You don't have to put up with it, but for now just concentrate on getting through the RT and healing. Sadly for me my WLE wasn't clear and I ended up with a Mx but I do have a cracking pair of implants now! Helen xx
Posts.Title: puckerred boob

Posts.Content: Hiya I think the only thing you can do is find out whether you are covered, and if not how much the operation will be. I would say that if your oncologist is recommending it then it would be covered.  Cancer is a pretty acute condition, and if is being done to prevent recurrence, then I think you have a good case.  It wouldn't be covered if you just wanted it for birth control reasons, for example.   Good luck.

Posts.Title: In need of some reassuring words!

Posts.Content: ... if you are struggling with sexual problems, and the lack of oestrogen is getting you down, this is worth a read. Is it your thyroid? If you think this could be you, ask your GP to test your TSH levels.  If it's above 3 (no matter what the ranges are), keep a check on them. Always get printouts of your results.
Posts.Title: Not a magic wand, but ...

Posts.Content: CWS Firstly, you have done the right thing by joining this community. We are a friendly knowledgeable and supportive bunch, and I know that you will find all you need. Now what you have had is the same as me  I had random pain and I went to the doctors. They didn't find anything, but referred me anyway  I got a breast cancer diagnosis from the one stop shop. I was just like you, catastrophising the worst case scenario  but, in fact, 90%. of patients are still around 5 years later, after which you get signed off as NED (no evidence of disease). So please don't panic, if you are diagnosed  then treatment, although not fun, is doable and we are here to help you through it   My diagnosis was over 7 years ago and I'm very much still alive and kicking. You can do this.  Oh  and the worst part is waiting for the treatment plan  once you have that  it's all go.
Posts.Title: Breast Clinic Appointment Tomorrow Afternoon

Posts.Content: Great news, Kaw66!  Glad to hear that things went well, don't rush your recovery, let others take care of you!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and node clearance all done

Posts.Content: No tips, I'm afraid. I was having terrible flushes but I suddenly noticed they'd stopped about a month ago. Hugs anyway.  I'm awake at 12. 30 because I have major altitude sickness and my head is banging. Nothing will touch it it's been 48 hrs now. Leaving in the morning so hopefully will improve.  At this moment I'd rather be sweating!
Posts.Title: My Night....

Posts.Content: I may be completely off track, but I think in a few cases you can get chemo induced diabetes. The excessive thirst is my reason for querying it. I would make sure your oncologist knows as soon as possible.
Posts.Title: Side effects of EC chemotherapy?

Posts.Content: Hi Audrey I know that you are trying to avoid the steroids but really, taking these as early as you can may help avoid the restlessness.  There are other benefits to steroids that may work with the chemo and by not taking them you may negate some of the helpful things.  Talk to your oncologist about why exactly you need to take them. As to the weekly taxol, it's supposed to be much kinder to you than docetaxol so fingers crossed it goes this way for you.

Posts.Title: Breast Clinic Appointment Tomorrow Afternoon

Posts.Content: They could reduce lots of breast cancer by checking the iodine in women on thyroxine.  There is a 200% increase in breast cancer in women taking levothyroxine and it has been proven that it is due to low iodine uptake.  Mind you, the way they treat thyroid patients, it doesn't surprise me that they don't.  And of course you only find out this stuff after you are diagnosed with cancer! Daily Fail has been taken off Wikipedia's list of sources as untrustworthy, I personally came off Tamoxifen and I don't think many people would tolerate it "just in case".
Posts.Title: Interesting article in paper today

Posts.Content: Donna Congratulations on coming out of the other side of treatment!  It's very common to feel the "what's next" effect. I rrecommend people to read Dr Peter Harvey After treatment finishes, what next? I am on my phone so can't post a link but you will find it on Google.  I recommend you bookmark it and come back to it now and then.  And show it to close family and friends and tell them this is how you feel.  It helps people understand.  Have a great day!  Helen
Posts.Title: Emotional rollercoaster

Posts.Content: Disney8042 Totally understand your fear.  The chances are that you picked up a virus or infection that you may not have even been aware of, and that particular node was the one that fought it off, hence the swelling. The doctor is being cautious, as he should be, in saying this, just on the off chance that a couple of stray cells have decided to divide in there and become a nuisance. Did your dad have a test for genetic causes?  Breast, ovarian and prostate cancers can all be linked to the BRCA gene, so if any of these are in your family, it might be worth getting tested (just one or two is normal, more needs investigation).
Posts.Title: Axillary tail lump.

Posts.Content: @mich32h I think you need to discuss this with your surgeon.  It's probably possible, but only a surgeon who has seen your breasts and can envisage the results would be able to give you a definitive answer. It is possible that they may not do a cosmetic procedure due to the implants, some health authorities are getting stingy about this, but again, it is something your surgeon can answer. Sorry not to be able to be more helpful.
Posts.Title: Surgery options when you already have implants

Posts.Content: Hi Judith Yes, it's a blood test although the problem with that is it doesn't tell you everything.  But it's a start.  If you want to know more, send me a message, as it's a bit off topic.
Posts.Title: Not a magic wand, but ...

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome to the forum.  I can safely say that pretty much all of us were planning funerals, thinking we would be dead inside a month, and wondering how our families would cope without us!  It's also safe to say that the majority of us are still here, alive and kicking cancer's butt hard! Paget's disease of the nipple is very treatable, though, and you have caught it early, so unless you were told it was definitely a mastectomy, it might just be a Wide Local Excision - they will probably remove the nipple, but a new one can be reconstructed easily.   Please try not to let your mind go out of control though - it's so easy to think about the what ifs, but it's not at all helpful.  Instead, write them down and take them to your consultation on Christmas Eve, and make sure that you enjoy the lead up and the actual day.  Good luck for your results.
Posts.Title: Just joined the roller coaster - help !

Posts.Content: Just to say that the heat in the room is to keep blood vessels open due to the vascular surgery so that it all heals.  Put up with it and let people wait on you!

Posts.Title: Emotional rollercoaster

Posts.Content: Hi Lou  Welcome to the forum.  We are all patients, former, current, or, like your self, just about to start. So we all understand the petrifying fear that paralyses you on diagnosis.  The good news is,  you are not going to die (well not from this). You are going to have a rough few months, but you will come out with a new outlook on life. As for reconstruction, it is down to the individual., Do your research and bear in mind that you may not be suitable for all options, so don't fixate on a particular type. Also don't rule things out without real information. I would never have considered implants prior to diagnosis, but now have two.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: Gosh, Lizane, that is quite some story.  My first thought was that I would open a bottle of champagne, I must confess!  But they really should have got their facts right before misdiagnosing you this way .  I can imagine how stressed and upset you were.   I would also write this down and send it to the pals section of your hospital.  You should at least get an apology, and they need to learn from their mistakes.   Enjoy the rest of your weekend.
Posts.Title: Told I was misdiagnosed and it's NOT bone secondaries, it's Avascular...

Posts.Content: You ask as many questions as you like!  There are CAT scans, PET scans,MRI scans and a few other less used ones. None of them will tell you at a cellular level if you have cancer, and all of them use radiation to work, so while you have a good result from one, having lots of others won't really give you a better result and may actually increase your risk. I'm not trying to frighten anyone,  just stay grounded and trust in your team.

Posts.Content: You could try taking the wires out of the ones you already have? Try a couple of old ones to see how they feel.   I certainly agree about the tops with bra supports.  I bought a few from primark and still wear them now.

Changed doctor in February as we moved.  He frightened me saying my thyroid levels were too high and I would get osteoporosis and cardiac disease and reduced my meds even though I was well in myself and doing loads.  I started to have issues in July, diagnosis in August. I have since done lots of reading up on my condition, but it is complicated, you are right!

Posts.Content: Yes, I have been told this.  HOWEVER. I've never cut myself shaving.  Safety razors are pretty safe.  It's the risk of infection from cuts and abrasions that is the problem, but since I've never done this, I just carry on as normal.  No issues. Posts.Content: I got all that too - it is DEFINITELY worthwhile!  My husband really loves my new look too (not that that is the important thing, obviously, but it helps!), and the stuff is great!  Highly recommended!
Posts.Title: Look good feel better

Posts.Content: Hi Lou Back on my laptop now, easier to post links!    When researching reconstruction, have a look at the Keeping Abreast website and if you are anywhere near any of the groups, do try to meet them and have a chat with ladies who have been through it.  It is worth a trip even if you have to travel and stay, because there is nothing like personal experience to help you make up your mind, and ladies will show you their surgery and talk about their own experiences. If you can't do this, have a word with your BCN and see if she knows of anyone who is willing to do this locally.  There may even be a similar group. Don't just go for what you think is the easy option, there isn't one. Go for the one that will give the best result and fit best with your lifestyle.  Bear in mind that options using muscle to reconstruct will impair the function of those muscles to some degree.   Feel free to shout if I can help, I've been part of Keeping Abreast and seen all types/shapes and sizes of breast reconstruction!
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: Hi Tetleysscooby   Firstly, well done for finding this group at such an early stage.  It will be a massive help as things  go on.  I'm sorry that you have had a cancer diagnosis, but please rest assured that your team will get you through this and you will get through the other side. I was diagnosed with cancer even though there were no physical signs at all, just some odd tingling.  I had to have a mastectomy following a lumpectomy and an op for further margins, but I am here 5 years later and living life to the full. You will too, once you start treatment, things do rather tend to take over, but ask any questions, we will do our best to answer them from our own experiences.
Posts.Title: I'm 43 saw a dimpling on the breast and went for a routine referr...

Posts.Title: So Scared

Posts.Content: Did you mention about your holiday?  I would ring and ask them. They let me go even though it meant delaying my surgery by about 3 weeks.  They thought the break would do me more good than not going.   Hospital admin is shite.  I'm afraid as an admin it makes my blood boil.  You're just a number and there are lots of them, so they don't consider you as a person.  I wouldn't want any of them to be a patient ... but ...
Posts.Title: Feeling Frustrated

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah Last things first, you may like to read this with your children, it's a booklet from Breast Cancer Care called Mummy's Lump. It explains things in simple language.  I would make sure you know the answers to their questions first, because they will come straight away with some and later with others.  Obviously you can tell them that you don't know and will find out if it's something complicated, but questions are usually quite straightforward. Now the first part of your question.  Welcome to the group.  You have done one of the best possible things you could do by joining us here.  We are all people who have been in your position and we know how that feels.  It's horrid, and if you could skip forward a few weeks, you would, wouldn't you?  Waiting is the pits.  We all felt the same. But the good news is you have a treatment plan, and you know what is going to happen to you.  The other good news is that although it is stage 3, it is still very treatable.  If you have known people who died of this 5 or 10 years ago, the treatments now are much more effective and focussed and you are likely to be in the 90% of people who are a given an all clear in 5 years. The remaining 10% are often elderly on diagnosis (and die of something else, age related), have other health issues, or have been diagnosed too late.  So the future still looks bright, and you will get through it with the help of the ladies (and the odd guy here and there!) on this forum.  Any questions you have just ask, the only silly question is the one you don't ask.
Posts.Title: Stage 3 breast cancer help & how to tell my children

Posts.Content: I don't know what phyllodes tumours are but you don't say what type of operation you are having?  Lumpectomy? Mastectomy?  Are you having to have chemo?  This is the thing that will knock you back in terms of working, but employers have to make allowances - you are protected under the Disability Act (if you are in the UK?) if you have cancer.   Anyway you are in the right place - lots of knowledge and support here.  We understand what you are going through, and then the waiting ...  is the worst.  If they knew how bad this part was, there would be help for it, I'm sure! It is worth checking with your GP re the depression - he may decide that you need extra help during this time. Helen

Posts.Content: don't forget that anaesthetic can leave you feeling depressed and stays in your system for a good while, so it could simply be that as well. Be kind to yourself - take things easy, this will pass.

Posts.Content: I think it's very early days, nosilla.  I wouldn't worry about what it looks like now, because the scars will fade, the swelling will decrease, and you will find that everything looks pretty fine in a few months.  I think we are too hard on ourselves.   Be kind to yourself - you've been through a lot, and you need to give yourself a break.
Posts.Title: masectomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: You might benefit from some CBT. You need to ask your gp to refer you.  But you don't have a belly for a breast. You have a reconstructed breast.  I suggest you think of it as your own tissue and not from where it came.  The thing is to get your self past this because you have been given the chance to restart your life.  And while you feel this way you will just be wasting it. I know that I spent 8 months coming to terms with my own reconstruction and I should have been getting on with things much sooner.  Helen
Posts.Title: masectomy and reconstruction

Posts.Content: Don't put up with anything, especially the fingers and toes. You really need to let your oncologist know asap so they can decide what to do as it can become permanent.

Posts.Content: I was told that there is such a thing as menopausal migraine so if you've been on tamoxifen, it could be that.   I have been given all sorts to help, nothing really does, but the best thing was amytriptylene to break the cycle - worked for a while.  Plus it's an anti-depressant although very low dose, so that helps break the anxiety cycle too.  Take it a few hours before bed and you'll sleep like a baby.  :)

Posts.Title: Grade 2

Posts.Content: Kazzie - it depends!  Is it a permanent expander or a temporary one that they will remove and insert a solid implant into? The permanent ones are more comfortable in the short term than the temporary ones, although I believe that the solid implants are more comfortable long term if that makes sense.  Having them expanded doesn't really hurt, but it's a bit like a brace on your teeth - each time it's expanded, the scar tightens, then softens over time.  The skin is tight, then relaxes, so after a few days it's fine.  If there's any pain, paracetamol will be plenty enough painkiller to deal with it.  It's more discomfort than anything.   Just don't let them put too much in at a time, because I had that and it was miserable.  I had to have some removed eventually, then replaced later on.  100ml is plenty at a time, less is better, and don't rush to have the full amount in.
